review_title: Nice morning walk in a traditional village
review_body: We spent about 2 hours exploring the Bukchon village. As there are residents staying inside, we have to keep our noise level to a minimum. There are quite a few streets that are more traditional than the rest. I just hope that the new building are not invading the old style buiding structure further, else this village is not going to retain its tradtional images.

review_title: My favorite place from our trip
review_body: I love the architecture, and what's more fascinating is that there are people still living there! There are a couple houses that are set up for tourists and you can pay to go in for some special activities. I also saw a house that is available for homestay.
Exploring the Korean traditional houses up the hill. It's an easy walk with interesting views at all angle.Try the fried tteokbokki too.
An hour walk in this area is sufficient. You can enjoy the beautiful architecture of houses. Will definitely stay in one of the guest houses here in my next visit to Seoul.
Love the old traditional houses and tiny alley ways. And with little quaint shops peppered all over with good cafes and eateries, it is indeed time well spent on a cold afternoon.
There are quite a few of traditional Hanok spread across the streets. All are very unique and quite well maintained.Quite a pleasant walk along these streets even in cold weather.

If you are going to this place just to take photos. I will advise you to find the actual locations of the spot that you planned to have your photos taken. I went to this place twice in my trip and I spent hours running up nad down to find the 'right' spot.Please be prepare to trek the uphills

We stayed on one of these traditional houses that was converted into a hotel/homestay. Really lovely experience to be in such a cosy home. The owner was very helpful and upgraded us to a room that had an adjoining toilet. My family of five slept comfortably in the two rooms even though they were kind of small. The village or area itself is quiet and is a great place with quaint little shops selling souvenirs, clothes, Jewellery. They aren't tacky shops but are shops that sell affordable local brands. Most of the shops are located along two main roads but you won't find it as busy or crowded as Myeongdong which is another experience of its own. So while most tourists spend an afternoon walking and looking and the old houses, this was actually a nice refuge and charming place to spend a a couple of days at. We really enjoyed the cafes and interesting shops that we could take our time with and not be hassled by crowds. From here we could venture to Insadong which was nearby.
Actually this village wasn't what I expected. I didn't see anything really exciting about this place. I do not recommend

review_title: Well preserved historic neighbourhood, great place for a stroll
review_body: A rare example of historic Hanok house architecture in Seoul. It's a great area to stroll around. What's great about the area as well is that it's not completely overrun by tourists - there is still a real neighbourhood feel to the place.

We strolled Bukchon and saw many houses with characters. Some are shops and some are residences. We went inside a few shops partly for souvenir and partly to just look at those houses.Due to the high volume of tourists, there were often local people held up signs to ask tourists to be quiet.

Really worthwhile to visit and to combine with other visits to local palaces and the Insadong shopping area. You can start with this village and continue to the palaces on walking distance, then end at Insadong.

review_title: A residential area with a taste of old Korea
review_body: Bukchon is just a residential area with a taste of old Korea and most of the houses were locked and closed when we visited there. Need to walk for 20-30 mins along the wall of Gyeongbukgung palace before reaching Buckhon. Do take bus or other transport to reach Bukchon. Honestly, nothing much in Buckhon and should be able to complete the area by 1 hour.

There is a good amount of exercise involved- narrow alleyways, very steep slope and stairs. A good time to go would be in the afternoon. At the bottom there are a few shops and boutique stores. Dolls wearing traditional Korean dresses also found here.

This district is very nice if you know where you're going, or if you have time to explore. It's not huge, but you might be disappointed. There is a famous street there, though, so make sure you see that one at least. The street goes uphill/downhill depending on where you are. Sometimes there are so many tourists there, so it might get a bit annoying. Bukchon is a walking distance from Gyeongbokgung palace (did I spell that right?). Also, sometimes people offer to let you inside one of their old houses there and give you a tour for a price. In my opinion, Bukchon is a must-see in Seoul. Not overwhelmingly fun, but just beautiful.

review_title: A little overrated but worth the visit.
review_body: The road below the Bukchon Hanok Village had clusters of private galleries, cafes and shops which makes it fun to explore and just have a cuppa in. To get to the village - follow the brown signs and be prepared to climb up a steep flight of stairs. Once there - just walk freely and you will eventually come across the popular slope where people like to take photos in. There are free maps along the roads so just grab one and explore on.

review_title: Terrific Small cottages full of history
review_body: I absolutely loved wandering the winding ways around this neighborhood. Quaint and delightful. Fun to walk about exploring. Caution to be quiet and respectful--this is someone' home!

This area has rows and rows of houses that are in traditional Korean style. There are signs that post recommended paths to walk through. It is residential area with people who still live in the houses, so being quiet is a must. Very nice views from the higher streets. Many of the streets are fairly steep, but it's not extremely strenuous once you get to the top area and walk back down. There are a few smaller boutique style stores near the bottom area, some small eateries, and some small souvenir shops. There are also some cultural buildings that are open to walk around in and some paid activities to do, such as wearing era appropriate costumes or making little trinkets to take home. Nice way to spend some time walking around. Beautiful views from the top and great architecture you won't find anywhere else.
These houses are being built in the middle ages and they are still in use. Beautiful. Nice boutiques and restaurants, little corner shops.

This is a nice area with some old style korean houses, with lots of caffes, small resturants, souvenirs and art. On the start in the tourist center take a map with the route to follow, helps not to get lost. It is quite a walk and you go high up with some stipe areas, to make the full round. Ideal for nice sunny weather. You can combine it with a visit to one of the two main palaces as you start / end close to them.Overall cc 1-2 hour is enough for attraction.

review_title: Beautifuel quaint village inside a modern metropolis
review_body: Loved the houses and how simply they are constructed. Felt like a trip back in time. Quiet in inhabited and so respect the neighborhood
Good place for photoshoot... but sometimes theres alot of visitor and its hard to take a good photo...

Nice walking around a traditional village with fantastic views over the city. Found many places you can rent the traditional clothing if you was with your wife so I would recommend this. Just respect locals by keeping the noise down as it is a residential area :)

review_title: A place for those interested in the past
review_body: A very beautiful place that presents the old architecture. Don't miss the artist-name difficult to remember- who has wonderful collection of his paintings-the swans and horses ; a few to remember.The people who live there even now get the credit of maintaining the past so meticulously. A wonderful place.

Lots of walking here. It is actually a residential area and do keep silence around the houses. If you have the time, you can stop by the cafes or stay a night in the guest houses, which is pretty expensive as told by our guide. But it would be nice to experience living in hanbok.

review_title: Old school Seoul - but too crowded with tourists
review_body: Love this place and its old school houses and the quaint of the surrounding. Good for a late afternoon walk which I did - but suggest for you to go early in the morning if you prefer quieter moment with less of a crowd and people appearing in your pictures from time to time. If you don't mind people appearing in your pictures then you can go anytime. But just 1-2 hours in this place should suffice. It's quite a small area I feel. :)

review_title: 2nd best place to visit in Seoul!
review_body: Bukchon is the "old town" of Seoul. It has preserved much of olden day Korea. From the nameless streets, to the grand doors and the old school Korean houses this neighborhood is legit.
A charming place to visit and experience walking through traditional Korean houses in the neighbourhood but also very touristy. Do take note that this is a residential area so keep your volume down!

I would probably put this area near the middle or bottom of your list for places in Seoul. Yes, there are some nice old houses in a residential area lined with very narrow streets. The houses are on a hill so there are some nice views available, but it may require that you have a prerequisite good health to walk the hills. And because it is a residential area, there are numerous signs and people (dressed in traditional Korean garb) standing with signs asking tourists to keep their voices down.There are also some restaurants and shops on the outskirts which provide some shopping opportunities.However, the area really doesn't warrant a must-see status...

The Bukchon neighborhood is a preservation of an old traditional Korean village. Bukchon is located in the north side between Cheonggyecheon and Jongmyo, hence the name Bukchon, which means the north village. You walk through alleyways that have these beautiful homes. I stopped at each house and looked at the beautiful architecture of the roof tops and the intricate carvings on the doors and walls. While we were walking we came across a home where a lovely young lady was waiting outside, eager to show us the house from the inside. The owners were away and allowed for their house to be shown. We gladly took the opportunity and paid her the 15,000 Korean Won ($12) per person for the tour. This was our chance to look at a traditional home from the inside. The huge door opened into a serene garden with bonsai trees and a little pond. Inside the house there was very little furniture but tranquility filled each room. I was thinking that clutter is what causes us so much stress but here there was none in this beautiful, serene, home. Note to self, get rid of clutter! At the end of the tour we were offered some homemade plum tea which we sipped while we gazed at the garden outside. Rejuvenated, we wandered about through the lanes and admired more houses from the outside. The Bukchon area is a "must see" and the bonus is that it it is within walking distance of the Gyeongbokgung Palace and the most famous shopping area of Insadong. The trick is to go to the tourist information center and get a good walking map because it is a bit tricky to find Bukchon. The area is also home to many small restaurants and coffee shops.

i went to this place with my friends at summer holiday, we waste some times to find this place because it is not very easy to find, so i suggest people should find some information from internet. I think the view is good and those building is special. There are so many stores which can rent some korea traditional clothing for people to take photo, but you should decide it carefuly, because some of it is expensive. We can feel the korea culture and the history at this place. We chage our clothes to korea traditional clothing and take a lot of photos at this place, the korea traditional clothing are very match with that environment. we feel like we are back in the korea old time, the feeling is interesting.

Bukchon Village is still a residential area and despite signs asking people to be quiet, many inconsiderate tourists still natter on at the top of their voices. Otherwise a quaint area with many houses still boasting the wooden beams and eaves that mark the architecture of a past era. A little bit of a hike through the hilly streets. Good to start with this before heading to Insadong

review_title: หมู่บ้านวัฒนธรรม The cultural village
review_body: เป็นหมู่บ้านวัฒนธรรม ที่ยังคงรักษาสภาพอาคาร บ้านเรือน ในแบบดั้งเดิมไว้ได้อย่างดี สวยงาม มีจุดถ่ายภาพมากมาย เดินไกลนิด เหนื่อยหน่อย แต่ก็คุ้มThis is the cultural village that remain old style and beautiful. Although it's a long way for walking but valuable for photographer and most visitor.

review_title: Get a good pair of shoes!
review_body: Yes, I found the place after walking around trying to find a road that went all the way up to the top of a hill. If you embark on this trail, you've better get a good pair of shoes, since this area is sort of hilly. The rooftops are as seen in many postcards. You can have a glance of the rooftops by visiting one of the houses that offer "a good view" for a drink, as I did since it was a drizzly day. The decorated doors are gorgeous. Many locals wearing traditional costumes also visit this area.
Absolutely love it! A must place to go. As an architect, I really appreciate the traditional style of buildings which were built to perfection.

review_title: Good stroll to see the historic homes and neighborhood layout
review_body: Definitely pick up a map before you start that identifies the walking route. It's worth it. My highlight was when I stepped into the doll maker's house and was worth it to see her craft. I even bought three of her dolls since they were very reasonably priced. Every piece was unique.

review_title: a unique enclave of Korean tradition 북촌한옥마을
review_body: A top-10 must visit in Seoul, we visited it just after exploring nearby Insadong. Not quite a “Village” per sey, more a neighbhood area which houses 900 plus Hanoks or traditionally houses. Bukchon means 'northern village", and some of these residence blocks are actually centuries-old of the Joseon Dynasty!Surrounded by a few very busy traffic streets the premise is quaint and picturesque, and surprisingly well integrated with its neighnourhood. It is modern meets traditional houses-architecture! Some of the Hanoks are still resident occupied while others were converted into chic galleries, restaurants, cafés and accessory shops. There are signs that remind all that being a residential area, one should not make excessive din. This area is visited by many tourists and you can see plenty of people donning the traditional costumes walking around taking photos (you can rent them ..). We stopped by the Bukchon Tourist Centre to check out more details of the area. There is also the Traditional Craft Experience Centre where host aa variety of cultural programs and activities. A rare opportunity for one to experience and immerse in Korean traditional culture indeed.We read from a blogger that there are actually “8 photo spots” where you can take the best pictures with the most picturesque background. We tried and found 3!! You should also. We thoroughly enjoy the meandering walk through Bukchon Hanok many small alleys and streets. Just note that it is on a slight hill so could be taxing for some. Remember to also walk to the top of the hill and take a stunning view of Seoul too.Throw away your maps and get literally “lost” in the charms of traditional hanok. Thoroughly enjoyable and experiential trip for me & wifey. We spent close to 3 hours before leaving via Line 3 Anguk Station.

review_title: Only place in Seoul to see traditional Korean housing
review_body: This is a must see area to get a feel for how beautiful the Korean housing was in the era before then concrete and steel apartment building. It is easy to get to, is very walkable (although hilly) and has nice local shops with crafts and food. It has become popular with Chinese tour groups so best to go during the week vs, weekends.

review_title: Charming Bukchon, old city neighborhood in Seoul, South Korea
review_body: The visit to this neighborhood was suggested by the visitor center. It has several small streets, old houses, and shops. It quite touristy and well kept. There are many food and souvenirs shopping options.There are a few employees of the visitor center who are in one of the streets and speak a little English. They will be able to give you information and directions. We needed to go to the shrine and they helped suggesting the quickest route to it.
Requires lots of walking up hills and downhills. Not suitable for elderly or children. The view is not bad. Visitors should wear proper shoes for this attraction. Sports shoes is highly recommended.

Walks here from my Hotel (Ibis Ambassador Insadong) only 15minutes. Went to information and asked about the location n maps around. Really like the old houses and salutes for korean that they still keep it and do the good maintenances to every houses. Wish to stay in one of the guest houses or hanok stay. Met some cute cafes along the alley and good pasta restaurant too can't took a good pic around the hanok since i went there in day time and so many people around. Recommended to come early in the morning to get a good pic

This is Just an alley to take good photos of the traditional Hanok village in Korea. Hanbok rental are also available for 10,000 krw. This is a beautiful place to Visit, You just have to be quiet because this is a residential area. Bukchon is 5-10 minutes walk to anguk station. Visit this place at Around 8-9AM because Group/bus of tourists usually arrives after this hour which makes it a little bit crowded.

review_title: Tasty fried pork and shrimp mundu
review_body: A small restaurant located on a narrow side street of Insadong and one of our favorite place for lunch. Seemed like the dumplings, especially the shrimp dumpling, shrunk in size since our last 2 visits but they were still crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. Beside the dumplings, the next best tasting dish was their kimchee. It was fresh tasting, not extremely spicy, and the saltiness of the cabbage was perfect to the taste. There were others eating cold and hot noodles which I would like to try on our next visit.

We went there by accident and found out that it's one of attractions once we've been there.Amazing architecture, tiny, steep streets, beautiful roofing, wooden gates and little walls surrounding each house.We found one house open to a public free of charge. You really need to see this.

Very subdued old neighborhood where you can still see what Seoul used to look like before modernization. Takes about an hour to walk through it. It's nothing spectacular but a convenient location to add to your list of sightseeing if you're visiting the palaces nearby.

review_title: A great place to visit within residential area
review_body: It is a great place to stroll if you want to know the Korean house that is actually with people living inside. It has a lot of walkings to do and the area is flooded with tourists in rented hanbok, so it makes you difficult to take some good photos as every corner you will bump into people.

whatever your time constraint is please do not skip the hanok museum because it is as close as you can get to see how it looks like on the inside. unless you have the budget to book a hanok during your stay in seoul that is. otherwise this museum gives you a great detailed explainations of the hanok. the restaurants nearby here are good too.
the hundreds year old houses nicely retained and still inhabitant. make sure be quiet and be polite while taking photo. Of cause surrounded by souvenir shops and cafe for tourists.

Rented hanok & walk around the village. Makes you felt like a Korean. Hanok give us an impression it is heavy but after experiencing, weighted much more lighter than expected. Mistaken as Korean & had some pictures taken with other tourists.

review_title: Nice stroll through restored hanok houses
review_body: Walking through Bukchon Village is a great experience. You will get to see many different Hanok houses that have been restored as well as getting stunning views of both the Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung palaces. End the visit climbing down the stone staircase into Samcheong dong.
Visit Bukchon, Hanok village require a lot of walk, but the old style houses are very beautiful, you must come walk a afternoon when you visit Seoul!

Absolutely enjoyed the walk in this small village.. there were a lot of people and we were lucky enough that it was hanbok festival so there were plenty of people in hanbok.. This is a must visit and i recommend that you try to go on the hanbok festival..
We had a wonderful time exploring this village! Quaint & insightful. Highly recommended. Will come back again!

I took the metro to Anguk and took exit 2. Heading up the road there are some quaint side streets and coffee shops/cafes that align the road. I managed to pick up a free guide of the area from a stand that had a useful map and a basic route that allows you to circle round the area going up hill area to the main area where the streets are lined with traditional Hanok houses.It's good to take your time and enjoy the area generally. The walk up the hill isn't too onerous and there are plenty of opportunities to take photos. There are quite a lot of people wandering around seeing the houses so be patient if you want to take photos as most people walk along the same route. As the houses are actual residences there are many signs asking people to not be too loud and be respectful. Some houses were open for visitors for a fee however I didn't take that option.The route down from the hill also presents itself with many opportunities for those who like to shop. There are also a large number of quaint and traditional looking tea houses plus the more modern coffee houses so take you time, wander the streets and sit down for a drink if you want to rest up!

review_title: Fantastic area to visit and stay in Seoul
review_body: This area is fantastic to wander around in. The village is nice to see and there are many great little shops and quaint cafes.We stayed one night and liked it so much we changed our hotel booking to stay another night. Definitely try staying in a traditional hanok for the night!
Very unique design of hanoks.. and there are also boutiques for sourv. And local foods to taste.. there are also "points to see" for good scenenaries of bukchon..
Beautiful Korean traditional house. Walking distance from Insadong. Uphill location so be prepared to walk. Must see place.

review_title: Interesting but for us, it wasn't as interesting as we expected
review_body: It is fun to stroll through the narrow streets and see the numerous old hanok houses. It was fairly crowded with tourists, both Korean and others. We especially enjoyed seeing the many local people dressed in traditional Korean clothing who come here to be photographed.

It's eye opener to walk along the bukchon street. Basically it's a mix of commercial and residential. The architecture of the houses are very unique. There were even guest houses in this area. Very interesting place.

review_title: A taste of Korean Lifestyle and House
review_body: Walking through the streets of Bukchon will give one an insights into the culture of Koreans. The traditional houses and streets that are still homes to Koreans makes it an interesting experience for tourist.

The area used to be a quiet residential area with traditional Korean houses but then became a main tourist attraction that was always overcrowded with visitors. It was full of people when we went there in late afternoon. Some men holding signs that reminded tourists to keep quiet were found in various spots where most people gathered and took pictures. We followed the crowd to walk uphill for about 20 minutes and found a side street where most Korean houses were located. Warning was found on the main door of some houses stating that no pictures were allowed. I felt sorry for the residents there but it was really the best place to see the real traditional Korean houses.
perched in the hills this area is quieter than insadong but more intersting cafes ( traditional style)

It's a very nice place especially if you wanted to see some filming locations, and old houses. We went in here for a morning walk and it was great, there were also travel guide posts during that time which helped us find our way

review_title: Good for a couple of hours stroll
review_body: A nice place to take a stroll and view the traditional Korean houses. The area is much smaller than expected, but do be prepared for a lot China tourists with cameras.You can get an area map from the Tourist Information Booth along the main road.
Very pretty street with loads of quaint cafes and shops along the way. A must visit when you are in Seoul!

review_title: Must go to for the Historical feel
review_body: I was amazed by the beautiful old Korean houses in this small village. This is a famous tourist attraction so there were a lot of people. This is an uphill location so prepare yourself in walking with some effort going up and down. Don't worry if you get hungry, there are food places located in the village or you can go to, just a few blocks away, Insadong, another famous tourist shopping destination.

This part/place was recommended by friends, but when we went there it was truly underwhelming at best. The two different areas are lined with traditional houses (Hanoak), but the area is not well marked, and many of these "homes" are commercial B&B/AirBB, tea house, etc. Still, it's a worth a visit just to walk around and take some pictures.
It's a bit of an uphill walk coming from samcheongdong. It's a very small village with hanok style houses. A bit of Korean culture in the metropolis.

review_title: Very nice place but please keep the Volumes down.
review_body: Very nice houses around. Many handicraft shops and cafe around. Very relaxing place. There will be people there to make sure tourist to keep the volumes down as not to disturb the people staying there. Very nice experience and culture exposure. Very traditional place.

Very nice and quaint area in Seoul. You will see locals walking around in their national costume. It's filled with unique shops which offer Korean products. Great places to eat or just to have dessert.

A bit overloaded with tourists-nonetheless quaint! It really doesn't photograph well-not sure why! Lots of coffee shops(coffee v expensive in Korea & weekly American!) to laze in-often with no nibbles! And craft shops & workshops where you can drop in for an hour and play

I recently visited Seoul with my husband and 4 month old baby. We stayed in a traditional hanok in the Bukchon area on our first night and loved it so much we cancelled our accommodation closer to town and stayed on in an airbnb. Loved the area, great cafes, restaurants, galleries and shops. Easy to walk to streets, easy access to the palaces and also the subway for anywhere else. Would highly recommend.

Beautiful old buildings not far away from the big scyscrapers quite unusual combination. You can stroll on and quietly admire the old Seoul not paying for it. Its very close to the two biggest palaces so it may be an idea to combine these 3 things together in one day trip.

The place is a residential area. Nothing new and interesting to see. Going up the street is very tiring because it's hilly and you won't see anything extra ordinary at all. However, the shops along the street, going to Bukchon, is pretty nice. That's where we bought and sent postcards for ourselves back home. =)
I did a self-guided walk, having picked up a may fro the local TI storefront. It was an enjoyable afternoon and was a nice reprieve from the hustle and bustle of central Seoul.

review_title: Please be quiet when you are there
review_body: It's a nice quaint place. Lots of walking. Uphill and downhill. Wear something comfy. Please be quiet as it is a residential place. Too many tourists who are quite rowdy and loud. Feel sorry for the residence there.

review_title: Absolutely lovely architecture in a quaint neighborhood
review_body: Once you get to this area, just start following the signs and climb the stairs to get to the beautiful traditional Korean homes. This is a neighborhood of many private homes admidst modern day Seoul. There is one particular spot where you can take a pic of the traditional homes in the foreground and the skyscrapers and the N Seoul tower in the background.Tip: on the weekend, many Koreans dress in traditional garb and use this area as a backdrop for their pictures. So, you get a bonus having them in your own pictures!!

review_title: Piece of the past in the modern city
review_body: Nice area in historical part of the city with old fashion/traditional style Korean houses. There is suppose to be several highlighted view points but streets looks very similar and i am still not sure if we actually found the right spots. Can be crowded with tourist (in this case just check the parallel streets). Anyway it is worth to see it once you are next to the palaces. Btw it is not a museum and people are still leaving there.

Tons of tourists rent hanboks and run around taking their photos. So it was full of Chinese tourists who were eager for their photo ops. They didn't care too much if you were standing around waiting for them to move on, so you need to be a bit assertive if you want your own picture. Nonetheless it was nice that they did have some businesses opened to teach you about their culture and crafts. It was also awesome that the red uniform friendly welcome team were nearby to give directions. It saved me from walking straight up the hill to nowhere. Although the climb was steep, to finally walk down on the other side into Samcheong Dong, it was rewarding to find tons of cute cafes and churros stores at the bottom of the hill. The churro/ice cream was welcoming. I'd go again, not in 30 degrees weather, and hopefully not during Korea Fest month (open mad tourist season).

The houses are now residences so tourists are advised to stay silent while walking through the village. There's nothing to see but old wooden doors and walls. We cant even see what a typical old house looked like inside. There were some quaint artshops and cafes but other than that, nothing special. They had lots of volunteer tour guides who will help you find your way.

review_title: Definitely worth the walk! Must do!
review_body: Bukchon village is definitely worth the walk, experience the real traditional Korean houses and on the top of the hill you will have a great view!

This is one of the few places I went to twice. Not that I did not want to see the other places again but the first time I went here was around 10am, so quite early. But it was a LOT of tourists. And at least 5 BIG groups of chinese tourists. And they wanted just like me to take a lot of photos. But it was impossible to get decent photos with so many ppl around. So me and my friend decided to go back the next day, but at 7am instead. We were still not alone but I got so much better photos. So I recommend going here before breakfast if possible. The place/area itself then. Such a beautiful place with traditional buildings. The Hanok village is situated on top of a hill Sotheby's view from there as well is really stunning.Be sure not to miss out on this great place!

review_title: Nostalgic charm with a modern twist
review_body: Get a map from the tourist information centre which is a short walk from the Anguk subway station (exit 2). This map shows the main points of interest and different walking routes. The traditional architecture of the hanok village makes for an interesting stroll for an hour or two. Just be prepared to deal with busloads of rowdy mainland tourists jostling to snap pictures and some pretty steep hills. Comfortable shoes are a good idea.Some of the converted hanoks house galleries and shops. A few hanoks are open to the public for a fee. Pop into Granhand (19 Bukchon-ro 11-gil), a shop which sells contemporary, made-in-Korea fragrances, diffusers, sachets, linen sprays and candles in ceramic containers shaped like kimchi pots and traditional vessels. The artisanal scents are named after famous people like anthropologist Jane Goodall and furniture designer Finn Juhl. The bottle labels can be hand stamped with your name or the recipient's name and packed in jute bags. Great service from the friendly English-speaking staff. The shop entrance is discreet and might be easily overlooked. Combine Bukchon with Gyeongbokgung (one of the royal palaces) and Insadong (local flavour, dining and shopping) to make the most of a full day itinerary. They are one or two subway stops away from one another.

review_title: A nice place to walk around!
review_body: This part of the city is beautiful. It's has a nice feel where the old city meets new with many interesting vintage shops to look around. There are many galleries and small snack stand to get cinnamon flat bun and spicy rice cake dukbokki. We tried two restaurants there. One was hanjunsik and the other one was a steak/fries place. Don't believe the hype. They weren't that good. The food was overpriced and there were not worth paying that price. Try getting food at insadong. But if you like cafes, it's definitely a nice place to relax and read a book. And yes, a great place to take photos as well. It's very picturesque.

Took a while for us to walk here and find the place. Although it was awesome to see, it wasn't as much of as experience as I was hoping. There are a lot of people all on one road and you can't be loud, as it is still a residential area. But go and see it, it's a nice area to just hang around in!

This place is now a residential area and very few were converted to art galleries, restaurant, retail and museums. So u can see lots of signages to request for silence as the residences do not want to be disturbed. Lanes were narrow and we can only see the exterior as all homes were locked. Maybe an hour is good enough as they were unique to Korean culture but almost all the same with little variations.

it is nice stroll amongst the small alleys with the little shops. there's one part where you get nice sunset view with roofs of the old houses as foreground for your photos. but please please bring down your voice level as it is actual residence.
You walk around the old houses with a lot of people to try to put the best pictures.Beautiful view from the top

This is quite an interesting "old but new" living place in Seoul, right between Changdeok & Gyeongbok palaces. It is a live neighborhood brimming with tourists (must be painful or exciting for the residents depending upon their outlook and attitude) totting their cameras and eager to take their selfies at every corner. The narrow alleys and the hilly terrain, along with the traditional walls, roofs and doors make up for a very nice stroll to spend anywhere from 30 minutes to hours. Do visit it, but realize that it is a refurbished community, so it has a somewhat of a touristic feel to it.

Bukchon is a must-visit when in Seoul, as you can get to see the traditional houses of South Koreans. Do lower your volumes when you visit as they are residential places. You can take really great photos here, especially when dressed in Hanbok.

A collection of traditional hanok houses in one area.The nearest subway station is Anguk (line 3 orange line). My suggestion would be to plan visiting Insadong,Gyeongbokgung palace and Bukcoh all on the same day as they are all in the same area.Be prepared to walk a lot. Before you get to Bukchon, get an area map from the tourist information center ( the is one near the entrance of Insadong street, not far from the Anguk station). This map will show the side streets where most of the hanok houses are located.Mind you, some of them are on a steep hill.Wear comfortable clothing and shoes, otherwise you may not enjoy this at all.Always carry a bottle of water with you.If you are not a history buff and you have only limited days in Seoul, I would suggest that you can avoid the palaces and the Hanok village.
Love the design of traditional house in this area. So peaceful and full of tradition. Located near Gwanghwamun

review_title: Explore the 8 Major scenes as your mission!
review_body: You can serve Bukchon as an maze request game. First, head to the tourist information counter to take a full map of Bukchon. Then, started to fullfill the request to view all the 8 legendary scenes. After that, once you are successfully, reward yourself with a coffee at Sam cheong dong which is beside Bukchon. Perfect i should say!At the end i am sure you have explored Bukchon upside down! p/s: Scene 5 , 6 , 7 is crowded with a lot of people. It is harder to take a non people picture.

Lovely quaint neighborhood to stroll around. It is touristy for sure but local residences as well. Be brave to venture into the traditional tea houses and little restaurants tucked into alleys. They are a gem.

A great area to walk and see all the wonderful architecture up close. With respect to the people that live here, you can walk up and down the streets in this beautiful neighborhood.There are many shops & nice restaurants close by.

I still like the place very much as one can just wander around and relax here. Me and my friend also got to join some activities there like wearing hanbok and making the traditional korean hair band which was quite fun.Although there might not much to do but Ill still recommend one to visit to take a look at this side of Korea and maybe join some of the activities there as well!:)
Unique residences and alleys. Great for photography and long walks. Do wear good walking shoes as there were lots of slopes.

review_title: 北村韩屋村有着街道博物馆的美誉!
review_body: Good experience to adore Korean old days architecture! Like a street museum. Well maintenance also! There is a food street here where you can get a lot of local foods, remember to explore it!

Korean traditional houses surely are interesting. Seeing them one by one and comparing the houses is fun. Like the fact that they are all well preserved since it's a part of the Korean history.Worth a visit.

review_title: Nice walk to explore the old style korean house.
review_body: At the back, there is a nice backdrop for pictures. Alot of photo opportunities there. A nice friendly old lady selling nice postcards there. Do buy from her.

Easy to walk to or take the metro. Very historical but somewhat taken over by corporations and shops. Still, lots of history and architecture. Bring some good walking shoes as some of the streets are steep

It's really cool to be able to walk through a neighborhood straight from the Korean past. These old homes are preserved from before the modern age and show how the Koreans used to live before Western influences. At first, I was annoyed by all the older ladies walking around trying to keep everyone silent, but after seeing how some of the tourists acted there, I could see why. Remember, people actually live here so try to remain quite.

Walking around in Bukchon village could be quite fun especially for those who like to have a feel of the environment and atmosphere. U can also choose to wear the "hanbok" and taking pictures around this area.
There's hardly anything much else to do. Lots of closed doors and security locks. Just make sure you have the legs for the rolling roads.

A must visit place for first time traveler in Seoul. We spend around 2 hours here. A quick tip is try to go here by noon, where it's less crowded then you will have a perfect picture to show to your friend :)
You will get lost in this area, forget the time, forget where you are. Wandering around the village is a beautiful memory.
Lots of old-style houses and shops on very narrow and hilly streets; make sure you get the map of the neighborhood at the Bukchon Heritage Center.

Walking around this area of traditional Korean housing is simply delightful: it's well preserved and maintained. I thoroughly recommend getting off the main streets too as it's a lot less busy and there are little exhibitions, temples and shops to discover.
Easily access via subway ( Angguk station). Keep your voice lower to respect the residence. No entrance fee was charged. One of the korean drama shooting location.

review_title: Lovely to walk around and see the authentic village
review_body: This was a great experience that I highly recommend!You walk around the old village, around the houses and find yourself in a different world. The small village is less busy and more authentic than the larger village but both are worth a visit!
Authentic Korea. Beautiful village. Very quiet place to appreciate history. Some local shops and restaurants available

Visiting Bukchon Hanok Village is a must-do when visiting Seoul. The area is beautiful and even if there are many tourists it's still lovely to take a walk and see the traditional houses and streets. Try to get lost on the side streets and discover areas not so crowded. There are many cafes and restaurants in the area.

review_title: Shopping in the traditional Korean residence district
review_body: Once you have visited Gyrongbok palace, consider walking toward Bukchon which literally mens Northern Town. It is full of small shops and eateries with the glimpse of home stay in a traditional Korean housing. In the house stay, there are no beds. Instead, a floor is provided much like when one goes to camping but more luxurious and comfortable way. I did not stay but walked into a house to get information.
Lovely little suburb to walk through where tradition and modernity merge. So many interesting shops and cafes to explore and definitely worth a visit!

The first time i went to Bukchon Hanok Village i was so exited. From what i know from internet it's a place that you can see a traditional korean house, and indeed it is a nice place to walk around and take pictures. You can also find small restaurant in this neighborhood with a korean traditional interior.
I like this place very much, you can walk slowing to feel what people live here from the passmany small shop for food and for clothing. spend one day here is worth....

review_title: Fun to look around the tiny streets.
review_body: Had a good time roaming the streets of Bukchon. Took awhile to find it but once we did had good time. If you enjoy old architecture this is for you.

there were lot of cafes and small places to shop, and you can get to the Bukchon Vallage (Korean traditional houses) they are very nice, and people are living in them. there were a lot of people rented the traditional outfit and walk around - cute & fun!

This place was quite nice and the old buildings were beautiful. However, I'm not sure if it's because I had high expectations or something, but that was about it. There wasn't too much. There weren't any houses open to the public to see (at least not where we went). It's also not that big.
In the middle of bustling modern Seoul, some people elect to live in traditional houses in traditional surroundings. Well worth a stroll (1-2 hours)

review_title: Watch out for the bikes and cars!
review_body: Take a map, it can get a little confising! Lots of old style buildings alongside the new. Take a hat and prepare to spend a few hrs on foot :)

Wonderful place.If you go during the week it should be quiet and peaceful. I thought it would only be a few streets but actually the area is fairly big with lots and lots of hank houses to take pictures of.The view from higher ground are also excellent.

Not quiet what I expected. The houses looked nice but that's about it really. Also didn't help that it can get very crowded being a tourist destination, making the whole experience a bit underwhelming. If you're close to the area then go for it but I wouldn't go out of my way for this one.

This was a fantastic neighborhood to simply get yourself lost and wander up and down the streets. In my opinion, it's the best way to travel. Please be mindful of your voice level to respect the people who live in this neighborhood. Most of the people who were visiting this area were loud and obnoxious with their selfie sticks. There are signs everywhere reminding all who are visiting the to keep their voices at a minimum. Just outside this residential area are little streets with shops, art galleries, restaurants and cafes. This is also a great place to explore.

review_title: Nice traditional village near the Gyeongbokgung
review_body: very excited to find out about the traditional village near Gyeongbokgung. It's like time capsule going back to Joseun dynasty. Enjoy strolling at the village, feel peaceful here.

review_title: Beautiful village showcasing old and new Korea.
review_body: Nice place to visit. Be prepared to spend a few hours there. A lot of walking is needed as you need to walk up a sloppy road leading to the village. On the way the road is lined with trees and beautiful scenery below and from afar. A lot of art work can be seen everywhere. The houses are mostly traditional Korean houses though some are renovated and look new. There are residents living in those houses , thus it is advisible not to talk too loud or disturb them. Good place to take photos. Not many seats are available for you to sit and rest but there are cafes around for you to relax and drink.You can even rent the traditional Korean dress ( hanbok ) for photo taking.

review_title: cute streets but not much happening
review_body: Picturesque little streets filled with restaurants, tea houses a a few shops. Nothing special apart from a nice stroll. Not far away from the city centre.

review_title: Interesting mix of old and new
review_body: Great area to wander around. Go off the main roads and get yourself lost a little, you'll easily find your way back. Plenty of cafés and places to eat. It's very popular, so be prepared for plenty of company, particularly at weekends. Lots of couples in traditional hanbok dress add to the atmosphere and the views of the old hanok houses against the background of high rise modern Seoul are fabulous.Walking out of Bukchon, you're only a stones throw from Insa-dong.

The Hanok Village in Bukchon is Korean traditional houses. It is famous and one of must go to visit attractions in Korea. The Hanok Village is on the top of the mountain, so you need to walk a long and steap road. Although you will feel tired, it is worth when you arrived at the Hanok Village. A lot of tourists dressed Korean traditional clothes – Hanbok, they took pictures in this beautiful places like a Korean. I am regret that I did not rent hanbok to try. It will a good experience. Also, I saw a foreign TV show came to there. They introduced the Hanok Village and interviewed the local resident to introduce the history of the village. Walking along this road, you found the air is fresh and the hanok is total different from each other. Each house have their feature and culture. I really recommend this place to take a visit in Seoul. However, our voice should as low as possible. We should not disturb the local residents.

Lovely village. You can't miss it. Just wander around the winding streets that some times turn into sidewalks that can end up as stairs. Don't worry if you end up in a dead end, just turn around and find another path. Charming area with innumerable cafes and tea houses on the main street. Do make sure you get off the main street, though.

Really nice to walk through these picturesque alleys with its nice little homes. But it can be quite busy there with tourists taking selfies everywhere and not even respecting the property of the people living there.

Had a little walk around here during the day. Very lovely but quiet busy. You can use the hop on hop off bus to get here which we did. There is also a lovely park surrounding which was nice to walk through. Good examples of olden style dwellings - there were written information plaques but I do not recall English - though I may be incorrect.

review_title: a glimpse of traditional Korean house
review_body: Be prepared to walk up and downhill when you tour around this area.It is quiet and you can have a glimpse of the traditional Korean house.

review_title: Perfect mix of a modern and traditional taste
review_body: What I found interesting is, this village is located in the city, integrated with other element of the city. It is surprising when you walk in the pavement with a busy traffic and the next turn you take bring you to the traditional taste of Korean home.I learned that this area is visited by tourist massively, but I was there late afternoon so I only encounter 2-3 people, which is amazing. This is basically a residential area, so you should respect them and keep your voice low.
Traveller MUST visit this village. Very unique and traditional place of Seoul. I love every minute in this place, feel very tranquility and calming
Very beautiful area that's full of tourists. Nice area with great views. Be prepared for the tourist crowds

Quaint and picturesque traditional village. Plenty of people rent the traditional costumes and walk around taking photos. Rather crowded but fun to wander around. There are several museums around, apparently, offering insights into the cultural background. Do remember that this is still a residential area, so they request tourists to keep their voices down.
If you want to see how korean traditional houses & village looks like, you visit here bukchon Hanok village. There are over 900 houses packed.
It's like going back to the past with all the older yet very well maintained homes of Korea. great street to visit!

This cluster of traditional Korean houses is located between the Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung palaces. Bukchon literally means 'northern village". Some of these residence blocks are centuries-old. The Bukchon Traditional Culture Centre located in this area plans and operates a variety of cultural programs. A walk through Bukchon Hanok essentially means a walk through meandering alleys. Thoroughly enjoyable and pretty!

review_title: Not what we expected... so much better
review_body: We visited the village early morning as a stop gap whilst waiting to start our Secret Garden Tour at Changdeokgung Palace. So glad we decided to stop by as it's such a gem. Not at all what we were expecting, but so much better, a great mix of old and new. Great little shops and cafes, had some nice restaurants too. Just a shame we didn't have more time.....Would definitely visit again, would just make sure we made more time. Lovely way to spend a couple of hours.

review_title: Lovely place full of hidden gems
review_body: We had a lovely couple of hours walking round all the hidden little streets.Some good shops and very reasonable priced.

I've heard so much positive about this place but when i arrived there it wasnt much. Its basically just a hill with traditional buildings. It's worth taking a visit when doing Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung Palace since its between those two, but do not plan to spend much time here.

review_title: The Way that it Used to Be
review_body: Take the time to visit the "old Seoul." High atop hills, with a great view of the city, you can wander up and town narrow streets, looking at old home and buildings of the ancient architecture. A MUST SEE!

We asked directions at the tourist information booth and was given a map of Bukchon where he highlighted the best places to go. On arrival at the village there was a coach tour getting off so it can get busy as it is a popular tourist site. There are many signs telling people to keep the noise down as this is a residential area. However this did not stop people talking loudly or posing for photos on the doorway of someone's house. The village mixes the old traditional houses with some newer style. I felt like I was intruding into their neighbourhood and they must get pretty tired of the tourists gawping in and taking photos of their houses. The only people that seem to benefit are the shops selling gifts and the cafes and restaurants.

review_title: overrated but the shopping is fun
review_body: The area of Seoul is lovely - and unique. Most of Seoul is in the process off renovation and Bukchon still has some of the old feel to it. Jump into the alleys for proper food. If someone is beckoning you into a hole in the wall sort of restaurant, go in. You will be in the right place. The pictures on the wall will assist you in choosing something to eat and you will love it. Best food anywhere
By sort of old I meant a little more than 100 years old. That in the scheme of things not really old but still a nice hour of walking and some shops

review_title: If you don´t do anything else; do this
review_body: We LOVED it! If you do not see anything else in Seoul this is definitely something to do. The feeling, the little shops, the beautiful streets... so sweet in the middle of the city. Do this. Short but sweet.
If you visit korea you cant miss this place i stay 2 night here and to me is not enough i wish i have more time
I really liked the atmosphere of the "village", it's quite calm compared to downtown Seoul. Really pretty.

review_title: A Walk in Korean Traditional Village during a Rainy Day
review_body: Bukchon Hanok Village is within walking distance from Anguk Station. If you are unsure about the layout of the village, I would recommend you to visit the tourist information center located along the way from Anguk Station to the village. The staff there will provide you with the village map and even will advise on the suitable route to enjoy the walk. I visited this village during a windy and rainy day. Even though our visit was somehow affected by the strong wind and wet clothes, but as it was just a leisure walk, we still able to enjoy the walk and took memorable pictures. The whole village is residential area with people living inside the traditional house, so we have to mind our manners and avoid making loud sounds. There are a lot of picturesque spots throughout the village. If you enjoy leisure walk and traditional architectures, this is a must visit area. In addition, Buckhon Hanok Village is near to Gyeongbukgong Palace and if you don't mind to walk for another 10 mins plus, you can just walk to the palace from this village.

The Hanuk Village in Bukchon is absolutely picturesque. The village successfully preserves the humble yet intricate architecture of traditional Korean houses. The road is steep so wear comfortable footwear! I also suggest joining a walking tour instead of a DYI so as not to unnecessarily waste any time and effort in getting lost.
Very easy to do a little walk about here, streets connect to lots of little restaurants and then you are close to the Palace to so that after.

Great place to visit to see the traditional building styles and methods of yesterday. Its a relatively small spot so it won't take long to see a lot. Keep in mind this is a residential neighborhood and apparently the residents are not huge fans of the crowds. You'll see a lot of people here taking pictures.

You can choose to go with a tour or like me - walking free and easy! It is a great area full of hanoks (traditional korean houses), boutique shops and cafe. I was planning to spend half a day but turned out enjoyed for a good 5-6 hours walk with breaks in between. It was great to take a break with some ice tea and Korean snacks in a hanoks cafe.For photography lovers, you may take more than half a day like me. It was great walking round to take photos along small alleys, definitely a great trip! I enjoyed getting lost in the village although I had a map with me. For those who love to stay in old houses, there are lots of guest houses too For the cafe lover, absolutely a place to go with traditional atmosphere with some Korean tea and snacks.For those who go with tours, please lower your voice because this is still a residential area with residents. Unfortunately many tourists were still making lots of noises - even the tour guides were loud, not exactly respecting the residents. Tips: Please visit early and plan for your route if you want to avoid the crowds, I managed to avoid it.Also, you may want to bring/ purchase electronic fan if you travel during Summer like me.
Many traditional house (hanok) in there. We can also try street food in some stores. Little bit crowded but not a problem

2 years ago, I tried to come here from Samcheongdong and omg it was so steep. This time I tried from Insadong/Anguk stn and it was so easy. Get out from exit2, wait for the green bus no.2 at the stop across the street from Starbucks and get off at 북촌한옥마을.돈미약국 (Bukchon Hanok Village/Donmi pharmacy) to save 10 mins of walking up the hill. From the stop, cross the street and just follow the crowd. From the photospot no. 4(if I remembered correctly) which is the observation point, you can walk down to Samcheongdong using steep staircase or the not too steep/far walkway. After that you can roam around the street. if you turn right you will shortly arrive at Kyeongbok Palace. If it's too much of a walk, after you reach the ground, just cross the street and take the bus to the palace or the main road for subway stn.

If you are interested in getting "lost" in a folk area in Seoul, Bukchon Hanok village is a good chance to do it. You can see how a Korean village did look like, how the ceilings are/were made, the entrance doors of the houses and so on. I would recommend to visit the "sample" of old house shown in the Bukchon Traditional Culture Center.

I highly recommend this neighborhood. This is the only neighborhood in Seoul where you can see traditional Korean houses. Some of the traditional houses have been turned into art galleries, coffee shops and museums where you can experience traditional Korean culture (tea ceremony, arts and crafts, etc.)

Bukchon Hanok village is a must see while in Seoul. Easy to get to and fascinating to walk around. I wouldn't spend a lot of time here but it is worth seeking out - just do it quietly, the locals who live there don't appreciate noisy tourists!

Go here if you're interested in their cultural houses. There's a lot of walking and there are steep areas that at some point, my parents would just wait for us instead of walk all the way up the kinda steep walkway. It was a nice walk along the houses. It can also be considered a fun mini hike if you're up for that kind of stuff. The view of the sunset and mountain is beautiful from here.

review_title: Too many tourists on a Sunday
review_body: I had high expectations of walking around quiet neighborhoods of hanoks which are traditional Korean wooden homes. My husband and I went on a Sunday. The streets were overrun with tourists taking photos of themselves with the homes in the backgrounds. You'll need to walk uphill to see the more interesting homes. The tiny Bukchon Tourist Office provides a good map and lots of helpful information. Go on a quiet week day. Hopefully, it will feel more authentic.

review_title: Nice views plus bought local clothes
review_body: I enjoyed walking and taking photos ans also bought local traditional cloths for around 20 000 for myself and the same for my wife. Children version cost 15 000. Also enjoyed fried rice with hit sauce, and rice drink!

review_title: Beautiful Korean traditional village. good for taking photo
review_body: If you like taking picture, or you interested in Korean traditional houses, you won't disappointed. You can see a different "Seoul" from here, The village is quite big, you can walk up and down hill, to take a pictures. one thing I was not impress, is too many tourists, can not take a good photo with no people.

I visited this area once in the summer and again during Chuseok in the autumn with family. It is a lovely and interesting neighbourhood to walk around.Although it is easy to get to, you must keep in mind that it is all uphill. This can be difficult for anyone with a bad knee or anyone pushing a baby stroller.It's also a short activity (perhaps an hour max of looking around) so it would be worth going to the palace nearby to make a nice day of it all. There are many cafes and shops nearby for refreshments too.

When you come to Seoul, Buchon Village is the little place that really traditional and if you love korean drama, this place is really like location for Korean Drama. But please do not make a noisy since this village still home for korean citizen.

A glimpse into village life. Would have liked to have a look into more homes beyond the gates. They look quite spacious. Interesting exploring the alleys and shops. Good craft beer cafe to finish the visit.

review_title: Convenient location to see traditional Hanok houses
review_body: Great walking tour between two of the major palace attractions, so a great way to get your hanok fix. The houses are well maintained and there is a small visitor center (Seoul Hanok Center) that can provide a map showing walking tour ideas and an extremely knowledegable and friendly guide who can provide more information and show you an unoccupied hanok and talk about some principles of it's construction. It is not listed on Trip Advisor but is right off of Gyedong-gil-2 streetThere is a lot of uphill climbing. Many cute little shops and some restaurants as well as micro museums within given hanoks.

review_title: Beautiful photo spot where traditional Korea meets modern Seoul
review_body: This is a very relaxing attraction where you can walk streets to see old traditional Korean houses. They were very well maintained. As you walk up the hill, the Seoul skyline begins to emerge in the background. This is a great photo spot!There were two helpful "information" givers, who provided maps of the area and spoke great English! The whole attraction took us about an hour. Signs throughout remind visitors that Bukchon is a residential area, so keep your voices quiet.Check this out if you like beautiful architecture and scenery. Probably not the #1 Seoul attraction, but definitely a cute spot to visit!

review_title: Well preserved traditional Korean living area
review_body: This is definitely worth to visit. I don't expect these traditional Korean buildings are preserved so well. When walking along all the lanes of this area, I felt history is around me. Also, there are few shops to on those beautiful traditional clothing and took beautiful shot with the background of old Korean building. So happy! Of course, suggest to go there during weekday because it is a very popular sport for tourist.
Nothing special at the place except for korea traditional houses. Namsamgol hanok village still the best i visited at seoul.
I love the structures of Korean houses here. I wish i can spend my night at least once in one of the houses here.

Lovely walk around this area. Cool buildings, nice doors. Cute shops some galleries, a private observatory which we didn't go to. Some nice photo opportunities. Busy with other people taking selfies and generally getting in the way. Nice place, I think the people who live there must get really annoyed with tourists, from the signs on the walls and doors telling others to be quite etc.
This place is so cute! Loved every corner! Walk in the middle of residential area and next there are more streets full of shops and small restaurants. Very nice.
Is near Sophia guesthouse I look around nice village town. A lot shops to look around. Night time is the best to shop around.
Again another place to get that Hanbok on! There's one alleyway that has great houses. resto not so good but tourist info people always ready to assist!

review_title: Prepare your walking shoes for some cardio challenge...
review_body: The traditional houses in Bukchon are beautiful and you would encounter small shops selling trinkets and restaurants offering local delicacies. However, take note that you would do a lot of uphill and downhill walks around here which may not be recommended for old people and with health issues. P.S. Bring a bottle of water. Trust me, you'll get tired from all of that walking.

review_title: Very nice and lovely place in the midst of mixed residential and commercial village!
review_body: After visiting the Changdeokgung palace (please refer to my earlier review of this place as well) as part of our full day city tour, which is just a short drive away from here, our guide brought us here for a short walkabout to immerse in another different aspects of the Korean culture and lifestyle.It was about 10.45am when we arrived and the weather warm and sunny. There is a small road with shophouses located on both sides of it (i.e. cafes, restaurants, retail and souvenir shops etc), and according to our guide, this place is very famous among the Japanese tourists, possibly because they are the ones who help to spur "tourism" activity here and true enough, in our walk around here, we saw many groups of Japanese tourists.As we walked deeper into the small road and into the lane where houses are located (of which some have been converted to retail and business operations). The walk was uphill on stone and rocky pathways. The houses here were very nice and lovely that depicted their long past history (of course some have been reconstructed or rebuilt and one do need to pay to admit). Most of the houses were well maintained and one could easily experience the Korean's enriching culture and history.As we walked higher (actually the walking trail was a full circle walk uphill and downhill and back to where we started), we saw more houses, unique shop houses, hostels and they were very beautifully decorated with flowers. When we reached the highest point, we did have a good bird eye's view on the vicinity and could even see the palaces from here, besides the mountains!It's a worthwhile visit here definitely as one could immerse in the unique ambience of the lovely Hanok Village of the past in present time. Although the walk can be challenging for some (at certain section, it was quite steep), just take your own sweet time and pace and you will still be able to complete the walk and see lovely things. If my 80-year old mum can do so, everyone can too!However, do take note of the following to make your walking trail fun and enjoyable:Do wear pair of comfortable/short shoes here and there will be lots of walking (especially walking uphill); Bring along drinking water, umbrella and hats during summer time; and Do keep the volume of talking low as there are still many residents staying here to avoid disturbing them.Highly recommended.

Nice peaceful walk along the old traditional houses. This village is quite big so remember to follow the maps which are available along the way.Hanbok rental are available as well but I would recommend rent it from the shops near the Gyeongbokgung Palace as wearing Hanbok will allow you to have free entry into the palace.

We signed up with Seoul Tourism Board free walking tour and we were assigned a English speaking guide Jennifer. She was very detailed and showed us the Village and even corners where no tourists knew. It was refreshing to find such as quaint place in the heart of Seoul city. I highly recommend you visit this place. Just a word of advice: Please be mindful that there are local residents living in midst of this village so please be considerate to the surrounding and the level of noise that you might be creating.

Definitely worth walking through in between palace visits--- convenient to do so. That said, it's hard to find the exact location- I'd recommend stopping in the visitors center to get map and guidance. Gives a great glimpse into Seoul's past.

This are has lovely old traditional houses and gives you a feel for what the city must have been like in the past. There are lots of nice little shops and galleries around the little streets. Many of the old houses can be visited for a small fee.

We had read about this location and didn't fully comprehend what it would be like. Be sure to pick up a map at the visitors center and watch the film. Then just wander around. It becomes quite obvious that this is a special place.

review_title: Difficult to find from the palace
review_body: It's not visible as it is behind new houses. Anyway it's very quiet and well maintained. There are many stores that sell clothes, cosmetics, foods, souvenirs, jewelry and many drink shops that are well decorated and nice view.

review_title: What a great place to visit
review_body: So stumble out of the subway and even if you get a bit lost like us you will eventually stumble across the village. People actually live in this village so please respect their privacy when trouncing around. Be mindful of your voice. There are plenty of options to look beyond the gated doors of traditional homes. Classic is seeing a lot of Asian you study going for Cosplay, wearing traditional costumes in the crazy heat. We came along in Autumn and it was still very warm. Can't imagine how uncomfortable it will be in mid summer Well worth the visit. Once back on the main drag grab yourself a traditional tea in any of the great tea rooms

review_title: Cool to see an old neighbourhood in such a modern city
review_body: The area is very cool. Go to the main information centre first, they will give you a map with suggested routes. It is best to follow the routes as determining the best route yourself could get tricky.
We walked through the narrow streets enjoying the pretty houses which were well looked after. The small shops and people gazing was in abundance. Definitely worth a visit.

It was very close to the Gyeongbokgung palace and I'm glad that i went there. You need to walk uphill to get there, but you will get a really nice view over the city. I really like the pictures i took there. But you should keep in mind that people still live in these houses. One of the houses is open for visitors and they also sell some souvenirs. There are also many souvenir shops or food stores in this area.

If you plan to visit this folk village, please ensure that you have good walking shoes. The road to the sites are all uphill, from Anguk Metro station. There will be a Tourist counter after you exit the subway. Get a map for the Bukchon Hanok Village. There will be sites that are numbered, site 1 for a view/glimpse of Changdeokgung Palace, site 3/4/5/6 are the main sites of the folk village.

Loved walking through this area! Fun to see the traditional style, stop in the little shops and eat local street food. Kids and adults were engaged the entire time and it is a great place to walk through as you make you way from palace to Insadong!

Beautiful area. Well worth visiting. Wonderful mix of old, historic Hanok properties with modern, on-point, trendy coffee shops and shopping options in other parts of the area. We did a tour to begin with and then went back and spent a whole afternoon there!
This was one of my favorite spots in Seoul. Traditional houses, good restaurants and great shopping.

review_title: Nice old Korean houses worth seeing
review_body: The narrow streets with the small wooden houses are beautiful and good for pictures. It is really worth the walk from Insadong shopping street. You should love it if you love art.

review_title: This is a nice add-on to a day hike in the area
review_body: Take the Orange Metro Line (3) and get off at Anguk Station. Take exit 3 and walk. You can access Insadong, Itaewon and Bukchon in the same visit. The National Museum is close, as are a few of the palaces. Keep in mind, this is a residential neighbourhood and people appreciate your silence.

review_title: Historical Hanoks that we've all seen in dramas
review_body: A historic area of Seoul among the modern city. Frequently see it in k-dramas so it was nice to visit. You do have to be careful not to disturb the residents there though.

Beautiful historic area in Seoul, and a contrast to the rest of the modern city. Try to go early morning, or around sunset to get as few tourists around you. A few houses let you in for a small fee. Lonely Planet guides have a good walking map of the area.

A nice short walk from the Palace and well worth going to for the good array of cafe's. When you decide to view the old style houses you will have a reasonable hole up the hill so not suitable for seniors on a wet day
Nice little area to see historic Korean homes - near many restaurants and coffee shops for a sunny day stroll.Close to both palaces of Seoul.

review_title: A feel of old Seoul in the middle of the city
review_body: In Bukchon you can get a very close idea how were the wealthy neighborhoods in Seoul 200, 300 years ago. Remember this is the middle of Seoul and people live in these houses... It is a nice stroll and some times uphill, so use comfortable shoes.
It is nice to walk around the area to see the more traditional architecture, where people are still living there.
After a long and tired walk u will arrive at this place, Its nice place to take a photo here with some unique traditional village

review_title: Seoul is an amazing city, but visiting this part is a must!
review_body: A lovely suburb with cute traditional houses and a view of the modern city down below - a unique experience.

Take a road map provided as you can find them along the street and just follow the steps given and you find yourself visiting these beautiful traditional houses without spending money on tour guides to bring you.

Best thing to do is visit the tourist office first for a detailed map of Bukchon including a walk visiting all the highlights. Some parts are really pretty with traditional houses, some parts are not too interesting. Cobble stones, art, greens, little shops, restaurants. You're asked to walk around respecting the residents.

review_title: Great place to spend a day
review_body: The walk from the palace leads u to many nice quaint cafes & interesting little stalls/flea markets, after the right turn, all along the way. Was so distracted n mesmerized by everything. Direction sign as to where the villAge begin is unclear as the building along it looks similar but just relax, get lost, get soak in.. it's worth the walk. The village is at the end of the road.The village itself is another great experience will definitely return

It's not easy to locate the traditional Korean houses but no worries there are walking tourists information which let you know how to go there. Bukchon area is fun to visit...don't miss Bing-Bing shaved ice...the best one I ever tasted during the visit to Seoul. Also please make sure not to make a lot of noises during walking surrounding the houses - there are notices everywhere.....I just couldn't imagine myself living in this area with nonstop curious tourists walking around especially if the tourists could not read the notice due to language barrier.

The surrounding area is very different with the modern city of Seoul, it is closed to UNESCO - Changdeokgung Palace Complex. You can feel traditional Hanok and palace is so peaceful. You don't find any luxury and brilliant building, but you can find how ancient Korea dynasty lifestyle, worth to go.
Street of traditional Korean residential houses left in the North of Seoul City.Not exactly old but still shows old Korean residential houses live in.

The village houses are owned and stayed by actual modern day Koreans so all the tourist just walk along the roads to take picture of the wooden doors and stone walls ... It is a hilly area and your photos almost cannot be exclusive as there are many others taking pictures as well

This is a cute area for good pictures especially up on top of the hill looking down. Pretty small area, but nice to look around and take a visit to the small shop that looks like an old fashion house.
It's a village of preserved old traditional Korean houses. You can go around but it will get boring because they look all the same but its good to have some photo opp in one of the houses!

We lovee this place, the houses, the tea houses, the mountain view at the end of the road was simply amazing. There's not much good restaurant nearby, note that we don't prefer eating at tourism areas. We were there from the morning and starved by the afro, couldn't find proper good korean meals and managed to walked down to angguk and went inside the crowded alley and found a great korean diner.

It's nice walking around here as you see a more historical side to the city. Note that some of the streets are actually residential so you can't make too much noise. The closest station is Anguk and we combined this with a tour to the palace.

review_title: Nice and cosy walk at this area. You may have your lunch and continue with a cup of coffee.
review_body: Is a short walk of my day. But I have a wonderful meal during lunch. Never felt regret to dropby this place. Many of them can speak a little bit of english and chinese, so i wont felt lost there.

review_title: Really enjoyed this place, but it was so difficult to find the exact area ):
review_body: If I'm not mistaken, my friends and I walked around in circles for about an hour just trying to find the exact area where most people go to take pictures of. Navigation is not easy as well, even with maps provided. Many steep pathways and stairs to climb, but overall, all of us enjoyed our time here. We got to experience the cultural village, take beautiful photos, as well as mingling with a local roadside vendor which sold idol products. However, take note that this place is a residential area and lower down your volume at all times! Don't be inconsiderate to others.

Visited in July16. Will require lot of walking to cover entire village. Pick up a map from info booth right at start of village that wil show the best route you can cover. You can see Traditional homes here and they look beautiful.

This area is adorable. It's full of cute little streets and various cafes. Whilst it is touristy, you can easily turn off to another street and be in peace again. It is truly lovely and is worth a visit!

Bukchon, literally mean North Village. It is basically surrounded by Gyeongbokgung Palace. Changdeokgung Palace and Jongmyo, and not far from Insa-dong too. Group them together for a day visit of Korean traditional houses and palaces is truly memorable for any history lover!

While a stroll through Bukchon Village may feel like a trip through the ages, the neighborhood is not frozen in time. Some of the hanoks are still private homes, but others have been converted into tea houses, coffee shops, cafés, art galleries, inns and museums.Although it seems like its nothing much but I think I spent like 2 hours walking around the neighborhood. Just admiring the beautiful houses and the serenity it seems to bring being around there.

Bukchon is a residential area and I had a good walk here with my friend. The traditional Korean houses here are so beautiful and you can take loads and loads of pictures around here. There are a lot of tourists around. You can get a map for the route to walk around at the tourist centre near to Anguk station exit no. 2. Definitely buy something cold to eat or drink if you come here in Summer!
