This was such an interesting experience. It's a long walk, going up and down the hills but it's quite worth it. The houses are very nice. Each house is different from each other but somehow tied up together and become architectural masterpiece. And it's amazing to see how the Koreans embrace their culture by still living in these houses. Highly recommended.
You might try to wear the Hanbok there and take a photo in their village it has some craft workshop. Near Insadong if you want to stop by it while in Insadong

Nice walk to just see how these old houses have been preserved and continue to used as residences. Walked through in the afternoon although I believed it would probably be more interesting with little cafes opened later in the evening and better sunset views...
Very interesting place. But be mindful. It is a residential area. So, keep you voice as low as possible and try not to anything not belonging to you.

review_title: Nice for a stroll, traditionak Korean houses
review_body: Walk in the narrow street to have a sense of how traditional Korean houses looked like, however its a residential area so its changing and some irrelevant buildings are also there. Good for taking some nice shots

We were really looking forward to exploring this area but when we got there it was so crowded and quite lacking in atmosphere. We stopped for a snack and a drink at a cafe and the prices were a total rip off.

A nice experience. Lovely to see the local houses and how koreans lived traditionally. It's very quiet. You walk up and down hills and stairs. Each house is different from the next and yet somehow all tie together. There is even a craft studio where you can make your own crafts. You don't need much time here- it's a quick stopover.

review_title: A must see must wander in Seoul
review_body: this is a must see/must wander through area in Seoul. Easiest to do it in conjunction with a tour to one of the two big palaces. Its a lovely district to wander through, some great coffee shops and also some lovely small boutique stores and jewellery shops. you feel a million miles away from the hustle and bustle and some lovely photo opps.

review_title: Long walk, but worth the effort.
review_body: Even though some are of Bukchon is becoming too much commercialized like Insadong, many parts of Bukchon remains traditional. I would recommend visiting this place to anyone who travels Seoul. Stop by at Bukchonok restaurant which I recommended in my other review.

review_title: Korean drama fans would like to have a visit
review_body: It's actually Korean traditional houses and there are really people living in it, so you cannot make loud noise. Quite a lot of people during that time. You will need to have a strong leg muscle to walk around Bukchon Hanok Village.

It is very special experience to live in a traditional Korea house. It is simple furniture and decoration. If you have come with an elderly, the Korea bed is too low for an elderly. Rather than this, everything is ok.

review_title: A glimpse of traditional Seoul life
review_body: This place is a short walk from the Gyeongbokgung Palace. It was a very nice surprise, full of cute little houses, coffee places and gift shops. This is one of the few places in Seoul I would definitely visit again, so I highly recommend it.

Love the quaint building structures especially the doors and rooftop styles. Enjoy walking the streets and exploring some of the houses. You get the opportunity to dress in traditional hanbok and take photos in them or wear these costumes and walk around in them - all for a fee of course
Very nice part of town if you want to connect with original culture. Houses are you spectacular and there are many old shops.

After visiting Changdeokgung Palace we take a walk to Bukchon Hanok Village. Its a nice place to discover the traditional Korean houses. You can see some korean workshop (bukchon chogo, bukchon jeotdae, ...).

I really enjoyed walking the streets. I entered up through the back up some narrow stairs and wound my way down the lanes heading in general direction of the Main Street. I walked there from G palace. Some beautiful old quiet streets of you wander off a little.
It's a nice contrast between the old village and traditional houses, with the modern city in the backdrop. However, too crowded and noisy when i intended for a relaxing stroll! !!

Personally I don't really get the point. You can't see inside any of the houses. Crowded with tourists. The only marginally interesting part was the view from the overlook point. It free so if you are nearby, but would not go out of my way to see it.

Get your sneakers on as it's a hilly area, sometimes very steap too. Besides there many little shops for souvenirs but also tiny restaurants for a meal. Lots of hidden gems, take your time to discover them. Many hanoks to gaze at, however do respect the residents!

Traditional rows of houses. While there are many notice and reminders hanging around indicating to keep noise level low due to they are people actually staying there, most tourists did not heed the advice. I think it will be a nuisance for me if I am staying there. Haha. By the way, we walked to here from Samcheongdong (would only suggest this if you have ample of time)

It is a very quirky place to be, lined both with modern shops and renovated traditional-style houses. It is essential to step into the alleyway offshoots and spend some time at an interesting cafe. Don't arrive until at least after 10 or 11am or else everything will be closed. Come in the afternoon for Bukchon at it's most lively and bustling.

A good place to take photo when you are here, It's best you get a map from tourist counter and walk not only Bukchon but some other places too. This place is residential area, so basically can't make too much noise a lot of keep quiet sign around the place.

review_title: Beautfully preserved old houses, still functional
review_body: Beautifully preserved old houses that are still being lived in. Some of the owners have used the location of their homes to offer tourists stunning views of the Seoul skyline (they charge and entrance fee). Worth walking through these several streets. On the weekend you can see young Koreans dressed in traditional customs walking around.

The Bukchon Hanok Village is an interesting neighborhood for wandering. The shops and restaurants here are smaller in size, but very nice and the quality of food and products is quite good. As one might expect in a older village, the streets are winding and full of hills, up and down. If you are looking for a great workout, this is your place! If you have trouble getting around, this is NOT your place. If it is raining or crazy hot it would be better to do this another day. You will need good walking shoes and an umbrella - not for rain, but for shade! If you are visiting during the summer heat, this neighborhood would be best visited early or late in the day.

It is a beautiful place to walk around and get a feel for the traditional houses and see with what care people take care of it and live in history. For me it was a good display that modern and old can live side by side without being out of balance. A minus can be that you have steep climbs. I went there with no expectations and what I saw was simply put beautiful.
Village with traditional Korean houses. Interestingly, it is in the heart of Seoul's most expensive district.

i must say this is one of best attraction in Seoul. The alleys are filled with traditional Korean houses that was so amazing to see. Unfortunately, you can't see inside the house because it is personal residences.

Went here with my family and I must say this village is one of the best area to visit in Seoul. You will see lots of houses which is transformed into shops and next to it there will be an alley leading to a traditional style house which people still live in it. Very nice and very interesting place to go for a walk.

as people still lives in this area, we tried to keep quiet during our visit here. but the most loud one is either chinese tourist or local people themselves -_- nevertheless bukchon is amazing. even the house is still preverse in traditional style, their doors, gate, ornament etc is very interesting. its kind of hard to get photo (alone) because of sea of tourists, even in weekdaysalso close to insadong, just across the street

This neighborhood of streets and alleys are filled with hanoks, traditional-Korean houses, that either serve as personal residences, guesthouses for people to stay in, or shops. I found the Bukchon Cultural Center one of the days and was able to make one of the art projects they had with a third-generation artisan. She was so skilled and quick that I was thankful for her. The urban explorer loved this, going down alleys to dead ends, turning around and having to go another way, happening upon a mural here, a cool coffee shop there, a lovely restaurant that served a bibimbap dish that was tasty, and so on...I'd go back to Seoul to explore this area more!

Loved the whole Bukchon area as it had several quirky cafes and shops mixed with traditional handicrafts, traditional houses (Hanok) and was such a mix mash of sights and sounds. There were many dressed up in the hanbok (Korean costume) to take photos also. Do climb (yes the slopes can get pretty steep here) to the vantage points for awesome views of the Seoul tower and mountains.

Bukchon, meaning North Village (north of the Han river) is a collection of traditional hanoks, houses of Koreans in the past. They are wonderfully preserved and people still do stay in them. As it is a residential area, do keep noise to a minimum, and let yourself get transported into the past. Try to find the eight photo spots - do not miss number 6.

The traditional local homes are very unique. Some homes even offer home stays to experience the Korean culture. Nice neighbourhood.If you are there in the evening, do try to catch the view of the sunset with the city buildings as a backdrop. Do observe their rules - be quiet as it is a residential area.

Not only did we enjoy the opportunity to stay in one of the Hanoks (traditional Korean housing complex) in Bukchon Village, we also spent the better part of two days exploring the village. It's great that these houses were preserved, that actual people live in them, and that the surrounding area is filled with vibrant shops, restaurants, locals, visitors and energy. I'd highly recommend visiting Bukchon Village.

There will be a lot of walking but you don't think about it when you admire the traditional Korean houses. There is a tourist info where you can get a free map with suggested routes. There are also small shops, cafes and restaurants if you feel like a taking a break or grabbing a coffee or smoothie to go.

Buckchon is a traditional Korean village made up of clusters of "hanoks" or traditional Korean homes. Stroll along the alleys and feel like you are back in time ( more than 500 years ago). The architecture- the old roofs, doors, and windows, and the beautiful courtyards are unique to this village.

review_title: Interesting but nothing much to do
review_body: I liked taking photos but that's about it. Maybe I just wasn't able to explore it properly? We followed the arrows though. Go here before or after Samcheongdong! If you're coming from Samcheongdong, look for the stairs going up to Bukchon.

review_title: Seoul's version of America's Colonial Williamsburg
review_body: I have lived in Asia for more than a decade and have traveled all over the region. To find such a well-preserved, clean, neat, tidy and interesting reconstructed ancient village is a delight. People do actually live in this village (lucky them!) so being quiet and respectful is a must. My local friend brought me here and we had many photo ops wandering the little streets and ducking into shops. I wish I had more time to experience this little gem.The shops sell items we foreigners really want, which is also a wonderful surprise. I was able to clean up in the souvenir department just in this one area. Coffee shops and trinkets galore. Enjoy!
Beautiful houses and quaint streets with great views of Seoul. Quite steep streets so can be tiring in a hot day . In the streets below there are high level shops and galleries, very affluent area.

This ancient city is a must do in seoul, it still has the essence of the ancient town with a touch of modern, here you will find a lot of wooden houses mix with concrete, along the town you will get free wifi in some places.They have several places where you can rent the typical dress of Korea to take pictures for 10000 won.Try to visit the observatory at the tea museum.
people actually lives here and it gets quite annoying when there are a lot of people. a great place to take pictures

Well worth an early start. We arrived at 10am on a Monday and it was already swarming with other tourists. Their noise paired with sea of selfie sticks and photo shoots impacted greatly on what would otherwise be a sceinic and pleasant stroll.

You walk up the hilly streets among the hanoks. Then you turn around and see the view of the modern city in between the traditional hanok walls. On the way down you get a glimpse of Gyeongbokgung Palace. This is why you travel 5000+ miles to Seoul.

Very interesting and unique styling houses. There are shops and restaurants close by. Main attractions are the houses and I can't stop but feel sorry for the residents. There's a guide there explaining to his tour that they need to respect the residents privacy by keeping their voice down during visit. Interesting that he said that when he was the loudest one there!
I enjoyed shopping in this trendy district. The food and handmade shops are excellent. There are a lot of good finds and plenty of places to explore!
I had an outdoor Korean BBQ dinner here and it was so cool, yummy too, just steps from this advertisement photo

review_title: Lovely but not a lot to do
review_body: As two travelers in our mid-thirties, we only found this engaging for about 30 minutes. The craft making is great, but primarily intended for families. Beautiful architecture and homes, but that's about it.

review_title: Worth visiting for a walk in a more quiet part of Seul
review_body: My fiancée and I spent about an hour or so walking through the streets in the Bukchon area. There are lots of old / traditional Korean houses there and next to no car traffic (only residents driving to and from their homes I suspect).Unless you are here early in the morning there will however be lots and lots of other tourists in the area - so many that I sort of feel bad for the people who live here. You will find signs everywhere reading "Please be quiet" or "Please don't stand on the stairs".You'll also find some galleries selling art (figurines, paintings) and shops selling perfume, soaps, candles etc. in this area.There are a couple of nice palaces in walking distance from this old town as well, hence visiting this area is well worth the trip.

Quiet and charming, this is such a beautiful cultural village with wonderful clean streets and nice shops along the way. I definitely recommend here as to myeongdong and since it is opposite of Anguk and Invading and smack in between the two top palace in Seoul, this makes a wonderful stop

review_title: Best place to see Seoul's traditional side
review_body: I loved the old style houses and numerous people wearing Hanbok. If visiting in summer, try to come in the evening instead of during the day as it is too hot.

People see the modern South Korea from various KDramas. Thus, they tend to know more of the present South Korea. This place actually enable people to have a glimpse of the past and get a grasp on how much had change since then. This is a good walking experience.Tip: not for those who have difficulty in climbing various roads or places.

The village is a pretty sight. It's accessible from the subway/metro Line 3 station Anguk. You only need around 30 minutes to go around the village. And one has to observe silence and respect the neighbourhood (it is a private village). There's a nice cafe, Dooroo, by the entrance to the village. And, there is a nice little souvenir shop along the road to the station (see photo).July by the way, is monsoon season in Korea so be prepared for rain.
A good place for those who like the korean traditional houses. Just prepare your self for long walking with road hill elevated. This place is a picturesque.

Beautiful architecture and great winding streets. I visited Bukchon on a Saturday afternoon in April and it was very busy, but it was beautiful. There are a lot of hills to walk so wear comfortable shoes. This is a great location to see the traditional korean houses.

The village is at a convenient location in the city which makes transportation quite easy. Since Korea's taxis are cheap, we decided to take it to Bukchon Village.At the village, there's some souvenir shops and small cafes for you to sit and relax. There are also some sites where you can walk into the traditional homes but with a small fee. The walk around the village for tourists is not that long. In fact, I would estimate about a 15 -20 minute walk in total. We came during the evening which was a bit crowded but it was tolerable. The views from uphill of the village is great. There were many tourists taking the views as well which shows the image of all the traditional homes.

The village located in the center of Seoul is home to hundreds of traditional houses (hanoks) that date back to the Joseon Dynasty. Many of these hanoks operate as cultural centers, guesthouses & tea houses, providing visitors an opportunity to experience, learn & immerse in Korean traditional culture. It is very easy going and one stroll through the streets and admire the scenery.

review_title: Must-visit place when you're in Seoul
review_body: I love the place, the place is a declared UNESCO World Heritage and so is a must-visit place in Seoul. Definitely a very nice experience. Make sure to grab a copy of the map for you not to miss the 8 photo points. There are markings to follow and you won't get lost. Make sure you don't have heavy bags as you will surely be engaging yourself to a long walk around the neighborhood. There are a lot of tea shops and small boutiques that are worth visiting.

Love the stroll recommended online (you can easily find plenty of info on bukchon village trail). I took about half a day to visit all 8 photo points on map. Don't worry about being lost - there are roving guides at various spots to assist. Do spend some time to soak in the atmosphere. Bring along water, a brolly and hat as summer can be scorching. Stop at various cafes and shops to rest and relax. This place is a must visit for first-timers to Seoul!

review_title: Bukchon is a must-do for art and architecture lovers
review_body: Bukchon is my favorite neighborhood. It's my favorite because of the preservation of historic homes and building styles typical throughout Seoul before the redevelopment. In one particular area, there are many of these homes that are living artist studios where you can visit (often for a $1 cost), and for an additional cost you can make art or a craft with them. We have done a few of these, and have done with just adults and with kids, and everyone not only had a great time, but also made a functional piece of art for use or display. Our party made painted necklaces for $10, painted hair decoration for $10, did a woodblock print ($3), and learned how to tie buttons from cord (free). If you have time, we highly suggest a visit to a studio or art center, there are mostly just drop in, so you can find one that interests you.Another popular stop is a teahouse. There are many, and most walking tours pass by at least one. Teahouses usually involve a cup of tea and a sweet, but cost more than many travelers think it should, but the experience is worth it for many. It is easy to enjoy a walking tour through the neighborhood, there are tours outlined in many different guidebooks or websites. We started at one corner down on the street that goes the palaces, and walked up and through the neighborhood, and then back down to the other side, and ended by the big palace and walking past the folk museum. Just make sure your walking tour gets you "up" enough where you can wander through the neighborhoods of hanok, the traditional homes. A picture of the roof lines is worth the visit.

Bukchon is situated on a sloping hill, like much of Seoul. So wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk work those calves! Beautiful houses, the only thing is its a little weird because people live there and I felt awkward taking pictures of their houses.
Good to have a quick stroll through but the Namsangol Hanok Village was far more enjoyable to visit in my opinion.

I went with friends in hanbok and it made for a wonderful photo opportunity! It was as if we had stepped back in time for a bit. Not the easiest place to find, because everywhere we turned said 'bukchon-gil' but after asking some locals we found our way to the main street that you always see in photos. Definitely worth a trip to if in seoul.

Can't believe I have missed this on previous trips to Seoul. Definitely very nice to walk around the village where nobles used to stay. Many cafes and small shops selling fashionable items as well! We enjoyed a great afternoon here. If too warm, would suggest to skip as a lot of walking and up hills.
What a sensational place to visit best in Seoul. Old historical area of seoul. Not far from metro station. 6 stops Seoul station line 3. Fine local food in area.

review_title: Nice and quiet street with good historical features
review_body: When u have done too much shopping, it would be nice to walk around here. Quiet Street and I am having some traditional Korean tea here.

review_title: A must see in Seoul and....
review_body: you can also see Insadong since it is a short 5-10 minute walk from there. Also, it is best to come by subway.
This is a nice part of the city, where you can see some original Japanese houses. Don't visit on a sunny day because it can be very hot in the small streets. Shops are closed on sunday!

Give yourself a day to enjoy the many art galleries, shops, great eating and beautiful old village of Bukchon. The architecture is a stunning mix of old and new. A beautiful heritage area worth the protection it has been afforded. Heaps of tourists there so don't be surprised by the request from residents to not step in their doorsteps and for silence when you're looking around.

review_title: lovely way to spend a few hours strolling around...
review_body: we really enjoyed spending a few hours strolling around the streets of Bukchon, admiring the old houses and visiting the shops and galleries in the area. There are excellent free english maps available from stands near the train station, which highlight the sights in the area. definitely a must do on a trip to seoul.

Bukchon is the area of transitional Korean houses. There is not much going on but certainly worth visiting just because you are in Korea. Some houses charges entrance fees for touring the house and asking questions. Some offer traditional crafts for a fee between 10,000-20,000 won. Is fun to try some of the crafts. They might look easy but you will be surprised it can be so tedious! My niece dropped her iPhone and the screen cracked. So be careful with your phones when you are there because there so many big and small stones everywhere on the floor. Whichever angle at which you dropped your phone, chances are the screen will crack.

This is an old part of Korea with the buildings preserved so it looks very nice. Yet it seems to be a tiny street and there is very little things which are uniform. hence it seems part of the charm as it is not entirely fake. A lot of tea houses etc and somewhat manicured look. A lot of museums around the area as well.

review_title: A stroll back to old times
review_body: It was like walking back in history. Get here early in the morning before everyone else and take the recommended trail starting from the main street. Enjoy the peace and tranquillity as you venture into the small alleys. You wonder what lies behind the walls of these houses and what was life like in the good old days. Some of these houses have been turned into galleries but will only open later when the crowds arrive. Quiet signs are everywhere and you can understand why as this is truly a popular spot.

review_title: Take a walking tour through Old Korea!
review_body: Bukchon is the historically preserved neighborhood of Seoul. Most of the true old style houses are located within a quite residential neighborhood. Nice to grab a map and stroll around. There are some nice photo ops, although most of the actual houses are not open to the public. I found some streets to be quite lovely and peaceful; some others I hit right as tour buses were unloading and that was not so great. They have people stationed on some of the corners asking tourists to be quiet, since it is a residential neighborhood, but the tour groups I was near ignored that and were very loud and rude. So, try to time it to arrive early before those buses. Some of the surrounding streets have some nice cafes and coffee shops. You can also find a bunch of places offering workshops in various crafts like woodworking, kite making, and knot tying. If I had an extra day I would have made time to do one of those. Plan on doing a lot of walking, including up and down a lot of hills.

real traditional houses . get a map from the street tourist info. We went early before the tour group arrived. lots of walking. These are private residences and some tourists are inconsiderate and spoke loudly. There is one particular traditional house that is open to public for a fee. Worth the visit to see inside it. Lovely garden and rooms. Recommend that U visit this house.

We were on a quest to find an example of an old Korean village and found Bukchon Hanok Village. The architecture was a great example of the old style buildings or "hanok" which means traditional buildings. The site is hilly and the alleys are narrow. Worth the trip and walks.

Residential area in the style of old Korea, worth a visit to see the architecture, these are private residences so bare that in mind. Don't go too early or all the shops will be closed. Many tourists come in by bus and can make it crowded, easy to get to by metro, and then visit the nearby markets.
Definitely sign up for the free two hour walking tour and the. Stay after to enjoy lunch and a bit of shopping.
not easy to find, we had a long walk before we found it. its basically a row of unique korean houses (its a residential area) which is only found in korea. along the way, there are shops / eateries.
went to visit since it's near to Gyeongbokgung... it was a nice walk seeing rows of Hanok.. but do be prepared for lots of tourists.

review_title: Warm hearts on a cold rainy day
review_body: It was a mild rainy day when we visited Bukchon Hanok Village, but it did not dampen the charm of the place. We started off with a late lunch as soon as we arrived, coming from a leisurely walk from Gyeongbokgung Palace. You could pair your sightseeing going to the Palace first, look around, watch the changing of guards, then proceed to Bukchon. Everything in Seoul is accesible by train or bus, anyway. But if you can take the 15-minute leisure walk to Bukchon, do so by all means. Good exercise and it helps increase your feel of the area. Then explore the place with the quaint houses and unique shops, eating really good ice cream and streetfood along the way, and just enjoying the quiet and lovely scenes around the village. We went up and down the streets, looking for interesting shops. I didn't realize that this could be an interesting activity for my young adult children. We even entered an art gallery with amazing paintings! The locals were very hospitable and though we were foreigners, we were made to feel so welcome! It truly warmed our hearts especially on a cold rainy day.
Seoul as it once was. This is a touristic place but still worth the effort of visiting. Book a guide to get an insight into the lives of the people who still live here.
There are a lot of Korean traditional house in that village. It is a mountain view and many tourist visit at place.

Quite a walk from the train station, but there are a lot of stores to see along the way, so you won't find it too tedious. Street is also lined up with coffee shops so you can take a break somewhere.This is a great place to have a look at traditional Korean architecture, perfect spot for a couple of selfies and photos. Don't go here on a rainy day.

Perfect place to see old Seoul architecture. If you want you can even rent a traditional costume and walk around the village. It is fun, though don't forget to keep quiet since it is a residential area.
Great place to have a look at Korean architecture and boutique shops and cafes. A bit touristy but that's given cause it is a beautiful and well preserved neighbourhood.

In Seoul, a city dotted with high-rise apartments, its nice to see these old Hanok houses in the Bukchon Village. Its pleasant strolling through the narrow lanes between houses. There are many arts and crafts experience workshops (at a fee) in the area plus many cute shops while walking towards the village from direction of Anguk Station exit 6. The up and down hilly feel of the village gives you a nice view of the city and the N-Seoul Tower. There is a house in the area (cant recall exact name/street) still occupied by locals, where you can go up to the terrace for a fee (I think it was KRW 2,000/pp) and order a free item from the beverage/snacks menu while enjoying nice views of the area and giving your feet a rest as well!

If you are just visiting Seoul and you are feeling overwhelmed by all the high rises and developed areas, this is a good look into the past. This is really a neighborhood and so please be respectful as you climb up and down the hills. You will see the traditional Hanoak style houses. The roofs are amazing and you can just imagine what it is like having a courtyard in the middle of your home. Come here to explore Korea's deep history and have some quiet time.

review_title: Interesting place to visit for free
review_body: For backpackers or any travellers who visit Seoul, I very recommended this place. If you love to take a walk by foot there are many to explore in this area. Take subway and stop in Anguk Station, at first you can cross or shopping for souvenirs in Insadong the just walk by foot about 5-10 minutes to Bukchon if you go directly but I bet you will stop couple of times because on your way to Bukchon you will see some interesting art galleries, museums, or old churces. From top of Bukchon, you can see the city view. You can take a rest and have some coffee or liquor and enjoy the fresh air. You can request free tour (check in internet, many volunteers offer free guide) or like me, I just like to explore by myself.

review_title: Pleasant walk but a bit touristy
review_body: Bukchon is touristy but it is still worth walking around and checking out this artsy area just to relax and see some historical homes. Come early in the morning to avoid the crowds and then you can check out the nearby palaces. Restaurants are expensive here but there is a good variety if you are hungry.

the strees of Bukchon give you glimspe of real Korean Culture. get a trail map from any of the shops in the street and walk through the trail. You can see the traditional Korean houses and on the way visit multiple Korean arts and painting centers. You can also take Korean painting lessons for 45 minutes. We were lucky that one of the residents was kind enough to welcome us to their house and show us around. The lay out of Korean Houses are very different and interesting.
Little 'fashionable' shops and where the trendy young people of seoul like to flock, but expensive by local standards. It has a nice feel and interesting little boutiques and cafes
Enjoyed walking around and seeing great history! There are a million photo opportunities and a shop and restaurant that caters to anyone.

review_title: Jeonju Hanok village away more beautiful
review_body: The sightseeing area is not very big. If you don't have time to visit Jeonju,better to just go at Namsan Hanok Village rather than Bukchon. For you who want to get more traditional feel of hanok village Jeonju is definetly must visit place.

review_title: Urban Village in a Gritty City
review_body: Let's all face it. Seoul is a gritty city not the least of which is the continuous smog and particulates (not to mention the seasonal flows of yellow dust from the Gobi) - albeit air quality is still better than highly populated Chinese cities. Once you've recovered from a long evening of neon lights and clubs, there must be something else. Yes, you got it; it's Bukchon. Only last year did I discover, via an offer for a weekend sightseeing afternoon from a native Seoulite, this quaint urban village after many years of business travel to Seoul. I think that most hotels will quickly send you to Insadong, which is fine. But it is largely craft shops on a single street without the diversity provided by Bukchon. Here you will find craft and designer shops sandwiched in among restaurants and coffee shops. The terrain is interesting too in that the roads wind and climb little hillocks. There are trees lining streets and Samcheong park is nearby for a stroll or a 1/2 day hike around the old Seoul city wall. Shared walled houses and B&Bs and curved roofs covered in tiles are a unique site in a city of largely concrete and glass. Take my advice and go there.

I went here in the evening, but I wish I'd arrived even an hour earlier, to see more of the nearby shops open. It's a lovely section, but quiet--this is not the place to bring kids to roam the streets. Duck into any one of the tea or coffee houses nearby and enjoy great people watching as well. Well worth a detour in your itinerary to wander through.
An uphill walk to get to the village. Kinda disappointed since there were no hanok rentals nearby but overall the place is a must see

If you are going to the palaces, it is a good detour to walk around the neighbourhood to see the traditional houses and take some pictures. However, it may not be worth the extra effort just to make a special trip to visit.
It's a residential area so please keep quiet whilst visiting! Go grab a map at the tourist information desk and follow the route, went during dawn and got to see sunset among the way. Stunning!

review_title: Interesting, beautiful, and a good cardio workout!
review_body: I would suggest for anyone to get a tour (one of those free walking tours), and let them bring you around the village. I had an awesome 2 hours walking around, taking pictures, listening to the history and taking in the beautiful surrounding. At the end of the tour, you will most definitely have a workout... as they have quite steep hills on certain streets, and the village in general is on a hilly area.
take a walk in bukchon a chill and relax stroll a fantastic walk and relax walk around the traditonal house in seoul after the walk grab a cuppa at cafe surrounding it
Strolled this quaint, chic historic neighborhood. Adored the shops and restaurants nestled in the historic buildings. A cool, hip vibe we enjoyed!

review_title: Can still see traditional village in bustling city
review_body: This is a must go place when visiting Seoul. At least you will get a chance to see beautiful old buidlings which are still very well maintained. Some of these buildings were converted to museum which open to tourist. If going there during summer, can be very sunny, do bring along sunglasses and umbrella. Need some uphill walking(proper road),make sure you put on comfortable shoes.

review_title: semi-authentic, picturesque, but still too artificial
review_body: a nice look into the living standards in Seoul 500 years ago, however the renovation is demonstrated and does not contribute to the authentic spirit of this place. good preserved, sometimes overcowded

Alike the Kyoto of Japan, this is a residential area in the part of Seoul. There are many shops allowing tourists to try their traditional outfit.. The streets are also great for photography or just experience the ancient feel of Seoul.

review_title: quaint place although a bit overrun with big tour groups
review_body: After the Gyeongbokgung Palace you might as well visit Bukchon since it is just around the corner from it's northern gate exit. It's a very quaint place with keep quiet signs everywhere that unfortunately people generally ignore!

I had a good walk climbing minor slope of Bukchon Village. I loved to see old buildings that have kept in a very good conditions. There are many shops and restaurants along the street. It is amazing to know there are real people who still live in the area.

This area, although a tourist attraction is not for everyone. If you don't like climbing steep roads and taking in the atmosphere then this is not for you. Essentially this is a long walk around reconstructed buildings with homestays, shops and various activities you can participate in. Personally I think it's a nice walk and I enjoy the atmosphere. I'm not sure why the bad reviews say it's hard to find. I had no problems finding the place and there are even information helpers in red clothing if you need assistance. Remember if you go on Monday, all the activity shops are closed as well as some of the regular shops too.

review_title: How the Koreans in the past lived
review_body: Interesting place to see how Seoul people lived in the past. There are little cafes which have set up around the area which makes for interesting teas and dinner with friends
Nothing special to see, really. It was also very crowded with tour groups when we visited on a Monday.

Had visited this area before. A residential area with local people living here. Galleries, cafes, and local restaurants fill this area . Popular with tourists and high school students. Relatively quiet during weekdays compared to my last visit ( which was on the weekend). Pleasant stroll.

review_title: Hard to find the photo taking spot!
review_body: Pretty view but hard to spot. Stamina must be good enough to crawl up the steep slope. Look for information crew member before you moved on, signage was not visible showed on the walls. There is around 8 photo taking point. The famous E photo taking point is point 5 & 6. Try to go during weekdays and avoid public holiday. U won't be able to shoot nice scenery with many heads on. Haha! Sufficient sunblock is necessary. I had burnt even walking around at 11am.

We headed straight to the information centre for a map and asked for a recommended route. Lots of walking, lots of tourist, lots to see and photograph. The quaint shops along the way added to our enjoyment.

review_title: A pleasant walk in history, beautiful old houses.
review_body: This place is amazing! So glad I decided to come here. After coming out from the subway, I go straight to the tourist center to get a map of this area. There was a suggested route which lead us to some buildings/ houses with history. The route was beautiful and is like in the old movie. Sometimes there will be people wearing hanbook passing by and made this feeling of unreal stronger. Along the way we get to visit nice shops, craft shops and nice cafe. I bumped into a cultural shop where after paying 10000 won, I get to wear hanbook for one hour. Such an amazing experience! The end of the route brought us to ChangDeGung. Really enjoy the whole experience and would come back here again.

review_title: Neighborhood with traditional Hanok style homes.
review_body: Interesting stroll through this beautiful neighborhood of traditional Hanok Village. (Remember to be mindful of people living here and not be to loud.)There are information stops if you need directions or helpful tips, map of the area. English speaker available to assist.)

Walk around Bukchon is a fun escape from the modern landscape of downtown Seoul.Make sure to pick up a map from the tourist center. Start the walk towards the east so you wrap up the walk on the west side where there are shops and cafe on the big Main street. Head over to Insadong right afterwards!
I just walked from my hotel to that place. It's lovely to walk around and see how people live ans shop in Bukchon. It wasn't sunny when I was there but it was really great!
I loved this place because it's very artistic and you could take a lot of pictures, you will also fall in love with those old buildings.

This is my second visit to Bukchon. The ancient houses still holds much charm to me. This time round we walked along the slope and found it to be another way to admire this area. Some areas can get a bit crowded and hard to get a good nice shot. Quite a number of people dressed in traditional hanbok came to have photos taken. Nice place to spend an hour or two for a slow walk and photo taking.

review_title: Nice place to see their traditional house
review_body: Good to just take a slow walk around this area. Taking photos and looking around.After here, you can go to Samcheong dong for a meal or hang out at their many cafes.

A lovely, quiet residential area that is nonetheless popular with many many tourists. Try to avoid weekends if you want an unobstructed view of Seoul tower from the top of the hill. It is really worth meandering around the streets between Bukchon and the palace as there are lots of funky little shops.
Some nice old wooden houses, but too touristy for me. All houses where fenced so not much to see for me. I would skip this if you have just one day.

Traditional houses in Bukchon village is very well maintained, maybe you can feel like you're in one of those Kdrama, lol. However, it is also a regular neighborhood area so we should also bear in mind to not disturb the house owner.One additional thing, I came here on Sunday so i don't know whether it is because of weekend its so packed there or in general bukchon is always crowded
Very interesting area, actually people really live there, some nice cafes and shops, but mostly artsy and panoramic views.

If you're looking to unwind and take your mind off things, then Bukchon would be the place to go. Because it's a residential neighbourhood, it's quiet so you can take long walks down the quiet alleys and enjoy the feel of old Seoul. There are also some neat little museums where you can take workshops like lacquering, tying traditional knots etc. I went to the Donglim Knot Museum and had fun learning how to make a bracelet, but if you're not into crafts, you can still always stop by to buy a hand-made souvenir.

We took the recommendation from Lonely Planet to walk around the whole Bukchon area. It's beautiful! We went there about 10am and the streets are still quiet. We have a lot of opportunities to take photos and take a good look of the shops and restaurants. If you are fit enough you should go all the way up to the look out. It isn't that high but it's interesting to look over some traditional homes. I m sure it looks amazing during autumn.

traditional village and absorbed the modern life too. It was interesting walking and seeing locals. Passed plenty of shop place and few good restaurant. Just admire the local staff creativity totally worth visit

review_title: very good for take picture especially
review_body: the house is beautiful, location really good, the environment is so comfortable, clean .I hope tourist more polite and not make too loud voice

review_title: Traditional charms still remain here even after attacks of franchises...
review_body: I used to live here until last year and I chose this area because its charm of traditional feeling and small cute stores around the town. Well, the first demolition happened a decade ago in terms of construction, then the second demolition in its personality is on the way. I would say even for that short 3 years of my staying there, I've witnessed more than 50% of my favorite stores including small handmade shops, real cafés, local restaurants had been replaced by worldwide or local super power franchises. This was really frustrating and became a reason to leave the town... I still give 4 stars though because there are yet some survivors struggling against the push of landlords and also there are beautiful narrow hidden alleys all around the corners. Just avoid the main road and super chains if possible if you want the real town coming slowly back to us.

Very nice area, quaint and clean. A must to see, because it's the old area of Seoul. the houses are very well kept. Many shops around it. Lots of walking and uphill, bring comfortable walking shoes. We found a tea house with an amazing view inside Bukchon, but cannot remember the name of it.

Good opportunity to see authentic Korean architecture still in use. Best reason to visit the place is the cheap food from numerous stands. Also the only place where I found the famous rice wine (and paid only 1,500₩ for a large cup!)

review_title: Where the old meets the new
review_body: It's really great to have this place and be able to see old-fashioned korean houses in the center of a modern city as Seoul. You will have to walk a bit but it is worthy, I got a lot of excelent pictures and fell in love with korean culture.

A nice place to visit and see the traditional Korean buildings but the narrow streets gives "crowdy" feeling. When I visited there, I found that many tourists rented the traditional Korean dress, a HANBOK, and travelled around the place wearing it and took pictures. You may try to taste but I didn't as I wanted to spent more time enjoying the nature environment.

But of a nightmare to find on foot but worth a visit on a sunny day for great views! About a ten minute walk from Anguk station, lots of restaurants to eat in albeit EVERYTHING is in Korean with little English translation. This is a residential area so visitors need to be respectful of locals who are living in the Hanoks. A good way to spend an afternoon or evening. We found a vantage point and watched the sunset, can't beat that!

review_title: Getting the feel of a Korean village
review_body: This place is really well known for both locals and tourists. It is best to put a Hanbok on (which can be rented at least for an hour) and take a picture here for an added feel.

Interesting place where we get to see well preserved traditional korean houses. Other than these, the nearby streets offered quaint charming shops selling clothes, accessories, arty stuff n food. Nice place to spend half a day.

We walked our way from the blue house exit of the Gyeongbukgong Palace to Bukchon.I found the place interesting. There were lots of shops, restaurants and people too. We were looking for the traditional houses and did not mind the what looked novel. It took us a while to find the traditional houses. We traversed the road leading up a hill and found concrete stairs leading down only to find out that we're back to where we came from. We climbed up again and took our chance at a corner leading to the observatory until we came to a narrow street that was lined with the traditional houses and there were several streets like this. We just followed the path where our eyes took us and reached another street that led us to Insadong.Over all you need the energy to do the walking that we did, but exploration was what we were there for. It was hard for us to take the bus because the routes were not written in English. It was quite exhausting but worth it.

review_title: Nice area to have a walk in the afternoon
review_body: Lots of traditional houses as well as nice contemporary architecture around the area. It definitely deserves a visit.
Lovely area with original old houses and streets- how Seoul would have looked in the past such a contrast to the high rise of today . Lovely area to walk around and nice coffee shops and galleries.
This had more of a historical feel to it than the rest of Seoul. It's nice to walk around but no need to spend more than a couple of hours there.

bylanes of the old crisscross with the touristy and this up and down long walk deserves both aimless strolling and a useful local walking tour to catch what you may have missed in terms of vantage points and historical value.
The houses is almost old but still beautiful and so charming. Easy to go there and if you been there,please be quiet because all that houses still have people to live.

review_title: Seoul can call itself proud to have a quarter like this kept up and not levelled
review_body: This is how many years back Seoul must have looked. Growth and prosperity asked for its price and whole quarters got levelled. There is a nice round trip by foot with lots of cafe stops and interesting little handicraft places. In itself, it looks magically removed from daily pulse of Seoul...

The Hanok houses are all very well preserved, pleasant walk with really steep slopes at some parts. I feel really bad for the people living there, even though there were lots of signs reminding people to keep their volume down, some groups are still very noisy. Please be considerate!

This is a place you could not miss if visiting Seoul. This is my second trip and we still enjoyed the nice walks and the views when you walked around it. After the hilltop views, you can walk down with all the coffeeand a bit of shopping areas around. It's a very nice place to visit and choose the time around noon to avoid those tours as they mostly visit in the morning. Worth going and can do lunch around that area as well.

I love historical building there, been there three times already. When you feel tired due to long walk, you can go to coffee shops as a lots are there. A quiet and good place for visiting in city town.

As part of the incentives as Korean Air transit passengers, we signed up a 5 hours day trip, provided free by the Incheon Airport. This is one of the highlight we went, and all I could say was it was indeed a very nice place to walk about, even we just have 1 hour to enjoy it (2 hours return bus trip from and to airport, plus another 2 hour visit to other destination) . It is a bit steep in some part of the trail, but overall it granted the view of Seoul and the historic houses. The nearby has many cafe and shopping alley, and though the alleyways were small, they limit access of big vehicles and so it was relatively safe at the same time.

review_title: A hike and confusing starting point
review_body: Be prepared to walk, up some steep slopes and stairs. Since it's a residential area, unless you visit the tea house for example, you will not get a view of the quarters. The plus is seeing ladies wearing hanbok doing the tour, which is part of Korea tourism promotion.

nice architecture of the houses - if you stay in a city, this place might be worth visiting as it's something you'll never see in cities. surrounded by quaint shops nearby. only downside was that it's gets a little crowded as it's a tourist spot and crowd can get rowdy.

This area is walkable from Isadong. You may wish to include this into the itinerary if dropping by Isadong. For direction wise, you may seek assistance from the tourist office. It is about 20-30 mins of walking. Once you reached the Neighbourhood, you see a lot of nice old heritage houses and many being still occupied. There are also some nice cafes hidden in the alley as you walk deeper down. A nice place to explore and have a cup of coffee in the nice cafes over there.
I think it is a little bit far away from Metro, I suggest you can take taxi to get here. It is a residential area, so please keep quiet.
those traditional houses are really unique. need to be quiet when you're there, as there are families living in it.nice to just take a walk there.

review_title: A good stroll frozen in time
review_body: If you are looking for a no hassle Korean culture experience, Bukchon is a good place to start. Here, you can soak in the views of Korean living frozen in time. Walk the streets and enter permitted quarters that shows the interior of the hanok homes.

review_title: Similar to the "French Quarter" of New Orleans and equally charming!
review_body: We came here after visiting the Changdokgung Palace nearby.A very good Thai Restaurant is located in a basement on "Bukchon-Ro", about 1/2 way down the street. It is called "In The Mood For Love" Thai Restaurant. We had a wonderful meal there. We also got to see an original Hanok on that street, it has been turned into a museum of sorts.
Nice old buildings. Many of them now functioning as guesthouses, galleries, cafés etc. Quaint charm.
It's a great place to go for a stroll, but just be weary that there are plenty of hills in the area to get to a nice view point

Very nice to see the different houses and styles and craftsmanship. Seems like a very expensive neighborhood nowadays. Lots of embassies in the neighborhood. Walking distance from the great palace . Nice places to have coffee and/or lunch.

review_title: Thanks for preserving this piece of Korean history!
review_body: Delightful walking up and down Bukchon. Should have joined a tour that includes going inside one of those homes, if that is even available.

review_title: Worthwhile activity subject to your expectations
review_body: Personally, I went to Bukchon for the hanok style houses. I found them less impressive than the glossy photos in the Bukchon brochure, let alone they are hard to find! Having said that the quarter is very charming and I loved the little restaurants that are tucked away in all those little alleys. Best to go there late afternoon so you can take a few pictures and then have proper Korean dinner.

This area has some beautiful traditional homes. The architecture of the homes, walls and streets is well maintained. We were able to step inside one of the homes to see the inner courtyard and rooms. The hike to the top of the hill is worth it as you get some incredible views of the downtown area. The pictures are beautiful with the well-kept traditional homes and the big city skyline in the background. It is important to be mindful of the fact that people still live here and to be respectful of their privacy and space.

If it is hot, there is not a lot of places for shade. There are a lot of places to eat and souvenir shops which is convenient. However the Chinese tour groups are very noisy and distracting. It's a nice area to walk around but try not to go in the middle of the day when it's hot.
It is a village of hanok. Cause it is on the hill,you can see seoul sightseeing view. Nice place. But there are lots of people

Great, ancient looking building/ houses! However many Chinese tour groups (the people are so embarrassing- talking super loud!!) no wonder there are so many signs written in Chinese to tell them keep the voice down!!

This is a lovely area to visit right after the palace as it is close by and you can walk then on to Insadong. There were little streets with many tourists, but overall quieter than other tourist areas. The houses were nice to explore from outside but would have rather had a guide or more info as background rather than just walk around.

We arrived in the late afternoon with our tour guide and the place is crowded. Even though there are signage to keep our voices low but the tourists around were too excited and noisy. We felt bad for the people whom really stay here. Luckier our toddler were asleep and we had a quick snap of photos. Don't miss the past president house and Yido cafe. Is a quiet place for a good coffee and you may be tempted to buy some korea ceramics at Yido cafe.

review_title: Lovely walk along charming traditional homes.
review_body: Possibly one of the nicest areas of Seoul. The walk offered lovely and charming cafes, small boutique shops and galleries. Do remember to check out murals and a view of rooftops.
the houses were so beautiful and well maintained. nice stroll around the neighborhood but some roads may get to steep.

This is the place where all the old traditional houses are located. We stayed in one for 2 nights and enjoyed the experience very much. Most of the houses are very well maintained and great looking. The place can get quite crowded in the late mornings and afternoons with tourists. Best to come early morning.

review_title: Average for me as all those nicely deco house need to pay in order to have a look inside!
review_body: I felt that this place is over-rated for couple like me. We like to see cultural things but the price to pay for visiting their home is like a little bit over.
Nice peaceful village.A must if visiting seoul to see the experience the traditional culture of Korea.

It was pretty easy to get there by train. The village was ok at best. We didn't get a chance to go into any of those tourist handicraft places and just walked around to see the different houses. Can certainly give it a miss if you are rushed for time.

review_title: Just houses but not that old looking
review_body: I went here for the old traditional house but the place did not really match my expectation.Yes, there are houses, but it does look that old. It is a hilly walk up so may be i havent walk far enough to see the good thing.

Great for photo-taking as this is one of the last few original villages in Korea! There's a free museum to show you how it looks like inside and a few locally-run stores along the path. Other than that, nothing much else to do! Do keep your voices down as people still do live in the houses. Crowed with lots of people squeezed onto a small upslope path.

We rented hanboks and went there to take pictures. Was expecting a big village but I think it was just a small area. May be we didn't get to explore the entire place. It's still worth checking out, and it's right next to the Gyeongbokgung Palace.

review_title: Great photos but you'll be done within an hour
review_body: Bukchon is extremely picturesque and makes for a great backdrop in your holiday photos. This is especially true if you've rented a hanbok for a day!That said, you'll probably be done within an hour since most houses in the area look fairly similar. A possible itinerary goes as such: Gyeongbokgung Palace - Bukchon - Changdeokgung Palace. Get ready for lots of walking though!

This neighborhood has the last of the original houses of Korea. I found it fascinating as much of Seoul has high-rises and modern buildings. It's residential mixed with retail. Lovely homes provide insight into the history of Korea. Don't miss the smaller family-run shops and restaurants intertwined with the homes.
probably due to too many tourist at the scenic area, can't really get nice photo, and is a bit tiring to walk uphill also

review_title: immerse in the traditional Hanok village culture and enjoy the modern bric-a brac
review_body: Bukchon literally means North Village, traditional architecture of Hanok village where some Seoulites still live or conduct their business/cafe/restaurant.A very pleasant quaint eye opener into the past, there is that magic that is missing in the modern concrete jungles in most big metropolitan cities.Very easy to get to with the metro system, be prepared to spend a few hours even if you do not like "shopping".Stop for a meal in the old Hanok shop or coffee in a modern setting, admire some of the local creative and artistic wares.The prime minister's residence is just nearby, you can't miss it where so many friendly and polite police in uniforms standing around, I feel safer there, I did not see any machine guns!

review_title: Interesting village that everyone should pay a visit !
review_body: Interesting place with mixture of Modern and traditional chic ! You are allow to take photos everywhere but please do not disturb the locals as the old houses are still occupied by the locals.

Cute little preserved 'village'. Most houses have been converted into little boutiques and cafes. Has a very hipster vibe though. Its right next to Gyeongbukgung Palace. So club it with the trip there. Schedule it in the afternoon or evening so you can either grab lunch at the little dimsum bar with the longest queue or for a little cafe time.

review_title: Quaint precinct with interesting food places and shops
review_body: Definitely a must-visit! Been to Seoul twice in 2016, and went to Bukchon area four times - just beautiful. We had a walking tour the first time, and went back to dine and walk around more. A place suitable for families, the romantic and just friends hanging out.

We really enjoyed walking in the cool springtime air in Bukchon. The little shops were interesting and offered a lot of handmade jewelry and accessories, clothes, nice cafes and we stumbled upon a small flea market with a few unique stalls. Bought a perfume stick 15g for 7000won. We took nice photos with the interesting backdrops of the houses and cafes and even saw many lovely cherry blossoms trees. Enjoy and chill.

This neighborhood is very pleasant. Nice views, old houses, nice coffees and small museums or shops everywhere. Very different from the rest of the city. No longer very authentic though but still a good idea for spending a couple of hours
we enjoyed our casual walk. The surrounding area is fun for eating and shopping as well. Fun afternoon destination.

This quaint street gives you the hipster yet traditional vibes. We went by after Gyeongbokgung, there's this small corner stall that sells chicken skewers. MUST! (Short queue for it as they cook it on the spot) You can get some unique pieces here, totally different feel from myeongdong!

review_title: Takes you back to the culture of Korea
review_body: the area is a bit walking around 10 minutes from Anguk Station. uphill on some parts. it lets you see the way of life / houses of the past. there is also commercial area. you know that you are near the place cause of the many tourist and there are people that are around to ask question about the area. it is a private street so we have to be quiet at all times.

A street of old neighbourhood. You would need to walk about 15 minutes plus to reach there. Basically just an old alleyway that still retain old architecture. If you into architecture of common folk in olden days then this is place you want to go
A very interesting area to visit the houses has an amazing architecture some gift shops are available with good prices.
crowded at some spots but i joined a walking tour and received a thorough explanations on how they lived in the past. walk around the district, it's HUGE.

We really enjoy the up and down hills stroll in and around Bukchon Hanok Village. All the beautiful view points is within walking distances.At the corner of each streets in Bukchon will have a map indicate your 'Location Now' will help tourist to know where to go next. The view was wonderful, and you can get to see young and old wearing the colorful Hanbok beautifully posing for nice photographer. Please be more considerate when you are in this area, the residence dont mind that we tourist admired this ancient village but they are very annoyed with the noiseness some tourist make despite been warn by the tour guide, tour leader and shamefully by the locals there. This area easily took us 2-3 hours for a stop for photographing, visiting the tea house and museum. Best time to visit this area is when the tour group are not around, maybe early morning and after 5pm. This is not a nightlife area, so if you are looking for a peace and quiet accommodation, here! We choose to stay in one of the hanok to experience the lifestyle and have more time to spend in Bukchon. I encounter many friendly locals who kindly show and give you good directions when we loss track.

Pleasurable walk around small alleys and traditional Korean style homes. There is a lot of small shops, restaurants, cafes and places of interest throughout as well as really nice panoramic views of Seoul.Excellent place for a little walk around with some gems scattered about in between.

go early in the morning to miss the tourists. Beautiful buildings, gardens and architecture, wonder enough and you'll get a good view of seoul and find a street full of street food for a snack before moving onto the next location.

I'm not one for shopping so I can't comment on the many boutiques dotted around. However the setting is perfect for strolling around. If you pop into a tourist information office (easy to find) they can provide you with a map with an easy to follow walking route through some of the more beautiful areas. Besides the buildings there are also some good views of the nearby vistas. This is a good place for photos.
The whole village looks really beautiful. I don't know where i can find houses like those anywhere else. I'm so glad i got the chance to visit this place. A must see!!!

review_title: Lots of walking and scenic view
review_body: A lot of walking in Bukon village to enjoy the heritage site. You will enjoy the site if the weather is cool and not hot. However, do prepare a good walking shoe as there are many up hill and down hill route.

When you visit Seoul you must visit Bukchon to experience that part of the history, to see the architecture of the past. Best is to take the subway or bus to Anguk station as start/end of your walk through that neigbourhood. There is suggested route through the area that you can follow through the signs. On your way there are various local restaurants to try their typical local food. You won't regret the visit and there'll be many views to take memorable pictures of Hanok style houses.

Ok don't be mistaken - this is not some ancient village that tourists come and see what life was like in the olden days - people still live here!! And the olden houses are still very well maintained. No wonder it was said that tv dramas would be filmed here now and then. You can also see many locals or tourists dressed in traditional korean costume and taking pictures. If you think you want to skip this for whatever reason - DON'T!! It's a charming place that you have to visit and you would definitely be impressed how the area has been maintained even in this time and age :-)

This is a great place to stroll around and see some traditional Korean architecture. But get here early to avoid the crowds, especially if, like me, you want to take photos of the buildings without hordes of people in them.

review_title: Historical Korean homes. Living architectural sight
review_body: Nice to view historic homes but more a tourist attraction. Not a whole lot to do in the area. Gift shops geared toward tourists. Lots of small shops and cafes too.

Thoroughly enjoyed our tour of bukchon. We spent the morning exploring samcheongdong, which was a good blend of modern buildings housed in refurbished old buildings. The streets were really pretty. In the afternoon, we moved on to do a guided tour of buchok hanok. We saw many quaint and well preserved hanok. Our guide was wonderful and shared many stories with us on how a hanok was built and life in the buchon.

A selection of shops, crafts tea rooms and interesting houses, definitely worth a couple of hours. There are some nice traditional tea and coffee houses - they charge more than most but have much more character and serenity than the 100s of Starbucks that have sprung up in the city
To find this island of tradition in the middle of an exploding Seoul was a nice experieince. The wooden houses that once were all over Korea can still be seen here in this living museum.

review_title: One of my favorite place in Seoul
review_body: One of my favorite place in Seoul, been there many times, this is a lovely place to have a walk (really liked the traditionnal korean houses - hanok), near Insadong and the royal palaces that you can visit in the same day.It can be a bit crowded that is why I recommend you to go there on weekdays and especially in the morning cause it even more enjoyable where there is few people in the area

review_title: experiance some "oldschool" Korean culture and traditions
review_body: This beautiful Hanook village (traditional Korean housing village) is really beautiful. The buildings are well maintained and the activities on offer for tourists are fun to do and see. This area however, is a residential area and so when walking through it you need to be aware of that and remain quiet. It is worth a visit though!

review_title: Beautiful Hanok Houses nested inbetween modern buildings
review_body: The Bukon Hanok Village is located beside SamChongDong and is alittle complicated to find if you are heading there via SamChongDong. My partner and i spent quite a while trying to find that famous down slope photospot of the hanok houses. There are also tea houses located within the village and it is an interesting place to visit after visiting GyeongBokGung and SamChongDong shopping belt.

This was a really cool experience. All they pushes looked beautiful. It was as if you went back in history just strolling through the neighborhood. It's still houses real residences so we tried to be quiet as we walked through the 8 viewing points. But here is a cultural center that where you can experience making Korean crafts for a fee. I would highly encourage looking into this and making reservations. We saw some people wearing hanboks walking around and it turned out to be tourists that rented them for four hours so they could stroll around in those beautiful dresses as they went through the neighborhoods!!! Way beautiful... They indicated that the rental place was near the subway station! It's best to go to the tourist kiosks to inquire :)

review_title: Only if you plan on visiting the hip surrounding area as well
review_body: It is a hanok village with its' peaceloving residents. If you do visit: mind your manners (must say that even the locals were quite noisy while visiting the area). What draws locals to this area is not the hanok village but the trendy surrounding area with its boutique shops, cafes and trendy restaurant.

I found it amazing that in the middle of an ultra modern city, this gem exists. It truly feels like I have stepped on the set of those Korean dramas my father in law watches! Alongside quaint shops and cafes, this is truly a relaxing side of Seoul that I would highly recommend to all.

Visit the place very early to avoid crowd of tourist. Its best also to mind your noise since this is a residential place. Too bad a lot of posters are in their doors already because of noisy visitors but there are houses with camera badge for picture taking.

This is a small residential area full of small, traditional Korean houses. Basically, you follow a stone path up some alleyways past some doors of about 100 small houses. Then, the path ends and you're back on normal Seoul city streets. Not much to see here.
Really nice and Beautiful neighborhood. Typical construction that we could only see in this part of the city. Almost rebuild but still nice to walk and see. Be prepare for some hills...

We went on a free walking tour that is organised by Seoul tourism. Our guide was good. The area is busy with lots of tourist but the Hanoks are beautiful. Some of the streets are really pretty but it's hard to get a good picture. Maybe going at the end of the day might be better. The streets can be steep. Everyone that visits Seoul should visit here. It's not a museum it's a real neighbourhood.

This was a fascinating area to visit; very busy on a sunny Saturday afternoon.There are little streets with pretty little houses.In the surrounding area are a myriad of cafes, sweet shops, street food and the like.On week-ends (and maybe week days), the locals (especially the girls) like to dress up in traditional Korean costumes and have their photos taken. There are hire shops that cater for this (but I gather they don't hire shoes - they were all wearing Nikes and the like!). Apparently, they can get into the various Palaces for free if they are in costume. Most are delighted to have their photos taken by or with foreign tourists - I don't mean cynically, but they want to be noticed - that's the whole point of dressing up. Even children get into the act. And there are plenty in the Bukchon Hanok Village area, making for great photos.I had a great time here.

Took us a while to find this place, and there's lots of steep roads to negotiate when you are there. But strangely, it's a pretty enjoyable place to visit. Maybe because of the unique houses or the nice cafes along the narrow streets. Worth a visit.

review_title: A visual definition of South Korean tradition.
review_body: It is best to go to the Tourist Info Center 1st to get maps & ask which site to go. It is a huge area to go around. There are 2 main sites to see with traditional houses & museums around the area. It's quite a long walk so wear a comfortable walking shoes n hats as well. Most of the hanoks are private houses still being use by the locals so a lot of them are close and only the exterior of the houses and the roof tiles are available as photo ops. Some houses choose to open to visitors for workshops showing off kite making, lacquering, knotting, embroidery, and the hanbok. Thumbs up!!!

Definitely a busy spot for Japanese and Chinese tourists. There's some interesting Hanok architecture and even great cafes there too. A lot of hills and winding paths. Bring your most comfy shoes and try to be polite to the house owners.

review_title: A peek into the traditional villages
review_body: Well, only if you are into that sort of thing. It's quite a track and it's rather hilly. As the village is actually residences, you won't be able to see much except the streets and the outside of the houses. You will also see numerous (read: in your face) signs to keep your noise level down so as not to bother the residents there.

This would not be my top ten list in terms of the must-sees in Seoul. If you have many days in Seoul and you have already done what most tourists do...perhaps then. It gets quite crowded since all the Chinese tourist groups stop here. Besides the traditional homes, there are a few good restaurants including a thin pizza place which is well-known to locals. There is also a specialty department store which specializes in ceramic pieces, although quite expensive though but they do have memorable pieces.
be prepared to walk a lot of uphill& ve a good pair of walking shoes , best wear Loafercoming here just to see Korea old buildings
This is a great place to stroll through to see Korea as it used to be. The traditional architecture is so beautiful and the location near the palaces is very convenient.

review_title: Don't miss Baek In-Je house museum
review_body: There's a lot of retail and restaurants in this old quarter of the city but one can still find some traditional design structures. The Baek In-Je house provides a very good glimpse of the old designs. Not far from here is a samgyetang ginseng chicken soup restaurant which I found to be quite nice.

review_title: Traditional houses, traditional food, traditional clothing
review_body: This place is good for tourists who like to experience Korean traditional culture. You can hire hanbok here and walk around the area. Lots of korean traditional houses around, good for pictures and lots of korean food around, we just tried random restaurants and they serve the best kimchi jiggae!

This place is huge. We couldn't finish walking (with children). We also lost our way and a nice local guy showed us the way. There are restaurants and some serve really great food. However, they are really serious about having their own lunch that they do not serve guests at certain times. The traditional houses are very beautiful and they look really luxury. We went to a traditional hanbok clothing shop and rented them for photo-taking. These are real hanboks made of silk and really very beautiful. It was a real original Korean experience in Bukchon.

Yes, this area is about all the relentless process of modernisation has left behind when bulldozers and developers transformed former residential areas into glass and steel skyscrapers. Today, the residents of Bukchon no longer fear property tycoons but hordes of chinese and southeast asian tourists who flock the area they know as shooting sites of korean soap operas. The neighbourhood posted signs calling for "silence" and restraint. If you can overcome the moral quarrels and decide to be just one of these tourists, the trip to Bukchon is certainly worth your while, as it provides you with a last chance to experience the special charm of traditional Korean residential architecture. The area also offers plenty of relaxed shops and Cafés. You may combine a trip to Bukchon with a hike to the old city wall up the hill offering excellent views overlooking Seoul.

review_title: Great place to experience Korean Culture
review_body: this place had Korean traditional houses and beautiful view. a great place to experience some history+tradition! But I gotta say, I surely did walk a lot!
First thing we wanted to see is the old, authentic area of Bukchon. And it's well worth visiting. Lots of small coffee shops that makes you feel warm and welcome.
The whole place has an authentic traditional feel to it and brings you back to ancient Korea times. There are a lot of traditional crafts to try. Excellent place to go!

I was able to rent a hanbok for 10,000 won ($10 estimate) for one hour. Compared to the Myeongdong studios offering 5 times than that, this is actually a fabulous deal! The lady who runs the shop was also kind enough to take pictures of me on the 2nd floor studio and she even pointed the way to some of the wonderful photo sights. A definite must-go for all tourists!

Nice place to visit. Very calm. Not much of big shopping center. A lot of small shop selling traditional stuff. Can see teens wearing their hanbok walking around. The street food there can be abit pricey as it's a tourist spot. Get a map so you won't get lost. The visitor center very efficient . Speak English very good.

We decided to walk the area before the Palaces opened in the morning. It is residential so it is important to be quiet and not disturb the families living there. We wanted to do the Bukchon 8 photo spots and had read some blogs about the best way to do this. I assumed the area was larger than it was and we decided to skip spots 1-3. It only took us 10 minutes to walk the remainder so I wish we had done the whole walking tour. We were there around 8, so the streets were empty and it felt so peaceful.

Step back in time to see these beautiful hanok houses, still well maintained and lived in. The area is amazing and well worth it. However it might be difficult for people with mobility issues to get around as there are a lot of steep hills to get up and down.

review_title: A lovely area to walk around and take in the sights
review_body: The old buildings are well maintained and offer a fascinating contrast to the very modern city centre.

It's a residential area made of preserved hanok homes. There is a tourist strip along the main street, and a few renovated homes as cheap museums/arts centers, but other than that it really is a neighborhood. Nice, quiet, and quaint. But not somewhere I'd seek out again.
We enjoyed our time here. Lots of places to take great photos. There's also plenty of shops and restaurants in the area.
