It was a pleasure walking round this traditional village and I enjoyed the architecture. The trendy and traditional shops around added to the atmosphere of this place. Visited an old house which was free and enjoyed looking into the rooms. Stopped to have a lovely Ginseng Chicken soup meal. The view from the top was great and the wall murals were an attraction in itself. I enjoyed the exercise of walking up and down this Hanok village.

review_title: Old North town, from Joseon Dynasty
review_body: Very interesting to check out the old town from Joseon Dynasty. Buk chon (North Town) is village with old Koreab traditional houses built around in 1930s. In Bukchon village, there are 8 different spots to check out different views to enjoy the old town.

review_title: If you thought Seoul was only a modernized city, just go here.
review_body: This place is well known as Bukchon Hanok Village. Basically, this is the most "Korean" part of Seoul as the architecture represents the traditional Korea. This is mostly surrounded by housing, so make sure to lower your voice as most as possible, if you come on the afternoon it may get quiet crowded and busy as Bukchon is located in between Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung and most of the tourists may flow here.Just a quick tip, go to the tourist center located at Bukchon-ro 5-gil to get a map of the village as you may guide yourself with the route that is on the map.Make sure to wear sneakers, there will be hills on the walking route! Also, buy water on the nearest convenience store in order to rehydrate yourself, as this will be probably the only time in Seoul having to exercise.Also, if you time at the beginning of the route make to get a spicy rice cake called Tteokbokki on one of the food stalls to make yourself full a little bit before the walk and hike.

review_title: Piee of live history in the heart of Seoul
review_body: Nice traditional village located in the middle of the Seoul. Unforgettable experiance, feel the Korea as it used to be
Part if the world heritage .. The houses are scattered, will have to talk little and get lose often but it's enjoyable experience after all

Went there wanted to take nice photos but couldn't find the right spot as what i saw from YouTube and website. Quite disappointed. Might be good if there's sign board there directing us to the right photo-taking spot.

I was staying in Anguk for business and had a few hours to spare. I was recommended the Bukchon village and was not disappointed! Very quaint, older Korean buildings in a traditional style. Really enjoyed this little 2 hour stroll around...
An area full of traditional Korean houses which have been well maintained. Make sure you wear good walking shoes as it is very steep.

I've always been amazed with these hanoks whenever I see them in Korean dramas, so I made it a point to visit Bukchon last December. Wear the most comfortable shoes when you visit, as you will do nothing but walk. Be prepared for the uphill trek, too. The pathways are lovely, and the houses are a sight to behold.
It is a good place to take photos. Please remember to keep your volume down because there are people living there. We totally enjoyed the view and walking around those houses.

Get the area map from the tourist office in Samcheong-dong; they will be able to guide you on the route on exploring the area. Be prepare to some steep slopes and the traffic. Sign to be quite can be seen everywhere since it's a neighbourhood area.
If you fancy a walk and getting the Korean house vibes, this is a nice place to do so. Don't go out of your way, there are other similar places.
This is a nice area for seeing traditional South Korean architecture. Be sure to take pictures, but be respectful of the people here as well!

Bukchon is the old style ville. you can go there by sub-way. The ville is on the hill, you can go up there and see the high view perspective.Not too much attractive view point, or interesting point. The ville is not too much attractive.The good thing is the food street near the ville, don't spend too much time in this.

review_title: To be included in your samcheodong tour
review_body: Just rows of houses of the rich with hanok architecture. Make sure you drop by the tourist information office to get great tips. Then connect your walk to samcheodong for shopping and food.

i love history and the houses here are just so beautiful. i want to get in to see how it look inside. it is very tiring to go up and down the street. it is uphill and downhill.there are many shop where you can buy clothes and everything.restaurants and coffee shop not to get hungry.when you are up you will be able to witness a beautiful view, just relax and enjoy

This should be the #1 Must Visit place in Seoul! I enjoyed most this part of city than other places,even more than those palaces. Historic, charming places with beautiful streets,houses,shops,etc.. if you miss this place, be sure that you didn't visit Seoul really!
Very little interest. A few so called typical old corean houses. Nothing to be amazed of. Strongly recommend to skip and visit Namsangol Hanok traditional village instead, absolutely lovely.

review_title: Walk up hill and Down hill but worth it
review_body: Many of beautiful old houses with some handcraft workshop where you can take a look to their traditional things. People in the village are very friendly and welcoming.
Well preserved and interesting neighborhood - a time-capsule place. It's in the middle of a modern city, but you feel like you are in another century. Beautiful views.

review_title: Gorgeous little resi area of pretty old houses
review_body: Everywhere you turn there is a new detail to admire. Really enjoyed Traditional old Seoul. walking around here,

review_title: Better to go on not peak season
review_body: The Area is nice,and the buildings are beautiful, but you may find the expectation and reality of the crowd didn't match. I recommend to go there not on a peak season. so we can get great pictures

About 15 mins by subway from downtown and a nice traditional place. Lots of pop up stores and skin care shops. Nice view on top of the hill and be ready to walk. Tiring but worthy. If you plan to visit the palace probably shouldn't plan anything else for the day...

This place there are a couple of traditional houses kept. Have to walk inside the smaller lanes. However this is still occupied by the local residents so can't go in and visit it. However if wanted to experience the traditional houses there are a couple of guesthouse. Can visit one of the high school located uphill. What a nice atmosphere to study in the school.

We stayed in a hanok during our stay in Seoul and as such, this place is not a particularly interesting place for us.However, it is conveniently located between the 2 must visit palaces - Gyeongbokgung & UNESCO site Changyeonggung - and offers lots of choices in terms of cafe and eateries. So we headed over to Bukchon after visiting Changyeonggung, took a stroll around looking for an eatery, had a meal there while passing time before the free guided tour time at Gyeongbokgung.It's worth a visit as there are interesting cafes set in their traditional houses to spend a cosy afternoon with friends or a 1 hr stroll in between the palaces but if short on time, I would recommend giving the place a miss.
Nice for walking around, tea houses, small restaurants, feel of old Seoul. Make it a half a day trip if in the city. So far it was my favourite part.

review_title: Paasing by after a visit to changdeokgung palace
review_body: A straight walk after came out of the cdk palace, we arrived at bukchon museum which is the place one should see first before wondering around the area. All houses that were remained appear to be built of the same type of architeture structure, probably the same peroid.....never evolved? All countries have these remants but some are better than these primitive ones. Not too attractive in any perspective and it has been made too commerical. It was nice to walk for half an hour and hit to some other place.

A great relaxing place for tourists. You can meet up with artists here or view specialty shops. The roads are beautiful, the building historic. The people who live here are so lucky! Get a map because the roads are winding, take lots of photos and wear comfortable shoes
Seoul is busy, lack of quiet places for your own time. This is the right place. Lots of great architectures and streets with foreigners allow you to be your own.
The village is very interesting and lovely designs. It has traditional and modern. Then go to Samchungdong for lunch as it is very near Bukchon Hanok Village. This area has many nice cafes to choose.

review_title: I love this back in history place in the middle of busy Seoul
review_body: This hanok village reminds me of the hutons in Beijing I love the way there is such a relatively big area so well preserve and alive (people live in the centuries old houses) in a quite impersonal city as Seoul. Definitely worth visiting and having a traditional tea in our of the amazing tea houses

You have to pace your walk as this is not a single straight street. You'd have to climb up the hill/street to get a glimpse of the old houses. Note that they have old and new houses there, this is not some historical place protected by UNESCO. It was a nice walk.

Frankly speaking, this hasn't been a great place for tourists in Seoul. However, now it is transformed to the very perfect spot for any travelers. As it is located just next to two main palaces in Seoul, you can also walk through this place.
Absolutely beautiful traditional Korean houses, Slope of the street makes this place even special and beautiful, highly recommend visiting this place.

review_title: Experience Walking Through the Ancient Street!
review_body: Bukchon is an interesting olden residential town with quite a number of eateries, shops and visitors centres there. It is a cool place to take pictures of the ancient looking streets and walking through the steps (there are lots of steps!!) in the cool weather, is nice, I can't say that for summer time though :PWe managed to find cheap hanbok shop which provides Hanbok for rental for photo taking (selfies) at low cost, most of the shops charge extravagantly, and as we have quite a few of us, we didnt want to waste the money, so opt for the cheaper ones. Nonetheless, good experience and we will recommend to anyone who wants a taste of wearing Hanbok :)
Walking along the streets of Bukchon Hanok village will brought you back in time. It might be a little tiring as the street is upslope. Do wear comfortable shoes.

review_title: Traditional architecture, nice people, beautiful views
review_body: We were just walking around, for a few hours, even if it was very cold and we were freezing. The upside of such weather is that there was few tourists.Buildings are interesting, traditional, many of them have beautiful, detailed paintings on the door. It's nice that people still leave here, you can see children walking back from school, people doing their daily jobs, it's not an artificial place created only for tourists.We were invited by one woman on her hostel's terrace, and could see Bukchon from above. It's quite hilly, so there are many places with a nice view.I would recommend the visit if you want to see some tradition, take a look in the past of common people, not necessarily kings and nobles.

review_title: Pretty village. Traditional homes. Noisy tourists.
review_body: Lovely traditional Korean homes. Wonderful to wander (and get lost) around the tiny lanes. Lots of photo taking opportunities. Bukchon is growing in popularity, which means that more and more tourists are heading here. Wish they would respect the residents’ privacy and keep noise levels down. It would also make for a more tranquil experience as they explore this lovely traditional neighborhood.
Basically this area is good for a 2 - 3 hrs of slow walk. You will see a lot of traditional houses and building.Good for those that like to take a lot of photos during travel.

One of the best place i considered in Korea.. aside from the preserve traditional look of the place.. i loved the serenity and peace of the place.. it is definitely one of the highlight of our stay in korea

review_title: Dont know what the fuss was about .
review_body: Went with high expectations and well after a walk from the nearest station of about 10 mins reached the place . . kept on wondering what was there to see apart from small lanes and old houses . . only go if you have nothing else to see :)

At least during winter time not very special place, you can access differetn small scale museums with small money and there are some handicraft shops, but during cold vinter day area is pretty quiet. The old building are nice anyway, something not easy to find elsewhere in Seoul.

We went here using the "hop-on, hop-off" bus and a walking map. The houses are built in a traditional style with tile roof, masonry and timber exterior walls, masonry boundary wall and heavy wooden gate. The walk is quite long and parts are up hill so wear comfortable shoes, and don't forget to wear appropriate clothing as the full walk is several hours. There are marvellous street vistas and interesting views across the roof tops from the top of the hill.There are many cafes and restaurants for refreshments.
We went to Bukchon on a freezing day, but it was fun experience walking along the street which looks just like in a K-drama. We took place in a workshop to make a traditional book mark.
The buildings are very unique & beautiful.This is a must visit place which reflect the beauty of Korea in a traditional way.
This place is where one can see the traditional architecture of Korea. A sloppy place to explore, best done in the evening where it is not crowded.

accessibility - goodview - fair.for those who want to have a walk around the city, this is a good place to visit. Noteonly that this is a residential place so please observe silence as a respect to the residence of Bukchon Village.

review_title: Cute area but very touristy, especially during the weekend
review_body: This is a nice area to explore in conjunction with the visit of some of Seoul's palaces. Perhaps not quite as nice as Insadong though to find good food, but plenty of little restaurants nonetheless. It is often very crowded though, so don't expect a quiet traditional Korean village, at least on the week-end.

review_title: beautiful traditional neighborhood, very interesting to explore
review_body: We love visiting the Bukchon Hanock Village in Seoul. Get a map & it is easy to navigate. There are amazing traditional hanocks that are open to view. The neighborhood is fun to explore. A beautiful way to see the views of traditional & modern Seoul.

review_title: Korean Style House !!!! A must visit in Seoul
review_body: Listed in a must visit for Seoul. You must love it. All the area are the korean style house. good for photo and walking but please be silent as it is a residential area. I found that it is quite crowded when I visited and people were speaking too loudly.

Actually, there are only some houses which still have Korean ancient architecture. However, it seems to me that there are so many tourists, which makes Bukchon quite crowded and I cannot feel the ancient atmosphere here.Some places require to pay money for entrance.
This old korean village are beautiful. there are old houses along the uphill road. Be sure to be polite and don't be noisy, cause there are still people live there.

review_title: A beautiful place with nice view and nice people
review_body: We went there in the morning, not so crowded with tourists. Have a nice walk around and visited the traditional korean house. Love those small little lanes, quite environment and fresh air compared with places like Myeongdong & Dongdaemen.They are also some shops along the way selling food and souvenirs.Recommended to tourists.

review_title: One of the best tourist visiting places in Seoul city
review_body: It would take 15 min or so to walk from the metro station to the area, slightly uphill. Watch out if you go with young kids or elders, also during winter time too. Kinda cold for the walkBut totally worth it. Historic places but with nice contemporary cafes around. Next to the area, there is a cool and trendy area for young local people (not big brands but nice small shops for all kinda, lifestyle, fashion and cafes).You can spend about 1/2 day there and surrounding area.

Though this may seem like a touristy area, it is filled with great little independent boutiques selling one off clothing pieces, it reminds me a little of Covent Garden in London or Greenwich Village in New York. I love the cutesy cafes and coffee bars - one of my favourite neighbourhoods in Seoul!

Stayed here for 4 days. I will definitely stay in this area next time I visit in 2016. In walking distance of some of the main attractions. It's busy through the day with lots of tourists given its a heritage site.
If you need a moment to wander in the calm far from the city crowds, it is the perfect place. Really charming.
Is this a great place to visit? To me, so...so. Is there any interesting thing to see? To me, old Korean houses. Is it worth your time to visit? Do visit if you have the spare time.

I remember watching an episode on running man where the members exclaimed about the beauty of samcheongdong / bukchon hanok village. As I reached the place after walking over from Gyeongbokgung, I understood why even locals love the place. It's simply a charming district filled with rows and rows of hanok style buildings, and a mix of modern looking shops and restaurants. Every turn and angle leads to another path of beautiful shophouses. A very interesting place and I can say it's one of my favourite districts to just wander around, take photos and get lost in the many similar looking alleys. Even the bare trees in winter that lined the streets looked pretty! A pity we were rushing if not we could have explored the place more. There are 9 photo zones, but I didn't have time to visit them. I would gladly visit samcheongdong/ bukchon hanok village again during my next trip and take lots of photos of the beautiful hanoks! It is walkable from gyeongbokgung, changdeokgung and insadong! Topokki sold here is different from the usual, the rice cakes are on skewers. Found the traditional candy, ppopgi here as well and i was so happy! Touristy it may be, but we found some really good buys there :)

review_title: Winding through the serene neighborhood full of characteristics
review_body: My daughter, 9, and I picked up a walking map from the tourist info center. She had fun navigating the place. As it was still a place of residence for the locals, there were many notices put up to remind tourists to lower their volume. Definitely worth a visit to see the old architecture. Highly convenient as it was right smack in the city. Just a little cold in winter. So, if your schedule is flexible, pick a nice sunny day.

Great to stroll around the village early morning or near sunset, when all the tour buses have left. You don't need a map, just walk around. All roads lead back to the main road. Respect the quiet, people do live and work there.

Even though I don't have book knowledge of architecture of any countries, I do love visiting and looking at old architectures in different countries. It just amazes me how different eastern and western architectures are, yet both are really captivating to look at.Bukchon is a must visit to people who visit Seoul, especially if you are interested in history or architecture or both. You would have to be quiet while visiting though since the houses have people living in them. They are not just for display. Best time to visit would be Autumn or Spring.

My Korean tutor's husband was our tour guide for a day and this was one of the places we went to because I really wanted to see a Hanok Village. There are a lot of steep hills, and it is tiring (especially since it was HOT) but it was very much worth it. If you get to the top of the hill in the neighborhood, there is a beautiful tea house. I recommend sitting outside on the terrace and enjoy the view while sipping mango tea.We got up there just before sunset. It was so peaceful and relaxing but at the same time very exciting and vibrant. I have never seen another neighborhood like this in any of my travels.

review_title: The best place in the City
review_body: In the whole city during my time ther i found myself at everytime walking to here, it is because it's a calm neighberhood, old houses and the smell of wood, don't forget to get this Guide from the Tourist Information and Go to all the mention Spots, you will get the best Shots everDo it in the morning you will be alone there and perfect for shooting, the afternoon gets busy again Enjoy it

Bukchon and Samcheon are in the same neighborhood and are worth a trolley about (but not in the snow since some roads are steep). You needn't follow any particular route. I have been many a time and I am still pleasantly surprised by some of the little alleyway treasures. Also very near Changdeokgung Palace, so a good combo. Get off at Anguk Station exit 2

Visited Bukchon village after Gyeongbokgung Palace. Lots of alleys to venture into and get immensed in the traditional housing of the Joseon era. While some of these hanok houses have remained as residential quarters, many have been converted to shops, galleries and eating places.

review_title: one of my greatest expereinces in Korea
review_body: I visited Bukchon in my 3rd visit to Seoul, and it was one of the best experiences I had. beautifully maintained classic Korean style neighborhood and must see.

this attraction require some stamina to walk. it is situated along a slope and not recommended for elderly (unless the old folks are strong enough to walk up a slope). Views are great with many photo opportunities
Had a lovely day here wandering around. Great to see the contrast between the big modern city and traditional Korean village. A definite must!

review_title: A bit too gentrified for my taste
review_body: Yes, there are still hanok houses here, but most of them have become souvenir shops. I was a bit disappointed. I felt that it had lost some of its authentic charm. But it's hard to find places that are truly authentic nowadays. So, it's still a nice place to visit, but don't expect to see anything other than restaurants and kitschy shops.

review_title: Must see, early in morning best
review_body: Avoid the crowds while not getting in the way of those living in these wonderful homes. The architecture of these old homes is most impressive.

review_title: Nice walk around the area with views of traditional houses.
review_body: Visit was interesting looking at the traditional houses, especially in the cold weather where it is less taxing compared to summer. Lots of things to window shop and street side food as well as cafes too.

This place is a nice quiet town with so many back alleys to take instagram photos. There is a cafe right at the corner that sells sweet potato latte! Please take a map at the start of the walking trail to see which scenic spots to take photos
Was not too impressed, as neighborhood seems overly refurbished. Was hoping to feel the air of the Josen dynasty architecture.

It was nice to see old houses and this village was able to preserved their houses. This is a residential area but they allow the public to roam around and have their pictures taken with the traditional houses as their background. But be mindful with noises as the residents do not like to be disturbed.There's no fee when you visit the village and it is just 40 minutes walk from Gyeongbokgung Palace and few kilometers away to Insadong Market. Don't mind the long walk as the place is very nice for walking. Just enjoy the scenery and the culture that the Koreans has to offer.There is also a shop allowing the visitors to try the traditional Korean costume with a fee at the Bukchon village.

This places is where you can see the traditional korean houses. Many tourists as well as the locals came to this tourist attraction and took some photos. There isn't anything special except for the houses. As it is a residential place (where some people are living in), you have to be considerate and keep your volume down. There are also some souvenir shops and cafes around. Nice to visit if you are curious or interested about the look or feel of traditional korean houses.

Bukchon Hanok Village is an area of Seoul that every tourist should visit and experience. I was there on a Friday and some of the buildings were not open for viewing on that day. Fortunately, I got to experience the Korean Hanbok dress and take pictures. That was quite inexpensive. Otherwise, the locals do not recommend eating in this area as prices are higher than average. There are also some nice souvenir and pottery shops along the main street.

After visiting all city palaces don't miss this historical neigbourhood.Good for strolling in galeries, arts, shops, restaurants in the heart of Seoul.No visit to Seoul is complete without this place.Spend here some hours starting early morning and having you lunch as well.

review_title: Grab guide from tourist office to locate the traditional houses
review_body: Amazing to see the contrast in these traditional houses versus modern houses. Some houses offer photoshoots in traditional hanboks. I liked that food was readily available

If you need to get away from the shopping and modern city Seoul can be, then definitely head to this place. Small roads to fit yourself and a smart car side by side. Hills back and forth so you get a workout. The bugging of this place has little boutique stores and very few craft stores. There is definitely food all around

Good place to stroll around, see some old Korean style houses, and shop for some vintage souvenirs. With friends, not really worth visiting on its own, but since it's close to the palaces and Insadong, you can just pass by.
Tradional village with narrow street up the slope from the main road. We saw movie filming when you are walking. Lovely slow walk.
We enjoyed strolling along the small streets of this Korean traditional house village in Seoul. Very lovely to look at.
Great place to understand the culture of Korea and take photos of traditional Korean houses (Hanok) in this vibrant city.

This place is great and amazing. But, I'd like you to know that if you don't feel hiking and walking a lot, then u should not visit the place because you need to walk a lot and it's very steep. But, because of Super Junior, i visited this place!

review_title: Nice place where they preserved the old residential houses
review_body: Nice place where they preserved the old residential houses. And these are 'living' area where people are currently still living there.You won't need a lot of time there but good to see.

review_title: visit R coffee along the hilly road
review_body: watching sunset here is one of the most memorable time for me in Korea. sitting in R coffee shop (near the edge of the hill) and had a very nice, heartwarming conversation with So Young-the lovely shop owner. her tea is so good and she boils it 3 times for me :)

You cannot missed to visit Bukchon Hanol Village when you are in Seoul. Basically, Bukchon is a private residential area but the unique thing is their houses are Hanoks (traditional Korean house since Joseon era). These houses has been passed down to generations has underwent minor renovation to suits current lifestyle. most of the houses here are the same structure since Joseon era. A must go.

Came here early in the morning when its not too busy. The streets are narrow and hilly at certain parts. Wear a good walking shoe and be prepared to walk. Many small shops selling interesting touristy things. Enjoy the traditional houses and don't forget to shoot photos. Stop by at Gahoe 2nd Floor observatory for coffee and enjoy the view.

It was interesting to see the area, with lots of little shops to pop in and out of. I would recommend exploring the rest of Anguk, perhaps for lunch, on the same day, and the nearby Gyeongbokgung Palace

Its a beautiful well kept village, for a reason too. Since its a living village, visitors should respect the villagers, but i dont see much villagers there :). Mostly are tourist taking pictures with cafes, restaurant and convenience shops. Place are kept clean and you always have tourist police in red uniform to guise you.
The houses are beautiful , good for photos but that's about it. Not a very big deal. It's a good 15 mind walk from the station...just keep going . There are some coffee houses you can try

A very interesting place as it shows a traditional houses with alleys leading to more interesting houses. But many tourists do make a lot of noises which they are not supposed to do since there are people living in the houses.

Get out at anguk station exit 2 and just walk straight up the street until you see the information booth. There you can get a map, which I would recommend because you can get very turned around here. They have 8 spots for good photos which are marked on the map. There are also information people in red that walk around and can point you in the right direction. There are LOTS of hills which can be exhausting, but the views really are stunning. I recommend going in the Fall because all the colors on the trees are gorgeous. Must be quiet because people still live in those houses. When you go down the (rather terrifying) stairs of the 8th view, Samcheongdong is right there at the bottom. You can walk down that street to get to Gyeongbokgung. Insadong is also close by. We visited all these places in one day. Bring your walking shoes! Hills!
Great for shopping and cafes short walk from folk museum. We had our toddler in a pram which restricted where we could go as very hilly, but still a nice place to wander and get lost.
Visit this place early in the morning so you won't encounter noisy, annoying tourists. You'll be able to appreciate the houses more and find some relaxing time while walking around.

right after our tour at gyeongbukgong palace, we went straight to bukchon hanok village to see for ourselves how koreans live centuries ago. it was a great learning experience and they were able to preserve something of their past and converted it to modern times. we had a lot of photo opportunities and were able to pose wearing traditional korean costumes(hanbok). use your smartphones to take unlimited photos. they only give you one small colored photo.

review_title: A Historic Area Absolutely Worth a Visit
review_body: We visited Bukchon Hanok Village while in Seoul. It was a highlight of our time there. We found that it was absolutely fascinating to walk through the narrow lanes and alleys of this neighborhood full of traditional Korean homes. Part of the appeal of this area is that this area is lived-in. It is NOT a museum, but a living, vibrant community. People take care of their homes and the streets and alleys are well-kept. Be ready to climb some steep stairs to get there, though. The 'village' is perched on hillsides and as you walk around, you get wonderful views of the village and the modern city off in the distance. If you're up for a strenuous walk and ready to climb flights of stairs to get into this village, you will not be disappointed with your effort. Come and see this memorable village for yourself.
This area can show you how Korean people lived in 200 years ago. The house is called Hanok, which has interesting structure.

One of my favourite memories of Seoul! Authentic traditional Korean architecture still used as a residential area, so you won't get touristy stuff shoved in your face on every step. It's quite quiet but surrounded by cool little shopping areas too.

The whole neighborhood consist of traditional korean houses or hanok. There are volunteer that gave us map showing several location that is the best spot to took pictures. The area is very quiet and calm. Very relaxing
This place is awesome. If you want to see how old korean house style, you can come here.The architecture is awesome. This place is famous place for korean drama shooting.
was with a few korean friends so we went to a lot of places... this was one of them,., my first trip to seoul..but i will be back

just a few minute walking from anguk subway station and then you'll get there. very nice Korean's traditional house and still clean,but you should be quiet in this place because it's also a residential area. nice place to walk around and get some beautiful picture, and its all free :D

review_title: it was nice to see traditional houses
review_body: Just a few minutes walk from the Changdeokgung Palace is the Bukchon Hanok Village. it was good to see up close what korean traditional houses look like. we also discovered that there are guesthouses or hanoks for rent in this area which we want to try next time!there are lots of coffee shops and food stalls in the area. we went here in the morning before taking the 10:30 am English tour at Changdeokgung Palaceto get to Bukchon Hanok: take the subway, alight at Anguk Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), then take Exit 2

review_title: The old Korean styled houses are beautiful
review_body: If you want to have a look of the old Korean houses, this is a good place. I think they are beautiful. These houses are still being occupied by local residents. You can enter some of these houses by paying a fee but we were able to visit one with free admission. If you are lucky, sometimes you could finnd locals wearing traditional Korean clothes wandering around the streets.

Korean 's traditional houses on hill,near Changdeok Palace, Gyeongbok Palace and Samcheongdong-gil Nice place to walking around and take nice photography. Visit Bukchon Traditional Culture Center to get a free map and find out more attractions around Bukchon.You can see Namsan Tower clearly, suggest you to visit here on weekday to avoid large tourist groupsAnd because this is and active residential area so please do not disturb the residents and keep quite ^^

review_title: Traditional Korean Living, Made for Tourists
review_body: The Bukchon area is a great peep into the traditional Korean Hanoks, houses inspired by the Japanese style. The best way to tour this is to take the walk from Anguk st Exit 3 all the way up and then downhill till you reach the education Museum then take a right to reach the Korean Folklore museum and then to the Gyeongbokung Palace. Also at the end of the trail you will find a small shop which sells nice Dreamcatchers and Mini Cacti for a good price. Alternatively you could walk straight down across the road from Education museum towards Anguk St Exit 1

review_title: A great area to get a sense of Korean Culture and lifestyle.
review_body: I spent a week in Bukchon and while I did not get to visit all the main sites and attractions of Seoul I think living in Bukchon gave me a real sense of what it's like to live and work in modern Korea. Bukchon remains very traditional in the sense that several hundred traditional houses ( Hanok) and workshops remain so you can spend time wandering through the narrow lanes and a number of buildings offer workshop experiences such as kite making, ceramics, traditional dress ( hanbok) experiences to enhance the cultural experience. In addition I noticed a lot of Korean tourists were staying in houses converted into homestay or guest houses. The area also has strong connections with modern Korea as the streets are filled everyday when workers pour out of the Hyundai office blocks to buy coffee in the many coffee shops ( yes - these do include Starbucks!). Lots of food outlets too offering lots of variety. Sadly a few streets are overrun by tourists ( mainly Chinese) and this can limit the pleasure but there are plenty of times and streets when the coach tours are not there to spoil the sense of being in a living and lively local community. If you get the chance - don't just visit - try and stay in Bukchon.
It's quite a walk uphill but it's interesting to see the houses on our way up. Nice place to take memorable photos of your visit to Seoul

Because of a few mistakes in planning, we ended up spending an afternoon here, and were so glad we did. This is a hidden gem that most visitors on short visits won't get to as it takes some effort and walking. Beautiful architecture, interesting back story, lovely one-off shops and Doo Roo, an exquisite non-chain coffee bar that's so toasty and cozy!

Well, the experience was refreshing as this is something that cannot be seen in my home country. I would say the old-style houses are beautiful, but it can be slightly disappointing as that is about it. If you are have want to go there, You actually can as you can do some shopping around the area. It is also near Insadong, where you can do quite alot of stuff as well.

Worth a visit. This place are so beautiful, quiet and peaceful. We were in spring season, the weather was great and the flowers blooming all over the place. It was green environment. This village mainly filled with old style korean houses and there were cute shops along the street. Stairs were kinda narrow and steep. No need to rush and enjoy the amazing view.

review_title: Good add-on to a visit to Chengdeokgung Palace
review_body: An interesting area of Seoul to visit is the Bukchon Village near Changdeokgung Palace. This is an historic neighbourhood where you can find hundreds of Hanoks, traditional Korean style houses, recognised for its unique architecture and structural positioning in relation to the contours of the surrounding land. Here you can walk paved streets, lined with Hanoks, many of which remain residential while others serve as cafes, coffee shops, shops, galleries and a handful of small museums. Seems there are some homestay opportunities in the area as well if visitors fancy staying in a Hanok during their time in Seoul. We found Bukchon to be a good place to stroll and enjoyed seeing the many traditional Korean style buildings. It felt over-marketed and promoted but still a nice place to spend time, especially if you intend to be in the area, visiting the UNESCO World Heritage Chengdeokgung Palace. You can easily explore a good portion of Bukchon for 30-45 minutes before or afterwards. Note: The area where you find Bukchon Village is quite hilly so be prepared for some steep street climbs from time to time.

review_title: Nice look at traditional korean home
review_body: The picture that everyone sees of this place is really a small street. It is always filled with people so it's hard to take a good picture. Walking there, try to ask for directions from the volunteers in red. This is a nice place to take a stroll and see a less busy side of seoul. I recommend coming here first before Samcheungdong as you will end up in the middle of that street and you can take a walk downhill

The streets are narrow and steep and can be confusing to navigate without a map. The traditional buildings are interesting to look at but vestiges of modernity are everywhere, with fingerprint scanner locks installed over ancient looking doors. Over promoted as a tourist attraction, resulting in large number of tourists around, making moving around the place challenging at times.
Walking through the street with old style korean houses.it is an eye opener I would say. worth a visit.after that, can visit samcheongdong for shopping and plenty of cafes lined along the street.

Walking around in alleys and finding different Hanok houses was interesting. A lot of Hanok have been converted into galleries, cafes or guesthouses. This area is still largely residential. Be considerate when walking around.
The area is filled with traditional houses (hanok) and is a pleasant walk from Insadong. There are various dining options in the area.

This village preserves the old shapes of Korea in the era of Joseon Dynasty. Also, there are lots of restaurants specilazed in dishes, cafes, galallies, etc.. Go to there if you want to see Kirean cultures. There are lots of foreigners getting around.

review_title: Interesting walk through the hanok houses
review_body: Came to view the hanok houses which are beautifully restored, quite a nice walk from Exit 3 of Angkuk station on Subway Line 3. Can imagine it would very warm in summer but now being winter, the walk uphill was comfortable.Loved peaking into some of the beautiful courtyards housing local businesses which allow you to try on traditional hanbok, take some photos while they shared about the korean culture for a fee or do it like me just walk through the village on your own and let your instinct lead you through the winding paths. There are plenty of cafes, restaurants, shops to keep one engrossed and you can easily spend a few hours here.

review_title: Old Style Houses in a HyperModern City - Bukchon
review_body: Loved this place, architecture is so unique and elegant. a Mixture between modern and old houses in this area, lots of coffee, clothing and souvenir shops. Totally recommend for small groups, couples and families (first time visitors mainly). A little difficult to reach and confusing (because is not a Village but a set of streets in a small area....)

review_title: Great free to-do option in Seoul!
review_body: Bukchon area, especially the Hanok Village is a must-visit place IMO. You can walk around, sightseeing, and if you have the map, you can seek for the recommended photo spots and take some insta-worthy shots! Do mind that LOTS of walking is involved and the area does get crowded at times. And because the hanok(s) are private properties and people actually live there, we are not suppose to visit after 6pm, if I remember correctly :)

A great place to walk through and get a glimpse of old Seoul. I toured the Western Gyeongbokgung Palace in the morning and en route to Changdeokgung Palace and Secret Garden I toured through the narrow streets of Bukchon. A great place for photos and many little places to grab a refreshing beverage to quench your thirst or take in a traditional Korean BBQ. Highly recommend Bukchon Village as a destination while in Seoul.
Walking around the place, please maintain silence to give privacy to homeowners. Both sides should be visited

I spent a pleasant few hours wandering around here. While the traditional houses are interesting, I was happy just soaking in the local flavour and enjoying the delicious street food. Gets quite crowded late afternoons on the weekends.

Very beautiful traditional houses, steep lanes, plants and flowers - wonderful ambiance. The fact that people still live there normally adds a very "live" aspect to this area. In the part closer to Gyeongbokgung Palace there are lots of cafes, restaurants, art galleries.

review_title: Good break from Seoul city sights
review_body: Best to visit early in the morning because it gets crowded closer to mid-day. Interesting narrow alleys, clean; traditional Koreans houses have beautiful wooden doors. Most homes are private, but there is an interesting compound that is open to the public. Two other sites : National Folk Musuem and Gyeongbokgung Palace are walking distance from Bukchon - interesting 15 - 20 minute walk.

We took a morning walk from Insadong to the area. Mainly old traditional style houses where people live in -- not a museum but an actual neighborhood. There is a temple towards the top, plus some shops along the day. A place to look for persimmon trees if you have never seen one. Good place for picture taking if you love traditional architecture.Along the way to the area are some museums, souvenir shops, and street food vendors.

I feel like I would have enjoyed spending more time inside a palace or museum as we didnt get to see the inside of any house since my husband and I did the tour on our own. Seeing a few houses would have sufficed for me! Looks the same anyway hehe. Pretty steep inclines to the best locations so its not recommended for seniors or anybody who is too tired..

Beautiful houses. You can see how is korean traditional house is look like. No free tour available. All houses and close and there is sign not make noise. You can enjoy and feel the sourounding and take picture of the house.I
its such beautiful village, surround with old traditional home korea.you can find many traditional home here, clean place, you can visit for free. if you like history is good place to visit
Its history is 600 years long, but the area is so well-preserved and so full of tourists, art shops and guest houses etc. that it felt like a very nice walk in the Korean version of Disneyland.

review_title: In love with this old town
review_body: Personally I prefer this to Myeongdong. I could spend the whole day strolling along the narrow roads of this traditional old town, admiring the buildings, houses, rooftops, trying out every quaint little cafes. A must go if u r like me, prefer to have a taste of life at a slower pace. It's like Kyoto in Japan.
Love the place with perfect location of traditional view in the city. Lovely atmosphere to walk around.

I can say that this traditional village may be home of pioneer residents in the city. It is only in this village that I saw traditional houses with luxurious cars parked outside their porch.If you are a K-drama fan, you'll find here the gate featured in Lee Min Ho's drama 'Personal Taste'.

This was a very old, traditional part of old Seoul - which stands in stark contrast to all of the large buildings and skyscrapers you see elsewhere in the city. Here you find tiny, traditional houses as they once stood 50 or more years ago. This is not an exciting place to visit - more historical.
I think everybody would enjoy visiting this romantic, cozy and beautiful neighborhood. Stroll there to enjoy old times idyllic set up. Take a lot of pics.
You will pass by traditionalKorean houses. No other interesting activities. You can try to wear their traditional Korean dress but quite expensive 7000 Korean won!

review_title: 100 year old traditional Korean house & Korean traditional villsge
review_body: Our taxi dropped us off this 100 year old Korean exhibition house either a scenic overview of the Bukchon village, unfortunately we were not allowed inside the house because we were not with a guided tour. But fortunately they allowed us to enter & view the house from the garden -- to officially open in 2 months. This was a home of a Korean surgeon & now bought by the City of Seoul. Yes it's worth a visit then walk to G-Palace . Ginseng chicken soup Restaurant was our lunch stop in this area.

review_title: I Really Thought I Would Adore This Place...But, Not So Much
review_body: Pick up a map at the visitor's station nearby. Everything is self guided here. Free.*** A small residential neighborhood from the old days with period homes. Nothing more, nothing less.***Wear comfortable shoes/sneakers, for the route is Fairly steep...sometimes with stairs, etc. There are views to be had but hard to find, according to the map. A few guides placed around the village to give directions, etc. Just enjoy what you are seeing. Some folks have opened their homes for a VERY steep admission fee...I would pass. NO places to have drinks or lunch. Go back to the main road, and there are shops and places to drink & eat.Plan on about 45 minutes. You will tire of this place soon.Please give me a heads up vote if this review has helped you or yours. Aloha.

Interesting area to get a glimpse of how life may have been in the past with respect to the houses. A friendly lady invited us into her home to have a look, which was very nice. We enjoyed our stroll through the neighborhood and finished it with a nice meal in a Korean restaurant.

If you want to escape from the heavy urban mood when in Seoul, this could be one of the places to be. Unless it's summer season, Bukchon can be really quiet, especially in the mornings. On busier days there are usually many street musicians and you can also buy some handmade crafts. There are lots of coffee shops, desert cafes, restaurants and galleries around the place. It's one of those sophisticated areas of Seoul, that is always warm, welcoming and a little bohemian. Please note, that it's actually a residential area!

If you would like to see authentic, traditional Korean houses, you should definitely come here! Be prepared, that in will be too crowded, and you have to be super patient if you would take a good photo on the neighbourhood without tourist hordes.
This is an old house places and very interested to visit. Prepare to walk with comfortable shoes and many eating shops are other fashion shops.
We reached when its almost dark. We managed to take a few photos. Lovely view. Regret not to come early. I will come back again.
This is indeed a nice area for walking, a little uphill, but through quiet streets. The houses are old and quaint. Plenty of shops and eating facilities in the direction of Insadong.

review_title: A perfect blend of traditional and modern
review_body: Samcheong-dong + Bukchon is a must-visit area in Seoul . The Hanok (traditional Korean Houses) and modern buildings blended perfectly and gives this place its unique flavor. There are also many nice cafes in this area.The place is within walking distance from Gyeongbukgung Palace and is easily accessible.

I actually stayed in Bukchon for my first leg of my trip. It's quiet and charming. It's very close to two palaces. The subway is close by. I loved staying in this neighbourhood and walking round. If you don't love the hustle and bustle I highly recommend it for an area of stay.

Walked around the whole area. It might have been an historic site but currently it is all renovated. There are some coffee shops and small restaurants west of the Gyeongbokgung Palace. If you are willing to walk, stroll south trough Buckchon Road until the Insa-dong area and further south. Nice follow up after the Palace visit, which is a mandatory destination.

My husband and I walked around this area on a Wednesday morning and it was fairly crowded. There is a nice small museum set up in one of the houses that you can walk through. The buildings were interesting, but if you only have a short time in Seoul you could skip this. On a side street there were some good views of one of the mountains. There was also a little wine bar and a cafe with a good view of the mountain, but neither were open. I imagine they would have pretty views at night.

I had a quick walk through Bukchon village at night in Seoul. My intention was to return again in the daylight, but even in the evening, it was beautiful, and gives a glimpse into the past. The narrow streets and old, well restored houses are a delight to see.

review_title: Must visit when you are in Seoul
review_body: This is my first visit to Bukchon in my 4th trip in Seoul and it was amazing to see the traditional houses well kept in this quiet neighbourhood in Seoul.

review_title: Excellent historic Bukchon Village street walk
review_body: Seoul and Korea are full of history often unknown in the West.On a sunny Saturday, I strolled around the Bukchon Hanok village.This is a wonderfully restored series of hill streets, taking you back nearly 600 years to traditional Korean villages.The streets were traditionally the residential quarter of high-ranking government officials and nobility during the Joseon Dynasty (in the 1400s).Beautifully restored and with expensive residences with great views over the city, the small traditional homes nestle closely together on steep streets.Great to spend time walking, shop browsing and enjoying very good coffee in the numerous Korean-Western coffee houses.
You can visit Buchon's street for shopping then go to 31 Gahoe-dong or 11 Gahoe-dong route to view the hanok. Gahoe-dong is up hill and downhill need a lot of walking but the hanok is worth to visit.

This place has real traditional houses where people still live in. Of course they don't still live the olden way. But rather, they just restore the traditional houses and have electricity and water and all the comforts of modern day living. Nice place to check out.

Some people complain about lots of shop there. True, lot of those houses have been converted into shops and homestay. However, if you go further into the alley, there are MORE that are NOT been converted, and still keep it original, or even much older. You need to go out of what the "Map" tells you. Otherwise, you can only see what a tourist can see.

if u fan of Lee Min-ho & watch Personal Taste drama this is the place u must come. U can feel korean drama when come here. The location is very beautiful. Tips: please used the correct shoes when walk here as u need to walk and walk and walk & some climb the road.

If you love those scene in Korean TV series, you should not miss this place. You can easily spent your entire day exploring this place, shop to shop, cafe to cafe, etc. Be prepared to wear your comfortable shoe as the terrain there can be quite challenging for some. But the amount of food intake and easily burn-off at teh end of the day. Beautiful place. Must allocate time for this.
Walking around the small street of Bukchon is a must when visiting Seoul. It one of the only few remaining locations where you could see the traditional houses.

Took some time to stroll around here in-between visiting Changdeokgung and Gyeongbokgung Palaces. This neighbourhood is extremely charming and picturesque. It’s full of adorable restaurants, cafes, and shops that are a joy to visit. I recommend doing lunch in Bukchon and getting lost in the winding alleys and streets on a leisurely afternoon.

review_title: Beautiful area to walk around in
review_body: Right between 2 palaces, well worth a stroll around. Interesting to see the modern houses built in traditional style. Cut into the little side street for an 'old town' feel

review_title: Great place for a photo session
review_body: Made a lot of photos of my GF there, place is just great, Very atmospheric. Also can recommend stay there for a night in one of that ancient houses (its available)

Wonderful neighborhood of traditional houses very well preserved. This is mostly a residential area, but surrounded by great shopping and cafes. The building style is "old Seoul" and houses have been lovingly restored. Don't even think of driving on the narrow and winding streets - this is a walker's paradise. There is a neighborhood walking tour marked on locally posted maps and an information center that can provide more walk info. This is well worth the time!
I love the street & old korean houses here..so nice and pretty..It's so quiet because it's actually ordinary residence.the sign of "silence please" is everywhere..

Paid this a visit and it was worth it to see the hanoks which are a rarity in modern Seoul. There are specific photo zones (on the ground) that you can look out for to get the best angle for your photos. Is a popular spot for couples in every season, and there are traditional activities you can take part in, just do some research online. Since this is a residential area, visitors are reminded via signs to keep the noise level down in the neighbourhood.
Really? What's the big deal? Yes, you can see the glimpse of old neighbor hood, but it really didn't do it for me.I definately would not recommend people, i'd rather visit one of the palaces.

We were disappointed. It took us a good 20 minutes walk from the Gyeongbokgung Palace to get to the village. There were hardly any proper directional signs to lead us there and we had to ask along the way for pointers. When we arrived, instead of seeing hanok, we were greeted by a changing landscape of modern houses mixed with whatever is left of hanoks. What remained were converted to guests house.

If you have a map of Bukchon (easily google it or you can ask a map from their tourist guide dressing in red clothes), there are 8 spots you can visit. Because of our strict schedule, I only manage few spots here but I am satisfied! The view was amazing. This road is in uphill so prepare your foot! You can rent a hanbok in Bukchon Museum, right before you turn left to downhill (check your map!). The rent is cost 10000krw. It's expensive but worth it! The color is so pretty and you can wear it outside and enjoy Bukchon for 30minutes! If you want to go to Insadong, you can visit Insadong after Bukchon just by walking and chill the road. There are a lot of cafes, restaurants, and stores! Watch your wallet, ladies! Hihi Just easily check your map to see the direction from Bukchon to Insadong. It's easy to read, don't worry!

The traditional houses (Hanok) were really beautiful and many interesting shops lie within the little aisles. Do note that this is a residential area and minimise the noise level as it will affect the residents. There were guides from the tourist information centre who walk around to assist the tourists. No smoking is allowed and the guides will ask you to stop smoking if spotted, which I appreciate as non-smokers do not enjoy their experience at this beautiful village being tainted by the smokers. Be prepared to walk lots of slopes and stairs. You can get a map from the tourist information centre, the staff were really friendly there.

My husband and I really enjoyed our walk here. There are so many interesting traditional houses to look at and the view during sunset was amazing. We went during the weekdays and off peak season so there were not many tourists around.

review_title: Amazing and well kept Architecture of oldday houses
review_body: The traditional architecture of the old day Korean house were well kept since it was under the World Heritage property. A slow walk up hill will get you amaze with the different design of the house, roof and the wall design. A must visit for 1st time visit to Seoul.

If you want to see the old traditional houses and streets you must visit this. Be aware of some steep streets but worth it. If you follow the route then you will see most of the old houses. Also in some houses there are exhibitions or workshops or you can wear hanbok and take pictures.
This is great to see as part of a day exploring Seoul. However, I would not do this all day or plan a trip around this.
So much on offer, great café scene, hidden Korean eateries and lot's of culture. If you have little (or lot's of) time and like to absorb some the old and new Korean feel, it is the place to go

I've always wanted to see the various styles and it was quite quiet when I visited. The views are also good from the vantage points. Unfortunately I wasn't able to look inside a house but they looked really quaint from the outside.

review_title: Really lovely little place to walk around
review_body: We love this place , cute buildings old history and design but still nice modern shopping and food outlets , old houses have beautiful timber work , and the old tile roofs are amazing , do yourself a favor and check them out !!

Great to see the traditional houses still in korea Heard this place is famous as well because alot of the houses are in korean dramas I must say theres too many people here to even take nice photos tho
Bukchon 8 views are so interesting and worth to take a look. Avoid going there during weekend or holidays as the place will be very crowded.

Our guide, Gene, from "This Is Korea" Seoul tour company, took us to Bukchon first thing one morning of our Seoul tour. We loved the fact that few people were on the streets yet at 8:30 a.m., and photos ops were fantastic!

A very charming and rustic neighbourhood with a great variety of restaurants, cafes and little nice shops! Good to shop and stroll, with very traditional houses. It's like a wanderland away from the busy and crowded shopping district of Myeongdong.

review_title: Just keep wandering around, you'll find pockets of historic beauty
review_body: The two best pieces of advice in visiting Bukchon are: Ignore many of the “recommended walk routes” you find, particularly in guide books. They would be better called “If you walk in and around this general perimeter we’ve laid out, you’ll see Bukchon”. Go to the “Images” option of most search engines and type in “Bukchon”, you’ll find alternative, much more detailed (and perhaps better) walking route maps. Get an early start (getting to Bukchon by 8:00 – 8:30 A.M. is recommended). The area is surprisingly small and the streets very narrow. By 10:00, it’ll start to fill up with mini tour groups and other tourists with cameras to the point that any pictures you take will be mostly of other people taking pictures. This is especially true for the north-west section of Bukchon. [If it’s just you and the occasional resident walking their dog or walking to school, you’ll know you’re there at the right time]. If you’re staying close by, it might be a good idea to visit it until crowds start to show up, then leave and pick up where you left of the next day.Finally, not to be preachy but keep in mind that you are, for all intents and purposes, in these people’s front and back yards.

One of my favorite destinations in Seoul. It was crowded when we were there, but worth our efforts, time. You get to see the old streets and you seem to move back in time. A must see! I would definitely go back there - probably early in the morning.

review_title: Old village in the middle of city
review_body: located between gyeongbokgung palace and changdeokgung palace. it's a unique area where traditional and modern meets. you can either go shopping, eating or just walking and seesighting. most of the store have a chic design make the street looks even more unique and beautiful. very lovely. bukchon have a lot of korean traditional restaurant and also you can't miss the food street. The most popular spot on bukchon is Bukchon Hanok Village, is where you can find korea traditional houses in the middle of Seoul. awesome!

review_title: Very nice area to hang out! (Though don't expect something amazing)
review_body: Pretty beautiful area to hang out, and see the different architectures. Don't expect something that'll blow your mind though :) some nice cafés and restaurants. Dedicate easily 1 hour to walk around there.

review_title: Very calm and authentic experience of a Hanok Village. Great photo opportunities!
review_body: This is still a residential area, with some cafes and shops. So, not that commercialized like Namsangol Hanok Village. A lot of great photo opportunities.

review_title: My most memorable place in Seoul
review_body: Beautiful! This is definitely less crowded than Myeongdong. Many interesting and creative shops, workshops and cafes around. Best photo taking spot! Love this place!

review_title: Picturesque like back to the old time
review_body: Picturesque! A nice tranquil walk in the residential area, i feel like I'm back to the old times. But this tranquil walk can become very annoying if there are few groups of tour surrounding you. Since I'm going there free & easy, I just let them walk in front of me, so that i can have some peaceful walk and some nice pictures.

Bukchon Village was truly incredible and I was able to experience what life used to be years ago. As you visit you're required to speak on a minimal tone of voice to not disturb the people living in the area. Within the village you will be able to find souvenirs made by the locals.

On a sunny day this place is a must. It has been the highlight of our stay in Seoul. Awesome atmosphere very well preserved area gives you a very nice feeling of relaxation and how traditional areas looked like

review_title: It could be the highlight of your visit
review_body: A quaint little village with a community feel. (now gentrified) The houses are done with tiled roofs and stone in narrow alleys. You could easily spend the whole day walking around here. There are some cute shops, good food, pancakes were yummy, coffee, etc THere are a lot of tourists and locals on weekends. But hey, everybody wants a piece of history to soak in, right? It is also very close to the palaces. We stayed in one of the houses - Hanok style houses and it was easy to explore the area. The family we stayed with were very kind and cheerful people. The room itself was a bit disappointing. We expected a little original (after having stayed in a similar type of house in kaesong, in North Korea) but they seem to have plasticised stuff. So it felt a bit synthetic. There could be other homestays that are possibly in its original state. THere are museums and various tours that you could do. There are also cyclos that take you around the area, highlighting the important landmarks.

Bukchon is a a neighborhood close to the palace. From a very busy street, you take a turn towards Bukchon village and suddenly you are between low rise, old houses in small streets. Many small shops and not the ones that sell the same souvenirs. No, each shop has its own fingerprint. A very nice mix of modern and traditional.

review_title: A glimpse of traditional villages in Korea
review_body: One place that I would hope to visit again someday. It gives a cultural glimpse of the old life in Korea. The houses and streets are clean and quaint.

You can find a map of this area in most places. If you walk up the road next to Changdeokgung Palace you will reach the traditional houses. You can then make your way back down through the area, which has lots of cafes and traditional restaurants. It is between the 2 palaces.

review_title: Old neighborhood in a modern city
review_body: I recommend taking a coffee break there. It is a nice neighborhood with old houses next to the palace. A nice view of the city and lovely houses done like in the old times. Tourists information guys are at the entrances and will offer you an explanation and a map to a self tour with the mail attractions ofbthe neighborhood

I visit this place so many times, and every single time the experience proves to be different. On days when you're lucky, there ain't that many tourists or students, so you can roam around in peace while making the most out of the rustic ambience. Do give the croquette shop a try (there's only one along the way so you will definitely spot it! :))

walking around this area is so delightful, taking you back in time through the winding streets past the traditional houses. there will be lots of other tourists walking as well, but somehow it is still peaceful as mostly car free. This area is easily accessible and you can combine it with Insadong or the Folk Museum. Take your camera and follow the online TripAdvisor walking tour, or pick up a brochure from the tourist hotel.

review_title: It is nice to walk around and feel the culture
review_body: although it is a distance (around 1km) from subway and need to walk uphill. It is worth to go there and walk around so you can see the old style houses and feel the culture. scenery up there is nice which you can see folk museum from top view.

review_title: Lovely stroll in a traditional Hanok village
review_body: This provides an insight into the traditional Korean Hanok housing. Highly recommended to take a stroll through the many and little alleys for a close look at the Hanok housing. Don't be afraid to walk through the alleys which can be rather quiet. A few of these housings have been turned into commercial with homestay hotels and shops. So do take some time if you wish to take a glimpse of the interior of the Hanok houses.It is a real hilly walk at some areas, especially at Bukchon-ro-11-gil but at that highest point, you get to see the rooftop of the Hanok housing...real beautiful.Wear good shoes/ sneakers.

If you like traditional architecture, here you would be looking at the traditional houses of Korea, there are even places where they offer lodging korean style. Nice place to visit. There is also the school where they filmed Winter Sonata.
If you wanna know some traditional korean culture, then you can visit here :) You can also try wearing traditional korean costume and have picture taking :)

It's a nice to walk around this neighborhood surrounded by old houses. There are a few small museums you can enter for a small fee. The area is very local with very few tourists roaming around while I was there.
Lovely place with traditional Korean houses, but you'll need to walk quite a bit. Good for photography. Nice view :)

I have rather mixed feelings about Bukchon. The area is itself really neat and it's great to walk around. Don't forget to wear your walking shoes because it's uphill.But you'll see listings for all these museums where you can experience Korean culture. We checked one out and were pretty underwhelmed. I felt like we'd been ripped off. We also ate at this kinda fancy restaurant and paid 'way too much. Perhaps it's because beef is super expensive in Korea. Service was great and all, but it was really expensive.Still, if you've got some time, this is a great place to explore.

review_title: Where we can see traditional korean house
review_body: Here we can see the traditional korean house, small street left right traditional korean house with some art shops...and cafe in beginning of street....i like this area very much !
Like the title says. 15 minutes is enough. It's just a suburban area with a couple of authentic but modern renovated....

Bukchon offers a blend of old and new. As you wander the streets you will find very traditional Hanok houses and more modern dwellings interspersed with galleries, shops and boutiques. Samcheong-dong Street also offers lots of trendy boutiques and stores and is great for people watching.
Its really nice to walk in this village but it can be crowded becuse it is a tourist place so it well be better if you go early .

A very cultural and interesting to go to.. All the unique designs of the houses and street.. Do visit the place to experience the cultural feel. Will visit again and maybe stay in one of the houses if possible. Wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of walking to do.
Very nice little alley of traditional houses. Located up the mountains therefore might be tiring to go there with older people.
Visited without staying. If i have a chance again. I will definitely try to the homestay here. It just feels very different and would be nice to experience the korean culture.

review_title: A Must to Visit when in Seoul
review_body: A nice and lovely traditional Korean Village! A great surrounding, a lovely area!Nice place for picture taking, go early so you will not have hundreds of tourists in the pictures!

This was a very interesting tour . Some of the old houses are fantastic the streets are narrow and the front doors are a art in themselves . Some of the houses are not so old . People must get annoyed with tourists being there everyday so you can understand way the halls are high and private . Great craftsmanship in some of the buildings . The history of some of them is very interesting . There are a few shops in between like a soap shop jewellery shop and a gift and puppet shop
Its nice to go here on a sunny day when you can walk around and enjoy the beauty of the old buildings. They also have some small unique shops in the area.

review_title: A lovely traditional village, tranquil and pretty.
review_body: Loving this place! Not just the traditional houses, the surrounding area is such a lovely place to visit. I wished that I had stayed in one of the traditional hanok guest houses here, it would have been a good experience.

review_title: Little to see, nothing to do and full of people and cars
review_body: Very disappointing. The photos in the tourist guides looked lovely but the reality was thousands of tourists and because this is still a residential area all the streets and lanes were filed with parked cars (can only assume they were paid to park elsewhere when photos were taken or photoshopped out of the pictures in the guides) we stayed 20 minutes, took obligatory photos and left.

It was like you were being transported to the time Dae Jang Gyeum, the lead actress in the Korean Soap,Opera Jewel in the Palace, had the chance the wear the Hanbok, charming, I feel like an empress, i got the glimpse of how the past was for the Koreans, their houses was about the same with Filipino houses,
Found a free walking tour and went with a very nice lady guide. She showed us all the interesting spots. A nice tour for sure
Walking the streets and looking at all of the old historic houses was really neat. I'm glad I just so happen to stumble across this as I was exploring the city of Seoul.

I was really excited before going but in reality it's just modern versions of old houses in a residential area. Some good cafes and shops in the area but wouldn't go out of my way to go there (I was staying near by).

After a day at the palace take some time to stroll through through Bukchon and get a feel for the seoul of old. Slate roofed houses seemingly built on top of one another on the side of a mountain nestled with restaurants galleries street food....a must see. Through the neighborhood takes you back down towards Insagong were even more treats and sights await. Take it all in!!

Have you ever been to the oldest part in your hometown ? How do you like it ? In Bukchon there are several old-stle houses. And almost all refurbished and in good condition. So if you are near to Bukchon, just jump in. If not, don't worry.

A long established neighborhood of traditional Korean architecture nestled within site of the modern high rises of Seoul. Visiting Bukchon allows one to experience and appreciated the materials and style of yesterday's Korea. Very nice and upscale shops and galleries are sprinkled throughout the area.
Go in the morning to avoid crowds. Bukchon has beautiful little streets, interesting rooftops, and is worth an hour's visit.

The Bukchon Hanook village is a site to behold because of the ancestral houses being preserved by the owners. The place will let you see how they lived before and see the type of life they have before.

Talk about tradition. If you want to enjoy Korean traditional homes from 500 years ago check this place out its Beautiful you can even go into some of the homes if its possible do itIt's a unique opportunity in the heart of a giant city
This old city is amazing nice.....many old buildings with many very nice shops and galleries everywhere
Love this town, its so ancient feel, all the house and doors are so small, short. It feels really peaceful here.

We went here with friends who were living in Seoul at the time. They wanted to show us a contrasting version of downtown Seoul, which is very modern and fast paced. This street was great to see how old Seoul used to be. It was charming and a nice change of pace. I would recommend visiting if you're in the area. This wasn't close to where we were staying so getting here took some time and you only need about an hour here. This is a very popular spot for pictures amongst tourists and Korean families. Also know that this area is hilly.

This is residential area where most of the houses are still the traditional Hanok houses but since most doors are close you can only get a glimpse of the rooftops and doorways. There are some souvenir or artist shops that are open for tourist but it doesn't really give you the real feel- I guess for that you really need to stay on one those Hanok guest houses .

We felt like this area's charm was exaggerated. Pretty but not much to do besides take a quick stroll and maybe grab a bite to eat. Various guidebooks had advised us to spend several hours there, but we didn't understand the appeal.
The place is bit overrated, it's a residential area with bunch of old fashion design houses, not much to see really

the old houses in Bukcon are lovely and unique .i love those houses, but be prepared to walk up and down hill withgood comfort shoes and umbrella during summer.sometimes, you will notice young girls wearing traditional korea costumes andreally impressive and lovely.

review_title: Live Maze in Old Street of Seoul
review_body: place must visit when you travel to Seoul, old style houses and street and friendly local. buddy and i visit this place right after Gyeongbokgung Palace. Collect "maze map" in Bukchon tourist information center before start your long walk (^^,) we spend approximately 2-3hours in this huge place and visit almost all of the attraction in the map. really tiring walk after completion but worth it with the nice windy whether and interesting cultural houses.

Located near Gyeongbokgung Palace. Wear good walking shoes! The hills can be quite steep. This is a MUST visit. The area is beautiful and the traditional hanok houses are so interesting to look at and photograph. There were also museums (closed on Mon) and quaint cafes located within the bukchon area. Go to the Bukchon Traditional Culture Center (9am to 6pm daily) located near Anguk Station Exit 3 to get a walking map 1st. Bukchon is located in Samcheong-dong which is a very nice area filled with cafes, restaurants, unique shops. You can spend hours walking around this area. One of the nicer shopping areas with cheap pricing in Seoul.
My wife and I enjoyed getting lost in the small streets and pretending to be in a different time. You just have to block the hordes of tourists. Not to be missed to get a taste of traditional Korea.
A steep and winding road up a hill. The buildings are old, but only 100 or so years. Gives a bit of an insight about traditional homes, but crowded with tourists and a little over rated.
It is fun to walk around the area. Especially the little craft shops inside or the small cafe's. It is close to the palace!

The amount of legwork required to tour this place took away the enthusiasm that I initially had. It felt like we were traversing a cultural maze that had a small intersection in every turn. It was a constant mind boggling decision as to which direction to take to fully appreciate our visit. We had no one to tell us where to go and what to do. We just made a quick stop at the tourist information office where we got a map of the village and off we went. Looking back, that was certainly not a great idea. But we were clueless as to the availability of a guide anyway, so we didn't have much of a choice. The traditional looking houses in the village appeared to have local residents living inside. So practically, this was a peek of the actual traditional Korean village. It was quite an interesting experience, but we got too exhausted to a point that regret surfaced at the end of our walking tour. If you don't mind going for an exercise while on vacation, then this should worth your consideration.

Quaint little village with small alleys and interesting architecture. If you have the time and money, visit or try out the classes and attractions offered. If not, just strolling thru them with give you a view of old Korea. Most tourist maps will provide you a detailed path/ journey in experiencing Bukchon without getting lost. Wear comfortable shoes as some areas are steep and requires some effort walking or climbing u stairs. Food establishments are located towards the south part of the attraction.

review_title: View of the streets of old Seoul
review_body: The area is easy to reach although it requires waling up some steep paths to view. The buildings have residents and you can only view them from the outside, most appear to have some sort of restoration, which you would expect if people are expected to inhabit them.
