It gives you a feel though of what the area was originally like, with tight lanes and small building with strong doors. If you climb up the hills follow the signs to the observatory where you can climb the stairs in a building to the top where you get a view looking down on the area. You are charged 3000won each and get a free tea or fruit juice for every person, well worth the price.
It goes by really fast and you just might miss it. It is almost like walking into a time machine, I had no idea it was one of the top-rated sites to see until I looked it up.

review_title: Definitely worth spending some time in
review_body: We stayed in a beautiful here knock in the village, and wondered around well in the area. Really enjoyed just exploring the streets, which were surprisingly quiet for a summer day! It's pretty fascinating to see all of the little details you can find on the buildings and doors etc. Several great look out points also to see larger areas of the city or of the village.
We went in the morning and walked around- got some great pictures of our kids in the empty streets surrounded by the cool architecture. We went in April 2014.

I can only advise something ; woke up early to take the best picture of all when practically nobody will disturb you while taking the best shot! Bukchon is one of the best hanok in Seoul and notice the arch and sculpture that each house reflect certainly is an one in a lifetime experience!

review_title: Overall a nice area but few accessible houses
review_body: This is a nice area to walk through if you have time. Except for one house open to tourists, the rest seem to be private homes which seem to be nice but of which tourists can only have a peek through fences.
This is worth the walk to see the traditional houses and to get a view of the city through the smog. It is a bit confusing but just follow the others and head uphill.

For someone who has never been in Asia, it is impressive. It was the first thing I saw in Korea and it was really nice. Also we were very lucky cause there was a show and they were selling food and things in all the area.

review_title: Architectural highlight in Seoul to walk around
review_body: We spent a few hours on an afternoon walking around the recommended tour from the information centre. Absolutely beautiful original style Korean architecture. History is everywhere you look here. There are also a couple of cultural centres you can visit and check out the local art and craft. The whole family enjoyed this walk. It is a little hilly in spots, but just take it easy and it is fine. I would definitely visit this place again if ever back in Seoul.

Walked around this whole area from the slightly more modern shopping area and streets and food stalls, to the hanok village which was very quaint and charming (though some uphill bits!) Some great street art too.
Nice area but not a place where i would start off to get to know. Seoul. In that case i would go first to myeong dong area and surroundings

review_title: Like the Hutong in Beijing but much cleaner
review_body: Good for an hour of walkabout as this is not exactly a designated tourism spot, and people are still actually living here although some houses already coverted into Hanoks, so be discreet when wondering around. I am not saying that people are unfriendly but you can be treated as intruders.

Should spend 1-2 hour(s) walking around the village (early in the morning or late in the afternoon will help you stay away from tourists group if you prefer some quiet own time). Then find your way down to Samcheongdong for a tea house experience.

Had a layover in Seoul and since it was already after 6pm we thought this was the best thing to do so we could get a feel of Seoul before heading back to the airport. Saw both temples from the outside and got good photos as the sun set. It was disappointing that none of the art studios were open. I would recommend if you feel like having a wonder around an artsy part of Seoul.
We walked to Bukchon just before sunset and caught great views of Seoul- a mixture of the old traditional buildings and the new ones. Lots of lovely shops, restaurants and photo opportunities

We had limited time to visit a Hanok village away from Seoul and thought of settling for one just right inside Seoul. Took a train to Anguk station, visit the museum, walk pass the palace and reach there in approx 20 mins. It's away from the main street and you need to make a short climb up the steep slopes to visit various photograph spots. Best to visit before sky turns dark. It is a living community with various signs asking to keep noises down.
Cozy houses show the old times of Seoul. Impressive views of the city and you can appreciate the contrast between old Seoul and Modern Seoul. Be prepared to walk, since there are many steep streets.
Lots of shops, restaurants, ice cream and beautiful architecture. A must visit location in Seoul.......

There are good spots for a picture taking, they are numbered and there's a direction to go there, you just have to follow it since it is quite clear. It has a beautiful view on every spot. The traditional houses are unique and so beautiful. Don't forget to wear shoes instead of heels to get through the steep streets. Too bad I came on 7pm so I could not get a good picture, but the view was superb since you can see the Namsan tower and the city lights clearly.

review_title: Small area , just couple of streets
review_body: Here i had my usual problem : how can i find it ? At the end i could. As all of tourists . The most photographed street is on the top of the hill .

Its fun to see the Korean traditional houses from outside. But there werent many opportunities to see them from within really. You'd either have to pay for a workshop to get in or something. It wasnt very big either, a little disappointing overall.
Authentic old Seoul, on the hills. Some hipster shops, tasty street food, but not an amusement park at all, meaning it is authentic.

I enjoyed myself a lot just strolling through this village. Its a good contrast to the urban and modern developed part of Seoul. Id recommend this for those who are interested in culture, history and tradition.

Got a map and it shows a lot to explore the entire buchok hanok village! There are hundreds of houses with different designs of roofs, walls, doors, stairs, and if you love the mix of modern ancient architectures, you will love it. Try to enter some houses, there might have display of arts. Feel really like a local! It could take hours to explore, but you need not to visit the entire place! Some houses need a fee to enter.

Bukchon is very atmospheric, featuring many buildings in the traditional hanoak style. But that's the problem -- they're largely just in hanoak style, not actually vintage or historic buildings. In fact, knocking down an old hanoak to replace it with a new building in hanoak style is a common practice. That said, Bukchon is one of the last places in Seoul, maybe the last place, to see a traditional roofscape uninterrupted by multistory modern buildings. Definitely worth visiting for that, as well as some for the specialty shopping, small private museums and independent cafes and restaurants.

Had to come here since a lot of K-dramas are filmed here. Coming from the States and getting a chance to walk where these beautiful homes are was surreal. The day we went they were doing a cosplay photoshoot very nice so we saw Hollywood types following the actress/model.

review_title: A good introduction to the hanok architecture around in Seoul
review_body: The Bukchon area is relatively challenging as a climb, and not the most conducive for family travel, if you have children and old folks with you who tend to be very slow or shy away from exercise. Technically, the Bukchon area is accessible from Samcheongdong right at the end of Samcheong-ro, and via a pair of long staircases, you climb up to the top of the hill where you can see these traditional hanok (Korean houses). The area is still inhabited by locals, so you are advised to keep your speaking voice relatively low and quiet when walking around the area, and especially as the day draws to a close, even if you do desire to see the sunset and distant parts of Seoul from an elevation around this Bukchon hanok area, do take care not to scream, shout or talk loudly. This area is arguably one of the few areas in Seoul which still manages to preserve the traditional Korean hanok architecture very well, despite regular tourism.

review_title: Ginseng Chicken - expect a 45 mins wait
review_body: Bukchon is the location where we had their famous ginseng chicken (a whole spring chicken stuffed with glutinous rice and ginseng). The shop we went to was famous - we got there at nearly 11am and had a seat immediately (after only 15mins wait) , but by the time we finished lunch about 12ish the queue outside the shop stretched more than 500km - the shopkeeper told us it would be a 45 mins wait on average. The local guide with us told us that koreans dont go to this shop - it catered to tourists and an "authentic shop" for koreans were situated just 3 streets away. however, to this tourist's taste, this experience was good enough. Being accustomed to the chinese style of ginseng soup which is of a stronger taste, the korean ginseng chicken experience was quite mild. they give you a small glass of ginseng wine to drink or mix into your soup, which was quite interesting.
Great walking neighborhood with lots of traditional Hanok huts. Near Insadong shopping and dining, palaces.

We loved Bukchon. The whole area is just perfect for spending a day. It is a traditional Korean village. When you're there make sure to visit one of the little stores that has the traditional Korean Hanbok's of the King and Queen. Great souvenir photos. Enjoy!

It was nice to see the lovely homes. Definitely bring your walking shoes, and be prepared to be walking drenched in sweat if you are going in the summer, as we did today. Looked like there were quite a few options for food and other refreshments. While walking around, we saw a sign for the Institute of Traditional Korean Cuisine, however we were sad to find it was closed. In fact, many little shops and galleries looked closed due to it being Sunday. We did go into the home of Go Hui-dong who was Korea's first artist who painted in the Western style. A staff member gave us a little tour of his home which also featured his artwork.

We did a walking tour of this village. Sort of reminds me of parts of San Francisco, USA. Quaint little streets and shops nestled on the hillsides. A ton of walking so have you most comfortable shoes.

The beautiful houses... the neighbourhood filled with shops... we saw many fruit vendors cruising the street selling things off the back of their trucks... nice first day for us.The streets are narrow, so be mindful... we also found the Korean drivers to be a little... hmm... aggressive? Stay on your toes as a pedestrian (and buckle up if you're a passenger).Definitely take a walk through here... and bring your camera.
I got lost moving around this hanok village but it was worth the time. Lovely lines of Korean traditional houses. Next time I come to Korea, I'll definitely stay in a hanok.

review_title: One of Seoul's most interesting & charming neighborhoods
review_body: Bukchon is one of Seoul's most interesting and charming neighborhoods; it's full of 'hanok' -- traditional tile roofed houses -- as well as museums and galleries. In fact, Bukchon has become somewhat gentrified and prettified, so it's the opposite of gritty old working class neighborhoods like Mapo-gu; but Bukchon didn't have a Disneyland feel, either. You can get a very helpful map of the neighborhood ('Bukchon Wanderings') from the Bukchon Jaedong Tourist Information Center, which is just a few blocks north of the Anguk subway station; take exit 2 and walk north on Gahoe-ro (street). Since Bukchon is right next to Changdeokgung, I'd suggest taking the tour of the Secret Garden (unlike the rest of the palace, the Piwon is only open to those on a guided tour) and then exploring Bukchon, which also has a host of good and generally very affordable restaurants; after doing the tour of the Biwon, which is enormous, you may want to eat and rest your feet for a bit~!

to much alley at Bukchon and really confused to found the best alley. so, we try to ask and found the maps to seen the Bukchon alley. there's a couple houses with traditional Korean things, not to much. but I loves it.enjoy the alley with little rainy, so romantic :D

we wanted to go to bukchon because the pictures looked great. however, we should have stuck with the pictures. the real thing is so-so. not sure if we went to the wrong side of the bukchon village but there were also other tourists with us and so we were confident that it was the correct place.
It was a peek into the real Seoul, we were quiet and the neighborhood was most enjoyable. Lovely houses and a nice view from the top of the village.

This is a neighborhood in Seoul that includes numerous houses that are hundreds of years old and are beautiful to visit. Keep in mind that this is a neighborhood where people live, so as the signs advise, keep the noise to a minimum.

This was a really nice place to stroll. There is a tourism office that provides maps and the buildings are lovely to take it. There are shops, boutiques and cafes all along the way to make the walk more interesting.Be sure to stop at the craft center - it is a fun diversion!
Get a feel for a traditional Korean village and home. Narrow streets and alleys so it's easier to walk than drive. Stay in a hanok to get a real flavor of Korean tradition. Great breakfasts!

A village full of 600 year old houses (hanok) within walking distance of Changdeokgung Palace in the midst of urban development is simply amazing.The house owners are nice to accommodate having thousands of people plying their streets taking gazillions of photos. Especially considering as most of them are quite wealthy being able to afford these prime real estate & heritage houses. It was nice to walk the various alleyways & just see where the sageuks are filmed. We took a photo in one of the alleyways overlooking the city & one wearing korean traditional costume & have that as background. It's actually cool.
Such an amazing place with great history. We see Bukchon in Korean dramas and we thought of it as so beautiful. Seeing it in person made our trip worthwhile.

review_title: The perfect taste of traditional Seoul
review_body: It's obviously not the most authentic traditional village but what do you expect when it's so conveniently located between two of Seoul's most popular palaces? There maybe a few tourists milling about but the streets are still very beautiful and there are numerous cute cafes well worth a stop at. I'd definitely recommend taking the time to explore these tiny side streets to break up your palace sightseeing in Seoul

The streets are of the ancient past, however, very much renovated to add the modern feel. Hence to me, it has lost its ancient feel a lot. I walked for 15 minutes and was done. The rest of shops along the surrounding streets are almost 100% western and modern shops like café, coffee, souvenirs.

review_title: Good starting point for your Bugaksan day trip
review_body: The Bukchon Hanok Village was a nice place to stroll through. I enjoyed looking at the architecture, but it just seemed like a residential area, so it was a little weird just looking at people's homes. There were a few open doors for museums, craft shops, and restaurant, but not too many. I didn't really know where to go, so we just wandered around, and it was interesting. This by itself is not enough of a draw, but it is at the base of the Bugaksan Mountain, which is definitely worth visiting. So you can go here for an hour in the morning, then take the bus up the mountain, and spend the rest of the day hiking.
Quite and traditional walk in South Korea, we can have a nice half day walk. Don't miss the cafe with waffle and icecream or coffee in afternoon
Did not really find anything very interesting on my trip to Bukchon. Therefore would not be revisiting when i am in Seoul.

I highly recommend this Hanuk village. The architecture is tremendous and at residence tells a story of a bygone era. We actually stayed 3 nights in Hanuk accommodation and would visit there in a heartbeat.
Great architecture, beautiful view of Seuol, has some boutique shops that makes it more interesting to rest and catch your breath. Steep climb at times.
However there were a lot of tourists, so you might not be able to take good photos. But anyway, the traditional homes that were there are vibrant and peaceful.
The Bukchon Hanok village was an interesting journey through a collection of traditional wooden houses. The hills make the view of the centre of Seoul. This is a "must do" walk for visitors.

Nice to see a slice of historic Seoul. Go to the Bukchon Traditional Culture Center and pick up the English brochure Bukchon Wanderings. It gives a map of all the must see views (great photos) and you can shop around along the way.A note about transportation. Rather than using the metro and wandering around to find something we took cabs. Orange cabs are very cheap, we never spent more than six dollars and that is on the high end. Cab drivers don't expect tips but if it was a small amount we did.

review_title: Nice area with traditional Hanok houses
review_body: Nice area to just stroll around. The Bukchon hanok village has a lot of narrow cosy streets with traditional "hanok" wooden houses. Recommend to go up in Bukchon observatory (3000 KRW pr person). From there you get a good view over the hanok village roofs and across to N Seoul tower in Namsan.
Beautiful village with amazing old houses. Have a tranquil walk around, and take in the age-old scenery.

This wasn't my favorite place in Korea. If you're in the area, it's worth the stop to walk through, but don't spend more than 30 minutes here. Most of what there is to see costs (like small art museums only one room big) and isn't worth it (in this artist's opinion). If you're in seoul for a short time, go do something bigger like Myeongdong or Bukhansan instead.

review_title: A must see during your visit to Seoul
review_body: Bukchon is a small traditional area located an easy subway trip from central Seoul. It is famous for the traditional wooden houses that are dotted around the area. It is also the home to the Prime Minister of Korea - although his house is rather more grand. The area is great for a pleasant stroll so that you can take in the sights and also create some great photos of the old houses with Seoul's rising skyline in the background. There is a small tourist office which provides a free walking map - not the best map in the world admittedly - however it's enough to show you where the main photo opportunities are and enough to get you back on track when you inevitably get lost around the myriad tiny alleyways.The area is however quite hilly in parts so perhaps not suitable for all travellers. There are also a couple of palaces nearby although I didn't get the chance to visit - from a distance however they looked impressive.
This is a nice place to take pictures of the old buildings. Go all the way up for the best photo spots! Nice cafes around.

I was taken here by a local work colleague so that I could see the traditional old Korean buildings..I thought they were beautiful and a lovely walk up and down hilly streets. We found some respite from the heat in a tea house which was cool and served the most amazing fruit teas. I could have spent alot more time here..!

review_title: Good place to visit for a morning walk
review_body: Most of the old homes (hanoks) have been restored, and it's fun to walk up and down the neighborhood streets in among the old houses. As you go higher you can sometimes get a peek into the interior courtyards of the buildings. As the day goes by, more and more tourists arrive. This can make for some fun people watching as the tourists pose for pictures among the old buildings. When you reach the top and are done exploring the hanoks, head up the road near the top that borders the neighborhood to the left. Eventually you will come to a staircase on the left that will take you down a winding path to the main street far below. Along the way keep an eye out for the bar/cafe on the left side of the path called "Ontheground". This is a fun place to stop for refreshment and a chat with the friendly owners.

This large area is suitable for slow strolls and lots of picture taking. Make sure to get a pamphlet with the 10? views of Bukchon and get the cameras ready. You can see many traditional styled buildings and alleys. Many of the hanoks can be rented as a house stay for a reasonable price. There are many hanoks converted to restaurants, tea houses, museums, etc... The wall through the views are very hilly. Don't do it in a hot day. At places up high, you can see good views of the surrounding areas and mountains.

review_title: A walk in royal history of Seoul
review_body: This neighborhood is best to visit early in am or late at night, when it is not overrun with tourists and "selfies" . There a few streets, which are highly picturesque with older homes, located between the two palaces. We stayed in a real, legitimate :Hanok here (a Korean style high end B&B)

It is located in a hilly area. Wear a pair of comfortable shoes to walk around. It is like a time travel to see traditional houses first thing in the morning to beat the crowd. Peaceful and beautiful. Worth to visit while in Seoul.

Must visit if interested in traditional Korean architecture. Many excellent, well-preserved private houses (and some B&Bs) in a quiet district for the well-heeled. Nice area to walk around (only marred by noisy tour groups from China sad to say, despite signs saying to please keep noise level down). Stop at Books Cooks for tea (see my review for this cosy joint).

review_title: A fun day to wander through.
review_body: Definitely go see. It's even better during the lotus lantern festival time. The streets and shops are decorated with brightly colored lanterns and there's a celebratory air about the city.
This was one of my favourite places to visit in Seoul. It's very beautiful and special. Gives that older day feel. Definitely a place to see while you are visiting Seoul.
it is a quiet and beautiful street during Winter. There are shops and restaurant in this place. One of the best place during our trip here.

review_title: A great traditional experience without leaving the capital
review_body: This is a fantastic place for people to visit who want to see a traditional Korean environment without travelling outside of Seoul. Also good for K-Pop fans
It is a street with soul you have to feel it. There is a lot of small restaurants with virtually everything. Nice view from the top of the district.

review_title: For traditional walk through the villages
review_body: We went here on our last day and so glad we did. We spent approximately 4 hour strolling through the lane ways and walking into the traditional shops. We found lovely secluded coffee shops along the way which we had some wonderful iced coffee to cool ourselves down. Take some good walking shoes as climbing the hills is a must. You get to look down on the traditional roofs. If you follow the signs they will lead you to where you can obtain a map which marks out the walking routes to follow. Of course we got totally lost and went our own way but that is half the fun! Again there are more shops and some that specialised in arts and crafts. One of the highlights of our trip.
different style of the traditional korean house are right here. but you have to walk up and down to see all different house, sport shoes is better

Bukchon is a traditional Korean village, composed of several neighborhoods. It is composed of several narrow alleys.It has more than 600 years of history, allowing the visitors to experience the atmosphere of the Joseon dinasty.Some of the recently renewed houses can be visited for a cost.
Bukchon Village with winding streets, traditional building, shops and restaurants is a nice place to spend couple of hours wondering around. If you have an extra time it is worth seeing.

review_title: This is a very interesting part of the city
review_body: It is like a city within a city and most of the homes are preserved with the old ways of building. Lots of shopping too! Make sure you have comfy shoes on for this tour.
Nice stroll around old houses although some of them seemed very modern! There are many nice shops from local designers and a few nice cafes albeit very expensive!

review_title: Lovely area to walk and shop!
review_body: This was a perfect area to walk around, shop and eat for the day. Very close to Insadong and I actually like the shops a little better. While they were a little pricey and less like a market, it was quieter, quaint boutique shopping. This was probably my favorite area in Seoul!

Its Nice if you were to visit early mornings otherwise this place swell by noon time with large crowd of Camera touting tourist from all over the world !! Wonderful Traditional Houses You must look out for the Old Quiant corner where you find traditional simple food is being served !! Delicious

If you want to see a residential area in Seoul without all of the hustle and bustle of tourists, Bukchon is the place for you.Located north of the more busy Insadong area, it provides a contrast to the rest of Seoul. A lot of signs around the neighborhood telling you to keep quiet because its a residential area.Here you can see the Bukchon Hanok Village, which is an area with the traditional houses and little shops and cafes for the tourists that do make it out here.For an experience of the real Seoul, we recommend visiting this place.

Such a quaint place.. love everything about it, even the long hike up the hills. It was like a gem in the city.. there is one spot where you get to the highest point you can see the modern seoul at the back, simply breathtaking. I love the shops and cafes, they were all attractive looking. Loved this one fragrance shop called "Granhand". I hope I can go again to Bukchon taking my time and just wandering around there.

This beautiful part of Seoul is best seen on a nice cool sunny day. Lots of uphill walking, so wear your most comfortable sneakers. I walked all the way up til I can get a good view of namsan. The houses were beautiful and the shops around were awesome. Bukchon, together with samcheong ro can occupy your whole day. So many things to see and do.

review_title: Experience Korean traditional village, smacked in Seoul metropolitan
review_body: This place of interest has many narrow walkway uphill and downhill where you can see the house from previous Seoul era. Many of them has classical outlook, bamboo, wood, traditional roof tiles. They are not just for viewing, these are actual houses where local are still living in it. At here, time has rewind, back to the olden days. You will forget that you are in a busy metropolitan, as if you are still in the classical era.https://vinshengloh.exposure.co/butcheon-traditional-village

the place shows how life in korea was before all the modernization came about,beautiful houses some converted to become inns and restaurants/cafes. a definite must go to place for the arts and culture buff
It is, really, a piece of history lost in time. But ancient houses are scarse, not so well maintained. Other regions, around the palaces, exhibit same architecture.
Very scenic area with the traditional hanoks and great photography time. Nice strolls up and down the allies finding little hidden surprises.
Bukchon is a nice cultural place. Beautiful and quiet place for a stroll. The scenery there are priceless and to understand more of their traditional cultures there too.

It’s nice if you visit early mornings otherwise this place swell by noon time with large crowd of Camera touting tourist from all over the world !! Wonderful Traditional Houses You must look out for the Old Quiant corner where you find traditional simple food is being served !! Delicious
Good eats...if you sneak up into small alleys...sweet people...cool stuff to see. Shop for jewelry or clothes...or enjoy a romantic cup of coffee

review_title: Interesting hanoks and peeking into the lives of the locals
review_body: If you happen to be in the area, especially the Gyeongbokgung Palace and/or Changdeokgung Palace, this place should be on your to visit list. This would be my second visit, the first time was during the day and the second time was at night.Samcheong-dong is near to Gyeongbokgung Palace and is relatively near to Cheong Wa Dae (the Blue House a.k.a the President’s Office) and Insadong; both of which are tourist spots worth to visit. To get there just alight at the some subway station stop (Anguk Station, Subway Line No. 3) for Gyeongbokgung Palace.Just follow the signs and you will find yourself at Samcheong-dong, one of the most unique places in Seoul where there is the hanok (traditional house made out of wood and put together without any nails) Bukchon Village. Samcheong-dong is a beautiful neighborhood and will definitely take more than half a day to take in the sights.As it was evening time, there were many students on their way home after school and the crowd was lessened as compared to the last time I was there. It was literally an uphill task… it’s a hilly area with pretty steep slopes. We passed by a couple of familiar shops, but the night setting gave the area a slightly different feel and made it even more of an adventure.Walking through the neighborhood peppered with both the traditional and modern is an enjoyable activity: some hanoks are occupied by residents while some are into chic galleries, restaurants, cafés and accessory shops. And while you are here, don't forget to eat the yummy street food!For more on my experience and photos, please check out my blog: http://www.travelbytez.com/2013/09/samcheong-dong-bukchon-village-food.htmland http://www.travelbytez.com/2015/05/bukchon-village-at-night.html
This place is good for sightseeing and cafe hopping. It's quiet along the routes within the residential areas but nothing spectacular. Nice to have a walk around but not a must to go.

review_title: Gem of Seoul, not often known
review_body: We only explore this old part of the city in our recent trip. Close to the palaces, museums, presidential house, and, importantly, gorgeous mountains, small shops and eateries are fun and enjoyable.

Explored around the traditional Bukchon Hanok homes area today. The area is surrounded by Gyeongbokgung Palace, Changdeokgung Palace and Jongmyo Shrine,and is home to hundreds of traditional houses that date back to the Joseon Dynasty. Very colorful neighborhoods and many of these hanoks operate as coffee shops, cultural centers, guesthouses, restaurants and tea houses. After exiting the subway at anjuk, just look for the Hyundai HQ and head up the hill. So much to see.

It was a very nice tour to experience the old style Korean houses. They have it's own style and are beautiful. The place is unique, quiet & clean. Please be considered to keep quiet when we visit there as there are people living in the houses.

review_title: Okay for sightseeing, but wouldn't waste too much time.
review_body: It's pretty nice to see the traditional Korean homes, but asides from that this place was kind of boring. A lot of the houses are occupied with real tenants so you can't really explore any of them unless you book a room at one through airbnb.

This village is close to the two biggest palaces, so it's convinient to combine visits together. As many other areas in Seoul, this one is hilly, so prepare for climbing. Not many activities except looking at the traditional houses. Anyway, worth checking it out to grasp the atmosphere of many-faced Seoul.
Its a place where you can see a korean traditional village. Check out the local house. Dont forget to visit the gift store where you can get the kpop merchandise.
this village is located in the city and can see lots of students do their activities here ..nice view ...

review_title: Take a free tour with Visit Seoul
review_body: "Seoul City Walking Tours" is a free program offered by the city of Seoul designed for tourists who want to see Seoul’s top tourist attractions on foot under the expert guidance of multilingual tour guides. Reservations for this program can be made via the internet and mobile web at www.visitseoul.net.No tipping is necessary. We took a free City tour of these villages and it was great!! Our guide new all the alleyways and which paths to take to see the best sights and views. She also gave us much more info on the area and history that we would not have gotten if we had walked this area on our own. I highly recommend booking a guide with visit Seoul! The Bukchon village is not to be missed!! It gives you a glimpse into traditional Korean living.

Taking a walk through the traditional village of Bukchon was a great experience. This isolated area of Seoul was a pleasant surprise in contrast to the rest of of the city that is fast-paced and busy. It was good to see that some of the tradition of Korea had been preserved, although it is just a small area. I would recommend a visit to this area.

Tourists can go to this place before going to palaces. This is near to Changdeokgung Palace. There's a simple reminder for tourists to keep silence as a respect for the residents.Very nice place to take pictures.!

Going here, Chungmuro station then exit 3. It's the 2nd block from the exit, after Korea House.There's no admission ticket. I guess its because of the cultural week. The traditional houses/rooms and cook ware was well maintained. Upon the entrance, there were men who's on cultural outfit, who were weaving traditional baskets, shoes and etc.There was even a traditional wedding held yesterday. The bride and groom's attire was really beautiful.Even the traditional bed and pillows were well maintained.It was a very good experience of traditional korean life. N Seoul Tower is near the area through NAMSAN TOUR bus.

Visited Bukchon on an unusually warm day during early Spring. Other than the warm weather, the walk around Bukchon was interesting. The traditional houses are built closely-knitted and you wonder how it feels to live so close to your neighbours but I got a chance to step into a open house and surprisingly the internal compound was very surreal, cooling, private and cosy. On top of the traditional houses, there are plenty of quaint shops to keep your eyes and wallets busy. My girlfriend and I enjoyed our first trip there so much that we visited again during our 8-day stay in Seoul. On a good cool day, you can leisurely walk from Gyeongbukgong Palace to Bukchon. A must visit place.

review_title: A dressed-up view of "the way things were"
review_body: Bukchon Hanok Village has old traditional houses that people actually live in. It is a good daytime walk; actually can be a little crowded with Korean couples on a nice weekend afternoon. Hilly and some decent views of the downtown. You can also arrange an overnight stay there, and Bukchon becomes considerably quieter and more peaceful once the couples depart during the evening hours.The houses here are unique and definitely Korean. Most of them are remodels and a bit dressed up, but as a tourist you probably wouldn't realize that. Try to find a map which shows the recommended walking path to ensure that you don't miss anything worth seeing.

review_title: Tiring on the way up but the view was worth it
review_body: Had to walk a while to get to the top/ But the view was well worth it. Had a few cafes at the top which was nice. Nice to see the culture and old style buildings
We visited the Hanok Village, a collection of private, walled garden homes built up and down narrow streets. Beautiful architecture and lovely to see, first-hand.
Good place for walking, sightseeing and shooting photo. Near anguk station, can spend a lot of time there then visit the Gyeongbokgung palace.

This place is amazing, its located on a small hill. All the houses have big and cool doors. The funny thing is that this area looks like its been more than 100 years old, but some doors have very modern high tech locks. Most house are locked and these people dont want any disturbance. Only one house was open for public to enter and take a look. Very nice view when you walk to the top.Youtube - lolsia2000

Take a stroll down the lane to see the traditional houses. Many with home grown flowers/ plants and the great exterior. You will see many people walking the same path. It's linked to Samcheong area so enjoy a good cuppa after that.

It is a living history in the middle f a modern city. The architecture is pretty different than the ones can be seen in Europe or North America. Small houses attached to each other creates a cozy feeling. Such a peaceful area. There are also small guesthouses in this area where you can stay and enjoy the traditional Korean hospitality but you must book well in advance.
Bukchon is much like the palaces, not really old just remodeled. There are actually fine examples of old homes located in the neighborhood surrounding Bukchon.

review_title: take time to make art objects
review_body: great little artisan shops and cultural treasure activities where you can pay a small fee to make a mirror or paper mache box

review_title: It's all you expect it to be- great place for a walk round
review_body: On arrival at Anguk subway station we were met by an old man with a walking stick who insisted in showing us correct exit to see the village (exit 3) - such an act of kindness. Bukchon is beautiful, the streets quaint and is really is all you expect it to be. It's busy, it's beautiful - it's great and can't imagine a trip to Seoul without visiting here. This is not a stop on the hop on hop off, so you will have to make your own way here, but it's easy to find.

Exploring quaint streets full of traditional housing and monuments and just so tranquil. Easy walking for the most part with some small sections that are up hill but the views are worth it. It is a 10 min walk from Insadong shopping street.
It's really a beautiful place, it would've been better if the tourists could keep their volumes down.

This is traditional village in seoul.Not to far form Gyeongbokgung Palace. Its easy to get there ( Anguk Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 2) and u have no need to pay any fee. U can get a good view to see Seoul city from the highest place in Village.Before u go, remember to pick up Bukchon map at the Information booth .
Bukchon Hanok Village is home to hundreds of traditional houses called 'hanok' that date back to the Joseon Dynasty.

While very crowded with tourists the village is worthwhile visiting. Friendly city guides give you information about how to walk and give you directions. It's a walk mostly uphill and then you can get a nice view over the lovely old rooftops! On our way back between Insadong and the Lotte department store area we visited the beautiful Buddhist Jogyesa temple!

review_title: Traditional korean houses in the middle of new buildings
review_body: I liked the small area..you can see the old korean houses..old doors but it's a small area you can finish it in 30 min max but it worths visiting
It's a hideout in within the busy city. Traditional Korean houses can be seen in the area. Be prepared to go up slopes n also walk in a huge area. Wear comfortable shoes!

I enjoy getting lost in Bukchon area. I enjoy the tranquility, the culture, the history of what Seoul once was. If you are lucky and get to experience a little Bukchon home stay, that probably is the best decision you would possibly make during your visit in the wonderful city.

A quiet place to get away from Gangnam and Myeongdong. Nice, older style houses and some good cafes to relax.There isn't much there, but if you just need an hour or 2 of walking and enjoying architecture, it's a good place. It would be nice if they had some more information about the history of the area interspersed among the walking paths, but I guess that's why they have Google.

We stayed 3 nights in the Bukchon area and enjoyed the experience except for the uncomfortable sleeping arrangements in our traditional guesthouse. Young people would be fine, but as an older adult, the thin mats on a hard floor made for very long nights. We joked that the Koreans work such long hours ever day, because lazing around in bed would be too miserable. However, we ate at many delicious small restaurants, trying different kinds of food at each meal, toured palaces and wandered the streets just looking at houses and in shops.

review_title: One of my favorite parts of Seoul
review_body: I love wandering through this historic area of Seoul. The houses are beautifully restored. It should be on everyone's list to see how people used to live.

such a fantastic cute little traditional village in the city. the traditional houses, streets and culture is well preserved. There are nice museums and workshops that you can attend in the village. I would suggest that you go to the visitor centre at the bottom of the village and get a map so you know where to go. surely not to be missed when in seoul.
Lively, but not overcrowded. Lots of little shops and restaurants, good atmosphere. Try to sneak in some little back alleys and enjoy the non commercial side of the village.

review_title: One of the few traditional neighbourhoods left untouched
review_body: Thoroughly enjoyed wandering around the neighbourhood, with its traditional korean wooden houses, some original, others restored. Most of old seoul was destroyed either by the japanese or by the civil war somthis gives youna glimpse what seoul must have looked like. Take a map from the tourist office or the information guides posted around the area to help you navigate your way around.

review_title: Great, fit to your schedule even if you are in Seoul for one day
review_body: Village gives you a sense of traditional living in Korea. Beautiful views, picturesque houses, try to see a small museum-house. Many thanks to Michael Kim (ultimatekoreatour@gmail.com) from UltimateKoreaTour for bringing us to the Village.
This place is so picturesque! I highly recommend going to the visitor center first to pick up a map so that u would know where to go!

Strolling through the streets of this historic and well-preserved village will simply pull at your nostalgic heartstrings. I mostly followed the recommended walking course, since it is a residential area, but took a few little twists and turns along the way to get out of the crowded zones. It was really crowded when I went, but that may have been due to it being a national holiday. It was fun to see all of the intricate details that go into each of the hanoks, right down to the locks on the window covers. If you go early enough, you'll be able to participate in some of the craft-making options available. There's a whole area dedicated to traditional crafts up at the top of the hill. Check the map you can get at the information center near the start of the journey for details!

review_title: Amazing preserved old quarter in the centre of one of the largest cities in the world
review_body: Bukchon is amazing, because it isn't an artificial, touristy fake historical village - it is a real, vibrant neighborhood with homes, cool shops, coffee houses, craftsmen, and B&B's all using the traditional 'hanok' houses. It can get pretty busy with visitors on a nice day (which makes it hard to get good photos), but it is definitely worth a visit. To put it in perspective, Seoul is a city of 23 million, and packed into one of the highest densities on the planet. And yet they have managed to preserve this neighborhood right in the center of the city - imagine a 18th century neighborhood preserved in the center of Manhattan!

I have been here for 3 times.. but i never been bored.. this place is so cozy and feels like home.. you stop at anguk station and exit 6 after you exit you strait ahead and turn right at bukchon ilga 12 enjoy your trip..

unique and feel like back to the old day. Nice view from nice houses. Tourist map is help to find what to see and where to start. Must come early (start 10 am) so will have more time to walk up and down. Nice decoration in some house and nice wall painting in some area.

It was very accessible, though you need to walk for a few minutes. As of the houses we had seen, mostly were already restored, but still impressive. Or maybe we were just not able to see the much older ones. But we happen to stumbled upon some shooting near the Winter Sonata drama location. I just cant tell if it was for a commercial or drama or movie, and I didnt knew the actors. But goodlooking, though. :)
I was quite impress with the design. took tons of photos there. U can try on Korean traditional clothes here and snap a shoot. or maybe more than one ;)
As a huge Korean drama fan I expected more from this, but it was just ok. Very crowded on a Saturday , lots of coffee shops, and fancy souvenirs.
Rooftops upon rooftops. Lovely place to spend a couple of hours. Need good walking shoes as a few hills but otherwise worthwhile.

This place is a short walk from Anguk subway station. A stroll past quaint little stores and restaurants. Upon reaching Bukchon Hanok Village, it wasn't what I was expecting. It was mostly modernized. CCTV cameras everywhere, electric garages. I guess I was expecting more. Should've researched more.

We took the subway to the Anguk stop and managed to find the Jaedong Tourist Information Center for the super helpful Tourist Map of Bukchon. That included a walking tour through the Bukchon Traditional Craft Experience Center (different craft houses along a picturesque and slightly hilly street) and the famous Bukchon-ro 11-gil area of old traditional houses. My favorite shopping section was along the Gyedong-gil section of the tour. I liked it more than the Samcheong Dong Road area (though I didn't have much time to go into many shops in either area). I would allow time to explore the shops and the craft houses. People still live in the protected historical houses, but to get an idea of the traditional Korean home, you can go into the craft houses. I would highly recommend this area.
I love this place! Very traditional neighbourhood. Nice local artist, restaurants, houses... This is the place i like most in Seoul area.

The traditional homes here are still lived in and this is an active neighborhood. The narrow serpentine streets are very fun to wander. with many great views, the most famous is the view of the far off Namsan Tower. I really loved walking to th e top of the village and walking along Bokchon-ro-15 gil This is a road that is perched atop a high cliff/wall with great views toward Samcheong-dong and Palpan-dong, you can also get a glimpse of Gwangbokgung Palace. A great day on foot, wear comfortable shoes as some of the hills are steep.

Before this traditional housing village is banned from public access, you must go to see and walk through one of the last well preserved traditional housing areas in S Korea. There are traditional items being made with lots of cool shops and boutiques.

review_title: Experience old Korea in a touristy way.
review_body: Quite impressed with the old Korean village, arts and crafts places in the village. Great place to stroll around and experience old Korea. However, this place is becoming a bit touristy and in spite of the signs to keep quiet it is rather difficult to control an excited crowd.
Good place to walk around.More easier if you use Seoul Walking Guide service (It's great and it's free!) so you don't have to wonder around the big area.

review_title: Delightful historic district to wander through
review_body: Stop at the tourist info center to get a detailed map of Bukchon district. Nicely restored homes and some very nice shops.

review_title: Bukchon Hanok Village - a great place to wander round!
review_body: This is an area of traditional Korean house in a very hilly area between the Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung Palaces. It is quite a fashionable (and probably expensive) area and there are a number of interesting small museums and shops in the area. There is obviously a tension between the people who live there and the hordes of rather noisy young tourists who climb up and down the steep streets - signs urging quietness are everywhere!But it is well worth a visit - if you don't mind dodging the young girls with their 'Selfie Sticks!

review_title: Nothing like Staying in a Hanok to appreciate the Buckchon village
review_body: By walking through the alleyways of the Buckchon, one can only see, to appreciate it.It is best experienced and appreciated by staying in one of the hanoks in the Bukchon village. There is limited accomodation though. Then, one can experience the interior feel of residing in one of them, even if it is for a night. However, please don't bring your whole suitcase because there wont be enough space for that & dragging the suitcase will be tough in the confusing alleyways. An over-nighter bag will do. Then, one can experience the quiet & peacefulness of the village as the sun sets and enjoy meals sitting cross legged on the heated floor. It is an experience.Walking through the alley gives you photos to take-away but staying there is an experience no one can take from you.

Most associtate Bukchon with traditional houses amidst modernity. A bit more exploration and we went into Samcheong Park which extended upwards to the fortress wall over the city. I heard a lady's voice, singing operatic style from an unknown spot. Excellent place to exercise one's lungs & skills. On a good day, one could see over the city and beyond. Apparently we could join into Waryong Park but it was past closing time. Another time perhaps.

there were many many hanok houses here. And they said the government preserved it so that no one would be allowed to destroy any of their old houses or commercial companies buy the lands and destroy the houses. lovely neighborhood.

review_title: Corner of traditional houses in modern Seoul
review_body: There are many boutique shops,and small restaurants, narrow side streets,there is one of places to see old traditional Korean buildings,in spite that there are many people strolling there amazing cleanness everywhere.

It's a quiet place with loads of old Korean houses and winding lanes weaving around. You may find couple volunteers in those lanes for directions and information. They also keep remind visitors to be quiet since it's a residential area. Please respect the locals. Don't speak too loud while visiting.

Bukchon was the first place I went to visit in Seoul, great place to walk around and see the traditional housing. Nice window shopping and cute cafes. At the tourist info you can pick up a great map which plans out a 1-2hour walking tour covering the highlights.
beautiful road and houses lining the street. leads to samcheongdong .. where you can visit the nice cozy cafes!

Rows & rows of traditional Hanok houses weaving through many lanes.Very peaceful & beautiful.It brings one back to nostalgia, that in a modern city like Seoul; one can still see the tradition being preserved by these Hanoks.A must see when in Seoul.

This is my 1st visit to Seoul and over the 2 days visit I've gone back twice to this place. It is a place for people who appreciate old traditional buildings. I love wondering on every paths as many of them are unique and different in their own ways.One of the Hanok has crafted creatures on their balcony, another have plants in traditional pots outside their house, very Zen & peaceful.There is a shop called Granhand, love his creations of different scents. It's of natural scents made from plant extracts of quality ingredient, very different feel from the branded eau de toilette over the counter.Amongst the Hanok one of them are opened to public for a minimal price of KRW15000 entrance fee comes with a nice herbal tea at the end of the tour of. This house belongs to an owner who reside in Latin America and this is their summer house. I was told this house worth USD$4M.If i ever come back again I will live in the Hanok guest house instead of hotels.

We walked this historic district with a native Korean who regaled us with stories of her childhood in Seoul. This is now over touristy, but still worth the visit to see beautiful homes and some great views from the heights over Seoul. We really enjoyed it and will likely do again.
Enter this village via free tour guides from Seoul tourism website. Brings you to nice points you will not visit or think of in the village.

review_title: Traditional and pleasant part of Seoul
review_body: How nice to wander in the narrow streets of Bukchon, with their numerous little craft shops. Rather touristic of course, but some views on the old hanoks with their tiled roofs are simply fabulous,
There are some small shops and cafes along the walk. A good and pleasant experience.

review_title: Great view, small boutiques, old buildings
review_body: Nice walk up the hill to see the old style Korean housing and view over the city. on the way - tiny little shops and boutiques and coffee shops. Definitely worth of visiting and strolling through the narrow streets.

They seem to be bugged enormously by the deluge of tourists visiting, and I can well believe it. We more there on a rainy day in early April and it was maybe not stampeded, but crowded enough -so imagine what it must be like on a fine day in the season. Please keep quiet!That said, it's nice. Not the kitschy fake you might expect, really authentic. Nice and well worth an extended walking tour.

Don't be afraid to just wander about; go into alleys and such. The place is bustling with tourists so I doubt you can get lost. Climb uphill, like all the way up. The view looking down to Insadong is really scenic. Take a selfie in between quieter alleys with lesser tourists, try to capture the details of the hanoks. I bet you, the pictures will turn out unique and picturesque.
Narrow streets, peaceful neighborhood would be the one to welcome you. Love the intricate details of each houses. I will definitely go back and immerse myself with this locals.

Bukchon is a great place to meander. As the other reviewers have noted, while it has become a tourist location (with plaques on the ground indicating where you could take scenic pictures of yourself), it remains a residential area. In this way, it does give you a sense of what Seoul might have been like in a bygone age. Having said that, the city has invested in developing this area for tourists, and so there are activity centers, picture spots, and consequently, lots of tourists. If you go early in the morning or in the evening, it might make for a more peaceful walk -- there are cute boutiques, tea shops, cafes, and galleries in the area which also add to the overall feel. If you like to walk and wander, this is a great stop. If you're looking for one big thing to take a picture with, you might want to skip this area and head up to Namsan Tower via cable car for the bird's eye view of the city and cultural performances instead.
Beautiful, quiet with many lovely stores and cafes. Great for a stroll, a bite, people and building watching. Worth the visit!!

review_title: Can't miss. Can't go wrong. Must do
review_body: When in Korea. When in Seoul. Bukchon is a must. Traditional homes mixed with modern restaurants and shops. Take a half day and stroll the lanes and roads. Enjoy a coffee or meal at one of the many local places. Friendly locals and tourists
Gives you the chance to see how the houses in Korea used to look like.It's really close to the Gyengbokgung Palace and to the Secret Garden.
It's an utterly picturesque neighborhood & you will really feel the place, it is very well preserved & will give tourist a very good snapshot of what authentic Korean living is.

When I travel I always appreciate finding historic districts. Bukchon is an old neighborhood made up of mostly classic style Korean homes. You can meander down and around small alleys and there are surprises along the way. I was lucky enough to have a sweet snack being cooked in the doorway of an older man's home. Not sure what it was, but it was like a carmel cookie. Very yummy! The other good thing is that it is an easy walk from Bukchon to the Palace so if you like to walk, you can see a lot in an afternoon.

Actually this was my second time in seoul. I have heard about this village which is near the palace but I got no time to visit back then until this trip. And I was regret I didn't do that on the first trip. It was amazing and lovely village. You might get a bit tired from climbing up the slope but trust me it's worth. The area is really big so I suggest you guys to go to the information Center for the village and the staff will show u on the map which way to go and what is interesting to see so you don't have to walk the whole area and save a lot of time. Along the village track you can see a lot of houses that open for a small museum or a craft shops. For some reason you can also rent and try on the Korean tradition dress Hanbok for 7000 won. If you are a big group of people pls noticed that silence is required for this area!!

Up a set of stairs and along narrow passageways are lots of old (looking) houses that follow the ancient design for this area of the city. It has been renovated loads but there is still a strong sense of what it was. In amongst the grand houses are fancy shops, museums, and galleries.
I would say avoid this as it is mostly a tourist trap, with shops all over the place. Instead visit the Namsan Hanok Village, it is quieter, cleaner and is pretty much the same thing.

This is a wonderful walking tour of an area of Seoul that had been somewhat preserved. People still live here and there are signs everywhere asking to respect their privacy. Stop at the Bunchok information center first to get a map of the area then hit the streets with your camera. A wonderful flash from the past. Great views of traditional Korean rooftops.
walked with two young children...everyone enjoyed the day. stopped to buy souvenirs, ate street food, took tons of pics of architecture...wish we had known about guest houses in area!!

review_title: Nice to get away from the city
review_body: Nice place to stroll around. It shows some of the Korean history. It is worth having a look around - you get away from all the busy streets of the city. On a nice sunny day you can get great photos.

They houses were great to see. Very traditional and very nice. I found myself getting disorientated a bit but there are many info centers around that can help set you straight. The maps are good and in English and the street signs also have English.Cute shops and some nice street food.

The main commercial thoroughfare in Bukchon has a ton of adorable shops, stores and coffee places. It's also immediately quieter from the 6 lane streets, so you can easily wander and window shop. I also loved the residential area of Bukchon but because it's a populated residential area, it is a bit awkward to be wandering with packs of other tourists around people's homes. There are a lot of signs up asking people to be respectful, and the residential area is technically only open until sundown - but most streets I turned down had several dozen people on them. It's hard to keep several dozen tourists quiet. You won't be able to wander and absorb the feel of the place easily so I'd recommend checking it out briefly and then heading back to the more commercial area to explore some intriguing alleys and shops.
For photographer and walker. I like this place. Very quiet at day and night. There is one place 'Garage coffee', roof terrace with nice view, draft beer and foreign waitress.

this is probably my favorite place in Seoul, as I went there twice in my one week of stay! you feel like you've traveled back through time and every street corner is perfect to capture some great pictures! there's also many shops and coffee places that are tucked in the little streets, it's a nice escape if you want some quiet time and walk around the old housing and tea houses- it's truly a beautiful area to visit!
one of the best places in Seoul to visit on a lazy afternoon durin winter.If you're into nostalgic and quaint-stuff, then Bukchon Village is the ideal place to visit.

A very unique experience in this place, spent half a day strolling in the alleys, observing Korean traditional houses and take a lot of photos in the process. Made our presence as quiet as possible to avoid causing disturbance for the local residents as we saw reminders on the wall.
Authentic village Seoul, with wooden houses, great view to city. You must keep silence, staff on the streets help tourists.
Despite the swarm of tourists, this is a charming area to wander and where one can experience what Seoul was like before the high rises arrived.

review_title: Walk and Marvel at the beauty of Bukcon
review_body: Visited this in July 2014. Started off from the tourist center at Bukchon. Took off on its suggested route. It is a beautiful neighbourhood. There are Tourist Helpers along the route who can speak English, Chinese and Japanese to guide the visitors. Lots to see around the neighbourhood with shops, eateries, places of interests.

What a great use of time if you want to see something that takes you back time 700 years. What fascinating architecture that you can touch and sense. As you walk the streets and view the houses, you are able to step into some of them and and see what the elite class considered their homes. There are not many places where you can see and touch history.

This was probably my biggest disappointment in Seoul. Yes, the houses are somewhat old-fashioned, but you can see similar architecture all over Korea. Personally, I felt like I and the other tourists were being very intrusive - it is a residential area, after all. I'd only check it out if you happen to be in the area, and even then I wouldn't stay for more than a few minutes.

We enjoyed a nice walk through this neighborhood and took many photos. Although is was packed for the Lunar New Year, we managed to escape the crowd by leaving the main path.Great area to see how the people used to live. May photo opportunities.Grab a map from the small tourist stalls in the area. They suggest different kind of walks and good explanations.

review_title: Wouldn't see it anywhere else. Go high
review_body: Get lost in the side streets and explore. The higher you go the more you can see. Narrow streets that overlook the city below. Worth hiking up the hills for a unique perspective of the architecture.very touristy with lots of popup shops. Some homes open for a fee. I heard one say 800 won each just to go inside and look, no thanks, found a free one around the corner.Take your time and get lost. You'll find your way back eventually.
I like those charms of traditional Korean houses and the simplicity of beauty.It was a sunny day in winter, all wonderful scenes.
It's fab place to be to see how the OLD korea looks like. It's a short walk but it's worth it. I took so many pic there.
The architecture is beautiful in this historic area and you really get a sense for what the city might have felt like a few hundred years ago. It was really neat.

review_title: We were having fun with Hanbok.
review_body: Hanbok is the traditional Korean dress with vibrant colours. To try on it, you have to pay 7000 won including entry fee. Nice place to have fun and feeling Korean traditional culture there. You should try!
Hanok Village in the big city of modern Seoul. Should join the "Bokchon Hanok Village Walking Tour" for the first time to check out the important points.

Bukchon is a lovely area, well worth exploring. Old-school Korean architecture and lots of independent cafes and restaurants serving authentic Korean cuisine. Also art galleries and shopping. Not to be missed.

review_title: Bukchon: traditional Korean housing renovated for today's living!
review_body: Bukchon is one of the most delightful areas in Seoul to spend and hour or two comparing old Korean hanoks(not so many of them as more are being renovated every year) as they were originally built with beautifully renovated hanock for today's modern living. It is both interesting and informative to see how the modelling of these houses are enhanced with the use of pale wood panelling and modern fittings.Some hanok owners are offering home stay experiences, well worth a visit if not one or two night's stay!

review_title: Absolutely Go and experience the Charm of an Old Seoul Village
review_body: Just like some of parts of Tokyo, I love the low rise, old neighbourhoods that have been renovated but have kept the charm of an Old Seoul Village. It's walkable, and a lovely combination of the old with new shops and cafés. Charming!

Going here really does feel like stepping in a different place and time, so very different from Seoul's modern buildings. We had a free walking tour from the Korea Visit Org (highly recommended, the guides speak good English and are very friendly -- plus it's free) and it was enjoyable.Only thing is the entire walk can be very tiring, especially the uphill areas. My two elderly companions didn't enjoy it as much because of all the walking. Wear good shoes, maybe trim your itinerary a bit if you're short on time. This is a place best made for slower walks and absorbing the scenery.

review_title: Where history comes back to life
review_body: I went there very early in the morning thinking that there would be less people and easy to get around. I was right! It can be a bit difficult to find your way and manage to see everything, but there are maps and dirrections to help you. Even if it is a turistic area, people live there, so try to keep your voice down a bit!(just a small advice)
A nice place to visit. There are many Korean style houses which are in good condition.
If you have time, do make a visit here to view the architecture and streets of this residential area. Views from some of the streets are awesome!
It was nice to walk through an old neighborhood. So much of Korea has been modernized that it is nice to imagine what it would have been like.
Great way to spend an afternoon. Great for strolling and exploring. You can pick up a map with a suggested route at the tourist office at the foot of the neighborhood if you like.

review_title: urban hustle and bustle old and new
review_body: Great area with very old architecture beside very new buildings. Great little shops with a focus on creativity and arts and crafts. Great walking around with some cardio up those hills (but then you can go down, too). Definitely a spot to go while in modern Seoul for a taste of the past.

Bukchon...I've always wanted to visit it ever since I watched a Korean drama with my favorite actor Lee Min Ho which was filmed there...I did get a chance to finally visit the place in the fall. I was amazed at the number of narrow streets, traditional hanok houses and modern cars parked in front of them. Lots of tiny traditional tea houses are located on the main street leading up to Bukchon, which I visited. So many things aside from sightseeing can be done in Bukchon, but I only had a few hours to spare on the day I visited. There are cultural experience venues, traditional pottery and jewelry stores. You can even stay overnight in one of the specified houses. When you get to the top you have a fantastic view of old vs modern Korea with hanoks by your feet and modern Seoul skyscrapers in the distance. A paradise for a photography enthusiast such as myself. I will definitely be back there, and would recommend going to Bukchon to everyone. What a great experience. As I mentioned, I went in the fall, so everything looked twice as beautiful with fall foliage. Oh, and I did get to find the filming drama house location which I was ecstatic about.

Get a map from the Bukchon Cultural Center before wander through the streets and alleys of Bukchon. Do note that it's rather commercialized, with cafes and retail stores that is far from traditional. But still interesting...
See and take photos in this traditional hanok village in seoul. Takes a lot of walking uphill though but it's all worth it.

review_title: A mini glimpse at traditional Hanok villages. But for a more pure experience head to Gyeongju near Busan.
review_body: This is a good experience to see traditional Korean housing without leaving Seoul, but it's crammed with tourists like everywhere in Korea. However the buildings are cute and it's a nice place to spend an afternoon with good weather. If on a limited schedule and you can't make it to Gyeongju check this out instead.

review_title: Great Part of a Walking Tour Of Seoul
review_body: Let me just say that having lived in Seoul for two years, I developed a walking tour route for when people visited. This attraction is part of that tour that can be lengthened or shortened as needed. The general route was: Begin at City Hall, walk up through Gwanghwamun Square visiting the Cheonggyecheon Stream and a possible visit to Hangul Museum under statue, continue to Gyeongbukgung Palace. Time permitting walk up through Samcheongdong into the Bukchon Hanok Village, continue down to where the tour ends in Insadong. This is enough for just about a full day of touring and requires A LOT of walking.One of the interesting things about Bukchon is that it is in a sense a 'living museum.' People still live here and these are still active houses. Looking down the narrow streets over the roof lines really gives you an idea of what Seoul might have looked like long ago.Being one of the major tourism spots in Seoul, there are a lot of tourist trap type shops and cafes. But, all round this area are some really great traditional tea shops and even little art galleries tucked away. It's worth doing some exploring. As touristy as it is, it is not as bad as Insadong and tends to be far less crowded.Well worth the walk up for a vist!

This is absolutely fantastic! Bukchon is a traditional Korean hanok village in the heart of Seoul. The hanok houses are so beautiful, and I couldn't stop taking photos. It is possible to go inside some of the houses, and you can also buy morning or afternoon tea and just enjoy the atmosphere of this amazing place. The streets are quite steep, but it is definitely worth making the effort to navigate your way through them. And you'll find some great views over Seoul too. I would highly recommend a visit to Bukchon.

Bukchon is a place to go if you are into something different, unique for photography. You feel like you kind of step back in time a bit there with the architecture. Traditional village and some unique shopping can be done there.

been to this place the morning before our flight going back home (manila). though im satisfied seeing the hanok, but i would love to experience going inside and see how traditional houses were arranged. unfortunately, we were not able to follow the tour map and were not able to reach the highlight of the hanok village (where the abundant hanoks are located). dont forget to try a mango dessert at philippines dessert cafe. :)how to get here?we took a train from myeongdong. the nearest subway station is Anguk (orange line, line 3). take exit 3, walk few meters and take left turn for Gyedong-gil (road/street).For tour map, visit this site and print the map: http://www.visitseoul.net/en/article/article.do?_method=view&art_id=58509&lang=en&m=0004004004001&p=04

Bukchon is like a living museum, right in the middle of the city and within walking distance from the main tourist attractions in Seoul, namely Gyeongbokgung, Insadong and Gwanghwamun Square. Having said that, there are people living in the well-preserved village. Unfortunately, tourists did not think about that fact when they shouted at each other like it was an area full of residential buildings and nothing else. Because of this, there are signboards seeking tourists to keep their voices down which seemed to be ignored.It was nice to get lost in the village but it does not hurt to get a copy of the map from the tourist information counter at the beginning of the road.There are a plenty of hanok villages in Seoul alone. This is probably the most popular one due to its location and wonderful hilly view with photo opportunity spots you may find along the way.

review_title: Traditional Village Remind me my school days
review_body: Defiantly worth to visit to bukchon if you want to feel true atmosphere of Korea , especially traditional village is very lovely , gotta walk a bit but there is signage on the street in English and there is even a tourist information office to assist you when you lost your way , you can spend the whole day wondering around the area ,this is one of the best place we visited in Seoul ! If you are the type who appreciates and like to experience local attractions Bukchon is the place to visit in Seoul

review_title: Not so impress with old town
review_body: The area is nice filling with coffee shop and nice shopping area. However, I am not very impressed for the old town part. It is nice to visit but don't expect too much.

With so many noisy tourists milling around this small area, I felt kinda bad for the poor residents who have to endure this inconvenience day in day out. Some of the *ahem Chinese ahem* tourists were even screaming at each other to align themselves for the "perfect" "jump shot". (Dear me!)People talk about this place like a teleport to ancient times, but it's hardly the case, unless old roofs and old doors are your kind of history tours. There were no shops open when we were there (some of the houses have been converted to run-of-the-mill souvenir shops), but to see them open would probably affect the atmosphere even more!

I've visited Bukchon with my mom in one of the coldest winter day, but it was definitely worth all the chills! Its a must see sight if you are interested in Korean traditional culture and its old architecture style. Theres a free cultural museum/gallery along the hike so make sure to stop by and take a peek. (They sell souvenirs like postcards and magnets in there, too.) Last but not least, small tip for Catholics who visit Bukchon - Theres a cathedral nearby called Gahoe-dong Catholic Church, which is a historical place for the Catholic Church of Korea. The cathedral itself is a mixture of Korean Hanok and Western-style architecture which is worth a visit.

Its interesting to see the old style of housing and the juxtaposition of the old and new architecture in the area. We also went to the Bukchon Traditional Crafts Experience Center there and had fun doing crafts.

Located in Insa-Dong, Bukchon Hanok village is easily one of the best places we visited in Seoul. The ancient traditional Korean houses are beautiful. People still live there although commercialization has taken place where houses have been sold to be converted into shops, restaurants and cafes.We patronised one of the cafes, not just to have a coffee break, but also to experience a hanok. We were given a room where we had to sit on the floor round a low table. The architecture is interesting and the sliding doors similar to traditional Japanese houses. The view from the balcony overlooking the village was really awesome. (The café was located at the top of the hill.)If you are the type who appreciates and like to experience local attractions, Bukchon is the place to visit in Seoul. In fact, the entire Insa-Dong district is lovely with its Korean-themed shops that sell wares different from what you normally get at mall and even Myeong-Dong.
I LOVED THIS PLACE.You can spend the whole day wandering around this area. Traditional design buildings and cute indie craft shops and cafes a genuinely beautiful part of the city

review_title: Nice place filled with Hanok (Traditional Korea Houses)
review_body: This place is beautiful, gotta walk abit but there's signage on the streets in English. There's even a tourist information office to assist you when you lost your way.It's definitely worth the walk up the slope. A nice place to look around and take a stroll.
Definitely worthy to visit to Bukchon if you want to feel the true atmosphere of Korea. Especially the traditional vileage is very lovely.
Easy to find.. stop at anguk exit 2 so cool place and i miss to get back here next year.. many hand made store that i love the moat of Korea

review_title: Very pleasant stroll around the alleys
review_body: Very pleasant stroll around the alleys and neighbourhood. The Customs and arts are excellent. People are very nice. I dined in a couple of traditional Korean Restaurants in the neighborhood and they are very delicious and reasonably priced.

The streets of Bukchon are lined with many hanoks or Korean traditional houses. These hanoks are protected against modern development so you can see and feel the aura of old-style Korea. As the place is situated on the mountain, it is rather steep and hilly so do be careful when walking around the place. The hanoks are privately-owned so people still live there. Due to that, there are many signs along the way reminding tourists to be quiet as so to mantain peace and quietness of the place. The main street of Bukchon has many hanok-styled cafes where you can grab a cup of coffee whilst soaking up the atmosphere. If you get lost, fret not because there are many tourist information staffs around the place and they'd be happy to give you directions or answer any of your questions.

This corner of Seoul is a must see, if you want to experience the old part of the city. Be sure to pick up a map at the tourist information and follow their walking route to see all the best streets. You get great views of the city too, especially the Namsan tower. Best come later in the day and take in the sunset.

We were here by Nov 2014 after we visited Changdekgong. We saw many unique and magnificent Hanok houses. Most of the Hanok had changed to guesthouse. It's good attraction to know these traditional Korean people living places. Also we can saw some wall paintings with beautiful picture, very cute and special.

I stayed in a traditional house and slept on the floor for 2 nights. It was a little hard for my old bones but I enjoyed the experience. It was fun to walk around the neighborhood and see all the old houses. note:( I was there in April 2013, not 2014 but was not given that choice).

This would have received five stars had we not visited similar areas in Jeonjo and near Andong. Nonetheless, it was a treat to see these traditional structures preserved and to wander about. Interesting cultural center with excellent maps. I think I would have really enjoyed the culture/art making classes at the center if had had more time or in warmer weather!
I was ready to go home almost empty-handed. Then I came by Bukchon hours before my return flight... Very interesting things you could buy for your loved ones back home!

It is a great place to appreciate Korean archtectural beauty and functionality. It is also interesting to see how people actually live in these traditional structure with modern improvement. It is hilly but worth the cardio. There are several work shops you can vist and learn some of traditional craft.
