It is also close to the major touristic spots (e.g., palace or Insadong or the temple).

Its really worth a pay to visit. I enjoyed walking around the area and seeing the architectural aspects of the houses and how the entire alleys are meticulously planned. Its a good example of having the old and the new.

review_title: Well worth a visit to walk around these lovely traditional hanok.
review_body: Seoul's Bukchon Hanok Village is a traditional Korean village with a long history located not too far from the Gyeongbok Palace and Changdeok Palace and is well worth a few hours to explore and take in the culture. The traditional village is composed of lots of alleys, "hanok", and is preserved to show a 600-year-old urban environment, but it is a residential area with people living in the traditional wooden and stone houses and so you need to respect that when you walk around the hanok.As well as the lovely architecture of the traditional homes there are plenty of shops, craft centres drinking and eating places to spend your time exploring. Pick up a map from the tourist information office as you enter the Bukchon Hanok area as this I found was a great help in navigating my way around the narrow streets. It was very popular and very busy with tourists so expect to be one of many as you walk this fabulous historic district. It is rather steep walking in places so probably not suitable for those in wheelchairs or those whom are not in great fitness.

quite boring. shops and restaurants, not much really.But! there is a free shuttle bus right at the turn where the main palace Geongbukgong and the Hyundai art gallery. There is free shuttle bus service in front of the Hyundai gallery thatvtakes you to Sam Cheng Geok, a beautiful traditional Korean residence preserved on the hills with fresh air and trails. Kuch is delicious there at the Sam Cheng Geuk but pricey.

review_title: Cater about 2 hours for your walk
review_body: Its a series of well-preserved village houses with some nice views at the top. Be prepared for some steep climbs along some parts of the route though. There is a tourist information office along the way so go in if you have to and get your necessary directions from inside. We took about 2 hours for the walk at a casual pace.

If you are interested in history and culture, you will love walking around this historical and yet modern region. Beautiful hanok buildings, combined with the vew on the mountains, pine trees and bamboo wil emerge painter in you. There are shops and excellent restaurants as well.
Do TaKe a walking trip in Bukchon. There is a tourist information booth where you can get a map for a walking tour! You might not find all routes and photospots without it.
Next time I go back would like to stay in a Traditional Korean wooden home, kitted out with all the latest hi teach amenities. Worth a walk around. Good restaurants around.

review_title: Unique and people still living there
review_body: Whenever you visited an old village, one would think it is a show case. In this case, this is real life though the building dated back some 500 years ago. They have couple of houses open to visitors to see inside.It is only available to visit before sunset to give residence some privacy. The area outside the old village is also very interesting with cafe and restaurant', also very near to president residence.

Lives up to its name. Lots of nice buildings to admire. Just walk around and explore the tiny narrow streets to see what's around the corner. When tired, just find a nice cafe to rest and have a hot drink.
A must see if you like to see traditional architectural homes. Need walking shoes since it is a nice area to see the sights.

Walking in Bokchon and admiring the Hanok was one of the best experiences we had in Seoul. We visited all the 8 scenery and couldn't understand why some people advised travelers to start from scenery 3. They are all so unique and beautiful.

Went there on our last day in Seoul. It was very cold but we were so glad that we managed to squeeze this itinerary in. This is just a small village but as we were rushing for time, we didn't managed to visit the Traditional Culture Centre and probably covered only about 60% of the village alleys / streets. Definitely worth a return trip.I really enjoyed admiring the well preserved and maintained traditional houses in the area. Some streets are filled with quaint looking little cafes (unfortunately they were mostly closed, even at 11am) and various souvenir / handicraft shops. We bought some hand-painted ceramic paintings and art prints in some of the shops there. A friend gave me a Buchon Walking Map. Not sure where she got it from, perhaps the Tourist Info Centre or the Culture Centre. You can use the map to guide you around the alleyway, focusing on your area of interest. Do take note though that some streets are very steep, and in winter, it can get really tricky, to manage the slippery streets (due to the melting snow). My kids and I came upon this section near the top of the hill, where the street was extremely slippery. We met a group of tourists there and a few of them almost slipped, while trying to navigate up the hilly road.

review_title: Only visit if you like traditional designs and buildings
review_body: We just visited the Bukchon Village last week (10/Dec) and we loved it. As we went on a weekday afternoon, the place was quite deserted and peaceful. Moreover it is chilly and nice weather for a stroll around the place taking plenty of photos.. haha..We had a nice time moving around at a leisurely pace just getting the vibe and feel of the whole place.However in order to fully enjoy this place (in my opinion), you need to be relaxed and really like looking at the different structure of the Hanoks. We were on our own Free & Easy trip so we had no time restrictions... haha.. and go on a weekday, it seems alot of ppl will visit over the weekends...I feel sorry for the residents there over the weekends with all the crowd...Anyway be prepared to walk around and take photos...Getting there is easy: take the Line 3 to Anguk station and exit @ Exit 2.Just go straight for about 300m and there is an information booth. Take a map and walking guide and just follow the "suggested" route.. haha..Have fun...

review_title: Glad this type of culture is highlighted
review_body: I am so glad I made the trip out here. Easy to get to via subway with just a short walk. As I made my way through the windy streets I really enjoyed the care that people take to keep the streets and homes so well maintained. There are a lot of little alleys to explore and still stay oriented to where you are.Stop by the visitor office if you care to get a quick map to help navigate the streets.

review_title: Pretty village but nothing really interesting
review_body: Freezing cold to walk around the village. There were some houses open for visitors to look around to get a feel of the history of the place. But other than that, I did not quite enjoy it. We were lucky we were with a private tour company that had local guides who knew how to bring us to the top of a church that had a birds eye view of the village. That was the highlight of a rather dull place. Hmmmm.... nothing else to talk about it really.....

Many traditional houses in use. And also many well-interiored shops and cafes there.Chosun dynasty is living in the very modern city, Seoul.Old royal palace and other hot points are in walking distance.

review_title: The best long walks during winter time
review_body: Long walks during winter time is killing with the wind blowing pretty strong but we have a wonderful time at the Bukchon Hanok Village. Took lots of pictures and there are many shops to buy little cute items for yourself and as souvenirs.
after few days shopping with friends. I enjoyed my last day in Seoul by walk around Bukchon in the morning, with coffee and dessert, nice and quiet. Nice place to take pictures.

Lots of traditional homes still preserved from the olden days. I went here on mid May and it was still chilly. So bring your jackets during any season. You have to walk a lot from the station and the place is quite hilly so sneakers are recommended. The neighborhoods are a mix of traditional and modern houses. People live inside. Lots of flowers blooming on early summer. The roads were quite narrow and scenic. Excellent for pictures. It was great cultural experience. If you don't care about culture, don't bother with it. You might find it Uninteresting.I was very tired of walking towards the end of my journey there, so I rested in a Cafe And had some shaved ice cream with red bean paste and rice cake. The portion was big but still it was overpriced, in my opinion. Actually, everything in there is more pricey than anywhere else. It's a stylish little town. And I bet the merchants know tourists go there so it's expected, I guess.Despite the cold weather and aching feet, I still really enjoyed my trip there. Definitely recommend!!!! ♡
Like the fact that it's free of charge.. and we can wear hanbok with a mere 3 dollars rent price.. picture taken in traditional house OMG I felt like in a movie...
How s d place to explore it in the winters ?Please suggest as its too chill outside ...Reviews are tempting me to visit d place

I love all the buildings and the view. Historic and amazing experiences. Tourists have to be quiet and walk slowly because of the signboards hung all over the wall that required us to be quiet as the historic and classic buildings are housing areas.

review_title: If you're in it for Culture
review_body: I just like the idea of an old heritage village wherever it may be. Luckily Seoul has it with Bukchon. It's a nice feeling to get lost in here. Surprises await for wanderers alike. Here we wore traditional silk hanbok and tried imagining how it is to live in ancient Korea. Great experience! Dislikes - Hmnn... Sometimes we got into a private property or we struck a dead end. I hope more signposts would help DIY travelers like us who do not depend on tours. Other than that, the place is amazing!

review_title: If you want to traditional houses.
review_body: If you want to traditional houses, here is the best place. And it is also very near Insadong and Samchungdong where traditional couveniers and luxury boutique shops are located in.

The area has lots of beautiful housing that one rarely has the opportunity to see elsewhere. Most are distinct with its own character and all are beautifully designed and decorated. There were signs reminding people to keep their volume down especially from the evening onwards out of consideration for the residents. Many quaint shops and cafes in the area too. However, there are many stairs and steep slopes which might make it difficult for some.
there is really nice place!. wonderful traditional village!

Nice walk around the neighbourhood. You can see old style houses and visit some sites in the area. Get the map from the visitor centre on the main road. It's not recommended for people who cannot walk for long as there is a lot of uphill walking. We struggled to push our child's stroller. Lots of cafes and eateries at Samcheongdong and in the neighbourhood.

I've been here a couple of times and each time I was underwhelmed. The last time I visited I brought a friend who was passing through Korea, to say he was unimpressed is an understatement. It's a real shame that this area is not more interesting. It is a historic area but it feels very manufactured and sterile. You do not get the impression this is what Korea used to be like. Couple this manufactured feel with the huge crowds and it's just not a great place to visit. If I didn't live in Seoul, I probably would not have visited here. If you don't have much time to spend in Seoul, I would go other places.
really enjoyed this neighborhood. Definitely worth seeing and walking around. A Must see in my opinion.
(+) This is a village with traditional Korean houses with people still living in them so it's like a living museum.

review_title: Gives you a sense of the old Korean community
review_body: Walking through the streets of Bukchon make you feel like you're walking through the past. It's a nice place capture the essense of the old wooden house community. Even if commercial stores have occupied some of these houses along the roads, you can still see some odd shops like a hat making shop, a tailoring shop, an old style barber shop, where the owners themselves are still making the crafts themselves. It is also nice to turn into the small alleys and see the locals going on with their daily chores.

The Bukchon village is a residential area and while we go around walking about the rows and rows of well-preserved (if not, designed & constructed) hanok style houses, we were reminded to keep noise at a minimum in order not to disturb the families that live there. You don't want a tourist peering into your house, do you? Enjoy the sights and photograph all you want but give respect to the privacy of families that reside there. We descended at Samcheondong for some food and drinks and to rest our legs.

This is a very interesting part of the city. It is like a city within a city and most of the homes are preserved with the old ways of building. Lots of shopping too! Make sure you have comfy shoes on for this tour!
This place is so cozy.. many cafe many unique store.. old houses arround you.. you can spent whole day here.. i sure you no regret to come here.. i will gonna miss this place..

Yes, I'm a Lee Min Ho fan, so I made it a point to find the Sanggojae in the Bukchon Hanok Village where Lee Min Ho shoot for the Perfect Match koreanovela! The village is perfect for architecture enthusiasts who want to get a taste of the old Seoul. Perfect for a visit after your tour in the Gyeongbokgung Palace.

review_title: Not so much fit for travellers in wheelchair
review_body: The area is quite hilly and it's difficult to explore more than the main street (which also goes up hill).The houses are old and many of them require you to use stairs to enter or to visit the basement.So my experience there was short and unsatisfying.We did try some local snacks and they were good.

Must visit if you have time, its an uphill and traditional korean housing area, very nice , tidy and clean, lots of houses to take photos with and coffee strips just below the hill. you can get maps from nearby volunteer staffs or tourism board staffs they will guide you around the place with markings on the map. Yes its in korean words but its not too bad with the map. there's an observatory somewhere around the area, where you can have a clearer look and a taste of entering traditional korean housing.

This is one of the beautiful places in Seoul where travellers may wish to consider. I loved the traditional looking houses and it makes me feels like Iiving in a warmth environment. Going to this place is not difficult and it is about 300 m walk from Anguk station with tourist information signage to guide along. If you crave for coffee while walking to Bukchon, you may wish to pamper yourself with a cup of Americano coffee from "unlimited coffee" and I am sure you will like the aroma.

It was a very nice day when we went to Bukchon. Walking around w/ a map, while eating some red-bean manjoos, everything was going so very well. That is... Until my friends saw that we had to hike a bit to get to some of the other areas. The place was very nice and there's a tour, but you had to pay for it - We opted to go around the place on our own. The houses were very pretty and around the place, there are shops! There was one which sold little succulents and another one which sold clothes. The most interesting one is the quaint store that sold pen drawings! The details were amazing and it's done by just one person! My friends bought a few of his pieces, actually! Anyway, past the traditional houses, there's an area w/ more modern stuff - more shops and restaurants! Very nice place and the ambiance is great!

This is a must visit place if you go to Seoul. We got there by subway. Alight at Anguk station (line 3) and exit at #2. You can find a tourist information centre not far away and they will advise where are the places to visit. This place is really beautiful.

This village of traditional homes is probably the only single-family homes that you'll see in a city of high-rise living. The character is well maintained, there are good restaurants, galleries and shops, and a lovely view of the Seoul Tower. Don't forget to also walk through Insadong.
We came because we wanted to see traditional houses. It turns out to be really beautiful and clean. Wish there was more things to do around. It was a little hike and then there was all.

Bukchon is a pretty historic neighborhood in Seoul. The architecture is uniform, unique and typically Korean. Beautiful!The nice thing is, that it is not 'just' historic architecture. The area is also filled with galleries and cafes. Very cool.Read more here:http://curlytraveller.com/2014/02/bukchon-hanok-village-seoul.html

we were soooooo disappointed in visiting this place. going up is a challenge then when you reach the village all we can say is.. is that it!!!??!!?? i thought i could see the traditional old houses. not worth it! better look for other place to visit

review_title: Hiltop views of Seoul are enticing
review_body: I went because I had wanted to see a "traditional Korean village" and a friend had recommended it to me. I had me imagined a model village for tourists to see what traditional style Korean houses look like. However, upon arriving at Bukchon, it turned out to be a neighbourhood that happen to have a lot of traditional style Korean houses with real people living there in. The neighbourhood is on a hillside and so a lot of places it's quite steep. You also get some pretty amazing views and there is also an observatory that you can go to. Go in the day time so you can see the views. There are volunteer tourist guides all around that supply you with a map of the places to see in the area. Also just down the road there are some really good and inexpensive restaurants. There are some cute shops, cafes, and restaurants tucked in unexpected places.
All the small houses and road are very interesting. You seems to travel back in time and walk on the streets that history walk on. Just like going to Paris or other old Europe city.

review_title: Charming and authentic area of Seoul
review_body: Strolling through the streets of Bukchon you will get a completely different feeling from the one you can get in the other neighbourhoods of Seoul. Bukchon has an ancient and charming look but maintains the fashionable, hip and cool bars and cafés that are typical of the city. You can go shopping here, but also eat in an authentic small Korean restaurant or have an afternoon break on a rooftop, while watching the sun set.Definitely worth a visit!

It is a very tight place to navigate around as a tall person, and the streets would not be good if crowded, but people are still living in these places that are hundreds of years old and incredibly basic. I went mid week, and found a local guide for a few dollars who gave me a good and informative tour in English. After the megalopolis of Seoul and Gangnam, it is a simple and lovely space and a quick visit.
Nicely renovated, quite authentic, wear comfy shoes for lots of walking on narrow streets. This is a historic area where you can see how people lived before the 20th century.

BukChon is a great place to visit. The obvious reason is what every guide mentions: a look at a traditional village, and great views over JongNo, DongDaeMun, NamSan from the top of the hill. Obviously, BukChon delivers, although one could argue that the village is not overly impressive or that there are better places in town to get a great cityscape panorama. But there's a unique flavor to BukChon. It remains it's touristic flavor, with small museums, shops and trendy restaurants. But at the same time, it doesn't feel overblown like InSaDong. There's a right balance, as between touristic shops, you might run into people cleaning their cars, kids coming back from school, and more simply, people going on about their life in this nice, quiet environment. The atmosphere is really what sets this place apart, and I recommend strolling around without a map to get a real glimse at what BukChon has to offer.

review_title: Charming village and beautiful scenery, perfect for a weekday afternoon
review_body: This old village is a charm, but be careful to go on a weekday instead of holidays or weekends as there could easily be a crowd in this popular tourist attraction. It's much more enjoyable if there were less people walking alongside you on the rather narrow streets. Quite a number of lovely cafes and boutique shops here, though the price is on the higher range, you would definitely appreaciate their uniqueness and novelty. Rather than offer coffee, some cafes here provide specialty teas and desserts. You definitely would not want to miss trying those set in the beautiful backdrop of the Bukchon traditional houses and the Inwangsan Mountain and Bukaksan Mountain nearby! Some of the tables are even made of stone and have "ponds" in the middle of them. How interesting is that!
There are many traditional house hotels (hostels) around that you may stay and experience Seoul's traditions and welcome.

Went there on a sunday afternoon, it was nice walking on the streets and seeing the tradutuinal Korean houses, there is also an activity center kind of thing where yoh can go and make handmade jewellery and dye some cloth in the old korean way. I think a lot of things were shut there maybe because of a sunday so olease check before going there.

review_title: seeing Korean traditional houses in the city
review_body: You can visit Bukchon Hanok Village if you want to see Korean traditional houses in the city. Unlikely Namsangol Hanok Village, this is a real village where residents are living. You can take your time, looking around cultural centers, guesthouses, restaurants and tea houses, and at the same time feeling traditional Korean culture.

review_title: The "old" Korea, just right in town !
review_body: To be honest, I didn't plan to go there. My plant destination was the Changgyeonggung Palace, but it was closed (Mondays!)Hence I looked for something else and found Bukchon Hanok Village. It was certainly a good compensation for not being able to visit another Palace. I was strolling around for almost two hours. Just outstanding!

plenty to eat, see and do in Bukchon. See the traditional homes, antiques and shops, nice restaurants and coffee houses. Wonderful walking around the area. Go 'up Bukchon' towards Seongbuk-dong. Hit the old city wall. Next door is Samcheong-dong, insa-dong and the palace. Really worth your time - especially on a beautiful seoul day.

review_title: Bukchon Hanok Village has restored Korean wooden houses
review_body: A lovely area to stroll among a remnant of the Joseon dynasty (1392-1910) where you can view restored Korean wooden homes plus galleries, cafes, and shops. Hilly streets that reminded me of San Francisco. Great views. We reached it by taking subway line 1 to Jongno 3-a, then transferring to line 3 to Anguk.

review_title: Bukchon is good place to see the traditional korean houses
review_body: Bukchon is good place to see the traditional korean houses. and it is near samcheong-dong where you can see many boutique shops.

You don't really have to do much research to locate the best photography spots here because they have people (and a tourist information counter) placed throughout this residential area to lead tourists around with a proper Buckhon Hanok village map. On the other hand, if you are searching for some houses which may have been used as filming locations, you will have to come prepared as these information are not disclosed (rightfully so, as to not disturb the residents of those houses). All in all, there are a lot of tourists around the area so silence is vital to maintain its peaceful nature. Come prepared with a good pair of shoes though, as the climb can be pretty steep (especially for the elderly).

I love almost everything in Bukchon. Well except that you may need to go up the steep roads. But you'll love the view up there. I started from Samcheongdong. Less climbing than to those who started from Anguk Station.

It is a place full of korean traditional hanok houses. Most of the hanok houses are currently with residents stay inside. Therefore, you can only take picture and admire its architectural design from the outside of houses. Some houses are developed into shops such as coffee shop, tea shops, fashion shops, etc. It is a pleasant neighbourhood with nice and ancient architecture.

We climbed up from Samcheong side (Kyeongbok Goong east gate), following the map given by the red moving tourist info girls. Make sure your legs are ready for the extremely steep staircases. Definitely not for elderly and those who are afraid of height.

review_title: great point for photo shooting and cultural view
review_body: i stayed at bukchon during my visit at korea.the best time to visit bukchon is early in the morning before 8am cause it is not crowded. so, this is the best time for you to shoot a nice photo.then ,enjoy your delicious breakfast at bukchon area.please get a map of bukchon from the bukchon tourism center before you walk around bukchon.if you visit at the right time, you may enjoy their cultural monthly show for free as well. please checked the schedule before you depart.

We visited a renovated Hanok house and received a guided tour with tea after. Plan to spend the afternoon as there is so much to see. There are other small museums and many shops. Look for the people in red shirts and red cowboy hats, they are there to give you information and detailed maps.

Good scereney for photo shooting. It takes you less than 2 hours to check over bukchon. There are few more attraction such as "korea palace", insadong market and etc that you can explore over that idea. 5-10mins Walking distance from anguk subway station.
Lovely place. In the morning very quiet and hardly trafic. Don't skip this in your visit to Seoul it is really worth it. Friendly people (all over in Korea)

It is not prevalent to see so many old (600 year-old) buildings in one place. Especially with all the gentrification and rapid urban development going on, this is a rare gem situated in the heart of the city. It is like walking back in time. I'm glad they preserve these buildings to give an insight to the past. It is good for a relaxing stroll as there are signs urging visitors to keep their voices low as it is a real residential estate.
We though we were going to visit an old village but we ended up looking at people's houses. It is an actual residential area where people decided to keep the traditional design..

review_title: Good way to see old stile Korean houses
review_body: A very nice place and very convenient location, as it is walking distance from many other attractions.I would not call it "a traditional village" as the majority of the constructions are quite new... But following traditional architecture, nevertheless I can't imagine a visit to Seoul without stopping by this place.1 hour should be ok for a good walk around

Streets are really steep but you can have a look of another time as you walk through the streets and watch the traditional Korean Home Architecture, built of wood and with curved tiled roofs. In buckchon-ro-11 there is a traditional house that can be visited in a guided tour that cost about 10 dollars, but it is worth the visit and when you finish it they give you a cup of a really good prune tea and you can seat as long as you wish and watch the garden and verandas of the house and also the city scape.

review_title: A traditional village in the heart of Seoul
review_body: Visit early in the morning around 9 a.m. before the hordes of tourists descend on this village. You can see the interesting architecture of the houses, especially the roofs and the doors/gates. There are museums within the village--some are for free. On the other side are small quaint stores.
Traditional homes and structures. Quiet alleys. Like nothing else you've seen. We stayed there a could night. Loved it but our backs protested the sleeping on floor challenge.

Bukchon hanok village is a combination of old and new buildings, with some cute stores. There are also several little museums that are independently run, and lots of residential housing. There were good photo opportunities, but overall, it wasn't quite as charming as I'd hoped. I did like that it's still functional, though. Note that this involves a lot of walking, including up steep hills. It's not really handicapped accessible. There were fairly clear signs and also Seoul tour information people who could give directions and provide maps. Overall worth an hour's stroll.

This area has many traditional korean houses, and it is well organized with plenty of tourist offices and good maps with recommendations on the houses, views and businesses in the area. Get one before you head out.

Not really knowing what to expect, so ended up a little disappointed. It is interesting to see traditional houses mixed with modern buildings, though. Lots of coffee shops. İt's okay visit just to chill & unwind.

Loved looking at the traditional homes there. It was a very nice sunny day and we took a slow stroll through the village. I wished that we had more time to spend there because there were interesting stores and restaurants to explore.

I felt like I spent endless hours looking for it. There were absolutely no signs, and I was shocked to see the number of other tourists who were similarly lost as I was, as the village is deemed a main point of interest in the city. That said, the neighborhood leading up to the village is charming enough that it makes up for it.

review_title: Traditional houses preserved in a modern city
review_body: Perhaps it is because I have visited Insadong before coming to Bukchon, I did not find this area to be as interesting as anticipated. There were traditional houses everywhere and small shops along the street. The area is a lot less crowded than Myeongdong or Insandong. The hanoks are more authentic here, but it also means some need a bit more upkeep to remain beautiful. The streets could be a little steep, so you need to be careful. Also, since it's not a walking street all the time, there may be cars marching through the narrow streets. This is a nice place for a leisurely stroll and to soak in the atmosphere of a bygone era. :-)
very nice part of Seoul with pretty traditional houses (hanok). If You know Korean dramas (and like it) You can find house, which played in Personal Taste (where Gae-in lived).

review_title: Very good for a walking tour
review_body: Well documented, and very scenic. Reminds me of San Francisco, with a Korean spin to it. The houses, the landscape. Beautiful, and along the tour route there will be cheap (1000-2000W) exhibits to allow you to go deeper. If you stick to the suggested route - you start from the tourist center, and take a great walk back to Insadong area. You can even visit the palaces which flank the neighbourhood.

The area preserved the traditional village setting. There are information guides wearing uniforms with hats with the letter I! These are steep hills so be prepared, better yet book a stay at a Hanoi locally and stay for an evening. Lots of restaurants, plenty of tourist shops, and there is a visitor center which can give you a map in English.
it has a nice area around with a lot of small shops and cafes. each of them very unique. nice art work to buy
maybe in the past it had to be a great place, it still keeps some of the old fashioned style. you'll enjoy walking around 1 hour for sure

The neighborhood has home with old korean architecture. Stays open from 10 am to sunset. Nearby (betweem Bukchon and Seoul Museum of Modern Art) is a small market with quaint shops and eateries. Do have this place on your itinerary!

review_title: Great place, worth a stroll around
review_body: Here the old style houses line the streets and it is a lovely stroll around this area to see them and how cool it is that they have been integrated into modern day Seoul. The buildings, carvings, decorations, dragons, architecture is amazing. The streets are so clean with boutique unique coffee shops, restaurants and clothing stores all over the place. Really enjoyed my walk around, and even went back another evening. Very convenient from the metro. Totally different from Seoul city centre.

review_title: Take a Little Stroll Back in Time
review_body: Strolling the streets of the Bukchon Hanok Village is like stepping into Joseon Dynasty Korea for a while. The traditional houses are beautiful and kept in pristine condition considering their age.I suggest getting a map in your language since the streets felt a bit like a maze or labyrinth at times; although, there are so many people around, it would be nearly impossible to get lost. There are some really fantastic views of the city from this area as well; so, it makes for some perfect photo ops as well.Some of the hanoks have been turned into tea rooms, museums, and art galleries. This would be pretty much the only way you could view the interior of one of these historic homes; because the rest are still private residences.Go when the weather is fine and you have a few hours to stroll.
A beautiful place where you can take some excellent photos and learn more about Korean culture. It's easy to reach by subway, there's a tourist center with information guides and maps in english.

review_title: Hanok Village in Bukchon, a Lovely place to visit
review_body: We went to walk around in Bukchon and visited the Hanok Village on our very first day in Seoul, which was just walking distance from our bed and breakfast.We fell in love with this old village immediately even though the whole village only consists in a few blocks, we can easily trolling through all these little narrow streets admiring the very well kept Traditional homes, the colors and the designs of these home are so amazing, from walking around these streets in this village, sometimes we catch a glimpse of Namsang Seoul Tower, seeing the contrast between Old and New.Also don't forget to stop by and take a Tea break at Bukchon Best Prospect Tea Museum, they served very good tea even though the price is a little expensive, but it worths it. Tea and coffee's culture are huge in Korea.

review_title: Bukchon Hanok Village is where the present meets the past !
review_body: I'm really impress with this place. Walking along this road, seems I were in Korean drama.At Gahoe-dong Alley, You can see the traditional Korean houses along with modern buildings and N Seoul Tower as the background. he traditional Korean houses are still inhabited by residents. You can catch a glimpse of residents' day-to-day life. The contrast of modern life and traditional building is the best point of this place, burglar alarms at the wall of traditional houses and modern cars.(People who live here must be great at driving because the alleys are so twisty. I think it is really amazing ! )You can enjoy nice and antique cafes and galleries alone the ways also. It takes a few hours to walk all areas but it's worth.

The info desk had a nice map in English, that was helpful! The streets were a little confusing, but if you follow the other guests - you'll do fine. There are a few shops, restaurants, and guest houses on the way. It's a nice stroll. The only setback is the fact that you can't see inside the houses (at least when I was there - in the evening). Overall, it's a good afternoon activity.

review_title: Excellent. To take pictures and have a date.
review_body: Excellent. To take pictures and have a date. Bukchon means nothern villiage. You can enjoy traditional houses, guest house, experience. Houses are real house where people lives. A little modernized. Never the less, from the hill you can see Jongro Tower and N Seoul Tour those are skyscrapers. Tradition house with modern back ground this is really good place.

This is my favourite area in Seoul for the old feeling. From up the hill you can see both the old and the new (old hanok houses against the modern skyscrapers of the city in the backdrop). The area surrounding Bukchon is full of cute shops and boutiques. There is a hanok museum right at the top of the Buckchon village which is worth visiting to try the hanbok (the typical Korean costume) on: this requires a fee of 8000 won but when we went we were the only one there so we could take our time, take photos around the museum while wearing the hanbok and generally enjoy the experience without the crowds. If you have only time to visit one area in Seoul when in Korea then I would definitely recommend Bukchon. It is also close to two of the main palaces.

review_title: OK but not as special as I thought it would be
review_body: Don't really understand all the fuss. The buildings are not as old as they are advertised just built in traditional style. If you go now (August/September 2014) you can see a couple be built.If you are new to Asia and have not seen traditional style buildings then it is worth a visit. If you've been to Asia before and seen old buildings elsewhere, especially Japan, then I think it can be missed. Plenty of cafes and restaurants and some good touristy shopping.Near to several other sites (palaces) that can be done all together 1 one day.

Bukchom hanok village has the most number of traditional koren houses in seoul. Although filled with shops and cafes for tourists and locals, it is still worth strolling along its narrow streets. To see real traditional korean houses, go to narrow alleys. It is advisable to try one of the quaint cafes for a quick rest.

We stopped by the Bukchon tourist information center and pick up a map. There are 8 Buckhon scenic views in total. We went to no. 4 to no. 8. Of all the view, the best ones are no. 5 and no. 6. It's the uphill and downhill view of a street between row of hanok.It was nice walking along the street where actual people are staying but I gotta say the hanok are too modernized. If you love walks, then this is a good activity for you. Otherwise I find Jeonju Hanok Village in Jeonju has more to offer.
It was a shame, there was a lot of modernisation to the buildings and it's surrounding area, clearly themed to target tourist and there is little to no access to the so called 'historic' sights.

Picking up a tourist map from the Bukchon Information Centre we spent a few enjoyable hours following the tourist trail and admiring the traditional architecture of Korea. The views from some of the high points are impressive, as are the picturesque, narrow lanes of the village.Whilst this residential area risks being overrun by us annoying tourists, judging by the number we passed and the 'please be quiet before 9am and after 6pm' signs, the village is well worth a visit.

Came here after reading reviews on internet about the village.Here's a few things you can probably do:1. Explore and admire the village + buildings2. Sit and drink @ various cafés/restaurants3. WalkIf you're in the area, you can just drop by. Otherwise, I feel it isn't worth the travelling.

There are people dedicated to help tourists that you could ask for directions and they'd also give you a free map.The place is hilly. You'd only see the facade or the roof of the traditional houses. Good for taking pictures. I found no other activity to do here.

This is the old part of Seoul with the original houses that used to run through the city. It is a steep walk up to the top however it is beautiful when you look over Seoul from the top. Great picture opportunities also from here. You can get guided tours, however we just went to the tourist information centre and got a map. The lady in there was really helpful and pointed out the best places to go and have a look. Loads of little shops and places to eat round the area also. This is really near Gyonbokgong palace, so you could do both on the same day.

review_title: its cool if you're in the area
review_body: if you happen to be in the area, than check it out. the nearby temples are worthwhile, but to make a specific trip here, is not worthwhile. small area, not very large, and its just a small area which is a quaint "hold" street. there is also an old school library/education center nearby

review_title: history of old style Korean house
review_body: actually, lots of this area is private are which is owned by citizen. but the government opens for public as a tourist destination. so, they suggest you not to make noisy sounds. you can see the typical of old style Korean house. my friend who was my guide said that this area is quite expensive. so, all the house might have expensive price.don't forget to take a map at the tourist information, because they give a direction how to explore this place. only few place in the Bukchon that have free entrance. if you want to see inside the house, you have to pay 10.000 won. if you want see all around Bukchon from 3rd fl., you have to pay also (but i forgot how much is it). i've found nothing special in here, just to improve knowledge about the Korean tradition. Bukchon is very near to Gyeongbokgung. so, after visit Gyeongbokgung, try to walk to find Bukchon.

Super beautiful, recommend you to take a walk during evening and sit somewhere near the observatory to chill. There is one famous local noodle shop - 手撕面 (in chinese), it costs about 7000 won for one set. It is super good.

Great place to spend a few hours wandering the streets of Bukchon. Loved seeing the old traditional houses in Seoul. The area has guided maps along the way as well as Korean guides which speak a variety of languages which are very helpful (look for the people in the red vests - languages they speak are written on their back).

It's actually a bit over-rated because the place is swarming with tourists, particularly the two main streets with the old hanok houses. Some of the teahouses are nice but overpriced. The walk through Samcheongdong and into Bukchon is nice though.

We walked here from Changdeokgung Palace and looked for a place for lunch. Found a pizza place, very good. Then walked around the historic homes with the traditional tile roofs. Walked up hill and down hills. Could see Seoul Tower in the distance. There were stores for shopping also. Very picturesque.

Spend a few hours walking about the area taking in the traditional Hanok style houses. A few nice photo opportunities. There are quite a few museum/workshop type places where you can take part in making traditional crafts. I went to the Dong Lim Knot Workshop and made a necklace.
Perhaps the taxi driver didn't take me to the best part but what I did see wasn't very impressive. Just saw a few buildings and a historic house museum which was nice.

Got here on a stroll from Insa-Dong down the road and behind the Constitutional CourtIts a quaint place and has some very well maintained (though recently renovated) old Korean houses.It was a Thursday evening and the roads were deserted and I enjoyed walking in the narrow alleyways between these houses - This maybe the only photo-op a short stay Seoul visitor may get of Old Style Seoul/Korea. There is a walking tour route available with a clearly marked path.

review_title: Take your map, but then ignore it
review_body: This area of wandering narrow streets is filled with preserved older houses, many of them converted into small exhibits areas or so-called museums. It's fun to try to see how many of them you can find, based on the map distributed at information areas. It's just fun to wander, look in doorways, maybe stop at a museum or two. We saw the Gahoe Museum, Paper Doll Museum and Jewelry Museum. The latter has a somewhat high ticket price, but has a lovely collection. The views of Seoul over old tile rooftops are charming.

review_title: Beautiful little village inside the metropolis
review_body: Quaint little houses and streets, somewhat akin to old Korea (although also somewhat touristy). Certainly worth going for.

Since you are in Korea, this is a must visit place for tourist. Quite a long walk to the main place from the station especially during the hot weather. Wear comfy shoes and clothes. Nice spots for photography but can get quite crowded since the paths are narrow. There are some cafes around if you're tired after a long walk but they could be more expensive than your lunch meal.
I wonder if the old Seoul looked like this neighborhood. Anyway there are some nice spots inside but it is almost just a residential neighborhood, and it seems to be an expensive one.

I just walked around Bukchon with the map in hand, which you can get from the tourist information centre nearby. It is a quiet residential area. The houses are all traditional korean style. one or two are kept open to tourists. There was a lady there who explained to me about the features of the house. There are lots of small pathways in the streets so it is easy to get lost inside. But people are very nice there and will guide you if you are also nice to them. Overall it was a nice experience.

Bukchon Hanok Village is really wonderful. Do not follow any guide or path: just walk around wherever you want and make sure to get to the highest point, so that you can get an incredible view of the whole area. PS: the area is a residential district, so keep quiet while visiting.
i didn't do the treasure hunt or get any souvenirs but just walked around and saw the houses there's a view from the top :) a unique place to visit

Bukchon Hanok Village is still a residential district- houses are well preserved and are still occupied by various generations. Head to Bukchon Information Centre to obtain a map of the walking trails and be prepared to climb steep slopes in return for a magnificent view of Seoul and Gyeongbukgung Palace

Bukchon Hanok Village is unique because it is mostly residential. It is a quiet and calm area which is definitely worth visiting if you're only staying in Seoul. If you have more time in Korea I would highly recommend the Jeonju Hanok Village which is much larger and more interesting (it has lots of cute cafes and boutiques too).Pick up a map from the tourist centre and do some exploring in Bukchon :)

review_title: A throwback in time to peaceful, traditional Seoul
review_body: The visit to Bukchon was one of the more enjoyable aspects of my 5 day trip. If you are yearning for a respite from the city and all that shopping, it's worth visiting Bukchon.Recommended that you wear very comfortable walking shoes as there's lots of walking to do (think up hill and down hill as the roads are very steep), bring a bottle of water and a camera!The place is very scenic with lots of traditional Hanok houses/roofs!Did not spend much time walking around as it was summer and the sun was scorching hot! Took a rest at a cafe but would love to come back in the winter!

We went here looking for a specific restaurant, so we did not explore too much. It was hot and the place is hilly, but it's a unique neighborhood in a modernized city. Tourist information people hand out maps if you are hopelessly lost (which is easy to do) and it's imperative to keep quiet as it's a residential area, but it was a nice stroll.
Traditional Korean living district, recommend to walk there. Be ready for lots of ups and downs - the area is mountainous.

I enjoyed my visit to Bukchon. The walk around is peaceful and quiet. You get to see the old Korean houses and the view from the hills are beautiful. If you want a break from the city, this is the place to go. Would definitely love to go back!

review_title: Old Famous Korean style housing area
review_body: Way too many tourists in living areas. Visited the area with much nostalgia where I used to live as a kid. Some buildings seem to be out of the way and it does not appear to maintain the traditional Korean housing style any more. Eye sore. But it is still great to see many houses maintain the old style and receive local residents and tourists.

Took some time to find the village. From the route that we took, we have to get up a flight of stone steps before locating the village.The traditional houses are very beautiful. Especially when you can find rows and rows of it. They had inhabited houses, so we took care not to make too much noise. A lot of the houses we found are unique and we took some great shots.However, the area is filled with tourists. If there had been less tourists, I think it would have been a more relaxed stroll in the village.

A laidback place that's still located in Seoul, you get to experience the past while not travelling too far. Do not forget to visit the observatory as well, since you can get to see the view of Bukchon from above.

I walked by myself in Bukchon. You can book in for a free guided tour but I did not have the time to do this and i also thought it would be rather too long for me (about 3 hours). I walked up to the Tourist Centre and got a map of the area from them. I also told them my time frame and the girls at the centre advised me on the the best route. I only covered about half the area but it was a lovely, interesting walk, quite a lot up hill. I went into the open house which is run by the Museum. I wandered up and down the streets admiring the traditional houses and looked out over the city from the high spots. I would have loved to have done more but the day was very hot.
This is one of the few places you can see what Korea looked like before she became an economic giant. Take time to wander through slowly before walking to Chandeogung Palace.

review_title: good to see Korean traditional house.
review_body: beautiful Korean traditional house. There are some traditional house to stay.

This is one area not to be missed if you are in Seoul. A stroll through the streets of this lovely Korean village, with the traditional homes still being lived in, is an absolute treat for any traveler.
We visited on a Saturday morning. Very interesting to see a traditional Korean upscale neighborhood that dates back centuries but still functions as a residential area. Worth the 1-2 hours to stroll
It was interesting looking at the places where people lived. Want to try staying in a Bukchon the next time

review_title: one of my favourite places in Seoul
review_body: I would highly recommend taking the time to see this areaThere is an info office on one of the main streets where you can pick up a map and an itinerary and it shows you around most of the area and gives an insight into the life of the villagers who lived there and worked for the palaces surrounding the area, its very interesting and awesome views from the top of the city
But quite but not off the beaten track, still enjoyable. Gives a good picture of how the city used to be.

The awesome part about Bukchon, is that it is alive and utilized in compliance with its purpose - as a residential district. Inhabited traditional houses are mixed with culture centers, shops and cafes, street vendors and even a school. the district is laid-back and bustling at the same time, and every corner worth sticking your nose into =)However, if you plan a visit, please note that tourists are kindly requested to keep reasonable hours (around 10 am to sunset).

I went there on a Friday afternoon. I didn’t read up much on this place before I go so I was expecting it to be a fully developed tourist location. However, most of it is a local living neighborhood. It is nice to walk around this neighborhood slowly, as it got a lot of traditional houses and the view are stunning.

The houses and streets here are well kept and they are really beautiful. It is like going to a different city but it is located in Seoul. A place not to be missed!Get a map from the tourist center to help you go around the place easily, or ask the guides that are stationed there!
In here you can see traditional houses of korea and some handicraft that they made.You can try walking around here while eating some ice flakes. Yum ~♥

Make a turn off a busy street into this quaint neighbourhood with beautifully preserved traditional housing. There are still people living inside some of these houses while a few had been turned into galleries or shops, so there is a courtesy hour they ask people to observe (basically don't go there too early or too late). It's a steep walk with no facilities, but is worth it. If the weather is too warm or cold, get yourself a nice iced/hot coffee to-go from the little cafe right at the start of it to enjoy during your walk.
Nice afternoon spend doing arts and crafts with the locals. Kids enjoyed and had a taste of Korean crafts and culture including painting, bracelet making, jewellery box making. Time well spent!
This is a very accessible place to visit on foot. Delightful architecture and glimpses into inner courtyards with view of distant hills. September 2012 was a pleasant time to stroll there

review_title: Steep walk but well worth it!
review_body: Put on some comfortable shoes and get ready for an uphill walk. You'll love the architecture, view and stretches of cafes!

Hanging around at bukchon could easily spend you a day or couple. It's a place with rich historical stories and places there are full of Japanese accents. Little handicraft shops at reason am price are also key attraction

review_title: Traditional houses with the background of modern Seoul
review_body: Bukchon traditional Village is a great walk even though you would have to walk uphill at most of the streets. You would be able to see the beautiful traditional Korean houses, if you walk uphill a little more, you will see the modern high rises. I really enjoyed this place and it do not take long time. and It is just walking distance from Insadong. Get the free map from the tourist office at the main street.

review_title: Great place to see Korean tradition and quaint cafes and shops!
review_body: This area is definitely something travelers must go to when in Seoul. Not only can you see many examples of traditional Korean architecture with different streets lined by hanoks, but there are also various shops that focus on design along the nooks and crannies of the area. The streets from the hanok village towards Samcheongdong area are also lined with many different types of cafes and shops. There are also a lot of quirky street art, a feast for the eyes and photographers. It is a great place to stroll about, wind down, have a cup of tea, and maybe shop for eclectic items. We brought traditional Korean sweets from one shop, then a french baguette from a specialty bakery, took a break at a tea garden, gazed at the Blue House, and then window shopped at several of the boutiques in the area.

Bukchon really brings you back to the traditional old days and has a great vibe to the area. The hanok houses villages are beautiful. Great walk in the neughbourhood make sure you bring comfy shoes as there is a lot of uphill walking.Close by on samcheongdong road there are loads of cafés and shops which are certainly worth a visit
This is a neat area, with an older feel, to walk around in. Just take a stroll, grab a meal and do a little shopping, including a nice chocolate shop!

A lovely place to visit after you have finished the palace. The houses are all built on slope and the uniqueness in the houses take you back to ancient history. Make sure you wear good walking shoes.!

We had a good time and I loved all the little houses in the Hanock Village. However there were people EVERYWHERE. Not sure if it is that busy every day but it made it feel much less like exploring and more like everyone was just shuffling through it together. Still got some good photos and saw some interesting things though! Would probably suggest going on a weekday not in the holidays if you can to avoid the crowds!
Bukchon was great for shopping and eating, near the palaces and Insadong. Great place for traditional Korean food.

review_title: Great for a walk back in time
review_body: Fans of Heartstrings 넌 내게 반했어 (a.k.a You've Fallen For Me) by Jung Yong Hwa of C.N. Blue and Park Shin Hye, and Personal Taste 개인의 취향 by Lee Min-Ho and Son Ye-Jin will not be unfamiliar with the filming locations of the Korean dramas in Bukchon Hanok Village!Bukchon Hanok Village (북촌한옥마을/北村韩屋村) is home to hundreds of traditional houses called 'hanok' that date back to the Joseon Dynasty. Many of these traditional houses are currently used as cultural centres, teahouses and restaurants.Great for a leisurely walk. Photography lovers will enjoy the walk with the beautiful architecture.
Go here if you wanna see the country's traditional houses. You could easily stroll this place and it's for free. Take pictures everywhere!

It's worth spending an hour in the area to see the traditional Korean houses. Besides, you can also find some cute little shops that carry some unique stuff.Make sure you have comfortable shoes on when visiting there.

We made our way here from the Gyeongbokgung Palace and The national Folk Museum. It's not too far to walk at all. There are over 900 Korean traditional houses in this area. It is like a village frozen in time although the location is in the middle of the city. Although there are restaurants, cafes,art galleries, museums etc, it is still a residential area and there are many signs requesting to refrain from speaking loud. There were 2 tourist volunteers at the entrance to the area and we were given a map showing various routes to follow and specific areas marked on the map for great photo opportunities. It is definitely worth a visit.

review_title: come and see before commercialism takes over
review_body: I would like to ask the world to come and see "Northville" before cheesy tacky commercialism takes over just like it did to Samchung and Insadong. Some people might argue it already happened, but i still believe there are independent spirits trying hard to not be swept away. This is a cool neighborhood. You dont get to see a lot of 80 year old houses in Seoul with growing kids and veggie garden. Its absolutely rare to see open sky. Young and creative artists showrooms and ateliers.Northville used to have it all but its changing. Come and see before its too late.

Split by a main road into 2 parts, the western side is larger with uphill streets lined by old houses which make for nice photo shoots. Some houses hold art displays that are free to view while others collect entrance fees. Drop by the tourist info office for a map guide before you start exploring. One is along the main road 500m south of or before the entry roads to the village. The other is about 300 m up across the road opposite the 1st office. There are several cafés which serves as rest stops and to quench your thirst after the long routes.

review_title: Cute little part of town with nice cafés and stores
review_body: I walked through Bukchon on the way from Gyeongbokgung Palace to Changdeokgung Palace. It is a charming area with cute little houses, cafés, bakeries and some really nice stores such as 'Object'.

review_title: A land back to the past
review_body: Get the feel and architecture glimpse of traditional Korea era by roaming the hallway & streets of Hanok. A village that gives you ease & an eye opening land to your heart.

review_title: Take time out for a 'time capsule'
review_body: This has become one of the 'must do' sights in Seoul, and deservedly so. Translated as 'northern village', this well preserved time capsule of domestic architecture sits comfortably between two of the extensive northern palaces and is becoming increasingly popular, thanks to relatively recent publicity and promotion.As an architectural conservationist, I have a few issues with the commercialisation and sanitisation of parts, but am delighted that it is being maintained and integrated with the community.Allow a few hours; take your time and savour the all-to-rare historic environment, set against the backdrop of the expanding high-rise metropolis.

It was excellent place and residential place. Please keep silent during visit at there because it was is a residential neighborhood where people actually live. Bukchon Hanok Village is a Korean traditional village, those are staying with many yangbans (people from the ruling class). From there, we can visit a lot of different types of design. It was impressive. There are also a number of museums of traditional Korean culture including the Gahoe Museum, the Han Sangsu Embroidery Museum, the Museum of Korean Art and many more to get more information about hanok.

I recommend that you have at least 2-3 hours set aside for Bukchon to meander through the streets. The Hanoks or Korean design houses are beautiful and they are found. In various corners. Meandering through the alley ways and the streets are the best way to just enjoy the architecture and the quiet neighbourhood.

review_title: A leisurely stroll in an old-style neighborhood
review_body: The traditional giwa tiled roofs of the traditional houses (Hanoks) make this area in Seoul quite uniquely interesting. Head to the Information Center near the Jeongdok Public Library to grab a tourist map and walk at a leisurely place around. Note that the Korean Tourism organized guided walking tours are no longer provided due to complaints from the residents about crowds and noise, so be quiet and respect the people that live in the area!

review_title: Definetely my favourite spot in Seoul
review_body: Bukchon is definitely my favorite spot in Seoul.. it is a great area with narrow winding street, I find my self lost in the time, wandering what life was a long time ago. Go there early in the morning when the place is still quiet - less tourist.If you are into traditional culture and heritage, love architecture and have soft feeling for old times - this is the place you need to visit in Seoul.

review_title: Find a Hanok to stay in
review_body: What a great area – narrow winding streets, small cafés, art galleries, quirky little craft shops, and brave souls living like the Koreans of old in Hanoks. Sandwiched between the palaces to the east and west, and the narrow streets of Insadong to the south filled with bars and restaurants, Bukchon is a taste of Korea that you are not going to get staying in a large hotel tower.If you can't stay, go for a walk through the streets, try some soju at the cultural centre, or marvel at the restoration work underway on the houses.

This might just be my favorite place in Seoul. The first time, we dropped by the museum, which gave a good preview of a Hanok. It was early in the morning and most of the shops were still closed. So we had to visit it again during the day and it's nice to walk around and drop by the small boutique shops. It's good to know that regular people still live there although I also feel bad for them because there could be big groups of tourists walking pass by.

Really nice hilly stroll through an older neighborhood in Seoul. I wish we could have gone into more of the homes. If you do go, you have to look carefully and research which ones are open to visitors. Make a point into going into a few. Really special experience!

Quaint village... a little like you are walking through a movie setup for a period drama shoot.Go early before the crowd comes and you may get a good shot of the buildings, architecture and small lanes.We started on a small road immediately after the palace (this place is next to a famous palace but eh name escapes me at time of writing this review) - and this section are mostly residential.On the other side, there are lots of small shops and restaurants/food stalls.So, go for a visit, have lunch plus some window shopping/browsing.Overall, a lovely lovely visit and yes, I would recommend a visit to this place.
The surrounding is nice and very suitable for photo shooting, having fun around, but too many people and hard to take a very nice scene. If lucky you may find some hidden view in the alley.

Great to see all the gorgeous hanok houses,had afternoon tea at one that has been turned into a cafe.Area has great atmosphere and some great fashion boutiques.Walked here after going to Changdeokgung Palace which is a 5 minute walk around the corner.

The traditional houses are nice but i dont think the walk is worth the hike. I stopped midway through at a beautiful tea house and enjoyed a cup of ginger lemon tea and seoul views in autumn. I'd go again but just for the cuppa tea.

Its very informative and you're faced with beautiful buildings from the past. Some are used as shops/ restaurants but others are residential areas. So we had to be quiet so as not to disturb them. I would advise you to wear comfy shoes because there will be lots of walking and hiking!

review_title: Old n new co-exist side by side!
review_body: use the subway: Line 3, Anguk Station, exit 2. Walk to the Tourist Info booth close by and pick up a map of the heritage walk. Well worth the 1-2 hour stroll, with a stop at one of the cute small cafes on the walk path. The one we went was adjacent to the Music Boxes store. Had a really small n cute outdoor seating in the courtyard surrounded by the cafe indoor seating. Had relics from the past, including a old horn type HMV gramaphone. You will see the various designs of traditional hanuk homes, with a smattering of places offering various types of workshops. Dont miss this!
Memorable cultural walking trip! Lotsa photo taking opportunities! Traditional houses are very well maintained. Had breakfast at a traditional house and it was yummy! Can spend an entire day here!

You can get to experience and see traditional house here. Very nice place for people to visit and getting the feel of old traditional house. Their house are very well maintained and it's easy to get here via subway.

review_title: Beautiful traditional building but nothing special
review_body: It's a nice stroll if you come with your partner, but there's really nothing special.Might be better and able to experience more if stay in one of the hanok hostel.There are some unique stores selling art and crafts, nice cafés, but all are pricey.

A must visit in seoul, where the traditional old quarter situated in the middle of modern glitzy seoul. A comfortable stroll next to the palace and Insadong area. Can easily spend about an hour or two. Has the lovely korean traditional houses. We'll preserved. If lucky can visit some inside and take a look. Has some lovely cafés and art galleries.

May be nice for Korea; but doesn't compare to other historical districts in China or Japan. Very easy to find, just walk out of the subway and walk down the street. There is maps in the subway station. And the information desk provides maps to use for walking. I do like just walking around and plenty of nice shops and restaurants. Just not that special for historical district.

These streets and alleys takes you away from Seoul, like to an other city. Small roads and characteristic buildings are mainly well kept. There are several wonderful coffee shops, tea houses, restaurants and small shops. You must try one of those bakeries, just delicious.

Interesting to see the mix of old (traditional houses) and new (latest model of cars). You walk up and down the hills to visit real people's residences. Get a map at the information center. The map points out 8 suggested spots in this area for good picture talking. We had a very nice lunch in this area and had a nice stroll in the neighborhood after meal. Follow the map and read the information provided. It is worth a visit.
A great hike where tradition meets modernity. Gives you a glimpse into old Hanyang. Look out for the photo spots.
This is a great neighborhood. Take your time and stroll through all of the little alleys. There are great views of the city from some areas. The roving tourist helpers are wonderful!

The access to go there is very easy by subway. Getting off at Anguk Station, Line 3, take exit 2, and you will find a tourist information booth where you can get a map. Without a map it is a bit confusing. This is an awesome place because it mixes the Korean traditional houses with the modern part of Seoul. What I like the most about this place it that it doesn't get crazy and super crowded like Gangnam, Hongdae, Itaewon... It's very different. There is a lot of cute places to eat (Western and Korean food) along with coffee shops, and a bunch of cute little stores where you can find from jewelry and clothes to handcrafts. I definitely recommend this place!!

review_title: Not at all what I thought
review_body: I saw a lot of beautiful photos of Bukchon Traditional Homes so I expected a lot. But I was a bit disappointed as not did we walk way far from the metro station, but it was a steep climb up as well to reach the actual houses. They were awesome yes, but you can only take photos outside. Map was a bit confusing to us and there were no helpful signs along the way.

This was a really interesting part of Seoul. We got a map at the information center which gives your observation points and places that have appeared in korean dramas. We loved the narrow alleys with beautiful traditional Korean houses neatly packed together. Do walk down the stair alley for experience! Alot of walking to be done here though, so wear your most comfortable shoes and bring your camera! Do also try the traditional tea tasting here.Another reason I loved exploring Bukchon was because there were many interesting buildings along the way, and many coffee shops! Waffle and coffee are a must try.

This is really an interesting part of Seoul. Get a map from the information center and head north towards Bukchon. The left side part which is Hanok is much more interesting. We really enjoyed the twisting streets and the narrow alleys and of course the traditional houses with very low roofs. There is an observation point where one can have a magnificent view of the surrounding mountains and the Gyeongbokgung palace. Nice antique and art shops specially the one close to the main entrance to Hanok village (check the photo attached)

A nice place to take photographs but have to walk quite a bit from the nearest train station. It is a worth visiting place in Seoul as it is a place where visitors can embrace the beauty of traditional Korean houses.

review_title: view of the traditional and modern seoul
review_body: we took the subway to go here so it was a bit of a walk but the tourist guides (with the letter "i" on their hat) can speak good english and can guide you on which part to visit. get the map from the information center before you start the tour. it will take you 4 hours to go around bukchon but if you only want to see the spots for nice for pictures, then there is a short cut (it is marked with red line on the map) and will take you about an hour to complete. go up a little bit further and there is a great view of the traditional houses and then at the back are the modern buildings of seoul. i think the place looks better with snow but unfortunately there is no more snow when I visited. there are several gift shops in the area plus cafes and restaurants. after completing your tour here, you can go straight to insadong which is just near the area.

There are many Korean traditional house village and Buckchon is the one in Seoul.If you are going to stay just in Seoul, I recommend you to stop by here, because traditional village in Seoul is just this one.And It's next to Gyungbock goong,(royal palace) so It will be easy for you to find it.But if you are staying in R.O.K more than 1 week, I think It will be better for you to go to the countryside just like Junjoo or Andong.There are many traditional villages there and those ones are much more better and in the countryside, there is a traditional show so you can enjoy the show.

review_title: Mix of traditional and modern houses
review_body: A place that is good for evening walk and taking photographs. Not much to see here, only traditional/modern houses.Make sure you grab the map at Bukchon tourist information so you know how to explore it right. Bukchon is a big area, get lost among the alleys and enjoy the view! But if you go here during the winter, make sure you wear something to keep you warm. There're a lot of local restaurants nearby, make sure you try one of these ;)

review_title: Great little shops in quaint village
review_body: Be prepared to walk and if in winter, then dress very warm. A web of small streets with a variety of shops to browse in. When hungry, there are numerous cafés and restaurants to try. We had traditional Korean cuisine in a restaurant with no English name and hence will not be able to write a review on it. However it was hearty hot pot black sauce teibokki that was great on a zero degree day!We had amazing waffles in a Cafe Dal along Samcheongdong gil, an adjoining road.
the most beautiful place .... traditional places !! .... thats korea .... not just kpop and dramas .... this is the real south korea !
This area has some lovely old houses. Unfortunately, not all are restored and they can be an eyesore. To see these houses, though, is well worth the walk.

There are 2 ways that you can get there:1) From Exit # 2 of Anguk Statio2) From Exit #5 of Gyeongbokgung Palace StationWe walked from Gyeongbokgung Palace Station, along the palace wall to samchengdong area. We saw a signboard "Bukchon Hanok Village", however after walking some slopes and around the area, we just could not find it. We saw a sign "Tourist Information Center", however, we could not find that too.We wanted to give up but we saw a long slope. We decided to just try and walk up. It is about 10-15 mins walk up a slope. Along the slope, on the left side, you can see the city. Then finally there is a turn! And we found the place! Luckily we persevere on! And we are lucky that we climbed that slope as the main photo street of Bukchon Hanok Village is a super super steep slope if you climb up from there. For us, we climb down from that street. Along that street, there are all the traditional houses. However, I was kinda disappointed as I was expecting more houses instead of only on this street. Anyway, just took several photos, walked around samchengdong and I left the place. Nothing much and you need to spend some time and effort climbing all the slopes... At least I don't feel worth going there.

review_title: A great place to stroll in Seoul
review_body: This area has a mix of tradition mixed with modern amenities. There are so many museums, restaurants and quiet streets to visit. It's very photo friendly if you want to create great memories of Korea and it's connected with other major attractions. Please pick up a map from the tourist info booth before trying to explore on your own ... Bring a camera!

review_title: Nice change from the Big City
review_body: We visited the home area and went to a tea house. This is a beautiful part for the city and very different from the big city feel.. Lots of great artistic shops. We purchased some needlework and pottery here

This neighborhood is a fascinating walk back into Old Korea. Of the many times I have been to Seoul, somehow I have missed this neighborhood. I had even been to both Palaces that border this slice of history and still had never heard of it. I took Metro Line 3 to the Anguk stop. Walking out of Gate 2, one block down the road I found a Tourist Information Center. The woman there spoke English very well and provided me with a map and verbal advice that was wonderfully helpful. I followed the recommended map route which worked very well for my intentions. The walking course took me along the nostalgic streets of this old neighborhood past many of the old houses (and a few reproductions) as well as several rustic alley ways. There were a lot of picture-worthy sites. Along the way, there were also a few boutique shops that kept with the theme of the neighborhood as well as small restaurants and coffee shops that looked inviting. It was fascinating to see this place. It truly was a walk back in time. For those who have the time, there were also several activities and a couple of museums/galleries that were available. I would definitely recommend planning to at least stroll through this area. Before you do so, stop by the tourist information center to get an orientation.
Bukchon is gorgeous and very atmospheric. Weekdays are uncrowded, and it's possible to go inside some of the old houses - some for free. I really recommend a walk around.

review_title: a journey to the old Korea
review_body: while other corner of Seoul is hype and crowded, full of cafe and make up store and fashion, this corner is very silent and the house are still well kept in Korean traditional houses. this village is still so pure and people still living inside the house so be aware to not just enter and photograph, since there is some rules for photographing people in Korea please ask permit when you want to photograph them in their house. the houses is all private and some houses offering courses on Korean traditional drink 'soju' making, knotting, painting etc. the great thing is we can go to observatory, its on the hill part of Bukchon and held by old lady, from 3rd floor we can better view this whole village with palace on the background.the place offer green tea and coffee, in winter this is the warming station after freezing discovering korean tradition. :)

review_title: Explore Bukchon and learn more about Korea
review_body: This old village is a must visit. In here you will see not just the shoot locations of your favorite K-drama but also the old and traditional Korean houses. The architecture and designs of these old houses is a preview of the Korean culture. You should not miss it.

This area is full of little nice but surprising museums : chicken museum, embroidery museum, amulets museum. We even got the unplanned opportunity to learn how to paint on wood and get a tea ceremony. So don't hesitate to try some of those little museums , you never know what awaits you inside !

Outside Anguk subway station and around a corner, Bukchon has many of the traditional Hanok still standing.We went on a snowy day where the flurries added a sweet icing to the cake, perfect for photos.

review_title: Nice place to walk and see the architecture
review_body: We combined this with a walk around Insadong and then back to our hotel - The Metro Hotel. It's a lovely place to take pictures.
..to see Korean traditional homes in the heart of Seoul. Nice small shops with handicrafts are nice and lovely.
Explore the romantic walks on a quiet weekend and have some hot tea in their quaint cafes. Lots of galleries are open to the artsy fartsy set.

review_title: Take the time to view these typical hanok, traditional Korean houses.
review_body: Yesterday was frigid but we made our way up the hill and what a delight it was to view these lovely old,and or reconstructed homes is the old fashion. Most have been turned into restaurants, coffee shops or shops with varying merchandise, much of it quite ethnic and interesting looking. We were cold enough that we were finally driven into a coffee roasters where we had a divine and warming mocha latte. We took any number of photos of some of the more interesting "homes" but as darkness set in we decided that we should head back to the station.
