On our way downhill, we sopped to watch a gal half seated, half lying on the ground, who was heating a pot of sugar over an open flame (probably about 5 minutes) until she could pour this carmel colored "batter" onto a baking sheet where she folded it in half, cut it into 3 equal pieces, flattened each piece with a spatula, and then impressed each with a different imprint. She was selling them for 1 won each and you'd have thought she was giving away diamonds - basically just burned sugar but warm and wonderful - a sight we've not encountered before. Give it s try if you see it.

My parents, 76 and 70 years old and my self visited this village as I searched from online that its very near the place we were staying from Somerset Hotel, so with the guidance of the map and very helpful Souls of Seoul we tried to visit this village. Albeit cause the Osteoarthrtis of my father to act up, we soldiered on. We saw the famous street and its really beautiful, worth to take a photo as a memento. We chance upon one Hanok house that you need to pay 10 dollars as entrance fee, with the history of the house, guided tour and free delicious plum tea and you can stay as long as you like.if you can spare some cash , go and vist it, its worth it. You can see from the balcony the thatched roofs of the other Hanok houses, although some are residentials and people really are living there so need to be respectful of their privacy. But there are some Hanoks that can be visited just like we did and i say its worth the orice.There's a lot of interesting cafes, restaurants, stores you can broswe upon and I might say the people are very friendly.One can identify some locations from the dramas if you are a Korean drama fan.

review_title: A must see when visiting Seoul
review_body: This place is indeed a surprise. My friend was leading us to this place, saying its like a Korea cultural village. It was much more than expected. So many amazing architectures, we could not stop taking photos. Also, there are many arts and crafts lessons if you wish to partake in. My only regret was that we were there at about 2pm and most of the places close by 5pm, otherwise we could have explored more.
Beautiful traditional Korean houses. It's a real residential area so gotta keep your voice low... Go there for sunset! It's definitely worth the visit.
Very authentical residential area. It gives a good impression of local customs as well. there are maps available to guide you through the villlage

Went to Bukchon in the afternoon after heading to Gyeongbokgung. Walkable distance from gyeongbokgung and tosok ginseng chicken, would be good to take a day tour around the area. There are many tourist information centres at different spots to ask questions and get maps. There are also walking information guides dressed to red who can help to give directions around. Some of the museums provide demostrations on korean culture but comes with admission fee.Overall, a nice place to experience korea culture and see the hanok architecture.
如果你愛看漂亮的建築，如果你酷愛拍攝。。你超愛這里。。and there have very sweet shopping area uphill from 安國地鐵站，it's a bit like 自由之丘in Tokyo....all the shops are very cute....

Worth going to see the unique village and the houses. Just be aware it's basically uphill the whole way so not an easy walk. Easy to get to from the subway station and a short walk from Insadong shopping area.

The site itself was a bit far from the train station so my mother (being a senior citizen) had a bit of a hard time walking. I had to ask for directions from a tourist stall we came across. Upon arriving at the "village", it was nice to take photos in front of the Korean houses. Lovely cultural place. The day we visited though, there were a lot of police due to a demonstration so it was kind of unnerving to be walking with all of them around.

This is a real village that people live in. And it looks straight out of the old Korean dramas! There are free maps of the roads, and there are many little homes that offer you to make a Korean craft (paid). Or you can walk around and just take pictures. Also there is an artsy hipster like area where there are art, hand-craft items shops and little coffee shops. Very cute. What's also nice is that there are about 9 picture spots that are truely nice.
Great houses there, very culturalI really wish to be there again, sooner or later maybeTake the pictures front of the houses
I enjoyed thus little area, quaint shops. It was snowing, and cold but places for a coffee along the way. Enjoyable atmosphere. Not an earth shattering have to do, but fun.
Basically new or refurbished homes and streets set to look old but clearly for the wealthy in Seoul. Not so great but the odd original house is worth a look.
This is really not much more than a pleasant walk. Make sure you get a local map from the local tourist guides - you can't miss them dressed in all red.

Great place to know more about historic and cultural Seoul. An enjoyable walking tour through alleys and slopes, passing by traditional Korean houses, handicraft shops and residential areas. A very unique place to explore apart from the highly satisfying shopping trips in Seoul. Get a map from the tourist centre, follow the trail and look out for the "photo taking" spots. Don't miss these spots as they are really places to take breathtaking pictures. Immerse in the charms of Samcheongdong while taking your walk to Isadong. Experience the serenity, comfort and character in this area. A nice change from the bustling Myeongdong and huge shopping malls in Dongdaemum.

This is actually one of those heritage places that even though goes on with their usual lives, also allows the tourists to have a peak at their culture. The whole Bukchon is spread over steep and narrow alleys that have traditional Korean houses aligned along its line and along with these houses; you also get to see lot of handicraft shops and restaurants that serve authentic Korean cuisines. The walking tour is actually the best way to see seoul in its day to day life and you could interact with the natives to learn about their culture and lifestyles. The walking tour actually comes with proper instructions and guidelines so that you do not get lost around here. The place being an active residential area requires one to be in their best behavior so as to not meddle with the daily chores of the people living around here. The whole place is very quiet and serene and has lots of attractive and impressive view.

Like this place but try to go there in the afternoon to avoid group tours in the morning. There are areas where you can take a photo with n Seoul tower on the background. It's also near chungang high school famous place where winter sonata was shoot!!!

To get there, you need to get the subway to Anguk and follow exit for the village, once out keep walking straight and you can't miss the masses the tourists. The place itself is beautiful and have breath taking views. It was a nice change from the hustle and bustle of Myeongdong and there are several street food places jotted around the outskirts if the village, wifey would recommend the pasty that looks like a fish on the outside and red bean on the inside!

Walk up the hill to get away from the biggest crowds, and slowly take in the beautiful homes up here. Some are old, some are new, and some are new but made to looks historic. Virtually without exception, all are a feast for the eyes, with terracing and architectural flourishes that demonstrate an understated Korean luxurious life.

review_title: Nice change from the usual shopping activities.
review_body: Interesting old buildings but also many newer buildings that was constructed to replicate the old buildings charms. Too many shops and restaurants for my liking,

We did not spend much time here but I did manage to walk around the alleys and take lots of pictures of the old Korean styled houses. Perhaps it was due to the weather, extremely cold. The houses were very pretty and with the recent snow fall. Art and craft shops to visit!

Perhaps it was due to the weather, extremely cold.The houses were very pretty and with the recent snow fall. Art and craft shops should also be visited and experienced. Shopping is also interesting and actually slightly cheaper than Seoul with good quality too!

There are 8 spot for tourist to take photo within Bukchon, to complete the whole circle will take more than 1.5 hour walk (around 2.5km).Can reach there by subway @ Anguk Station, exit 3 and you could start the search of the spot follow the route shown in the tourist map (map could be obtain at Bukchon Cultural Center neat to Anguk Station exit 3). In my personal opinion, some of the spot could be omitted and Spot 1 & 5 got the most photogenic spot.Get ready for a good walk as some of the route are very steep.

review_title: traditional style buildings and a lot of walk
review_body: I would recommend to get the map from tourist center before start your walking trip in Bukchon. And pls be quiet!

A different feel from the usual shopping areas in Seoul as this area comprises of older architecture. Good to venture beyond the shops along the roads to see the homes on the steep hillside. Enjoyable cafes here too.

review_title: A lot of "new traditional" hanoks, but beautiful
review_body: I had a free guided tour all to myself, so it was quite nice, it gives you an idea of what real hanoks looked like however, most of them were reactualised,and there is also many museums abs things to see in the area. Wear good shoes as you're there for a walk! Although it was a rainy day I enjoyed the walk and sights
make sure you didn't make a noise when entering this beautiful housing area. These tradisional house is very beautiful to feast by your eyes.Love it

It was a cold day when we took a walk in the Bukchon Hanok 'village', where there are many rebuilt houses in the traditional style. Go prepared with good walking shoes so that you can enjoy the stroll. There are ample opportunities to snack and enjoy hot drinks. Thankfully the residents do not seem to mind us tourist taking photos outside their houses and along the streets.

Tourists who look like ethnic Chinese should be wary when walking along the narrow roads and taking photos. Some of the resident simply hate Chinese tourists and will abuse you and force you to delete the photos they claim should not be taken as Bukchon is not a public area. That was the experience of our group of 10 people on November 25, 2013. A woman from one of the residences with a dress tag describing her as a "staff" abused our group, snatched a camera to delete photos taken and screamed "we do not welcome Chinese to Korea. We hate Chinese!" We tried to complain to the "Information" people in maroon to no avail. The police were not helpful either, language was a huge problem. We are writing to the Korean ambassador to lodge our complaint.

We did not spend much time here but I did manage to walk around the alleys and take lots of pictures of the old Korean styled houses. It is nice to find history so well preserved here and there are lots of small restaurants in the periphery if you want to grab something to eat whilst walking around. I was told by the lady at the information office that the areas marked 5 and 6 on the map that they handed out was the most picturesque.

korean traditional houses right in the heart of busy seoul? surely you don't want to miss it! i think it's one of the best site in seoul. it's very near from changdeokgung palace, and you'll still have times to explore other sites nearby. i really love the architecture of the houses, but please be silent, for people are living in those beautiful houses. there was a backyard in a house with adorable exterior. i'm not quite sure what place it was, weather it was a cafe or just a backyard, but it was really-really charming. my advice: be prepared to hike the hilly pavement, and prepare your camera batery full.

This is a neighborhood near the 2 palaces (Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung) where sometimes houses of nobleman existed during Yi Dynasty. A lot of the traditional houses have been converted, but half or so houses still keep the traditional old flavor (and now they are unable to take them down and build modern structures). This is an area where you can experience staying in Hanok (Korean traditional houses with warm floors - Ondol), and over the years, many living national treasures have started to congregate to promote the traditional crafts and traditions. Few examples of such are: traditional artisan Soju maker, knot maker, embroidery, etc. It has become extremely easy to see this area as starting few years back, a detailed map can be obtained from tourist kiosk and follow the path.

I visited this place on last Sunday and it was very nice. If you want to see traditional Korean houses - Bukchon village is the best place. To go there you can take subway. Get down at anguk station. Form anguk station, it is at walk-able distance of 5-10 mints. For more clear directions you can also take help of help-desk near anguk stationThings to see here : - traditional Korean houses and roads.- In few place you will see some workshops for different activities. You can also enjoy over here.- There are few shops which sells some traditional things of Korea like ornaments.Overall place is very good for one time visit.

This is a place where someone should not miss if you want to feel like coming to korea. When we venture along the village streets, we could enjoy the Korean traditional houses closely. Streets are clean and quiet and we enjoy the serenity.

review_title: An adventure into history with a modern twist
review_body: Read ten things one must do when i am in korea!!! So went with low expectation with tourist trap mindset. But what a lovely surprise. I loved the small shops, and restaurants, loved the tourist shops, and loved that every corner was a surprise. I walked for hours and had a most wonderful time. The shops were so amazing and shop keepers friendly. I would really recoomend this for all who travel to seoul.

Although it did make for a good walk around to explore, I always all that amazed by the hanoks themselves. Lots were new, and some were still being constructed. I didn't feel very much like I was "back in history" like many others claim. Different experience for everyone I guess, just not a great one for me.
A great walk around the streets of old Seoul. It's free and you can really see and feel the history here. A must for you Seoul trip

Worth an hours walk after seeing one/some of the nearby temples. Gives a sense of what Seoul must have been like before the concrete took over. Lots of small guest houses for the more traditional stays. Small restaurants selling a lot of cheap traditional korean food....

review_title: cute town with lots to see!
review_body: it's a dynamic neighborhood with lots to see - with shops and people from around the globe in the most traditional Korean atmosphere

I went to Hanok village with my mother in early November. The old houses are very well maintained as there are people staying in them. It was nice to walk through the narrow streets although there were cars parked along it. Although the roads were quite steep, my mother still enjoyed it. Actually what I liked most was shopping around the area near hanok village. There were many eateries and shops which were busy and it was fun walking around. It's easy to get to - take the subway and drop off at Anguk station, exit 2. Walk for 300m straight and you will be there. I went there after strolling around Insadong street which is a slightly long but manageable walk from Hanok Village.

It's a nice neighborhood to go around and take pictures in, but that's kind of it. We went on a Sunday morning, so it was..sleepier than usual, I think. Be prepared for a lot of walking. We got tired pretty quickly. Luckily, there are a bunch of small restaurants in the area.

review_title: Traditional village in a middle of bustling metropolitan
review_body: I thought I was going to have a photographic feast in Bukchon Hanok. The houses were nice but to me, the whole area was nothing special. Only get a few nice shots because there were so many tourists flocked the houses. If you are planning to come here, you can start your walk from Insadong area, then make a stop at Ssamsigil (they have plenty of cute knick-knacks for your family back home), then continue your walk a little bit to Bukchon Hanok. There are plenty of tourist guides along the area just in case you need some directions.
We were able to check out one of the guest houses in this area. Very cute area. would love to try out the guest house the next time we visit Seoul.
Nice place to feel the past while being in the future. House are very nice and very authentic. Please respect that people are really leaving in these houses.

Enjoyed walking through Bukchon. The houses are traditional and historical but are occupied and updated in terms of front and garage doors. Would love to see inside the homes. Walked past one where the owner was installing an outdoor light fixture and could see the modern conveniences through the open gate (yes; I was looking). Fantastic view at the top of the street. Stand on top of the cement clock/cornerstone at dusk. Beautiful! Loved the character and feel of the neighborhood. Worth a look!

Walking through Bukchon is a very refreshing experience. You get an eclectic mix of shops, and there are also many small boutiques and boutique hotels there. There are also coffee places and tea houses for you to get a cuppa to soak in the atmosphere. All this makes a walk through Bukchon a different experience from other parts of the city.From Bukchon, you can also get a panoramic view of Changdeokgung, and there are many arts and crafts shops there too. Go to the tourist information at Changdeokgung to get a walking map of Bukchon.

Well not much feel of old Korea as when we were there, there are a lot of renovations going on there. Some of the old house you can sees it has preserve the old construction but using modern material. Example the main door entrance of the houses are using digital code lock but the door was old wooden style. :)For photography, this is a good background view of village buildings. We took a lot of picture here. Great things here was the Korea tourism guide are standing around the corner if you need any assistance. They will point you where to take the nice picture as per their map or flyer.

review_title: flash back to the old korea
review_body: this area are full with traditional korea house"hanok". my korean friend told me that all the villagers in this places were rich family who worked with goverment or have relation with the king in ancient year. this village is now recommended by unesco, hence some of the villager had to rent their house to be restaurant or to be various museums.some of the shops such as the rice cake (toppokki) shop in front of Doo Guest House has been operated for at least 35years by using the traditional style to cook the rice cake.i love this village and i stayed at the hanok house in this village for four days. the best way to explore the village is to have morning walk around the village and walk into the museum to experience the culture and traditional of korea.

If you don't have the opportunity to see the traditional houses (hanok) in Jeonju or in one of the folk villages, you should not miss Bukchon. There you can see these lovely old houses - and it's not a museum because people actually live there.

Bukchon Is an alley, where you can find the Hanok village, its not the real village but a re creation of what their traditionbal house looks like. I like the alley, where there are locals shopping for Korean made trinkets, there are also restaurants there that offer affordable meals

This is as authentic Korean village and entire experience was delightful!We lunched at a tiny family owned cafe...The language barrier was overcome by the welcoming warmth of the owners! The homes are lovely and the overall feeling was simply awesome!

review_title: Beautiful houses but not a tourist destination
review_body: This area has some lovely looking houses in the traditional Korean style. The area is not hard to get to from Insadong.However, it isn't really designed to be a tourist destination. These are people's houses. They live in them. There are signs asking the tourists to stay quiet (though they are not that effective). People living there try to drive to their house and tourists are blocking the way.There are few signs so it is a bit challenging to find the best streets of houses though there are often people in red shirts directing the tourists where to go.It was an alright visit but I felt quite awkward being in a residential area.

review_title: 600 years history, convenient to access by subway
review_body: Nice place not only it shows you 600 years history of Seoul in Bukchon, but also many nice shops established in the neighborhood. They sell hand made products. And there are some gallery and some art works placing on the street when you walk around Bukchon. The tourism develops not bad with well maintainance of Bukchon old style and the special landscape. Worth to have a day trip or a stay at traditional guesthouse at the area.

Had an amazing time wandering the alleyways of Bukchon and peeking into various shops. Samchongdong street has an overabundance of 'super cute' coffee shops, but the Sujebi restaurant with a long of Koreans waiting to get in as if it was a meatpacking club is a gem - they serve traditional handmade noodles.

review_title: A glimpse of Korean history and culture.
review_body: I arranged for a free goodwill guide for this Bukchon Hanok tour and we're so glad we did. The guide, Mr. Park educated us with the culture and history of Korea before we headed to the village. It is located in a hill which makes it even difficult to walk. I am so amazed that they were able to preserve the original structures of the hanoks built centuries ago. There are homestays to better feel what its like living in the past.
Wander around, get lost in the small streets, get into all the houses. Have coffee, tea, take your time. Discover Korean arts, Korean food. Experience Seoul away from the concrete jungle.
Was so tired after climbing the stone steps all the way to the top but you will see very interesting Hanok guest house. More picture taking!

review_title: Like the Hutong area of Beijing
review_body: Bukchon Hanok village is a sampling of ancient Seoul. Famous artisans and well connected families supporting the palaces used to live here. The area is near Gyeongbok Palace, Changdeok Palace and the Jongmyo Royal Shrine. I spent an entire day walking between these three places since I like to hike. It's possible to see women in traditional Korean wedding dresses using these street corners for photo opps on weekends. Steep hills and a few cobblestone roads make running or hiking shoes with ankle support a wise choice for touring these places.

Bukchon Village is an interesting place to explore and you can find many traditional Hanok over there. Good for taking pictures!I had written a blog on Bukchon Hanok Village you can read it at http://loveanqila.blogspot.sg/2013/09/travelogue-bukchon-hanok-village.html or www.loveanqila.blogspot.com under the travelogue tab.
An active neighborhood of traditional architecture. The view down from the hill looking at the rooftops of the old buildings is interesting. It was easy to get to with the subway.

review_title: A walk through the historical footpath
review_body: I loved this place! However, due to the wet weather, we only managed to spend half a day walking around the alleys and admiring the hanoks. For people who plan to visit, please respect that this is still an active residential areas hence please control your excitement and keep your volume down.

review_title: Amazing place to experience a bit of Korean
review_body: This place is very organized. There is a small information center before the walk starts. Just ask around where the information center is. They will give you a map and then you can follow the map to walk around all the typical Korean streets in the area. It can be quite hot if you go in summer time, however there are coffee shops you can stop, which makes is very enjoyable.

review_title: Probably the most beautiful place of Seoul
review_body: Walking though this typical old style streets you can feel the real hearth of Seul. Lovely shops and cafè make the atmosphere more enjoyable. You can find typical korean handicrafts (I have to say not very much..). Easy to reach using the Line 1 of the Metro. There are also some guesthouses.

The stretch of traditional Korean houses were very appealing to the eyes and for picture taking as well as the elaborate design of the houses were fascinating. Houses were located at the hilly side so it is quite steep going up and down. There were like two areas where you can see the stretch of said houses. Others traditional houses were mixed with the new ones in the area hence were not exclusively traditional houses in one location or village.The place has many restaurants, coffee shops, convenience stores. What is so great about visiting this place is that Korean Information (personnel who assists tourist locating the areas) was available in the area.Recommending this as a must see for first timers.

Bukchon is an area where we can enjoy artwork. Also we can have a walk in the ancient wall. We can know something about ancient Seoul. But be sure to bring your passports as you have to register for safety procedure.

Whatever you do, please take time to walk around this area. You will not regret it! The most lovely Korean homes on multiple streets! There are staff from Korea tourism walking around to point you in the right direction should you have difficulty finding anything!

Homes of Nobility and High ranked government officials in the Joseon Dynasty period. Historically significant. Homes had intricate details. Just lovely. Twenty minutes is all you need. Good shoes needed for steep walk. People live in this neighborhood today. We didn't feel good imposing on their privacy.
Nice place to shop, cool cafes and nice restaurants. Some of the restaurants are private kitchens with limited menu selection but food is delicious and comforting, very home-made feel.

We stayed in a Hanok when we spent a week in Seoul & enjoyed every second of it. So needless to say this was not top of our list of things to do because we had already spent time staying in one. On our last day staying in Seoul we decided to check Bukchon out & Im glad we did. This place really is beautiful & special. If you get to understand Korean history & culture just a bit you will understand why this is special as well. My favorite spot was the street where you can see the N. Seoul Tower, it was a moment & view I will never forget spent with my husband & 2 children. & just for the record ANYWHERE you go in Korea in the summer, especially outside touristy stuff in Seoul, you are going to be HOT! Why do you think everyone carries fans everywhere?!?! ITS HOT! So get yourself a good fan & an umbrella & enjoy all of the beauty that is Korea! :~}

We saw pictures online of the place with a lot of traditional houses and activities happening. We went during Summer in Korea and Summer is extremely hot and humid. Had to walk about 300M from the subway and up and extremely steep slope to the Bukchon Village. Nothing much to see except beautiful traditional houses but that is about it. Great place to take some pictures but if you're there in the summer i'd say it isn't worth to travel all the way.

this old area of seoul is full of traditional style houses, that have been well preserved and maintained. it seems that any renovation or upgrade work is strictly controlled to maintain the look and feel of the area, which is great. it is definitely worth spending some time walking through the narrow streets and soaking up the atmosphere.

The name "traditional Korean village" had me imagining a model village for tourists to see what traditional style Korean houses look like. However, upon arriving at Bukchon, it turned out to be a neighbourhood that happen to have a lot of traditional style Korean houses with real, live, living inhabitants in them. There are signs along the narrow roads asking tourists to keep their voices down and no photos inside the residences out of respect the the privacy of the owners. A couple of the houses actually will give you a guided tour of the interior at a fee. We didn't do that, so just walked along the lanes and looked a the houses from the exterior. The neighbourhood is on a hillside and so a lot of places it's quite steep. You do get a good view at certain points though and there are some cute shops, cafes, and restaurants tucked in unexpected places. We happen upon a little cafe that was so cute. The shops etc. are not in the same area as the traditional houses though. We wandered beyond them but I couldn't say exactly in which direction. We ended up down by the main streets and close to Gyeongbokgung Palace. The houses were pretty from the outside but I don't know if it alone was worth the trek. The view down below and the nice walk was good though.

Have to say that I love this place! I love wandering around the village. There are many restaurants, cafes, shops and private houses but all are in traditional style. Verybeautiful. I also love the atmostphere here, quiet and peaceful. I visited many famous places in Seoul, but all other places are busy and noisy. Come to Seoul everybody should visit this place. But don't forget the map in case you get lost!

A quaint little, well maintained village behind the gyeongbokgung palace. My suggestion? Once you are done with visiting the sights one has ticked in this village, just close the map and walk around the streets with the aim of getting to Samcheong Park. The walk itself will be worth it and once you get to Samcheong park, do the trail which leads to the wall and view Seoul from the top of a hill.
The old but renovated building is attractive. Walking at a place which come out in the drama make me feel slightly excited.

If you like ancient architecture and buildings, you will enjoy the Bukchon Hanok Village. Don't except too much as you can only admire from the outside and not the inside as it is the actual residential area. There are also signs for you not to disturb the resident. Fair enough. Still nice to go and have a look, but I wouldn't say it is a must go.

You will find many traditional homes and guest houses here. My favorite was a cafe with the hours of operation listing "9 am - whenever". I come from a city where things shut down at 6pm for the most part and most people go home after work. Too see shops like this was a treat along with the historical backdrop.

review_title: The beauty of winter with traditional roofs covered by snow
review_body: I can say this place is one of the must-visit spots in Seoul. Specially in winter of Seoul, try to visit after snowing even though it can be freezingly cold. The village is on a hill so the view of Seoul from there is wonderful,,,you can feel the unusual mixture of standing in the middle of the traditional village with a view of modern buildings ahead.
good walk with volunteers in red speaking both Mandarin and English to guide you if you are lost.Policemen are very polite and courteous.

review_title: Best place for a relaxing afternoon
review_body: Walk down the streets, have a coffee and waffle ( the one I recommend will be C I- 2 Cafe ) the waffle with green tea ice cream is great ! Visit the art gallery and check out the local designers accessories. I can spent a full day here and not feel bored. It is a must see place in Seoul.I cannot describe the feeling. Walking along the street you see a mix of building of old and new. The overseas chain of coffee as well as the local chain. Of course the local chain of coffee wins the market share. It is suitable place for families, couples and for singles and friends who want shopping , window or buying, gather for chit chat and have a slow afternoon.

The highlight of my trip this July! The Bukchon is a cluster of traditional Korean houses, small shops and musuems. Try to avoid Mondays as most museums are closed and even the Tourist Information office is closed! If you see young people in RED T-shirts standing in a street junction, they are in fact mobile TI and they will point you to the right directions They spoke good English and Mandarin too. Do ask for directions as signage is not adequate in the area and you will easily miss a turn and you will never find the traditional houses.

review_title: Traditional private hanok houses near central Seoul
review_body: Interesting to have a wander through this hillside area. The houses are mostly private homes and the locals do not want to be bothered by intrusive tourists. Clusters of houses converted to restaurants and cafes, and some interesting little cottage museums, like the Embroidery Museum.

review_title: Like walking thru history of Seoul
review_body: Its a traditional village architecture in the middle of seoul. Interesting architecture & good for great picture. Walking thru the place makes me feel like walking thru the old days of Korea. Its not easy to take great nice picture due to the people walking thru the alley. You need to walk up the hill thru the alley with 3 kids. Tiring but its worth it. There're some shops, cafe's at the end of the alley where you can clear the thirst. We found 2 tourism representative where you can get pamphlet & info's with regards to the place.

Village with some restaurants, small shops, and private homes built in a traditional style. Prepare to do LOTS of walking. Good for people who have have plenty of time to spend in Seoul. If not, you can skip this place. It was just okay.
I would suggest walking the neighborhood. The place reminds me of the old Seoul that I used to know as a child. There are a few restaurants around here but nothing special.

review_title: Great walking & window-shopping area; the folk village is charming
review_body: The little alleyways full of traditional workshops and homes are beautiful, and this is a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of nearby Jongno and Insadong.

review_title: Amazing traditional Korean houses smack in Seoul!
review_body: This is my second visit here (my 1st was in September 2012), and this time I made sure I covered the area (see my earlier review). I think September is a better time (maybe even October) because one gets to see the greens turning colors with the autumn coming. Last year I even spotted a pear tree. Make sure to come in the morning when the sun is not so high up because it sure gets hot when you walk around admiring the houses in the quite hilly area, houses that have been maintained and live in. Get the map from the tourist information center as you walk from the metro exit towards the Bukchon area. You will also be informed of the house number where Korean dramas have been filmed i.e Lee Min Ho in Personal Taste and Jung Yong Hwa in Heartstring - just the outside people:(

The most impressive feature of Bukchon Village is that it is nestled in the heart of a global metropolis. You will be amazed that such a traditional village exists and wow just about everything you see. A truly must see for anyone coming to Seoul.

review_title: Hidden residential area in downtown Seoul
review_body: This is a lovely neighborhood, with private houses more than a century old. It's nice to stroll the narrow streets, avoiding the tourists groups,that annoy the locals so much. Signs are placed in many walls, reminding the visitors these are family homes and asking for silence.A couple of such houses allow guided visits to admire the interiors. The lack of furniture there is to see is compensated with an intresting and versitle distribution. Take the time to visit one of this houses.
Love the charm of this place, like walking through the"old Korean time". Do plan to drop by Bukchon Hanok Village when in Seoul

review_title: Small houses on a steep hill
review_body: If you want to see small houses on a very steep hill with lots of time to kill, here is a suitable place. This used to be a rundown and cramped lower middle class area which failed to draw attention by the destroy-anything-old syndrome of the 1970's and 80's building craze in Seoul. Most of the grand mansions down below on more habitable flat ground were long gone even before that period. Now there are only two homes worth mentioning in the area. One belonged to former President Yun--a 99-unit home in traditional Korean style. The other is at the summit of Bukchon--a genuine Victorian home. In any case, both homes are privately owned and not open to the public. The small houses in Bukchon are also privately owned and are not possible to visit inside. Those few that are open to the public, you have to pay an entrance fee! Why on earth would anyone be interested in visiting a claustrophobic home that somehow avoided demolition decades ago? Bear in mind, they may be well-maintained now but are not homes built two, three centuries ago. It is shameful and embarrassing that there isn't a single area of grand old residential homes surviving in Seoul. If quaint charm is what you are looking for, try Hannoversch Münden in Germany with homes more than 600 years old. Or Dinkelsbühl. Or San Gimignano in Italy. A bigger city? Try Florence. Bigger? There is always Paris.
A very short walk from the Folk Museum, this suburb is wonderfully scenic, though small. Stop at the tourist information centre for a more detailed map and directions. They are multilingual.

Walked around Bukchon Hanok village for hours, taking pictures and loving the pretty traditional houses. We only found one of the eight photo spots but it didn't matter, still got to enjoy amazing views ^^ Be prepared to walk up and down a lot, this place sure has a lot of hills
Loved walking around this area. We went into one of the traditional hanok village building and did a stamp rubbing and had some tea. Really interesting place to see.
interesting architecture, small modest museums, and craft displays. Bring a map (available free at tourist center) so you don't get lost.

If I were to move to Seoul, this is where I'd stay. Love the quaintness of the whole suburb with its mixture of new and old from residences to shops to museums. Will probably need 3 days to complete the whole suburb and take in the sights, not counting the palace visitations! Bukchon sits between 2 palaces. The area is pretty hilly where the houses/hanoks are and a gentle hill where the main shopping street of Samcheong-dong is. If you're looking for local designs and quirky what nots, Samcheong-dong is the place to go.
Bukchon is a lovely place to walk around. It's not as big as I expected after visiting the hanok maeul in Jeonju, but it's pretty (great views from the tops of hills) and has lots of little shops.

This place was a little hard to find. The tourist info office was closed when we arrived at the area around 9am so we had to ask people in the street for directions. which is a bit of a task because few can speak english. It's a good place to see. We went inside a private house where the girl guide explained the traditions of Hanuk houses. (charged us 10000 won).

This would be a good place to visit if you want to see the traditional houses of Korea. Most of these houses have people living in them so we had to make sure not to make too much noise while we were visiting the place. There was a couple of houses where they actually allowed you to go in and take pictures but I guess it's all up to the owners. There are museums and workshops inside too but we didn't manage to visit them all as we didn't have enough time. Would definitely come and explore more again if I had the time.

review_title: Travel back in time to old Korea...
review_body: Bukchon Hanok village is an interesting place in the middle of Seoul. It nestled between the 2 main Palaces, Changdeokgung and Gyeongbokgung. Walking distance away from the first, its originally a housing complex for High Ranking Official during the Joseon Dynasty. Now most of the hanok had been turned into museum or cafe but some were still occupied by families. Find a small but beautiful museum here that offers experience in trying out Hanbok, korean traditional costumes. Ended up spending most of our visit to the village taking picture of ourselves in multicolour Hanbok..haha! Unforgettable souvenir from Seoul.
See korean traditional houses and the best view of Seoul here. Experience the old world charm and snap beautiful pictures of old houses and alleys.

review_title: A scent of Korean Tradition "KKok-doo Museum"
review_body: I visited Bookchon Twice. When I visited Bookchon on Monday, the main street of bookchon was a bit quiet and not many people around. It was quite enjoyable for me and my friend to walk around Bookchon area. The only problem was the Bookchon Information Office was closed on that day. Fortunately we met two Bookchon tour guides, who provided us with a proper tour map and explained to us how to reach the lane with many traditional Korean houses. Finally we found the lane and had many photo taken in front of a traditional Korean main door. When we were about to leave the lane, a group of Chinese tourists with a guide turned up. It appears that the lane is quite famous. On the way back to the main street, we found "KKok-doo museum". I was fascinated by the exibition, älthough the museum is a branch of "main KKok Doo museum" located in Haewha-dong. Even so, the exibition items at "KKokdoo museum at Bookchon" was facinating. I read a newspaper article before that KKokdoo had an exhibition in London. "KKokdoo is a human shape craft, which decorated coffin in Chosun Dynasty. In Bookchon area, there are many shops and restaurants decorated by creative designs. I bought many souveniers, including magnets, books and Korean traditional design post-its. I want to visit Bookchon again at my next visit Seoul. This time, I will visit Bookchon perhaps Tuesday. I would like to visit museums and galleries at Bookchon.Tip - Certainly Bookchon is a facinating place to visit, if you like traditional Korean style. Monday looks to be the best day of a week to visit Bookchon, if you want a quiet environment. The only drawback of visiting Bookchon on Mondays is the fact that many galleries and museums at Bookchon and near Bookchon are closed on Mondays. I visited on Saturday and surprised at the crowd. The Bookchon main street was packed by so many people Saturday afternoon.

review_title: One of the few places to see "old Korea"
review_body: Beautiful old hanoks mixed with new ones makes this a special area. Filled with artisan pottery and textile shops along with tea houses, gardens, coffee shop, boutiques and restaurants. It is particularly lovely in autumn when the leaves have turned.
Wish to visit the inside of the house rather than looking at the over from the roof tops. The free walking tour guide was very helpful.
We were able to have a private tea in the presidents previous residence which is now a high end bed and breakfast. Truly amazing. The entire area is residential but tourists were swarming all over

This neighborhood is awesome, though I wonder how the residents feel. It's great to just explore all of the various tiny (and I mean tiny) roads. Just be respectful and mindful that people do call this place home.I recommend that you go on a weekday to avoid a sea of visitors. I actually went twice. The first time was great because it indeed was a weekday. I decided to return on my last day in Korea to capture a few more photos. This time, it was Buddha's Birthday (a national holiday) and the place was crawling with people posing for photos. Not ideal if you're trying to capture that quaint residential feel.

Situated right next to the main palace, if the weather is right (dry and cool) these streets are worth a visit. Situated in a residential area the houses are lovely to see and so are the cultural museums scattered around the area. With lots of (not cheap) funky coffee shops around you will never be too far from light refreshments. The little nik nak shops are all pretty cool as well.It's very hilly here and the views are delightful but do make sure you have comfy shoes on!TIP: Try not to go on a Monday as many of the museums are closed.

A must see in Seoul and good to do this along with the palace tours as it is just east of the main palace. Similar to hutongs in Beijing, these are the traditional Korean style residences perched in alleyways on a hill in Seoul. Great for just wandering and having a coffee break at one of the bohemian coffee shops that artists have around the area.They usually have tourist volunteers on some popular corners where you can get a map and they show you the popular walking routes. You could do this in 1 hour, but definitely worth checking out for your first time visit to Seoul.

review_title: If only I have more time
review_body: love this place.... the place is really huge, if you really want to visit all 8 photo spots, remember to wear your most comfortable walking shoes, winter sonata fans, the high school in which the bae yong jun and choi ji woo met is in this area as wellToo bad i went on a rainy day, and I got lost, though we holding a map and asking the locations of the photo spots from the locals, we still got lost, nobody seems to know where the photo spots located
I love this neighborhood. Absolutely adorable and the best place to see traditional Korean houses. Walk around the alleys to soak in "korean style" of living. please budget 2 hours.

review_title: An old neighborhood on a hill
review_body: A nice glimpse into what Seoul used to look like, but with paved roads and presumably cleaned up considerably. This is a great place to spend an afternoon walking around taking pictures, etc. Lots of cafes in the surrounding area, and on the roads leading up to the neighborhood. Most of them are independent cafes, which is pretty odd because most of Seoul's cafes are the same handful of brands.
After decades of war there wasn't much left of the city but in this place you can still catch a glimps of what it must have been like.

review_title: Unique walk in the ancient city
review_body: Experience architectural traditional building. Start off the walk by going through some well maintained hanok reaching the top you can see the samcheongdong and gukbyeonggung

It was a wonderful area to explore. The view is great, but the walk is steep and winding. Many people have turned their homes into museums, like the Owl Museum. The area below the hill is also great for resting and getting a bite to eat. It was picturesque, historical, interesting and fun. Could be crowded on weekends and holidays in good weather.

Well maintained, elegant and pretty, this in an area of intrigue. Beautifully landscaped, touristy and endowed with museums and workshops but it is still real place where locals live. A must see! Allow at least four hours. There are numerous places to eat and drink.
So, this is what Korea looked like before. Worth a look. But be prepared for the uphill climb. Thought could go in the houses but they're residences! So keep quiet.
Preserved homes and lovely walk through the area. Definitely worth a visit. A better tourist map would help.

A visit to one or more of the royal palaces, a wander amongst the shops and restaurants of Insadong and around the Bukchon neighbourhood makes for a very good day out in Seoul.The Hanok houses are beautifully maintained and you can pick up a map from one of the Information booths in the area which sets out a walking trail around the area.
A nice neighbourhood to have lunch or afternoon "Koppi" in.Walk up the maindrag from the ... Metrostation. Do then go into the sidealleys if you want less tourists and more living quarte to SEE.

Visited a few Hanok village. Thought this was excellent. Korea Tourism office, near Angguk Station Exit 3, has a walking trail (you can still get lost as it is not very detailed) which will take you through all the good spots. This is a living Hanok vilalge. Some hills to climb. Average fitness is required, I think!

This is the historic Bukchon Hanok village where some traditional Korean residences have been preserved. Village isn’t quite the term I would give it, as it’s really just a residential district. It may occupy you for an hour or so. The houses may interest you from an architectural and photographic point of view but there’s little else. If you’re in this area then you may as well visit the nearby Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung palaces.

Great market to see. Many people speak English. Great mix of old and new. You can see traditional Korean dresses for sale mixed in right next door street food! Reminded me of a county fair in the United States!
Loved looking at the old style homes of Korea. Beautiful architecture and awesome cafe's, restaurants and great shopping. Neat boutiques and stores galore. All outside.

Located North east of the main palace I love how this area has renovated and offers lots of shops, restaurants and cafes while at the same time retaining much of it's traditions. Definitely worth checking out

review_title: My favourite escape to the past
review_body: If you wanna lost yourself in the hide and seek of a old village inside the city. Escape to Bukchon. First get yourself a guided map at the Bukchon cultural center then seek out the treasures. Its a maze.

There are tourist information assistants walking around to provide information and guide in this area. Perfect place for phototaking, the traditional homes are beautiful and there are private houses for korean traditional tea. Cafes and shops - excellent to hang out on a lazy afternoon. Very close to Insadong, which we walked to after visiting Bukchon.

review_title: Good way to spend a lazy lunchtime walking
review_body: We spent an hour here just wandering about and having lunch after we visited Gyeongbokgung. It was easy to get here and once you are on the main road you are immediately surrounded by lots of other tourists. The first tourist information booth we saw gave us a walking map which we followed. This was as good a way as any to see the area and get some scenic photo shots. Since we were there on a Sunday, most of the shops/houses that were not on the main road were closed.I was a bit disappointed by the whole thing since it didn't really feel like an 'old town' (in the European sense at least) but DH was very keen to get the photo and video shots so it was worth it for that. Overall, the area is overun by tourists all doing the same thing (heading for photo spots to snap away). If you like that kind of shopping it appeared to have lots of small boutique like shops around the main road which my teenage daughter found quite interesting. Otherwise, it lends itself to just walking around aimlessly taking in the atmosphere. Since it is located right between two palaces, it also makes for a good 'bridging attraction' between the two. Just don't underestimate (like we did) how long it can take to visit Gyeokbokgung. By the time we finished there, looked around Bukchon and had lunch we had missed the timing for the English tour at Changdeokgung.

We found this a very peaceful area of town that was nice to walk around in the morning. We stayed at a wonderful traditional Korean homestay (hanok), and Bukchon was an excellent base for visiting other sights in Seoul. We easily walked to Insadong and Myeongdong from this area. Taking the subway is also very easy as well. As for Bukchon itself, there are lovely traditional wooden houses here and there as well as some interesting western style buildings. We found it an excellent neighborhood to stay in since we were mostly interesting in visiting the palaces in Korea along with some of the shopping districts.

Go back in time and experience the feel of heavy wooden doors and low ceilinged houses. Be impressed with the cobblestone paths and intricate details of the dainty houses. A map may be provided at the tourist information center near the subway exit. They also have English speaking personnel in the area in case yo needed assistance with the Directions. This is a great place to visit if you have 1-2 hours availability.

We went to the Traditional crafts experience center in Bukchon and my daughters enjoyed the workshops they are providing their guests. They tried the dollmaking, dancheong accessory and the jewelry box making.

review_title: Goes with a visit to insadong
review_body: This is a neighborhood of traditionally built Korean traditional houses with a bit of semi traditional houses built in between.Best done with a visit to insadong since this is just a 20minute walk/climb away.the whole bukchon experience-walking around the area-can be done in a maximum of 2 hours.2 hours since there are bits of steep climbs.Regard this as just a walk along a neighborhood and you will not be disappointed...there are areas where you get a nice view of the palace and walls.This is a residential area where people are still going about their daily lives,best to keep this in mind.some houses are open to receive visitors for a fee.inquire at the tourist kiosk found before entering insadong street.ask for a map of a walking route and to see which houses are open.Only for the able bodied.kids strollers ok as long as the kid can climb on his own when the climb gets too steep and uneven.

Here you will see their old traditional Hanok Village. There are about 8 photo spots where you can snap beautiful pix with stunning backgrounds! Along the way, alot of cafe and waffles shops. Drop by for a tea :)

I was looking for Changdeokgung Palace and was relatively lost when I found Bukchon Hanok Village. The first thing I saw were the quaint cafes around it, then I decided to explore and saw the neighborhood. It's quite a sight to see the hanoks all clustered together, their roofs very distinct in the horizon. If you're lucky, you might find a hanok that opens their doors for you to visit for a fee. I found one at 47 Bukchon-gil 11, and was completely entranced with the architecture and design of the hanok. The owners will allow you to enjoy the view while drinking tea. It was fascinating to go around the hanoks and see the old mixing with the new. You could probably spend an afternoon here just strolling through the streets. If you get lost, try to look for people roaming in red vests. They're tourist information people who speaks English. They will basically help you around the village and give you a map of the vicinity. They were really helpful. I found some of the nicer parts of the village through them and managed to get directions going to Changdeukgung Palace.
Quaint little neighbourhood. It's actually an old residential neighbourhood. There are also many small cafes around (try their patbingsu! shaved ice). Overall a nice place to visit

I had a difficult time finding the more scenic areas here and became rather frustrated. There are however many great shops and cafes in the area. I'm glad I took the time to do this, but I was looking for something more than just another shopping area in Seoul.

I read the review and walked along the trail but could not find the beautiful scenery spot that they were talking about. There were too many people walking along the same path and most of them were playing. There is nothing much to do as most shops were closed on Sunday.

I read some of the reviews wondering what people expected to see and why they were so negative. Bukchon is a gem: it is extraordinary in a city where anything built per-1980 is "old". Several hundred single storey houses in a tight little area in a city where real estate prices are sky high and the pressure to develop is intense is a testament to a combination of good fortune and enlightened government. A stroll through Bukchon is delightful and there is always the opportunity to dive into a gallery or coffee shop if the slight climb to the top Is too much effort. It is no wonder that film crews are regularly found preparing their scenes for Seoul-based soaps.I imagine many reviewers go on package tours. That is a mistake in Seoul - everything is so accessible and the delight is coming across little lanes almost by accident. So it is with Bukchon. All you have to do is walk between the palaces (less than a kilometre) and you are then in the midst of a wonderful example of modernity embracing a piece of history.

...if you like steep up and down! But seriously, tucked away next to the Gyeongbokgung Palace, it is a fascinating area with many original cottages preserved, most still lived in, some converted to living workshops or little museums. Tourist guides literally patrol the streets in the area to be at hand to answer any questions - brilliant.

It's easy. You can stop by the Bukchon Traditional Cutural Center as we did-empty and lifeless when we were there-and pick up a map, or just take a stroll. Poke down alleyways to find galleries and artists workshops. We stopped in the Bukchon Arts & Culture Museum. Interesting collection but the docent couldn't be bothered. in great contrast, very helpful staff at the Asian Art Museum and the brand new branch of the Kokdu Museum located in a traditional Korean house (hanok) at 48/48, 11-gil, Bukchon-ro, Jongno-gu. Three dollar entry fee, a delightful collection of carved figurines that come from funeral biers, and the pleasure of being in one of these old houses-which is why you came to Bukchon in the first place.

review_title: worth a look, but nothing special
review_body: Maybe I just didnt find the right part, but it didnt seem like there was a huge amount of old architecture there
This might be a little hard to find, and many might not find it worth it after you see it, but it's very interesting to see this traditional housing and how they are built.

review_title: A glimpse of the traditional Korean home
review_body: When we were walking along Bukchon (the start of which is about 500meters from the Anguk Station exit 2), you start to feel that you really are in Korea as you see the traditional houses around you. We went there during the weekend and there were some very helpful tourist guides stationed in certain areas to direct you to the different spots with the best views.
The most beautiful place in Seoul, I think.You can feel the traditional beauty of Korea with the traditional houses in 북촌. I love there and I go there sometimes for a photo shoot.

Bukcheon is supposed to be Seoul's old historic quarter and while it still does have a few quaint Korean-style houses (hanog) to see (which, incidentally, are much prettier than traditional homes in, say, Japan), the folks here have been very inconsistent at keeping their historic archictecture, if they ever tried to at all, so the hanog, even in this most historic part of town, come interspersed with thoroughly modern functional buildings -nothing even close to the solidly historic neighbourhoods of many European cities. One of the hanog I saw sported a mass of barbed wire all over the garden wall, which was not exactly a pleasure to look at. Still, it is a precious piece of heritage as all the other historic architecture (the very small amount left of it) in Seoul are either religious or military/government buildings, not civilian ones, so this is both special and something ordinary people can more easilly relate to. It is possible to stay in a hanog bed and breakfast in Bukchon and this would be something I would definitely go for. I only had dinner in a hanog restaurant here and it was a great experience, although of course you need to be able to be comfortable sitting on the floor.
It's really nothing special to me and really didn't impress me compared with other Asian attractions...If you have limited of time in Seoul, I would say you don't miss out much if you skip this.

this place is easy to find, about 200m from the Anguk station. But is it a traditional village, or residential houses that look traditional, or handy craft workshops or...the highest concentration of coffee shops in the world within a square km? it is all of the above...cute? sure but it wears off after five minutes...my girlfriend summed it up: it costs 3000won to visit the palace but it costs 10000won to visit someones house in bunchon?

review_title: Old Houses as you are in Korean Drama
review_body: I got a map from Seoul tourism office and walk around this unique neighborhood. There are 8 photo stops and lots of supposedly traditional crafts exhibition. It is great to take pictures outside but a lot of times I have to be careful not to be run over by cars. Since people still live in this area.
the view is awesome. we just walked around and it was strange; contrast between the high scrapers and the old village. It is very beautiful.

Lots of good food in this area. They don't speak english but they have pictures of the food and brief description and the prices are posted. Here you can see traditional korean houses and can try/wear their traditional outfit called Hanbok. Up to the top at the end of the main street, you'll find the Private School as seen on the famous K-drama, Winter Sonata. A few teahouses and guesthouses in the area too,

You can get a free travel guide from the seoul tourist office or walk around yourself in this quaint residential area that showcases the preserved old korean houses even cobbled paths. It is quite interesting and admirable that they have chosen to preserve this community amidst the unceasing urbanisation of seoul

review_title: Historic Seoul - A Must for Photographers
review_body: This is a nice place to visit for a quick walk around and some sight seeing. We spend all of about an hour here, but it was nice to walk around the streets and see the old houses (hanoks) framed against the skyscrapers in the background.There are a few hanoks that operate as tea houses and B&Bs now, so there is an option to get inside if you like (we did not).I'd recommend not driving through here. It's tight and crowded with tourists. We saw one car get quite damaged trying to turn around.

The thing about our afternoon in Bukchon is that we explored it on our own. It was a freezing afternoon (a windy -4 degrees Celsius!). We saw a lot of the hanoks from the outside, but only got to go in one of them, which was a bed and breakfast place. There we got to rent one hanbok each, and take pictures of ourselves in traditional Korean costumes and accessories. It was so much fun! Had we planned our Bukchon visit better, we would’ve been able to do so much more that the place offered: participate in Korean handicraft making, learn to make kimchi, among other things. But it was a good walk anyway, like a blast from the past of Korea. There were a lot of independent cafes and small stores that were really interesting. The lunch we ate at one of the cafes in Bukchon was probably the best one we had our entire trip in Seoul.Bukchon Traditional Hanok Village is a definite must-see when in Seoul.

You can get a free travel guide from the seoul tourist office or walk around yourself in this quaint residential area that showcases the preserved old korean houses even cobbled paths. It is quite interesting and admirable that they have chosen to preserve this community amidst the unceasing urbanisation of seoul
We couldn't find this place and couldn't get much help too but we walked around that area and it was quite interesting, saw a protest and had good lunch :)Make sure you know where to go unlike us :P

ok, this is a small neighborhood up on top of a hill that is full of traditional korean homes. They are very nice with amazing wood work. the homes are set up around a central courtyard, and several offer tours for a small fee, dont miss out on at least one of the tours, and dont skip this attraction because of the steps, it will be worth walking up all the steps for sure.

Bukchon is like a tiny maze with lots of tiny streets appearing at unexpected corners. It's a peaceful neighborhood. If I could afford it, I would buy one of the hanoks there! The architecture really fascinated me. I even got the chance to see how a hanok was built. The frames were fused together by joints and not nails. A walk uphill will reward you with a great view of the heart of Seoul. Within the neighborhood, there are cafes, galleries and museums. You might want to pop by one of the tea houses as well. Don't be afraid of getting lost in Bukchon. Volunteer guides are present at selected spots. Thanks to them, my friend and I had a good walk around the neighborhood and out to Samcheong-dong, just outside of Gyeongbukgung. You would need to spend a couple of hours wandering and taking photos. Don't rush past this place.

I found my dream cafe in Samcheong-dong. The nice cafes is a mix between modern and traditional. You find modern cafes, housed in traditional looking building. A must try is waffles and coffee in any of these cafes.Just sit and people-watch and see the world goes by at these cafes. Do take a slow walk up to Bukchon Hanok Village. You find very unique Korean Traditional House. There are 8 photographic spots. The unique thing is the locals still resides in this traditional houses. Do spot for persimmon trees growing at the higher ground of these residences. Definitely a place recommended to visit. Read More on: http://snewthewanderlust.blogspot.sg/2012/12/bukchon-samcheongdong-seoul.html

This is a really sweet place to go, there is also a Buddhist temple near by, which you can go to, these are traditional Korean Houses that have a variety of things going on, you can make traditional knots or create some traditional paintings, they cost a little, but not much and it makes a fun day out.Worth a visit, they also have good tea houses in the area.

quite ok for those who like to see the traditional houseshowever, we did read about the history and etc about this houses at the museum before entering the area....its ok if you didnt choose to look at the houses.. all sorts of information can be found at the mueseumwe walked quite a distance from end to end of this areaits a great experience nonetheless.. there are tourism staff available to assist you should you face difficulties in finding the housesdown the hill...is an array of boutiques, cafes and etclotsa coffee shops/cafes...

Awesome juxtaposition between traditional Hanok rooftops with the Seoul skyline in the background. You will get some absolutely picturesque shots here. Do drop by the tourist information center to get the handy map with photospots clearly marked for the camera-totting tourist! Also, there are all sorts of arts/handicrafts/cultural experience workshops. We didn't get to try any but they look really good!
Nice but a bit disspointed as there isnt much to see. There are some good houses and residents are well off judgibg by their cars etc. Fairly commercialised

After taking the city bus tour (hop on-hop off), I chanced upon a website in their brochure where you could book a walking tour in a hanok village. When the day came, I wasn't sure if I would show up or not because of the cold. In the end I did. And now I would like to go back there sometime!What was so good about the tour? Well, the volunteer guide was a friendly, engaging chap. And the village itself was a sight to behold - with snow covering the rooftops and the green pines. We got the chance to do some interactive touristing: gold leaf imprint (spent about an hour there!!!) and dyeing. Of course you would have to pay for the materials (e.g. 100% silk scarf, silk bookmarkers or cards) used during the 'demo' but it was worth every won!I spotted a hanok that accepts people wanting to stay in to experience the life. I hope to do this the next time I visit Korea (preferably in spring). It should be very interesting to be exposed to how Koreans lived in the past, wouldn't it!!!My big regret: going there on a Monday so the embroidery and knot museums (2 Korean things that fascinate me) were closed. But I shall return!!!A TIP: you could explore the village (where we went was in the ANGKUK stop) on your own. But to save time, it is best to ask a volunteer tour guide to accompany you. Hope you get as lucky as we are to get a very affable one! We even got to have coffee and donuts in a nice office with his churchmate, a soft-spoken journalist who spoke English. You can check out the Korean Tourism website for info about how to book one.

Seeing these homes - and people are still live in them today is amazing. It is very quaint and worth walking the neighborhood. If you watch Korean dramas, you'll recognize that they use these houses and streets a lot as the setting for their stories.

It was relatively easy to navigate to the Bukchon Hanok area from the subway station, because there were helpful tourist info helpers along the way who provided maps and pointed us in the right directions. It is an extremely lovely and pleasant area to walk around, and do visit one of those hanok-converted museums to learn more about the hanoks.

review_title: Interesting place and a different view of Seoul
review_body: Bascially if you like to have a look at how a hanok house looks like, this is the place. They have interpretors around, dressed in red tops, and get a map from them! The mapshows you the different areas of the village and where the good spots for photo taking are. Try it if you can since it's free entry anyway.

I want to call this area 'cute' but that seems patronizing, but I do think the old houses and buildings are quite cute. There are many new buildings in this area as well, as well as shopping and food.

If you like the traditional houses (Hanok), you have to make a trip here and get lost among these houses. It gives a nostalgic feel and there are some traditional centres around to teach traditional skills such as painting and knot-tying.
Long street with plenty of boutiques, jewellery shops and cafes selling coffee & waffles. Apparently eating waffles is a romantic Korean thing to do these days. Very quaint!
Interesting place to relive how traditional Seoul was like. Pretty near from Gyeongbukgong, it would have been more fun if we stayed there, or took some of the classes.

Entering Bukchon I was initially disappointed. It is a western influenced part of town owing to the wealth there. After passing umpteen coffee and waffle shops along a street with obvious European influence, we moved up the hill. There the residential quiet along with the gorgeous views of the city and the fall colors took over. The actual "traditional houses" are largely eitherrenovated or reconstructed to look old, but they are charming, especially when you come across a lane of them together. When there isn't a tour group or a late model luxury sedan nearby, you can almost imagine what the area might have been like for a rich Seoulite a century ago.

If you want some good light for photographs, definitely go for a look around dusk. I have some amazing pictures of Bukchon Hanok Village. This area is really the sort of place where you can wander around for a couple of hours and just get lost in the maze of streets. One thing I was disappointed with was the advertised Bukchon Hanok lookout... it was at the top of a persons' house on their balcony and was around 5000 Won. Not worth it! There is another panoramic view you can check out not far from there, it's just a little lower, that's all.

We went on a walking tour with the Royal Asiatic Society. The guide was well informed and gave a lot of interesting info about the place. It was very pleasant to walk through this part of Seoul and well worth it if you are a resident of tourist...

review_title: Worth a visit for the handicraft classes
review_body: I found the Bukchon Hanok village to be rewarding soley for its nifty handicraft classes. The area is dotted with different "museums" where you can practice everything from Korean calligraphy to knot-tying. You can find some truly unique gifts here that are superior to anything I have seen in Insadong. However, if you are not shopping, I suggest visiting other areas. I feels a little tourist trappy.

Nestled behind the imposing and majestic Kyeong-Buk palace and a stones throw away from the president's residence 'the Blue House', Samcheong dong really is Seoul's best kept secret. Although it has an exclusive feel, it is very easy to get to: just follow the road which hugs the right side of the palace (if you stand at the entrance). Art galleries line the right side of the road and soon you will hit a feast of little artisan shops selling jewelry, shoes, clothes and other goodies. You would be forgiven if you got slightly confused as to whether you were in Europe or Asia. If your feet get tired, you can enjoy Korea's thriving cafe culture with a warming coffee and perhaps that cafe's special snacks and cakes. There are some very high quality restaurants on the main road which typically specialise in only one or two main dishes. You may think that you have seen enough on the main road, but do take the time to get lost in all the little alleyways. Don't worry, they all lead back to each other but it is in these tributaries where the true spirit of Samcheongdong can be discovered. You will see wall art, quirky shaped buildings, vintage clothes shops, ceramic wares for sale. You might even get to see a craftsman at work. I don't want to name specific places because the whole point is to go and find things for yourself with a blank canvas and open mind, but if you are fortunate enough to find the tiny alley cafe that sells patbingsoo, don't be put off by the fact that the waiting list is already an a4 side long....that's a quiet day! Samcheongdong is a refreshing celebration of creativity, self expression and talent. It's on my must-do list every time I go back and if you've never been, my question to you is...why ever not?!!!!

review_title: A historic place to discover in Seoul
review_body: One of the best place you must see if you want to feel an authentic Korea traditional house.Terrific place with an awesome view and tt is nice to walk through the street to visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace.

This is a very fascinating area, and a definite visit if in Seoul to get a sense of culture, history and tradition. The Bukchon Hanok Village is nestled between the Gyeongbokgung Palace and the Changdeokgung Palace. It is located in the Insadong area of Seoul and an easy walk from the Angkuk subway station. The history of the village goes back 600 years, but the area has been preserved and reconstructed to the way it was. The narrow streets and the walls are all brick. Many winding hilly paths, and great views of the old Korean residential neighborhoods. There are still people living in these houses and also some people still working their businesses out of these houses. The problem is if you start on one path and continue, you my not see what is in the other direction. There really is no specific course to take so it is pretty much on your own instincts. There will be modern structures also as you go thru the area, maybe a place for a meal or drink and of course souvenirs, but not in a tacky way. It is a great picture taking attraction.
The Korean tourist office put out an excellent walking map of this area - do the walk late afternoon and stay on for dinner in Samcheong

review_title: Combine a great walk with some dinner
review_body: Go at various times of the day if you can - the light in the late afternoon is lovely and then stop at a roof top restaurant for dinner - lots to chose from

Little but charming. I was lucky enough to visit it during a special week for foreigners, when they offered traditional Korean medicine advice and treatment inside the hanoks, by young doctors wearing traditional clothes - and their English was really good!!!
There are lots of tourists in a residential area. It's interesting to see traditional houses. It's a beautiful corner ; it feels peaceful.

This neighborhood is quaint, looks and feels like traditional Korea, and has been taken good care of. It's simply a delight to walk down the streets and check out the various shops and buildings. If you want the complete Korean experience, stay in a guest house!

We had a great time exploring Bukchon for an afternoon - there are so many amazing sights and it's fun meandering through the alleyways enjoying the old traditional Korean architecture, some houses with more modern additions and also the quaint coffee shops, art shops and other interesting restaurants along the way. Found a great little store near the observatory where they take ideas from anyone willing to submit online and if they like it, they manufacture the product and cut you in on the deal. Some amazing and creative things to buy - spent half an hour there! Great place for exploring the more artsy side of Korea - close enough to Insadong, the Palaces, Jongno and the Cheonggyecheon stream to make a lovely day of it!

review_title: Interesting place with the traditional houses
review_body: the bukchon hanok village was interesting and we could see how the traditional korean houses looked like. some points also had views of the city!
It's like living in Korea long before western influence dominated the skyline.Typically a korean village set in a long forgotten era of kings. noblemen, and commoners.

review_title: Glimpse of the Past in Modern Korea
review_body: If you are visiting this place, do also set aside some time for the nearby Samcheong-dong Bukchon area, which has quaint cafes and street shopping. Over here in Bukchon, you get to see the traditional look of the villages. My feel is that while the facade has been perserved to some extend, you cannot help but feel that that is all that is there. The neighbourhood is actually quite a wealthy people place. While you walk around, just be considerate, do not make too must noise, and try not to intrude into areas you are not suppose to go into. The view from the top is quite nice showing the old houses with the city view in the distance.You will also notice it's quite "touristy" - meaning many tourists will pay this place a visit, so just don't expect it to be exclusively just you and the place with great quiet. Nevertheless, you can try visiting on weekdays, hopefully it will exclude more locals from the visitor count :)

review_title: Quaint Leisure Walk in a Cafe Filled Place
review_body: Would be nice to walk along the road, and see the cafe lining up the road, and the shops selling interesting stuff in the back lanes and smaller roads. Feel free to stop and have a cake, snack, coffee or tea, and watch the world go by. If you are done in the cafe area, walk up the hill to the Bukchon place to see traditional houses from a higher ground, and travel down. Nice place to walk around on foot for an afternoon! =D

review_title: Just a peek of the real Korean Traditional House
review_body: The Bukchon Hanok village is quite big if you are on foot. The tourist information center near the Bukchon Village Cultural Center provides a walking map. Follow the 8 view of Bukchon Hanok village in the map, if you are interested in taking great pictures of all view.
