If you are just plain lazy to walk, hit the number 4,5,6 and 7 picture spots which are around each other. if you are afraid of getting lost, you can join one of the walking tour provided (free but at scheduled time).All the exterior of the hanok looks almost the same, and it is a shame that tourist cannot enter any of it. We saw one Hanok that is open for public, but the owner is charging 10,000 Korean won as entrance. That is a hefty price to pay!If you are game for the Hanok experience, some of the hanok have been converted to guesthouse.I sort of pity the residents that are still staying in the hanok, as the alleys are crowded with tourists. The alleys widths are only the size of a car. So you can imagine if some inconsiderate tourists talk louder, the voice will be disturbing the residents.Do come here early to avoid the crowd.

review_title: Bukchon Hanok Village-korean drama or not...
review_body: Those who had watched korean dramas may appreciate the actual sites of what you saw, they are different, interesting - but then I like "old architectures" unlike my friend who walked with me. I wish I had time to really walk all the streets and imagine how life was then. I appreciate that this hanok village has been preserved amidst the city buildings. And there were guides to help you when you're lost in that array of old streets and hanok houses.To guide to where this drama or that drama was filmed. You can walk to Insadong for souvenir shopping when you are done sight seeing.

review_title: Quaint village within a mega city
review_body: Bukchon Hanok Village is a neighborhood of old houses on top of a hill overlooking downtown modern Seoul. To reach here you can go to Anguk station. The houses themselves are lovely to look at, with their old architecture style. Some of the houses are still occupied by residents but most of them have been turned into museums, craft shops, or cafes. It is a great way to spend an afternoon walking through the narrow alleyways and taking photographs along the way. We booked a walking tour of this neighborhood which I strongly recommend. Our guide took us to see 8 spots in the village and each one had a different history. This village is situated between the 2 major palaces of Seoul so arrange to see at least one of them after you visit the village. Afterwards you can have lunch in one of the local restaurants along Samcheongdong. After lunch we walked through Insadong, then we walked along Cheonggyecheon stream which is lovely (and we decided to return to it the next day and walk along its length) and then we walked to Myeongdong. A lovely walk through old and new Seoul.

review_title: Lotsa Traditional Korean Houses & Nice View from the top
review_body: This is located on top the streets of SamCheong-dong. You will see stairs leading up the hill when U r walking along Samcheong-dong. Climb them & viola! U r at the Bukchon Village.

Made it to Samcheong-dong by accident. My sisters and I were walking around Bukchon, when we realized that we're lost. Somehow getting lost was fun because we came across this dainty street. Samcheong-dong is parallel to Bukchon so it was nice to see two cultures that Seoul offers: traditional and modern. Samcheong-dong is lined with low rise buildings that are well thought off. The paintings on the wall, water hydrants that has designs and cute little shops make walking and taking pictures around Samcheong-dong worth visiting.
For the real experience, stay in a Buckchon. Else you just walk the small corridors, but you don't get the real feel for the place.

Just like much of the old Korean architecture, most of Seoul was destroyed in the Korean war and in rebuilding, several areas were rebuilt to dimensions of the old style villages that Seoul originally began as. There are a plethora of small shops, museums and art centers. Weekends are the time to visit, as the areas are residential and more are open on the weekends. Interesting, but not more then other Korean sites.

The architecture of the traditional houses were beautiful. Will need a good pair of shoes and strong legs. Some of the streets were winding and slightly sloppy. It's not as crowded as Insadong which was nearby. I will like to visit it again and have a cuppa of coffee in one the cafes.
go there on sundays. walk around, shop for great souvenirs, food and delights, rest in a coffee shop, buy great tea to bring home. don't forget your camera.

When you think how Seoul was flattened in the Korean War and how modern times results in conformity in dress, architecture and lifestyles, be certain you don't miss this village for a sample of traditional Korean house architecture.

The Village is like a museum exhibit, only later will you realize that the houses there are actually lived-in. I like the various art shopes in the fringes of the Village. A must visit area after a stroll in Insadong, has a good view of the Korean Folk Village Museum and Gyeokbokgung Palace.

You have to visit this place. There are so many little corners to explore and the old Hanok structures gave us a great old feeling vibe. It also feels very trendy here. Look out for the uphills and downhills.

I enjoyed my short time here. The locals are trendy and there are so many things to see. My girlfriend and I found a little coffee house nestled at the corner of one alley way. They served up awesome waffles with coffee. We chose to sit outside to experience the Autumn breeze. It reminded me of those romantic Korean movies that I used to watch. Of course people watching here is great too.
Good place to find a cute cafe and relax! Love the area there! It's much like those which in Korea drama, so cute!!
It's good place if you would like to see some traditional houses in Seoul but you won't stay long there as the houses are not open to public. Just take some pictures will do :)

The old hanok houses which are so quaint. Its nice to walk in the alleys and look at the architecture, enter the art galleries, small musums, shops selling hand made crafts, tea cafes, great photos will come out of this walk...definitely should not be missed

i was here on Monday and the information center was closed,but there were a lot of walking information provider which are wearing a red jacket.you can get the bukchon map from them so you can plan the route that you will like to go.I only visit the 5 photospot out of the 8 as not much time i have,if you are really good stamina and have more time,give here a visit for looking at the traditional hanok.
A few small traditional houses. After seeing the palace nearby, this wasn't too impressive. Just a narrow street on a hill.

good to take a walk within bukchon hanok village and down the hill have many nice cafe , restaurant and boutique, hand craft boutique and art shop.. it is truely a wonderful oasis in a bustling city, up the hill point you could get a view of the city and mountain. must visit.

review_title: A rare treat: a sample of old Korean life
review_body: This wonderful oasis of quiet in a bustling city features reconstructed traditional Korean houses, demonstrations of Korean hand crafts, such as basket and shoe making, Korean dancing (check times for shows on bulletin board at village), and a shop selling art work and a bit-better-than-average souvenirs. We did not take the free walking tour offered by Seoul Tourism; however, we had been to other traditional villages throughout S. Korea, and could make comparisons. If your visit is only to Seoul, I'd recommend this village as a good place to see how Koreans lived in the past. There are some steps at this village but also wide, open spaces where wheelchairs can go (albeit a bit bumpily). It's not a huge place, so walking should not be a problem.

review_title: Go on a Free Walking Tour to see this village.
review_body: We booked a free Seoul City Walking Tour with Seoul Culture & Tourism Volunteer Guides to see this village. You must book ahead; you can call or book online. They email you a confirmation and tell you where to meet. We went on 3 of these walking tours and all the guides were very knowledgeable, friendly and helpful. You are not expected to tip the guides as it is voluntary and the guides are paid a small amount by the government. Have fun as you walk and learn with a local.

review_title: A Pleasant Walk in the Past
review_body: This is a great place to visit if you like quiet places, old houses and artsy craft shops. A walkable distance from the subway station, take a taxi from the station if you aren't fond of walking since you will have to take a walk to the best picture stops with a good view of many traditional houses. Other nearer areas are a mix of the old and new houses. If you aren't sure which way to go, you might want to ask the red vested tourist information people standing in strategic corners, like we did. You can go inside some of the houses for a fee, and there are also some houses where there are classes for kimchi making, traditional knotting, embroidery and some traditional musical instrument. Some of the houses have been converted to guest houses and it is nice to take a free peek at the interior courtyard with rooms that open up to it.
It's hard to see those old fashion houses in big city so please enjoy a walk here. Not to make too much noise here as this is a residential area.
this place was too amazing! lovely art cafes tucked into little corners. the view from here was amazing, can see all of downtown
A number of featured shops, food and handcraft stuff. Either Korean style or foreign style. It is nice to walk through the street before or after visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace.
Take a walking tour of a traditional Korean village, view some demonstrations, learn about how difficult life was before now, and try on an hanbok!

This place is simply awesome, I love it !Clean, safe and very relax to see the traditional houses along the way.. One thing you should keep in mind that try not to make so much noise during your walk here cos I saw many tourist laughing , talking loudly while taking picture, it's pretty annoying for the residents who live there. I like this place a lot.

review_title: Normal Bukchon Hanok Village to visit
review_body: It not so interesting place to visit as it normal village to explore and it locate up in the hill for us to explore.Only there was show for us to see with open air and if sunshine we feel warm.

We were looking around for Insadong and we found this Bukchon area. Its a collection of old houses in traditional designs that have been preserved in this area. I believe that these are all privately owned houses and that this is now a very upscale area.The walk allows you to get a sense of how old Seoul must have felt, as you walk through the alleyways and up and down the walking paths. The nice thing is that they have helpful guides in red uniforms as well as kiosks where they provide maps through the area. Other than the nice old houses, there are a collection of art galleries and coffeeshops that make the entire experience a pleasant way to spend the afternoon.

I took a morning stroll along the small hillslope of the village. The area is very clean and the fresh morning air makes the place very nostalgic. I went into the only house that is available to be visited and opened to visitors (for a small fee of course). The house is beautiful and well maintained. We were served with a very nice plum juice before we left. Good to visit early morning when the air is cool and fresh. Take your time to appreciate its beauty.

We enjoy the visit to this village. It is very near to the palace about 20 minutes from entrance of the palace(side entrance to be precise)We took a walk there and we pass through guards and was told the prime minister or president live around there so you see guards.One get to see the old house and design. very interesting.However some of these homes have modern locks so it really spoil the traditional look.While you walk, there are many shops as well as restaurants serving international food. As this is a tourist area it is not surprisning the restaurants cater to the tourists.Taxis are affordable and cheaper than in Singapore. So after walking,shopping and loads of photos, you may just take the taxi back to hotel. S$10Only caution is you have to walk about. The ladies or guys in red outfit called korean ambassadors are really a welcoming sight. They welcome tourists and help the tourists with their queries. they even recommend what you should see. Do approach them whenever you see one.They are in red outfit with a hat.We guess perhaps because everything is written in teh korean language that these ambassadors coem in handy.Nice place to visit and just have a stroll and enjoy korea as if you are a local.

I stayed a few streets away from and here and it was such an amazing experience to walk a few hundred meters and be transported back into Korea of centuries ago. Give your self enough time to walk about and immerse yourself in the surroundings. A quick pointer some houses here are residential so try not to wonder into someones yard.

a different perspective to the bustling city. what a refreshing change to see that a place like this exist and that the village is an actual residential neighborhood vs a tourist trap. we had to ensure that we behaved appropriately and contained ourselves from prying into homes!

There's not much here apart from pretty houses and people taking photographs. But, the pretty houses are very pretty! And walking up the hill to get to the viewing point is a nice way to walk off a meal ^^
Really nice pedestrianized area with examples of traditional Korean architecture and crafts. Good coffee shops, very friendly people.

review_title: It could provide a better experience
review_body: The place is located on top of a hill from which you can see a good part of the royal palace. It is worth a visit but do not expect much more than sightseeing. It is good if you want to spend 1 hour trying to figure out how old houses were. In the surrounding many small restaurants.

review_title: Back to the past in the heart of the city
review_body: The houses in this village are hanok style and it gives a glimpse of olden days korea among the modern days building. It gives a feeling of going back to the past. Some of the streets in this village gives a very beautiful view of Chandeokgung,

Nestled in a hilly location between the massive and boring Gyeongbokgung Palace and the wonderfully thematic, tree clad Changdeokgung Palace, is this residential neighborhood. There are many examples of authentic reconstructions of Korean houses of yore. Some museums abound as well. Start at one palace and walk through this picturesque neighborhood on your way to the second palace.

It is an area where there's concentration of heritage houses. It's paved with pebble stones. It's full of traditional colour and ambiance. There can be lots of tourists that to take a photo without traffic is almost impossible.

review_title: See small houses in old traditional style
review_body: Walking along small roads, looking at people's houses. Not so entertaining. There are some nice corners but this is only a residential area. not a nice place to go expecially during hot summer or rainy season.

Just the walking tour itself is good. The tourist office provides a detailed map to follow, which was good. The buildings themselves are very quaint and picturesque. However any of the attractions, such as the knot workshop, art shop etc are require a fee. Depends how much you really want to see them. Otherwise just strolling around is a pretty way to spend an hour or two

review_title: You have to visit it to apreciate how meticulous the Korean culture is.
review_body: This might sound ridiculous but I couldn't stop looking at the walls and roofs of the houses on this ancient town, great place to spend a morning and eat traditional Korean food, just be careful when ordering and make sure you are ordering for one person or you'll end with a lot of drinks and food.

What a time we had trying to find the place! Once there we could talk to the red uniformed guides (at tourst places around the city and always in pairs) who spoke English and were friendly.One house was available at 10,000 won to go inside but not much to see other than exteriors unless you took the invitation.

Bukchon Hakok Village was a fantastic experience. The activities available like kite making, weaving, craft knotting and photo opportunities make this worth the visit. Warning don't try to travel there by taxi because the local taxi drivers don't understand even when you show them a map. A suggestion is a travel there via the subway. Its cost effective only costing approximately $1.
I believe it is number one must do in S Korea, go there take some pics of traditional houses.
If you visit S Korea than you should allow a good half day to see this place, well worth it for the photos alone.
When you walked along Insadong, you should take some time to visit Bukchon, where you can find lots of traditional Korean houses up the slope. Very nice environment to take photos!!
This is a gem of an area in Seoul with historic houses, galleries and museums, craft shops and cafes. A great walking experience as long as you can cope with some hills.

I spent two weeks in Seoul and 6 nights in this general area or close to it (being Anguk metro station). So I had 3 separate relaxed wanders through the area, including spending two nights in a hanok room (what's with the Hakok spelling TripAdvisor??). Mind you with a shorter timeframe and a detailed map it is probably only an afternoon for the committed tourist.It has become not uncommon for such "old" traditional areas in inner cities to become rediscovered and maintained in their original form. Given that so much of Seoul has been concreted and glassed over thank goodness for that. The walk up some of the steep streets will give you a contrasting vista over the more so-called "modern" Seoul - thank goodness for the old wood and stone!A reasonable mix of coffee shops/places to snack and traditional businesses along with some quirky boutique shops.
you can walk in great atmosphere and great view.but very crowded. you should visit here in early morning.you can use English guide.

review_title: Beautiful traditional architecture in the middle of the city
review_body: We visited Bukchon Hanok Village for an afternoon. It has extremely beautiful traditional architecture and is in the middle of the city so you get an amazing contrast between modern and traditional. It is this contrast that, for me, epitomises Seoul as a city. The most interesting part of the village is that the homes have been restored and are actually inhabited. There are interesting restaurants and coffee shops (and a museam) on the way up to the village from the station and back down again. Seoul volunteers that help tourists make it easy to navigate your way around the place. The downside is that whilst it is nice visiting the village, there is actually not much to do there (unless you sit down at one of the restaurants for a meal or coffee).
We went up and down the hills to see the views and the traditional housing areas, plus the crafts. There are lots of little gems hidden all over for a camera enthusiast.

This is a gem up the hill but well worth the walk, about 10min from Anguk station. It has a nice garden/front porch and a 2-level house. What caught my attention was the coffee roasting machine at the entrance which produces the perfect aroma. The rest of the decor is tasty and simplistic. A bit of retro as well. The waffle with chocolate ice cream is to kill for. The double expresso did not disappoint either.

The area, which is off Anguk Station Exit 4, is filled with interesting little coffee shops, restaurants, clothes shops and galleries. The place is located in hilly terrain so be prepared to walk up and down roads a lot.

review_title: One of the most amazing places to visit in Seoul.
review_body: Wow. Just... wow. This place is so amazingly beautiful.You could get lost here for HOURS just trying to discover every lovely secret each sidestreet holds. From coffee shops to art galleries to street food and craft and curio shops, Bukchon is one place you can't miss.

Nothing more than a common city block. Traditional house are all private own and you can go in to look inside. Take photo to the roof is the only option. Road is slope and deep high, not recommend for elder and small child

Must remember to go to the tourist booth to get a Bukchon area map before walking around.The map show you where to walk and places to take nice photos. If you have not take a map there are a few walking 'tour guide'that can answer any questions on where you want to go and they have map with them .
Tjis area is just a short walk form Changdeokgung palace and an eclectic collection of trendy shops and authentic old houses! Really interesting wandering around here!

review_title: Very Cute and a Little Hidden
review_body: I tried to find this place on my own once, failed, and came back again with my husband. The areas that area easily found are lined with cute little shops, and it feels like some of the hipper spots on the West Coast in the US. Lots of Pasta, Pizza, Waffle, and Coffee places to stop at and people watch. Eventually we found the area with lots of restored houses and I adored it. It you go to the top of the hill, you can see the Blue House very clearly. Overall, I enjoyed this little trip, even though I got lost ^_^If you love old houses or interesting architecture, you'll love this place!

review_title: Different Neighborhoods Lumped Together Offer Variety & Confusion
review_body: The name, Bukchon, or Northern Village, is a new name for an old part of northern Seoul. Actually, Bukchon encompasses Gye-dong, Gahoe-dong and Samcheong-dong. Having lived in Gye-dong for nearly a dozen years, it's been interesting to see the place change while learning about the real history of the place.Originally, the three neighborhoods used to make up a very swanky residential destination due to their location being near the center of power in all Korea, Gyeongbug-gung. Many home owners were lower officials who worked in the court or others who sought residence in the community due to its prestige. Most of the traditional homes, or han'ok, were built during the first couple decades of the 20th century. A few of the largest buildings survive from the middle of the 19th century, but they are few in number.Even back in the 1960's, President/dictator Park Chung-hee recognized the collective architectural value of the neighborhoods. As such, he designated the communities to be an architectural preserve. And so it was until the gradual democratization of the nation descended down to the local village level where denizens could take more matters into their own hands. During the 1970's, 80's and 90's, homeowners envied real estate holders in other parts of Seoul who were able to demolish their old buildings and build high rise apartments and thereby greatly increasing their wealth. So when in the 1990's local governance was granted, the first thing to go was the architectural preservation designation.Immediately, 3- to 8-storied brick cramped apartments and condos were built where the original han'ok once stood. Whole blocks were demolished and to this day the community has not fully recovered. Eventually, entrepreneurs and some enlightened city bureaucrats realized what was happening. They made it more difficult to tear down han'oks and started providing financial incentives to preserve the buildings.Today, Gye-dong is evolving from a sleepy, traditional neighborhood that was the relative step-child of the two other communities. It is now chock-a-block with upscale coffee shops, handmade apparel boutiques and, yes, some of the traditional stores making tofu and rice cakes. It also has some upscale restaurants and is now the latest "find" for many Seoulites.Gahoe-dong is both bustling at is south end, just across the street from Insadong, and elegant if somewhat desolate at its higher elevations on the north end. The lower south side is very popular with university students and young adults. It features many small restaurants and boutiques plus a couple of tiny museums. The north end is elegant with arguably the best han'ok collection in Korea. As such, it is the site of many postcard-type photos. However, it is hard to call the neighborhood a community. Most of these large and elegant buildings lack inhabitants other than possibly during weekends, holidays and special events. Many of the buildings have become the playhouses of the super rich who live elsewhere and go "slumming," should that be the right word, in their multi-million dollar playhouses.Samcheong-dong could be compared to some of the nicer shopping communities of Tokyo, if it were not for too narrow sidewalks and the crowded main street constantly filled with traffic as the two-lane street serves as an important traffic artery connecting expensive northern suburbs to the center of Seoul. As a result, pedestrians need to be particularly mindful of cars. Nonetheless, some of Seoul's finest small restaurants and boutiques can be found in this pretty neighborhood.Overall, Bukchon is one of the nicer neighborhoods of Seoul, conveniently located among some of the best palace grounds of the nation. That is why I've lived here so long. At the same time, as attractive as this place may be, tourism propaganda can easily mislead tourists into expecting things that are not quite as implied.Good shoes and a non-hurried agenda are required to enjoy Bukcheon. And while here, you may wish to escape the urban bustle of Seoul by heading into the Samcheong Park that is located north of Gahoe-dong and east of Samcheong-dong. If you are up for a moderately challenging hike, take the trail on the north side of the park that takes one up through dense forest to the north wall of the old city. The dense forest soon hides the visitor from the reality that the hiker is still very much in center of one of the world's largest metropolitan areas.

review_title: Gives a taste of old Korea
review_body: Brings you back to old K-town in the middle of the city.What made this walk interesting for me is the fact that it leads to Chung-ang High School/middle school!? the filming location for Winter Sonata. (being a Kdrama Addict that I am.)

A trip to Samcheong-dong Bukchon felt like being in old Korea with all some Hanok houses converted into Museums. It was a tiring long walk from Anguk passing to Samcheong-dong all the way to Gyeongbok Palace, but it was all worth it.

review_title: Old styles of Korean house, back in 1970, 1980s.
review_body: If you walk the small allies of the village, you can feel of 1980's Seoul. most of Korean "well-living" class used to live those kinds of houses. You can also have a look inside of Korean guest houses where many tourists stay to have cultural experiences.
Wear comfy shoes as there is a lot of walking (up and down hill). Try to enjoy the scenery and the peace of mind away from the city. Take little breaks in the local cafes!

Bukchon village, Hanok houses, old style Korean architecture. Very little remains of this type given the vast destruction during the Korean War and the phenomenal development including massive skyscaperisation in last 15 years or so. The houses are occupied and very upmarket but exteriors have been largely retained. Its a long walk up and down hills, but there are plenty of coffee shops and a few teahouses.Some guidebooks suggest staying here as some of the houses are guesthouses. Coudl be good BUT catch taxis to and from.
Not as interesting as what you see on film or picture. However still worth a visit.

review_title: Bukchon - a journey back in time.
review_body: The Korean Government has actually paid the residents of these ancient Hanok traditional Korean houses to have them restored to mint condition. As a result, they are now a tourism attraction in their own right.The area covered is quite large, and needs to be covered on foot. Do also visit the Bukchon Traditional Culture Centre for a briefing on the area. Wonseo-dong is where traditional artists and artisans work. The Bukchon Hanok Guesthouse was once the residence of a famous Korean painter, and now accommodates tourists.
Hard to find, not mentioned on the map in the subway.A few nice houses, but lost in the middle of unremarkable buildings.Go if you have time, only.

review_title: Picturesque old town charm meets trendy vintage
review_body: Possibly one of my fave spots in Seoul. It's a suburb that mixes the old with the relatively new and the result: awesome.Be prepared to see some old school buildings as well as trendy vintage and retro decors.Getting pricier too, but oh so pretty!Check out pictures on my blog:http://www.girlwhodoeslunch.com/2012/05/just-typical-mid-week-lunch.html
Definiely take the time to spend an hour or so strolling through this village. The are lots of very interesting buildings and many fabulous restaurants and coffee shops.

This was a nice area to walk in with some nice traditional architecture, however, you aren't missing much if you can't fit it in to your schedule. We went on a Monday as all the museums were closed and enjoyed the walk, stopping in lots of the small cafes. But this isnt the most memorable part of my trip.

It's great to see such unique architecture still being inhabited. Don't read up on it too much beforehand - they have gone as far as numbering all the 'views' which kinda made my experience feel less unique.

The tourist office just up the street from Anguk subway stop is very helpful; the map is great. Follow the map for all the best views. Shops at the end of the walking tour are GREAT! Really wonderful creative products. Be sure to go to the top of one of the hills (well indicated on the map) for a superb view of the rooftop tiles of these old homes.

I didn't find anything special about this place. Descent walk with a view of many Korean traditional buildings, but those can be found in many other places. Go to Changduk palace (the palace next to Bukchon), and skip this place. I wouldn't not recommend it. If you are looking for somewhere special, I would recommend Korean Folk Village. Yes, the site is awful, but there are more things to see than Bukchon. This place also appears a lot in Korean soap operas.

This is the place to go if you want to get the experience of traditional Korea. The grounds are beautiful and there are many inexpensive activities you can do there. You can dress up in a traditional hanbok and take pictures. There are tea ceremonies you can participate in, and so much more.

This area is really different from anything else in Seoul!! -- Why to go and how to reach it:Seoul is mainly glass and concrete, all very modern, very crowded and noisy. I have been to several so-called Korean villages built purposely for tourists, but did not much like them, they lacked atmosphere, it was more like watching a play. But Bukchon Hanok village is not like that!It is where people actually live. We visited on a Saturday afternoon, but it was surprisingly not crowded, and most tourists behave quietly and seemed to not disturb the residents.It is very centrally located between the two palaces (Anguk st. No 328 of the orange line 3, exit 2) and near Insa-dong (artist street). -- What to do in there:Here you will see narrow winding streets, low-rise traditional houses, many traditional Korean workshops, small art galleries, nice shops with hand-made clothes, accessories etc. and various cafes. The village is situated on a hill, it is all up and down, and it offers a splendid view of the surrounding "mountains" at one direction and the metropolitan area with its sky-scrapers and Seoul Tower at another direction. We wandered around for a few hours, took lovely pictures and sat in a cafe on a 3d floor outside veranda. It felt so good and cozy to watch the hills and the small streets and roofs below. A few nice cafes are found on Samcheong-ro, near so-called Bukchon 8th view. There are also restaurants. mostly Korean, Chinese and Italian, but also Indian and fusion. You can also experience traditional Korean arts or even sleep in a Korean homestay. -- Finding your way aroundYou can get a free map of the area from several Tourist Information Centers. I know that there is one at the entrance of Insa-dong street (Anguk st., exit No 6), another one is at Gwangwamun, and two more are in the Bukchon village, you can reach it if you go straight from Anguk st. exit No2 in the direction of hills. The map has a recommended route and photos and descriptions of 8 views of Bukchon. It is a bit hard to follow the route, because the streets are so steep and tortuous, but do not worry, there are plenty of signs with directions and also friendly volunteers are around ready to help you.Overall, I highly recommend to visit this area, it is a most charming and atmospheric place in Seoul! It seems that this area is not widely advertised in guide books and tourist prospects. I am a frequent visitor in Korea, but somehow only found it by chance, never heard of it before this April. I would put it as a Number 1 in Seoul!

Best for able-bodied travellers, the steep streets are charming and the adjacent shopping streets are interesting. I can see that if it is cold or raining the attraction of navigating this area could be diminished. A good map is important, as one can get turned around a bit at the base of the hills where there are no major landmarks. But good for the tourist, there are several "you are here" maps located in the neighborhood, just keep an eye out for them.

review_title: Nice place the weather distrupt our tour
review_body: We wish we can stay longer to tour around the Hanok area but since it was raining and we were basically drenched, we have to make our tour short.

We came here also as tourists, but we were mindful that this is a residential area and that people live here, and so we respected their environment and were quiet, but the majority of people, including a lot of school children, were not and they were very noisy, treating it like an amusement park. It is an interesting part of Seoul full of beautiful buildings and history, with great views.
I went there with my senior of Hanyangdae. that street was clean and peaceful. Waffle is not half bad...Delicious. Nice!
if you walk that place, you can feel that you are in the ancient times

It's quite interesting neighborhood, because I think it's the only one neighborhood left which are still in old traditional houses. We didn't wander thoroughly since I got really tired. Here, you can also learn some of their customs and learn a few traditional Korean skills.

Very nice walk to see the hanok village. Visit the tourist information booth and you will be given a map showing the 8 photogenic places to catch good shots of the area. There are guides all around the Bukchon area so you will never be lost. They wear red shirt and will approach you automatically.
Great walk around with traditional house that has been renovated by still keeps the old wall, roof and charm

review_title: Tiring but leisurely walk along small alleys
review_body: Finding the place is a little bit challenge, good thing that tourist information center is available around the areas. It is up a small hill so the walk is tiring but viewing the old traditional houses along the alleys are very relaxing.

review_title: Do the walking tour with Robert Koehler...
review_body: This area is amazing to wander through, but even more amazing with the insights from Robert Koehler. Robert runs an afternoon walking guided walking tour every Saturday (to find out about it go to "Seoul Selection Bookshop"). Robert has a really deep understanding of Korean history and culture and was wonderful to gain his insights whilst walking through such a historical area. We were also able to have tea in one of the Hanok houses. This tour is an absolute must if you are visiting the area.

review_title: Great spot for a bit of history!
review_body: Located in the middle of the city, it's a quick and easy chance to experience some interesting architecture and customs! Our family got tickets to the Korean Tea Ceremony and we all enjoyed it! The hostess didn't speak very much English, but we all understood what to do. It was great! And after walking around a bit more, we were off to more sightseeing in the city...
Great place to see the old old houses of Seoul.. It's so serene and beautiful..
Much better spending your time in the village streets and shops around the Hakok village, which was in itself disappointing. Found delicious ice cream, crazy art and an ice museum!
u'll find beautiful traditional house.. be prepared with comfortable shoes :)

review_title: An opportunity to take nice photos
review_body: Clusters of traditional designed residential houses. It is quite a big area so there are several tourist assistants along the way to guide "lost" visitors. Lots of tourists particularly Korean drama fans flock to a certain house # 43, just because it was the door front used in Lee Min Ho's drama, Personal Taste. Another favorite spot is Choong Ang Middle School, a shooting location in one of Bae Yong Jun's series. If you have a free afternoon, a stroll along this area would be nice. There are several small museums and houses that offer traditional Korean art activities. Small interesting stores and coffee shops are also in the area. But aside from the above mentioned stuff, do not expect too much. This is just a normal residential neighborhood with beautiful traditional houses. If you plan to just walk around to take some nice photos and not visiting any museums, alloting 2 hours is more than enough.

Dont expect mush going to this place or choose to stay in a Hanok, because you chose to stay in an old house hahaha. There isnt good restaurant around the area. But if you want an experience, just stay in Hanok for 1 night, the second nite will be horrible. Trust me!

This was the most disappointing attraction of all the ones we visited. To be fair it may be that we were here on Easter Sunday and the majority of the craft shops were closed but I did not gain what I expected from this visit.
A good pair of walking shoes is necessary. Lots of up and downhill. The walking tour gives a good insight to the traditional and cultural of korea. Suggest you spent at least a night in a hanok.

review_title: Wonderful views of Old and New Seoul
review_body: In the beginning I must admit I was a bit worried. I'd seen all these beautiful pictures in korean travel guides but we couldn't find them when we arrived. There were bits and pieces of beautiful old houses here and there, but nothing that looked like a unified hanok village. Luckily we were spotted by two wonderful red aproned volunteer tour guides, who gave us a map and pointed the way to the "most famous view" in the hanok village. They weren't wrong. It's a bit of an uphill climb, but when you get tot he top of a row of beautiful hanok houses and look down the street to see modern seoul framed in the distance, it really takes your breath away.Some great waffle and coffee shops abound here. so make sure to sit down and take a break after the climb. One in particular is near the subway exit 3, and serves what is essentially a grilled sandwich shaped like a fish with your choice of savory or sweet ingredients inside.

This is a great part of town to walk around. The Bukchon village is a village of traditional Korean homes set on a mountain in the northwest part of Seoul. The roads are steep and twisty, turns, which add to the excitement of exploring this village. At certain points you can get some great photos of the village with the city views in the background. Highly recommended. It is also close to several other tourist destinations in that part of the city, so you can include several other stops during your day.

review_title: this is a residential area; don't disturb the people
review_body: This is a real residential area. The signs say not to disturb the people who live there. However, I saw some signs that invite strangers into people's houses for a charge. The map is not very good, but the views are excellent. Very crowded (I went with 2 other people on some Sunday). A lady from my hotel said this village has some tea ceremony, and a lunch break around 12noon-1:30pm, but I did not see where either would be happening. People just live their rich quiet lives there.
A great walking tour, but the maps need to be updated to reflect current workshops and a better idea of where to go for seeing specific things.

review_title: One of the few places in Seoul that is a pleasure to visit
review_body: It is generally quiet here if you leave the main street which has little worth visiting. There are a few examples of beautiful architecture here but I believe there is talk of destroying them for more profitable construction. Few people seem to visit the area.
This place doesn't have much to offer except coffee shops, restos and shopping stores. It's still a good place to walk around if you're visiting the Bukchon area.

This was the first thing we visited on our first day in Seoul. Travel a bit early if you want to avoid the crowd. Walking around the village gives you that sense of the old Korea. The hanoks look beautiful and well preserved. A must-see for travelers!
On the all, Seoul is, like Berlin before, not a beautiful city, it is chaotic. Bukchon Hakok Village is the place where you would like to live, small houses, friendly people...

This is a wonderful village i ever visit... the neighborhood are very kind and nice people..they are so helpful, although they dont understand english and we dont really understand korean. when someone ask, they will try to help. Bukchon Hanok Village also famous with their 8spots. Dont miss to complete the 8 spots task. You will see the sceneric places and pictures.

review_title: A wonderful day to stoll back in time
review_body: Just walk and eat and drink tea and eat and walk and enjoy a sunny day lost in time.

review_title: Living heritage village in central Seoul
review_body: This is a well preserved and maintained precinct of heritage domestic dwellings in central Seoul, close to the palaces and other sites of interest. People live in the houses and there are lots of small shops and coffee houses. There are suggested photo spots along pictuesque streets and over the amazing rooftops.

review_title: Great day for a walk in Traditional Bukchon Hanok Korea
review_body: Step back and step ahead.. the area is a beautiful walk and the quaint restaurants are a change from the busy city fare.. it is good to visit both Palaces that border this area.

review_title: An Interesting Contrast to Seoul's Fast Pace & Modern Architecture
review_body: The Bukchon Hanok Village (not "Hakok") is a small cluster of narrow twisting lanes where all the buildings are intact Joseon-era residences, most of them 100-200 years old. It is really the only significant historic district left in Seoul, other than the preserved imperial palaces. Seoul is a shockingly modern metropolis, but here is an opportunity to experience Seoul as it used to be. Many of the houses here are still residences today, but there are a number of art galleries, shops and guest houses as well.It is worth spending an hour or two wandering around (easy to get lost, but too small to make that an actual problem). Bring a camera, and a sense of appreciation for a time when life was slower, and everything was made by hand. Bukchon Hanok Village isn't what I'd call "an attraction" per se: it hasn't been turned into a tourist-zone, and there's no western fast food places, little English signage, not much glitz and glamour. For some people that's a reason to stay away, but for others that's a big part of what actually makes it an attraction. Note that this is a daytime destination: the area is pretty dark and poorly marked at night. As indeed it would have been 200 years ago...There are plenty of small restaurants in the area, as well as two of the significant palaces (the Gyongbokgeung Palace and the Changdukgeung Palace) to visit. It's easy to get to by Seoul Metro, or a walk from most of the bigger downtown hotels.

review_title: If you want to see 250 coffee shops, this is the place to go
review_body: Really disappointing, I can not understand the need for having so many coffee shops. No exaggeration, there are more coffee shops than all the other businesses combined. It would be funny if it wasnt so disappointing. Nothing to see, difficult to navigate super narrow sidewalks. I went on a weekday so it wasnt crowded, but I am sure it is miserable on the weekend.

review_title: Great walking tour of traditional Korean architecture
review_body: This is a very interesting place, but make sure to pick up a map before you go.
It was really worth the hype. Plus, with all the cool cafes around, I believe I can stay there for the whole day and still enjoy myself to the fullest.

review_title: Pictures and Video of Samchung-dong Alleys
review_body: Samchung-dong is one of the best place in Seoul for foreign residents!!!Here we could enjoy the harmony of traditional Korean-style houses and modern building (i.e. a lot of modern art galleries are located on the same street). There are many alleys in Samchung-dong and you can find affordable street foods (like Hotteok) and small accessory shops. Most people who work here are 'okay'(..) with English.You can watch our video for the full details of the visually stunning streets!! :-)"http://youtu.be/R8Rb_XzF2kA"

review_title: A bit of the old Seoul.
review_body: Unfortunately there not much of old Seoul to visit so definitely a must.
Its nice to walk around. also nice looking coffee shops, restaurant. Must visit!

The place is easy enough to access by subway. A 5 min walk will take you to an intersection where the information kiosk is. Grab a vicinity map, follow the directions and it'll lead you through beautiful shopfronts and buildings that beg for you to slow down to a leisurely pace to appreciate its surroundings. In almost every direction you'll find quaint cafes/restaurants and a couple of eclectic trinket shops. It's just the right blend to cleanse your palate from the overwhelmingly touristy places like Myeong Dong or Insadong.
Going this place is really a cultural walk. The houses are the Hanok style architecture which is a native in Korean. amazing how these houses are kept well.
peaceful and quiet place for afternoon tea. There are numerous cafes and tea houses along the street to choose from

We really enjoyed walking around Bukchon, the largest cluster (~900) of privately owned traditional wooden homes or hanok in Seoul. Beautiful alleys, lots of cafes and a bit of history. Within walking distance to the beautiful Gyeongbok-gung Palace.

I saw the Korean traditional house and small back street.You can walk to Samcheong Garden in 5 minutes.You can walk to observatory spot which is on the city old wall in 20 minutes.The view is good.It is good tour to try.

review_title: Well preserved traditional houses in the middle of the city
review_body: Good place for you to see traditional hanok houses - right in the city centre and there are actually people still staying in these houses. Samcheong-dong is now a fancy area with cafes/fine dining restaurants. Nice area to walk around and spend the afternoon in the cafe.
here you can find many cafes and art shops in traditional korea house. the street is nice to walk around and you can find many surprise in every little shop

review_title: Great place to spend an afternoon
review_body: The area is filled with quaint cafes. Great place to walk around after visiting Gyeongbokgung.

Spent Sunday afternoon there. Lots of nice cafe and gallery in converted traditional Korean houses. Very interesting to see how they preserve the old distric yet to make use it for new modern activities.

Anyone who loves traditional houses, want to be away from hustle and bustle, come to Bukchon Hakok Village. Lots of small interesting cafes, handy craft shops, artists workshop can be found in this beautiful village. We explored different photo spot in this village which are marked on the floor. The atmosphere is serene, just walk into any of the cafes and you can enjoy a lazy afternoon watching the clock slowly ticking away and have a nice cup of "hand drip coffee". Visit Bukchon Hakok Village when you are in Seoul, just bear in mind that local residents respect privacy, so do not walk into their house without knocking..

It's great to see how tradition and modern life blend to become one of the most interesting areas in Seoul. Samchong Dong is a great place to hang out on the weekend and enjoy a coffee and a waffle while watching the yound and afluent Koreans passing by. At the same time strolling through the little alleys and watching all the traditional and renovated buildings gives you a feeling how Korea must have looked like many years ago.

This is a very pleasant area to wander around and see a mix of traditional homes, cafes, art galleries and the like. I enjoyed it very much. There is a wonderful little tea house that serves the most amazing tea and red bean soup. I don't know the name, as I have no English translation for it...only a picture I took with the Korean signage. I'm sure that there are lots of hidden gems equally as interesting that one can find in this neighborhood just by spending some time leisurely strolling around...there are many surprises, which is what makes this area interesting.

This is a nice neighborhood to explore, from the old traditional homes to the modern art galleries to cultural centers. It has a lot of tourist groups, but they usually disappear if you're taking side streets or exploring hidden corners. I suggest starting at the Bukchon Traditional Culture Center at 37 Gyedong-gil. They have free maps and guide books in English. The views from the hill tops highlight the contrast between the traditional homes and city life and are worth the climb.

review_title: A traditional, picturesque oasis from chaotic modern Seoul
review_body: In a city like Seoul that has rapidly modernized, it was nice to find the traditional hanok area of Samcheong-Dong as a sort of peaceful getaway, right within throwing distance of Insa-dong and Gyeongbukgung. The traditional architecture is beautiful and has been well-restored and you'll find all sorts of small, quirky cafe's and galleries along the way - make sure you stop in to them, its half the experience. Unlike a lot of other Hanok villages in/around Seoul, people actually live in Samcheong-Dong, so take the opportunity to tour one of these houses and you really get a feel for pre high-rise Seoul. Even if you just want to join the others wandering around the narrow streets, its a great way to spend the afternoon. Here's a tip. You can get a samcheong-dong specific map at the KTO information booth at the end of Insa-Dong and they can chart out a route for you before you walk down.

review_title: Arty Street with Cool Cafes and Interesting Shops
review_body: The shops and restaurants were lovely and charming.The walk from the station to Samcheong-Dong was a little long though.

review_title: Put this in the bottom half of your list of places to visit
review_body: Many private homes, some art galleries, some studios that teach traditional handicrafts like knot tying, sewing...near the main road that cuts thru the village are places to eat, tea, coffee. As you wander the narrow lanes in the interior of the village, we did not see that much. Lanes are lined with walls, gates are closed to the private homes, could not see anyone's front yard or the front of their houses. Gates to the studios were open, class hours and fees posted on/near the front gates...did not enter any of these areas...presume these are in-home studios. To be fair, we did not walk all thru the village, but we did see parts on both sides of the main road and we started our visit at the tourist center. It has a quiet neighborhood feel to it...also an artsy type of atmosphere due to the galleries, coffee/tea houses, small cafes.

On a recent business trip I spent two afternoons walking the alleyways. Great little shops and many many restaurants. You really feel like you've gone back in time and are far away from the big city atmosphere of Seoul.A short cab ride from major hotels.

I love this area of Seoul mainly for the traditional homes mixed with the cafes and small shops. Being an artist it is a great place to explore due to the various galleries. Also not a very crowded area since it is a bit out of the way having no subway near. I feel though it makes a great escape from the usual overcrowding of many areas of Seoul. If you don't really a have good sense of direction you can get lost through all the completely random alleys and roads.I make it a point to visit this area ever time I return to Korea especially to visit one of the coffee shops. But that is for another review.

review_title: I'm a local and I frequent this place often-that's how much I love it.
review_body: Samcheong dong is a quaint neighbourhood just east of Gyeongbokgung palace. It's filled with small cafes and restaurants; art galleries and museums as well as boutiques. Here you may also find some colourful murals and interesting art installations. You can walk through Samcheong dong en route to the Bukchon traditonal Hanok village which is very close by and a great way to experience some Korean culture and history.Have a look at my travel blog post about it. I'll be happy to answer your questions about it.http://koreantravels.wordpress.com/2010/12/01/the-splendors-of-samcheongdong-road/
It a fusion of the old and new. It's an interesting mix of shops and cafes. I ate very delicious waffle at Beans Bins. All in all, I can say, it was worth the trip.

review_title: My idea of a modern Korean town
review_body: In Seoul for a business trip, got lost in Samcheong dok looking for the public bath mentioned in Lonely Planet - thoroughly enjoyed the 2 hour walk!. Treelined avenues that turn off into quaint shops, a little Japanese / Korean-ified Ubud. One of a kind local boutiques and cafes which are quiet and civilised and true blue local eating. no signs in English here! My most authentic experience thus far

review_title: Nice way back to the history of Seoul
review_body: Bukchon Hanok Village is placed in the area between two old palaces in north Seoul, Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung. This is a kind of an 'old town' of Seoul, although there are some other villages of the similar kind – some of which are inside Seoul metropolitan area, while the others are outside the city. Bukchon site is easily reached from Anguk subway station (Line 3, Exit 3). You can start your exploring by visiting Bukchon Traditional Culture Center at first (a kind of an audio-visual information office), where you can get basic information about the history of that part of Seoul and traditional Korean building crafts. In the Center you can see various posters-pictures with textual explanations and watch some video clips. In addition, there you can get a copy of information brochures. In opposite to the old palaces in Seoul, visiting the Bukchon Hanok village as a whole community is free, although there are paid tickets for some particular museums within the same area.I did not plan enough time for visiting these museums (I just passed by some of them), but I did enter one of the protected 'guest houses' in order to see its interior. A woman who lives in the house was not much fluent in English, so she was not capable to show me the whole house and describe more details related to the style of living in a traditional housing called 'hanok'. (The visitors are invited to enter some of the 'hanok' buildings, in order to see their interiors. Be prepared to take off your shoes or boots before going inside a traditional house.). I also saw the Hanok house in which one of the first hospitals was established and long ago.After spending some two hours by walking through the narrow streets of Bukchon area, I visited a pottery gallery and academy (called Yido or something like that), where I saw much artistic Korean tableware and bought a small vase (30 Euros), in order to remember the visit. The staff of the gallery's shop was kind enough to present me a small gift in shape of a bathroom soap stand. That was a nice gesture.Just before I left the Bukchon area, I spotted an 'organic food' shop down the street, where I bought a couple of snack packages, around 2000-3000 won each. Later I was sorry for not purchasing much more, because such 'healthy' articles I did not find in the shops of Myeong-dong where I was accommodated during my stay in Korea's capital. In addition, I found similar food much more expensive at Incheon Airport's duty free shops.As said, I entered the area by using the subway up to Anguk station (the same station I used the day before when visited the Jongmyo shrine). When finished my visit to Bukchon, I discovered that close to an another exit of the Anguk station was the 'upper' end of Insadong-il, the main pedestrian street of Insa-dong, the artistic soul district of Seoul. Therefore, I walked through it until I reached the 'lower' end of the street, followed by a 10-15-minute additional walk to Ibis Ambassador Hotel. That means, if you are not in a hurry and if the weather conditions are not bad, you can skip additional subway rides and take continuing walk by visiting several things in a row, one after the other, before you finish your daily route.If I planned another visit to the Bukchon village, I would reserve at least half a day for it alone and would try to enter more 'guest houses' as well as local museums, in order to get more feel about the life of the old Koreans.

review_title: Work through sweet & old in Central seoul
review_body: This is my best place to go. Samcheong-dong gil(road) is a sweet and old are in Seoul, especially central Seoul. I go there after work or weekend then can make the rest of my day feel cozy. It is best to start the promenade from Pungmoon Girls' High School. It is near the No. 1 exit of Anguk subway station.Stroll along the stone walls, and by the time you reach Jeongdok Public Library, petit shops, art galleries, delicate cafes and restaurants will start to peek out.I did not take an any pic of samcheong-dong gil, but you should see and go there.below link is Korean official tour site about the road. take a look http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SH/SH_EN_7_4.jsp?cid=561239
